(If 10 people collectively wrote War and Peace, it would be wrong to speak of the author of that book.) And if a given thing did uniquely invent bifocals, then “the inventors of bifocals” does refer to it. 
So there are two dimensions to the semantics of “the inventors of bifocals.” There is what it refers to: this is the referent of “the inventors of bifocals.” (Sometimes “reference” is used instead of “referent.”) And there’s the property that a thing must have to be its referent; this property is the sense of that expression. The referent is BF, and the sense is the property of being a unique bifocal inventor. 
Analogues of these points hold with respect to “the first postmaster general.” There is its referent (which is BF); and there is its sense (which is the property of being a unique first postmaster general). 
The reason that TB is non-trivial is that, although the definite descriptions in it have the same referent, they have different senses. A comparison may help. Imagine that you’re looking at a certain person in the distance. That person is in fact Ralph, but you don’t know it, because he’s so far away and also, let us suppose, because he is (for reasons that aren’t important) wearing a suit of armor. You see that he is doing jumping jacks. Later Ralph is standing right in front of you and, of course, you see him. He’s wearing a plaid shirt. Once again, he’s doing jumping jacks. 
The first visual perception has the same object as the 
second. And each of those perceptions says of that object that he or she is doing jumping jacks. But those two perceptions pick out that object in different ways. In the first case, that object is presented to you as something that has one set of properties (it’s far away, it's wearing a suit of armor, etc.); in the other case it’s presented as having a different set of properties (it’s nearby, it's wearing a plaid shirt, etc.). And that’s why, even though those perceptions have the same object, and even though both attribute the property of doing jumping jacks to that object, those perceptions tell you different things. 
Something similar holds of “the inventors of bifocals” and “the first postmaster general.” They have the same object (referent); but they pick that thing out through different bodies of information. That’s why ‹the inventors of bifocals has phi› and ‹the first postmaster general has phi› tell you different things, even though they attribute the same property (phi) to the same object (BF).[171] 

4.1 Evaluating Frege's solution 
This all seems not only plausible, but practically self-evident. But, so far as what Frege says doesn't coincide with TD, what Frege is saying is false and, indeed, incoherent. 
Let’s consider the two sense perceptions discussed in FR. The one perception tells you that there is something in the distance, that it's wearing a suit of armor, etc., and that, moreover, that thing is doing jumping jacks. So the sense in which Ralph is the object of that perception is that your perception describes Ralph. Your perception says: “something or other is over there, in the distance, wearing a suit of armor, (etc.).” Who (or what) fits that description? In other words, who has the relevant properties? Ralph. So Ralph is the object of that perception in the sense it describes him. 
The information borne by that perception has the form “something has such and such properties (it’s wearing a suit of armor etc.), and any such thing is doing jumping jacks.” Thus, the content of that perception is given by an existence-claim (a claim of the form “something has phi”). Ralph uniquely satisfies that existence-claim. (In other words, he and he alone has the relevant property.) And it is in virtue of his doing so that he is the object of the perception in question. 
The same thing mutatis mutandis is true of your second perception. The information borne by that perception is along the lines of “something has thus and such properties (it’s standing nearby, is wearing a plaid shirt etc.), and any such thing is doing jumping jacks.” Ralph is the object of that perception by virtue of the fact that he and he alone has the relevant properties—that he and he alone is a thing standing in the relevant place while wearing a plaid shirt, etc. 
In general, when a given thing x is picked out by way of descriptive information, what’s really going on is that some statement of the form “something has such and such properties” is being affirmed (not necessarily verbally), and x is what fits the description. 
If we bear this point in mind, we find that, so far as it isn’t totally incoherent, Frege’s analysis collapses into Russell’s. Consider the sentence: 
(IB)[172] 
“the inventor of bifocals is tall.” 
By Frege’s own admission, “the inventors of bifocals” picks a given thing 
out if and only if that thing fits the relevant description (i.e., if and only if that thing is a unique inventor of bifocals). And if there is a unique inventor of bifocals, that thing, whatever it is, is the thing to which “the inventors of bifocals” refers. So supposing that there is such a thing and that x is it, IB describes x as being tall. 
It goes without saying that, if there is no unique inventor of bifocals, then there is no way that IB can be true. Frege himself emphasizes this last point. (And he’s right to do so. There’s no way that “the elephant in the corner is eating peanuts” can be true, if there’s no elephant in the corner.) 
The upshot is that IB is true if and only if: 
(IB*) there is a unique inventor of bifocals and, moreover, that thing, whatever it is, is tall. 
But what does TD say about IB? According to TD, the meaning of IB is: something uniquely invented bifocals, and any such thing is tall. Which is precisely what FB says. So Frege’s theory collapses into Russell’s. 
By obvious extensions of this, it follows that, if Frege’s theory is right, then CB’s meaning is identical with that of CBR. So Frege’s theory accounts for the non-triviality of CB in the same way as Russell’s theory (as TD). 
4.2 Evaluating Frege's solution (continued) 
For argument's sake, suppose that the prettiest living woman is identical with the most evil living person. Given only that: 
(1) “Smith wants to marry the prettiest woman on the planet,” 
is true, it doesn't follow that: 
(2) “Smith wants to marry the most evil person on the planet,” 
is true. But why not? Because what (1) really says is that: 
(1*) Smith wants it to be the case that Smith is married to a woman who is prettier than anyone else, 
and what (2) really says is that: 
(2*) Smith wants it to be the case that Smith is married to somebody who is more evil than anyone else. 
Thus, if (1) is correct, Smith wants a certain proposition to hold, namely, that Smith is (or will be) married to a woman who is prettier than anyone else. And if (2) is correct, Smith wants some other proposition to hold, namely, that Smith is married to somebody who is more evil than anyone else. Since those two propositions are different, the fact that one of them has the property of being desired to be true by Smith, whereas the other lacks that property, does not constitute a violation of Leibniz’s Law (if x=y, x has a given property iff y has that property). And the “substitution-failure” whereby a truth (namely, (1)), is turned into a falsity (namely, (2)), corresponds to the innocuous fact that, whereas the grammatical complement in each of (1) and (2) of “marry” is a singular term, the grammatical complement is an expression denoting a proposition (as opposed to a person). The occurrence in (1) of “the prettiest woman” is an orthographic expedient —an orthographic stand-in for a more perspicuous but (for that very reason) unwieldy expression. And surely we shouldn’t let orthographic expedients dictate our semantic beliefs. (Frege himself would be the first to admit this.) 
Few authors, if any, deny that apparent exceptions to Leibniz's Law are to be solved in this way. So given that, according to TD, the meanings[173] 
of (1) and (2) are given by (1*) and (2*), and given that, nuances aside, there's no other way to deal with the datum that (1) and (2) can simultaneously be true, it's odd that authors have continued to countenance Frege's system. 





4.3 Special compositionality in relation to Frege's theory 
There are other, related problems with that system. According to the principle of special compositionality (SC), what a referring term picks out is a function of what its parts pick out.[174] 
Bearing this in mind, let's suppose, as before, that the prettiest woman in existence is also the most evil person in existence. And let's also suppose, with Frege, that definite descriptions are referring terms. Given these suppositions, it would seem to follow that the underlined part of: 
(3) Smith believes that the prettiest woman in existence is identical with the prettiest woman in existence, 
refers to the same proposition as: 
(4) Smith believes that the prettiest woman in existence is identical with the most evil person in existence. 
But the underlined part of (3) very much seems not to co-refer with the corresponding part of (4)[175], that being why, even if the prettiest woman in existence is the most evil person in existence, (3) and (4) can differ in truth-value. 
There are only three ways to go here. (i) Deny SC. (ii) Deny that the underlined parts of 3 and 4 refer to different propositions. (iii) Deny that 4 is what results when a referring term in 1 is replaced with a co-referring term. 
Understandably, Frege rejects each of (i) and (ii) and thus accepts (iii). (To this extent, his semantics coincides with Russell's, give or take some technicalities relating to the fact that, according to TD, each of 3 and 4 is syntactically ambiguous.) Frege thus says that the definite descriptions occurring in 3 and 4 refer, not to some person, but rather to their "customary senses." What he means is that, in each of 3 and 4, "the prettiest woman in existence" refers, not to Sally or Betty or Ethel, but rather to the property (or concept) of being a woman who is prettier than every other (or some such[176]); and in 4, "the most evil woman in existence" refers to the property (concept) of being a person who is more evil than any other. 
An immediate consequence of Frege’s theory is that the word “snow” has three utterly distinct meanings in: 
(5) “Snow is white and Jerry believes that snow is white and Fred believes that Jerry believes that snow is white.” 
The first occurrence of “snow” in (5) refers to snow. The second refers to the sense of the first occurrence. The third refers to the sense of the second occurrence. 
But surely all three occurrences of “snow” in (5) mean the same thing. Frege’s is clearly jumping through hoops to make his bankrupt theory work. 
Another immediate consequence of Frege’s theory is that the word “snow” doesn’t refer to snow in: 
(6) It is true that snow is white. 
But that’s obviously false. (In any case, there's no independent support for this claim.) The occurrence of “snow” in (6) clearly has the same meaning as its counterpart in “snow is white.” 
In any case, what does it even mean to say that, in (5), the third occurrence of “snow” refers to the sense of the sense of “snow”? If you say “Socrates was bald,” you are attributing baldness to Socrates—not to Aristotle or Plato or anyone else who isn’t Socrates. If you say “Socrates was intelligent,” you are attributing intelligence to Socrates and Socrates alone. Thus, “Socrates” refers to Socrates because, the remaining semantic rules of English being what they are, ‹Socrates has psi› attributes psi to Socrates. By parity of reasoning, if the third occurrence of “snow” in (5) really referred to a second-order sense, then it would make some statement about that sense—it would attribute a property to it. But it doesn’t. It doesn’t say anything about such a sense. Whatever it is that it does in connection with such a sense, it isn’t comparable to what “Socrates was intelligent” does in connection with Socrates. 
Finally, to the extent that Frege's views concerning indirect reference are intelligible, they undermine his own semantics. According to Frege, the proposition meant by: 
(#) "The prettiest woman in existence is smart," 
is true just in case: 
(##) somebody who is smart is uniquely a woman who is prettier than any other. 
In general, the proposition meant by: 
(*) ‹...the phi... ›, 
is true just in case: 
(**) something x such that...x...uniquely has phi. 
Let "FR" (short for "Frege-Russell") be the principle ("hypothesis" might be a better word) that the meaning of (*) is given by some proposition that is equivalent (if not identical with) (**). It is to be emphasized that Russell and Frege both accept FR. 
Here's where they differ. According to Russell's system (TD), ‹the phi› is in the same category as "something," "everyone," etc. According to Frege's system, ‹the phi› is not in that category. 
Here's the problem. Let O be an occurrence of "the prettiest woman in existence" that falls within the scope of four epistemic (or modal) operators. So O might be the underlined expression in: 
(&) "Smith believes that Sally knows that Larry hopes that Mary is certain that the prettiest woman in existence is smart." 
A consequence of TD and of Frege's system is that the semantics of the occurrence in (&) "the prettiest woman in existence" is given by FR. But if Frege's system is correct, then that occurrence refers, not to Sally (who we'll assume is the prettiest woman in existence), but to the "customary sense" of the customary sense of the customary sense of the customary sense of the occurrence in (#) of "the prettiest woman.” (Let O# be the just-mentioned occurrence.) So, if Frege's system is right, then the semantics of each of O and O# is given by FR even though, whereas the one occurrence refers to Sally, the other refers to a fifth order property (or concept). Thus, a consequence of Frege's theory is that, in respect of their semantics, two expression-occurrences can be functioning in the very same way even though the one occurrence refers to an individual while the other refers to an nth order property (for any whole number n). So a consequence of Frege's system is that there can be reference-shifts where there haven't been semantic shifts. Which is obviously incompatible with the principle that, it is in virtue of how a given expression E affects the truth-conditions (or meaning) of sentences in 
which it occurs that E refers to this as opposed to that object.[177] 
We saw in Chapters 3 and 5, and will see in Chapter 6, we saw that for "Socrates" to refer Socrates is for ‹....Socrates...› to be to the effect that ...Socrates...We saw that this condition's being satisfied is necessary and sufficient for that expression's referring to that individual. Thus, for a given expression to have a given referent is for it to have certain effects on the truth-conditions of the sentences in which it occurs. 
A corollary is that, where those changes haven't occurred, there hasn't been a shift in reference, a related corollary being that, where they have occurred, there has been such a shift. For any property phi, and for any whole number n, the semantics of an occurrence O^ that falls within the scope of n epistemic (or modal or otherwise intensional) operators of the phi is given by FR. Thus, so far as Frege’s clearly contrived and ad hoc theory has any intelligible meaning, it’s clearly false. 
Chapter 6 Slinging the Slingshot: How a famous argument of Frege’s proves his conception of reference to be incoherent 
1.0 Is Frege’s analysis of reference tenable? 
In this chapter we’ll find that Frege’s analysis of reference---which, on the face of it, is not only reasonable, but downright truistic---is indefensible. Frege’s analysis has consequences too spurious for a reasonable person to accept (e.g., that nobody has thoughts about anything, that my typing this sentence is identical with your reading). But rather than rejecting Frege’s analysis, philosophers chose to accept these consequences. Why did they do so? First, they couldn’t come up with a viable alternative to Frege’s analysis. Second, absurd though they are, these consequences supported positions that, independently of their views about semantics, these philosophers had made their life’s work to develop and that desperately needed reinforcement. Third, Frege’s analysis, preposterous though its consequences be, very much seems cogent. 
In this section, we’ll identify the flaw in Frege’s argument, thus stripping its credibility and preventing it from retarding philosophical progress any more than it already has. 
2.0 The Slingshot 
A "slingshot-style" argument is one to the effect that: 
(i) 
logically equivalent expressions can’t have different referents, 

(ii) 
intersubstituting co-referring terms preserves truth-value, and 


(iii) given (i) and (ii), it follows that (iii) some class that would seem to comprise several objects (for example, the class of things that are referred to by true sentences) in fact only comprises one object (for example, the property of being true). 
In a moment we will present such an argument. That argument is based on the following four sentences : 
(1) Mozart was a composer. 
(2) 
The class of all things x such that Mozart was a composer and x is self-identical is identical with the class of all things x such that x is self-identical. 

(3) 
The class of all things x such that Bill Clinton was U.S. President in 1997 and x is self-identical is identical with the class of all things x such that x is self-identical. 


(4) Bill Clinton was U.S. President in 1997. 
Here is the argument (“SS” is short for “slingshot”) 
(SS[178]) (1) is logically equivalent with (2). Therefore, (1) and (2) must co-refer, supposing that either refers to anything. (It is being assumed, very reasonably, that logically equivalent expressions cannot have different referents.) 
(3) 
is what results when a referring term in (2) is replaced with a co-referring term.) (“The class of all things x such that Mozart was a composer and x is self-identical” refers to the class of all self-identical objects, and so too does “the class of all things x such that Bill Clinton was U.S. President in 1997 

and x is self-identical.”) Since intersubstituting co-referring terms preserves reference, it follows that (2) and (3) co-refer, supposing that either refers to anything. 

(3) 
is equivalent with (4). Therefore, (3) and (4) must co-refer, supposing that either refers to anything. Therefore, (1) and (4) must co-refer, supposing that they refer to anything. 


If the occurrences in (1)-(4) “Mozart was a composer” and “Bill Clinton was U.S. President in 1997” are replaced with occurrences of any two true sentences, the argument that results is cogent. Thus, any two true sentences co-refer, supposing that any true sentence refers to anything. (For the same reason mutatis mutandis, any two false sentences co-refer, supposing that any false sentence refers to anything.) 
The property of being true is the one semantically significant thing that (1) and (4) have in common. So, supposing that sentences refer to anything, (1) and (4) must refer to the property of being true, and true sentences must in general be assumed to refer to the property of being true.[179] 

3.0 One problem with SS and with all other slingshot-style arguments 
Like all slingshot-style arguments, SS fails to establish its conclusion, the problem with it being that it embodies a spurious conception of reference--­one that, were it correct, would entail that reference was indistinguishable from quantification. 
Suppose for argument’s sake that “the class of all things x such that Mozart was a composer and x is self-identical” is functioning as a device of reference. In that case, it’s picking out the class of self-identical objects, and what (2) is saying about that class is that it’s identical with itself; in other words, (2), thus interpreted, says that: 
(2*) The class of self-identical objects is identical with the class of self-identical objects. 
But (2*) is not equivalent with (1). Therefore, if the definite descriptions in (1) and (2) are assumed to be referring terms—which is precisely what they are being assumed to be—(2) isn’t equivalent with (1). For the same reason mutatis mutandis, (4) is not equivalent with (3) if “the class of all things x such that Bill Clinton was U.S. President in 1997 and x is self-identical” is taken to be a device of reference. 
In order for (2) to be equivalent with (1), the former must be taken to be to the effect that: 
(2#) There exists a class to which a thing belongs iff Mozart is a composer and that thing is self-identical; and there exists a class to which a thing belongs iff that thing is self-identical; and the first class is identical with the second class. 
But if (2) is interpreted in this way, the definite description occurring in it is a quantifier, not a referring term. And in that case (3) is not what results when a referring term is replaced with a co-referring term. (It’s what results when a non-referring term is replaced with a non-referring term.) 
So SS is a failure. 
Note: Some would disagree with our contention that, when read attributively, occurrences of definite descriptions are functioning as quantifiers not as referring terms. Some, in other words, hold that there is such a thing as "attributive" reference. This is the position of Frege and his followers (e.g., Church). In Section 7.0, we'll see why Frege's position is both indefensible and unnecessary. 
4.0 Is the conclusion of SS correct? Do true sentences refer to truth-values? 
In this section we'll see that, in respect of its semantic properties, “snow is white” bears little resemblance to "the property of being true." And we'll see that, for this reason, it is implausible, if not incoherent, to hold that "snow is white" (or any other true sentence) co-refers with "the property of being true" (or "the True" or "the truth-value True"). 
Let’s start with some platitudes about reference. To say that expression R refers to object O is to say that, for any property phi, ‹R has phi› attributes phi to O. If you want to say of Benjamin Franklin (BF) that he’s bald, you can do so by saying “Benjamin Franklin is bald.” (Of course, BF is no longer with us. But to set aside some extremely intricate and, in this context, irrelevant issues relating to tense, let us pretend that Franklin is alive and that we can speak of him in the present tense.) And (the remaining semantic rules of English being what they are) if you couldn’t attribute baldness to BF by uttering that sentence, then “Benjamin Franklin” wouldn’t refer to BF. If, in saying “Benjamin Franklin is bald,” one was attributing baldness to Aristotle, then, in that context at least, “Benjamin Franklin” would refer to Aristotle. 
Let’s generalize these points. For any property phi, “Benjamin Franklin” refers to BF (and not to Aristotle, for example) because ‹Benjamin Franklin has phi› attributes phi to Benjamin Franklin; and if one couldn’t attribute phi to Benjamin Franklin by saying ‹Benjamin Franklin has phi›, then “Benjamin Franklin” would not refer to BF. Further, if, in uttering that sentence, one was attributing baldness to Aristotle (but not BF), then “Benjamin Franklin” would refer to Aristotle (but not Benjamin Franklin). Thus, for “Benjamin Franklin” to refer to BF it is both necessary and sufficient that ‹Benjamin Franklin has phi› attribute phi to BF. The fact that “Benjamin Franklin” refers to BF is identical with the fact that ‹Benjamin Franklin has phi› attributes phi to Benjamin Franklin, for any property phi. 
In general, expression E refers to O if and only if, for any property phi, ‹E has phi› attributes phi to O. E’s referring to O may be identified with E’s being such that, in virtue of containing it, a sentence ipso facto attributes a property to O. 
Bearing these points in mind, let's revisit the question: Do sentences refer to truth-values? Does "snow is white" refer to the property of being true (which, in this context, we're assuming for argument's sake to be identical with the truth-value true)? No. In virtue of having the form, ‹…the property of being true…›, a sentence is about the property of being true. (“Everything Bill says has the property of being true” says of the property of being true that it is instantiated by everything that Bill says.”) But it isn't the case that, in virtue of having the form ‹…snow is white…›, a sentence is about the property of being true. 
Of course, “if snow is white, then snow isn’t green” can, like any other sentence, be interpreted as concerning the property of being true—it can be interpreted as saying that the property of being true is a characteristic of the proposition that snow isn’t green if it’s white. But given how artificial it is to paraphrase "if snow is white, then snow isn't green" in this way, it's clear that, in some respect that is deeply relevant to their semantics, "the property of being true" and "snow is white" aren't comparable. Which, in its turn, suggests that it isn’t in virtue of its containing an occurrence of “snow is white” that “if snow is white, then snow isn’t green” concerns that property. 
But even if, in virtue of having the form ‹…snow is white…›, a sentence is about the property of being true, the way in which, in virtue of having that form, such a sentence concerns that property is obviously different from the way in which, in virtue of having the form ‹…the property of being true…›, a sentence concerns the property of being true. A story may help make this clear. You are my philosophy professor and I am taking an exam that consists of just one question: I must identify at least one property that all propositions of the form x is even iff x is divisible by two have in common. I duly say (or write) "the property of being true." I pass. But I would have failed if I had instead said "snow is white" (or "grass is green"). In any case, you'd have no reason independently of Frege's argument for passing me. Which, taken together with the points made in the previous section, suggests that you'd have no reason at all for passing me. 
It's hard to find any reason, apart from Frege's argument to the contrary, to hold that "snow is white" refers to the property of being true. Which, given how far Frege's argument to the contrary falls short of being probative, suggests that "snow is white" does not so refer. 

4.1 Can sentences coherently be stipulated to have truth-values for their referents? 
Some (e.g., Church 1943) have stipulated that true (false) sentences refer to the property of being true (false). But some stipulations are incoherent, and this particular stipulation falls into that category. If I stipulate that "Gloxo" is to unambiguously refer to the number two, I cannot coherently stipulate that it is also to refer to the number of sides had by an arbitrary pentagon. 
Bearing this in mind, consider the following variant of the just-told story. You are my geography professor, and you've just given me a test containing just one question: identify the state that lies on the Northern border of California. Instead of saying "Oregon," which is the right answer, I say "snow is white." You duly fail me. 
Of course, if you and I had agreed that, by our stipulation, "snow is white" is to refer to Oregon, then "snow is white" would have been an acceptable answer. But to the extent that "snow is white" would, for that reason, have been an acceptable answer, it obviously wouldn't have been functioning in the same way as the homonymous sentence "snow is white." And it is thus incoherent to stipulate that "snow is white" is unambiguously both an English sentence (to the effect that a certain crystalline substance has a certain chromatic property) and is also an English expression that refers to the state of Oregon. For the same reason mutatis mutandis, it is incoherent to stipulate that the English sentence "snow is white" unambiguously refers to the property of being true. 

4.2 To what, if anything, do sentences refer? 
Given that "snow is white" doesn't refer to the property of being true, to what, if anything, does it refer? It seems to me that, if it refers to anything, that sentence refers to the proposition that snow is white. In virtue of having the form ‹...snow is white... ›, a sentence is ipso facto about the proposition that snow is white. “If snow is white, then snow isn’t green” says that the proposition that snow is white entails (or otherwise has as a consequence) the proposition that snow isn’t green. "It is not the case that snow is white" says that the proposition that snow is white has the property of being false. "Grass is green and snow is white" says that the proposition that snow is white has the property of being a thing x such that both x and the proposition that grass is green are true. So given the reasonable presumption that E refers O if, in virtue of having the form ‹...E... ›, a sentence is to the effect that...O..., it seems to follow that "snow is white" refers to the proposition that snow is white. 
And even if it doesn't follow, we'd be doing less damage to the concept of reference by saying that "snow is white" referred to the corresponding proposition than we would be if we said that it referred to its truth-value. 
A brief detour through the philosophy of science will clarify this last remark. It often happens that, in order for a discipline to move forward, the scope of a given term must be expanded. To be of use to science, terms such as "temperature" and "acid" must be given meanings that, although consistent with the pretheoretic judgments of laypersons, have a much wider sphere of application than do the concepts associated with those terms by the laity. By defining "temperature" as (I'm simplifying) "mean kinetic energy," the jurisdiction of the former term is increased even though its meaning is otherwise unchanged. Such redefinitions are sometimes referred to as precisifications or delineations. 
It's a distinct possibility that, in saying that sentences are referring terms, one is precisifying the term "reference," not identifying its existing meaning. Supposing this were true, it's still wrong (or, in any case, bad in some relevant way or other) to say that sentences refer to their truth-values, and it's less wrong to say that they refer to the propositions they express. In order to be a precisification of a given term T, as opposed to wholesale redefinition of it, an extension of T's jurisdiction must be consistent (for the most part) with T's existing meaning. (I say "for the most part" since pretheoretic judgments are sometimes revised in light of their own theoretical off-shoots. There are, or could be, objects x such that x is cold according to pretheoretic intuition even though, if temperature is identified with mean kinetic energy, x is extremely hot. ) What we know about the existing meaning of "refer" is that (the remaining semantic rules of English being what they are) it is in virtue of the fact that "Socrates" refers to Socrates that ‹Socrates has phi› attributes phi to Socrates; we also know (same qualification) that, if one couldn't attribute phi to Socrates by saying ‹Socrates has phi›, then "Socrates" would not refer to Socrates. In general, we know that to, the extent that, in virtue of having the form ‹...E... ›, a sentence is to the effect that...O..., then E refers to O and that E fails to refer to O to the extent that this condition isn't satisfied. Given this fact, it follows that we'd be horribly misprecisifying the term "reference" were we to say that sentences referred to their truth-values; it also follows that we would not be misprecisifying it as horribly were we to say that they referred to the propositions they meant. Give or take some niceties, if S is a sentence that has proposition P for its meaning, then, in virtue of having the form ‹...S... ›, a sentence S* is to the effect that...P...This suggests that, if sentences refer to anything, it is to the propositions they express and, moreover, that it is not to their truth-values. 
5.0 Davidson on facts 
Despite everything thus far said, Donald Davidson (1967) took it for granted that SS is cogent. And he argued that, given the (alleged) fact that SS is cogent, it follows that there is only one fact. His argument is simple. Put the expression “the fact that” in front of each of (1)-(4): an analogue of SS shows that the resulting expressions must co-refer. 
Instead of rejecting SS, Davidson concluded, absurdly, that these two facts are identical and that, by obvious extensions of this reasoning, there is, at most, only one fact. Having, in his mind, established that there is only one fact, he argued that, for this reason, mental states are not representations. Since there is only one fact, Davidson argued, no two mental states represent different facts. On this basis, Davidson concluded that differences between mental states—between, for example, my perception of the piano in my living room and your perception of the ink-marks in front of you—are not representational differences. 
Why is this? Because, says Davidson, representations, supposing them to exist, are representations of facts; and, says Davidson, we've seen that there is only one fact. Therefore, Davidson says, my perception of the piano in my living room doesn't differ in respect of which fact it represents from your perception of the ink-marks in front of you. From this Davidson concludes (fallaciously, even relative to his own assumptions), that the one perception is representationally just like the other. Thus, the differences between those perceptions have nothing to do with any representational differences that there might be between them. This in its turn means that, if there are any such differences, they are innocuous: in other words, it is not in terms of those differences that the palpable differences between those perceptions are to be understood. This, in its turn, means either that: 
(i) Neither perception represents anything, 
or that: 
(ii) If either perception does represent something, it is irrelevant to how that perception differs from the other perception and, therefore, to what sort of thing that perception is. Which, give or take some unimportant nuances, means that 
neither represents anything. 

5.1 Evaluating Davidson's contention 
Davidson’s position is obviously false. The fact that I am typing this sentence is distinct from the fact that you are reading it. There is more than one fact. What could be more obvious? 
Of course, the word "fact" is a vague one; and, surely, it's at least partly for this reason that Davidson's position has been given any credence. In any case, there is no precisification of the term "fact" that validates Davidson's position. 
In some contexts, the word "fact" is synonymous with the word "truth." ("The fact that arithmetic is incomplete was unknown to Frege" is synonymous with "the truth that arithmetic is incomplete was unknown to Frege.") Since there are many truths, this interpretation of the word "fact" doesn't validate Davidson's view. 
In other contexts, the word "fact" seems to refer to (re)distributions of mass-energy---to the spatiotemporal conditions and changes in virtue of which certain propositions are true and others are false. Let M be the mass-energy (re)distribution in virtue of which the proposition x is now asleep (where x is any sleeping person) is true. Let N be the mass-energy distribution in virtue of which the Earth is now traveling at approximately 17,000 mph with respect to the Sun is true. M . N. That's just a fact. Pun intended. 
Are there other precisifications of the word fact? Probably. (For example, physical laws may qualify as "facts," at least on one interpretation of that word, even though it's not clear that physical laws are identical either with truths or with (re)distributions of mass-energy). But, apart from Davidson's argument to the contrary, there is no reason to expect any of the remaining precisifications to do a better job of validating Davidson's contention than those we've just considered. 

5.2 Evaluating Davidson's argument for his contention 
Davidson's argument fails for the same reason mutatis mutandis that SS fails. But Davidson’s argument involves a blunder of which SS is innocent. For a mental state to be representational is not for there to be some fact that it represents. It is for that mental state to be to the effect that there exists some fact. Suppose that I hallucinate that there is a pink elephant in my living room. (Assume that, in actuality, there is no such elephant.) My hallucination is representational. It isn’t like a rock. But there is no elephant x such that my hallucination represents some pink elephant x such that x is in my living room. My hallucination is representational in the sense that it is to the effect that there exists some pink elephant x such that x is in my living room. For mental state M to be representational isn't (necessarily) for there to be some fact that M represents; it is (or can be) for M to be to the effect that there exists a fact having such and such characteristics. And the non-existence of such a fact is obviously compatible with the existence of erroneous propositional attitudes to the contrary. 
6.0 Neale on a variant of SS 
In his (ironically named) book Facing the Facts, Stephen Neale puts forth what he believes to be an improvement on SS.[182] 
Neale’s argument involves the following four assumptions: 
G1: The sentence ‹Fa› stands for the same fact as the sentence ‹a = the unique thing x such that (x = a and Fx).› (In 
this context, “=” is to be taken to mean “is identical with.”) G2: Any sentence can be put into subject-predicate form. G3: What a complex expression refers to is a function of 
what its parts refer to. G4: Definite descriptions are referring terms. “The even prime” is an expression that picks out the number two. 
Assume that for some individuals a and b, and some properties G and F, the following are true: ‹Fa›, ‹Gb›, and ‹a . b›; and suppose that these sentences stand for facts F1, F2, 
and F3, respectively. Bearing these assumptions in mind, consider the following seven sentences. 
1. 
Fa. By assumption. 

2. 
a . b. By assumption. 

3. 
Gb. By assumption. 


4. 
a = the unique thing x such that (x = a and Fx). Follows from 1, by G1. 

5. 
a = the unique thing x such that (x = a and x . b). Follows from 2, by G2. 

6. 
b = the unique thing x such that (x = b and Gx). Follows from 3, by G1. 

7. 
b = the unique thing x such that (x = b and x . a). Follows from 2, by G1. 


1 and 4 stand for the same fact, namely F1. 2, 5, and 7 all stand for the same fact, namely F2. And 3 and 6 stand for the same fact, namely F3. ‹The unique thing x such that (x = a and Fx)› co-refers with ‹the unique thing x such that (x = a and x . b)›, since both expressions refer to a. Therefore, 5 is what results when the definite description in 4 is replaced with a co-referring definite description. Therefore, 4 and 5 refer to the same fact. Since they refer, respectively, to F1 
and F2, it follows that F1 and F2 are the same fact. ‹The unique thing x such that (x = b and x . a)› co-refers with ‹the unique thing x such that (x = b and Gx)›, since both expression refer to b. Therefore, 7 is what results when the definite description in 6 is replaced with a co-referring 
definite description. Therefore, 6 and 7 refer to the same fact. Since they refer, respectively, to F3 and F1, it follows that F3 and F1 are the same fact. If G4 is wrong, then definite descriptions are not referring terms, in which case 5 is not 
what results when the definite descriptions in 4 is replaced with a co-referring expression, and 7 is what not results when the definite description in 6 is replaced with a co-referring expression. But assuming that G4 is right, we’ve 
established that F1= F2. Therefore F1= F2= F3, and ‹Fa› therefore co-refers with ‹Gb› and also with ‹a . b›. So, assuming that definite descriptions are what they appear to be, viz., referring terms, it follows there is only one fact. 
This result, if it is in fact true, is astonishing. But G2 allows us to go further. Let S and S* be any two distinct statements that are true. (So S and S* needn’t have subject-predicate form.) According to G2, S can be put in subject-predicate form, and so can S*. Given any existing individual a, S can be rendered as ‹a is an x such that S›; and given any existing individual b, S* can be rendered as ‹b is an x such that S*›. And once that is granted, it follows, by the foregoing argument, that S and S* stand for the same fact. It follows that, given G1-G4, any two true sentences stand for 
the same fact. 

6.1 Evaluating Neale’s argument 
The problems with this argument are very similar to the problems with Davidson’s. Consider line 4 of Neale’s argument: 
4. ‹a = the unique thing x such that (x = a and Fx).› 
If this sentence is read attributively (in other words, if the definite descriptions in them are treated as quantifiers, as opposed to referring terms), then it is logically equivalent with: 
1. ‹Fa›, 
in which case those two sentences can therefore be seen as standing for the same fact. But if 4 is read referentially (in other words, if the definite descriptions in them are treated as referring terms, as opposed to quantifiers), then 4 stands for the same fact as: 
4R: ‹a = a›, 
in which case 1 and 4 cannot plausibly be seen as standing for the same fact. For exactly similar reasons, 5, 6, and 7 must be read attributively if there is to be any plausibility to the claim that they stand for the same facts as, respectively, 2, 3, and 4. In general, G1 is false if 4-7 are read referentially, 4­
7 must therefore be read attributively. Bottom line: Neale’s argument fails if 4-7 are read referentially. It also fails, for obvious reasons, if they’re read attributively. 
7.0 A final note concerning SS 
SS assumes that: 
(i) Each of the two definite descriptions occurring in it is a singular term. 
SS makes the additional assumption that: 
(ii) Reference isn’t changed by intersubstituting co-referring terms that have different senses. 
And, of course, SS assumes that: 
(iii) Referring terms can have both sense and reference (it assumes that the definite descriptions occurring in the second and third sentences have both sense and reference). 
(i) is innocuous. Even though, for reasons already discussed, some hold that definite descriptions are not singular terms, being instead quantifiers, we could obviously stipulate that the definite descriptions in SS are referring terms. We could stipulate that, for any property phi, and for any object O, ‹the phi› refers to O exactly if O uniquely has phi. 
But this wouldn’t be enough to get SS to go through. For argument’s sake, suppose that ‹the phi› refers to O exactly if O uniquely has phi; and further suppose that, in virtue of having the form ‹…the phi…›, a sentence is true exactly if…O…In that case, supposing that O were a unique phi, ‹Plato thought highly of the phi› would bear a proposition that was true exactly if Plato thought highly of O, it being entirely irrelevant what properties (other than being highly thought of by Plato) O had, and ‹the phi was a great wrestler› would bear a proposition that was true exactly if O was a great wrestler, it being entirely irrelevant what properties (other than being a great wrestler) O had. 
Thus, supposing that ‹...the phi…› were defined in the way thus proposed, there is some x such that x = Socrates such that: 
(*) “Plato thought highly of the great philosopher who died 
of hemlock poisoning," 
would be true iff: 
(**) Plato thought highly of x. 
Thus, SS not only assumes that ‹the phi› is a singular term. It also assumes that, in virtue of having the form ‹…the phi…›, a sentence is true if and only if exactly one thing O has phi and…x… 
But even though each of those assumptions is perfectly defensible, they are incompatible with each other. Unfortunately, the essence of Frege's theory of reference is that both assumptions are correct. Thus, that theory is spurious, and so is SS, given that it relies, in a particularly brazen way, on both assumptions. Sadly, the obvious fact that sentences don't refer to truth-values wasn't taken to show that Frege's semantics was defective. Instead, it was assumed that Frege's semantics was non-defective that sentences therefore do refer to truth-values. For some reason, philosophers haven't been deterred by the fact that there is basis for this contention, apart from Frege's theory. This means that there's no basis for it at all, given that little credence should be given to a semantic theory according to which "snow" refers to an abstract object in "it is true that snow is white." But, in this case as in so many others, philosophers chose to hide their failure to see the obvious beneath a lot of gratuitous logic-chopping. 
Chapter 7 Some Puzzles Relating to Language and Logic 
1.0 Are there meaningless sentences? 
According to some, there are bona fide sentences that are meaningless. Among the various confusions underlying this totally erroneous position, three can be cleared up right away: 
(i) 
There are expression-like entities that, given their phonetic properties along with facts about the linguistic environments in which they occur, are easily mistaken for bona fideexpressions. Given what the words flanking it are and what it sounds like, the occurrence of “blerko” in “sometimes a blerko can be a man’s best friend” is likely to be mistaken for an actual word. But it has no meaning and is thus no word. 

In many lectures of his that I attended (as a student at UCLA), David Kaplan, a well known semanticist, insisted that the opening sentence of Lewis Carroll’s Jabberwocky (“ Twas brillig, and the slithy toves/Did gyre and gimble in the wabe”) was a bona fide sentence. It is not. It is a sentence-impostor. (Obviously “brillig,” “slithy,” “tove,” etc. are meant to bring to mind the words “brilliant,” “slimy,” “toad,” etc. But those two lines no more token a sentence than a man wearing a Richard Nixon mask is Richard Nixon.) 

(ii) 
According to Carnap (1932), “this stone is thinking of Vienna” is literally meaningless, even though it is a bona fide sentence. Carnap is making the familiar mistake of confusing the property of having a meaning worth affirming with the property of having no meaning. That stone was not thinking of Vienna; so Carnap’s sentence was false, and therefore meaningful. 


There is obviously a sense in which an utterance of “this stone is thinking about Vienna” is “nonsense.” But in that sense of the word “nonsense,” a sentence's being nonsense consists in its having a meaning, albeit one that has no chance of being correct. 
Chomsky (1957) made the very same mistake, though in a 
less brazen way, when he famously said that “colorless green ideas sleep furiously” is meaningless but that, since it has the right syntactic properties, is a bona fide sentence. On one of its two disambiguations, it says that there are ideas that are both colorless and green, all of them furious sleepers. Thus disambiguated, “colorless green ideas sleep furiously” is meaningful, but its meaning isn’t worth affirming. On its other disambiguation, it says that anything that is a member of the class of colorless green things that are ideas is also a member of the class of things that sleep furiously. In other words, it says that nothing that falls into the first class fails to fall into the second class. 
Thus disambiguated, that sentence is true but trivial: given that the first class is empty, it follows vacuously that there is no member of the first class that isn’t also a member of the second class. It’s obvious that the first class cannot possibly have any members and therefore cannot possibly have any members in common with any other class. So, thus disambiguated, that sentence affirms a proposition that, being vacuously true and therefore devoid of significant information, is not worth affirming. 
Thus, contrary to what Chomsky says, “colorless green ideas sleep furiously” is perfectly meaningful. In fact, it’s hyper-meaningful, since it has two meanings. One of them is a correct (but trivial) proposition; the other is a false (and absurd) proposition. Triviality and falsity are properties of meanings. 
So Chomsky’s contention is proven false---and not, contrary to what he seems to think, proven correct---by the very fact that, depending on how it is disambiguated, “colorless green dreams sleeps furiously” is absurd or trivial. 
Russell claimed that “quadruplicity drinks procrastination” is a bona fide sentence that is meaningless. But that claim is false; the reasons for this are similar to those just given in connection with “colorless green ideas sleep furiously.” First of all, unless “quadruplicity” has a meaning, this sentence of Russell’s is no more a sentence than “drinks procrastination.” 
So it must be assumed that “quadruplicity” has a meaning. According to Russell, whose word we can trust here, that word does have a meaning; it refers to the property of having four members. (So the smallest set consisting of the numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 has the property of quadruplicity.) Given this fact, Russell’s supposedly meaningless sentence is quite clearly false, and therefore meaningful. Being abstracts objects, quadruplicity and procrastination neither drink, nor are drunk by, anything. Russell seems to be committing the oft-made mistake of confusing absurdity, which is the property of having a meaning that is logically incapable of being true, with meaninglessness. Russell’s belief that “quadruplicity drinks procrastination” was probably also motivated by his acceptance of the Theory of Types, which we’ll discuss in Section 3.0 of this chapter and which, in agreement with every mathematical and philosophical logician alive, we’ll find to be false. 
(iii) Oftentimes, a homonym of an actual word occurs in a context in which no semantic rule assigns any meaning to it and in which it therefore means nothing, even though the context in question is one that is otherwise just like a sentence. What occurs in “the absolute is one” is not the word “absolute,” but a mere homonym of that word. For the occurrence of “absolute” in “the absolute is one” to be a word, there would have to be some semantic rule that assigned it a meaning. Although there are semantic rules that assign meaning(s) to homonyms of that occurrence, that occurrence per se is assigned no meaning. Anything that is assigned no meaning is ipso facto not a linguistic expression. So “the absolute is one” is not a sentence, but a sentence-impostor, at least until it is said what "the absolute" refers to, or is supposed to refer to---at least, that is to say, until the semantic rule for it is identified. 
Anything to which no semantic rule assigns a meaning ipso facto isn't a linguistic expression. Because the logical positivists overlooked this humdrum fact, they sought some criterion by which to distinguish "meaningful sentences" (e.g., "the moon is made of cheese") from "meaningless sentences" (e.g., "the absolute is one"). But all of the meaningless so-called sentences that they identified weren't sentences at all; they were sentence-schemata, since they contained undetermined expressions (expressions to which no semantic rule assigned any meaning, at least not as far as occurrences in the sentence in question were concerned) and therefore no more qualified as bona fide sentences than does "x has property phi." 
Thus, in trying to explain the meaningless of pseudo-sentences as “the absolute is one”, the logical positivists were on a fools errant. In that pseudo-sentence, the term “the absolute” is a restricted variable, albeit one whose connotations constrict its range of possible values more than the range of the (almost entirely) non-connotative variable in, say, “x is extended” restricts its possible range of values. 
2.0 The liar’s paradox 
We’ve found elementary blunders in each of the reasons already considered for holding that bona fide expressions can be meaningless. But there are other reasons for holding this that don’t involve any obvious blunders and demand careful treatment. In the process of considering these reasons, we’ll make some headway on some important, open questions in semantics and philosophical logic. 
There are sentences that, so initial appearances suggest, are true if they’re false and false if they’re true.[183] 
Consider the sentence: 
(LIE1) “I am now lying.” 
Given the law of excluded middle (“any proposition must be either true or false”), LIE1 cannot fail to be either true or false. Given the law of non-contradiction (“no proposition can be both true and false”), LIE1 cannot be both true and false. So if LIE1 expresses a proposition, that proposition is both true and false. Therefore, given that no such proposition exists, LIE1 doesn’t express a proposition. But it’s very hard to believe that “I am lying” is not a sentence. Exactly similar reasoning holds with respect to “I am lying” and “I am a Cretan and all Cretans are liars,” and each one of the infinitely many other sentences that are relevantly similar to those two. 
LIE1 is indeed a sentence. But it’s not both true and false; it’s just false. LIE1 is equivalent with: 
(LIE2) “There already exists some proposition P such that P is false and such that, by virtue of producing this very utterance, I am affirming P.” 
LIE2 thus entails that, existing prior to, and therefore independently of, any LIE2 or any utterance thereof, there is some proposition P such that (i) is false and, moreover, such that (ii) is true only if, for some utterance of LIE2, P is true only if that utterance is true. Since P pre-exists any such utterance, 
LIE2 is not false and true; it is simply false. Therefore, LIE1 is false. So we don’t have in LIE1 a counter-example to our thesis that there are bona 
fideexpressions that are meaningless. 
2.1 The liar’s paradox (continued) 
There is another way of dealing with the Liar’s paradox, or at least with one version of it. Let UTF be a specific utterance of the sentence: 
(TF) “This sentence-token is false.” 
To what do the first two word-tokens constituting UTF refer? “They refer to UTF”, it will be said. ”In other words, that occurrence of ‘this token’ means “the sentence-token I will have produced by virtue of completing this sentence.” If only for argument's sake, let’s suppose that this is so. In that case, TF is equivalent with: 
(TF*) There exists some proposition P such that there is exactly one sentence-token that I am now uttering such that my utterance affirms P (and is therefore true if, and only if, P is false).[184] 

A proposition is a truth or a falsehood. So P has been a truth or a falsehood as long as it’s existed. (Since—see Chapter 2---propositions don’t come into existence or go out of it, this means that it’s always existed.) If P pre-dates TF*, then it was true or false before TF* ever came along. In that case, TF* is simply false. For TF* falsely says the truth of P is contingent on the truth of TF*, which is not the case. If P does not pre-date TF*, then TF is simply false; for it starts with the words “there exists a proposition P such that.” Even if that proposition pops into existence by the end of the TF*, TF* is false, since it affirmed the existence of some proposition that pre-dated TF*’s completion. 
3.0 Russell’s Paradox and the Theory of Types 
Other sentences that are obviously comparable to “I am now lying” are “this sentence is false” and “I’m a Cretan, and all Cretans are liars.” But there exist sentences that, it has been argued, are meaningless and that, unlike those two, are not in any obvious way modeled on “this sentence is false.” The best known example of such a sentence is[185]: 
(RP) K is a member of itself iff K is not a member of itself, 
where K is the class of all classes that are not members of themselves. (If K is a member of itself, then, since K includes only classes that aren’t members of themselves, then K is not a member of itself; and if K is not a member of itself, then, since K includes every class that is not a member of itself, K is a member of itself.)[186] 

According to Graham Priest, a contemporary logician, RP is meaningful, 
i.e. there is some proposition that it affirms. According to Priest, since that proposition is both true and false, we must reject the law of non­contradiction.[187] 
In a moment, we’ll see why Priest’s reasoning is spurious. 
Unlike Priest, Bertrand Russell held that the law of non-contradiction is correct and, therefore, that there is no proposition that RP expresses. But Russell has a very different view from us as to why RP fails. 
Russell’s view is embodied in his famous “Theory of Types” (“TT” for short). According to TT, any given sentence belongs to a certain "type"; given any two types, one is higher than the other. The lowest type is Type1. 
Sentences of Type1 concern “individuals.” (An individual is anything spatiotemporal and, therefore, anything that isn't a set, property, sentence or proposition. In this context, for the sake of expediency, references to 
"classes" will be short-hand for references to classes and to properties and to propositions and to sentences.) Sentences of Type2 concern individuals and classes whose members are individuals. (Sentences of Type2 thus concern inter alia sentences of Type1.) Sentences of Type3 concern everything with which sentences of Type2 are concerned as well as classes of classes of individuals.[188] 
In general, for any whole number n, sentences of Typen+1 may concern everything with which sentences of Type n are concerned and, unlike sentences of Type n, sentences of Type n+1 may concern classes of Type n. 
A consequence of TT is that, if the free variable in “x is a member of class C”, where C is of Typem, is replaced with an expression denoting a class of Typem or higher, the resulting sentence is meaningless, i.e. there is no proposition that it affirms and it is therefore neither true nor false. 
So, according to TT, “C is a member of C” is meaningless, and so is its negation. TT entails that RP is no more meaningful than “blurka derka derk." Given his acceptance of TT, Russell understandably holds it to be a failing of the English language that it permits the construction of sentences like RP. 
3.1 Why the theory of types is false 
RP is ambiguous; there are two ways of disambiguating it. RP can be taken to be to the same effect as: 
(RP1) There exists some class K such that all and only those classes that are not members of themselves belong to K. 
Thus disambiguated, RP is false. There is no such class. A contradiction follows from the supposition that there is a class whose membership includes all and only those classes that aren’t members of themselves. Therefore, there is no such class. 
The fact that no such class exists is to be established by a garden-variety indirect proof, just like the fact that there are no square circles.[189] 
Let x be a square circle. Being a square, x has four sides and therefore doesn’t have a uniform curvature. Being a circle, x has a uniform curvature. Therefore, x both does and does not have a uniform curvature. This isn’t possible. So x is a non-entity. K is a non-entity for the same reason mutatis mutandis. 
There is another way to interpret RP. We could take “K” to be defined thus: 
(AI[190]) Assuming that there is some class O whose members include all and only those classes that are not members of themselves, then, in virtue of having the form ‹ …K…›, a given sentence S is true just in case O has…x…(i.e., just in case…O…); and, if that assumption is false, then “K” picks out nothing, and ‹…K…. › bears no proposition and is thus neither true nor false. 
Thus taken, RP doesn’t say anything. Since there is no class of the requisite kind, “K” picks out nothing and, the semantic rule for “K” being what it is, RP fails to encode any proposition. Thus disambiguated, KP is like an utterance of: (TPE) “That pink elephant is coming right at us,” 
made in a context where there is no pink elephant. So, thus disambiguated, RP requires neither an abandonment of the laws of classical logic nor an acceptance of TT. 
3.2 Two kinds of meaning: type-meaning and token-meaning (revisited) 
Here we must revisit an issue discussed in the previous chapter.[191] 
There seems to be some sense in which an utterance of TPE that is made in an elephant-free context is meaningful, notwithstanding that such an utterance bears no proposition. The sense in which such an utterance is meaningful is this: the semantic rules of the language to which it belongs determine what would have to be the case for that utterance to be meaningful. The semantic rule corresponding to TPE is this: 
(TPE*) If, in context C, there is some pink elephant E that is 
being indicated by some person P1, and P1 is indicating no 
pink elephant other than E, then an utterance on P1’s part, 
directed towards persons P2….Pn (2 = n), of “that pink 
elephant is heading towards us” is true exactly if E is heading 
towards P1…Pn. If there is no such elephant, that utterance 
fails to encode any proposition. 
So, when uttered in an elephant-free environment, TPE is meaningful. It’s meaningful in the sense that it has well-defined truth-conditions. Whether those conditions are fulfilled has no bearing on whether TPE is meaningful. Nothing relating to the whereabouts of elephants redounds to the credit or the discredit of the body of rules that constitute the English language. 
Similar reasoning holds in connection with RP. RP has truth-conditions. Whether those conditions are fulfilled is irrelevant to whether RP is meaningful. "But there is a difference between RP and TPE,” it will be said. "Whereas tokens of TPE could be true, tokens of TT cannot possibly be true: the laws of logic prohibit it." Yes---but the laws of logic aren't coded into the semantic rules of English. One can master those rules without being a master-logician; one certainly doesn't need to know whether there exists a class of all classes that aren't members of themselves. So RP, though not proposition-bearing, is meaningful. 
To conclude: on neither of its disambiguations is RP a counterexample to our contention that all bona fideexpressions are meaningful. This is another instance of a philosopher failing to distinguish absurdity from 
meaninglessness. We discussed other such examples in Chapter 1. 
3.3 The theory of types revisited: More problems with it 
According to the Theory of Types (TT), no meaningful sentence occupies an order equal to, or lower than, the order occupied by any one of the sentences that it concerns. Since TT itself concerns statements belonging to every order, it concerns the order to which it itself belongs and, supposing it correct, is therefore meaningless and, being meaningless, is not correct. So TT is not correct if it is correct. Since, therefore, TT is inconsistent with itself, it is false. 
Also, TT has consequences too counterintuitive to accept. For example, according to TT, the sentence: 
(i) “Jim has three pairs of socks.” 
is of a lower order than the sentence: 
(ii) “The sentence ‘Jim has three pairs of socks’ is true," 
and (ii) is of a lower type than the sentence: 
(iii) “The sentence ‘the sentence “Jim has three pairs of socks” is true’ is true.” 
If TT is right, the property that one ascribes to (iii) by describing it as “true” is one that cannot possibly be had by (ii) or (i), and the property one ascribes to (ii) by describing it as “true” is one that cannot possibly be had by (i). So, if TT is right, there is no such thing as truth simpliciter. There is truth1, truth2, etc. 
By similar reasoning, if TT is right, the occurrence of “three” in: 
(iv) “Jim has three pairs of socks,” 
doesn’t have the same meaning as its homonym in (i). (i) is to the effect that: 
(a) There are three true instances of the propositional-form x is a member of the class of pairs of socks had by Jim. 
The occurrence “three” in (i) denotes a property had by classes of individuals. (It denotes the property of being a three-membered class of individuals.) The homonymous occurrence in (iv) denotes a property of classes of classes of individuals. (It denotes the property of being a three-membered class of classes of individuals.) So the property denoted by the one occurrence is distinct from the property denoted by the other. Given how counterintuitive this is, TT must be presumed false. 
This presumption is easily verified. TT concerns all sentences. It isn’t concerned with sentences belonging to this or that specific order. According to TT, any proposition that concerns all sentences is ipso facto meaningless. So if TT is true, then it’s false; therefore, it’s false. 
4.0 Vagueness and indeterminacy 
The word “indeterminate” has two meanings. The sentence: 
(BW) “Bill’s whereabouts are indeterminate,” 
can be taken to mean either: 
(BW1) given the available information, it isn’t possible to arrive at a principled judgment as to where Bill is. 
or 
(BW2) there is no fact as to where Bill is. 
BW2 cannot possibly be true. At any given point in time, some space-time region R is such that Bill is occupying R. Of course, half of Bill's body can be in the garage while the other half is in the drive way. But that’s because the region he is occupying is itself half in the garage and half in the driveway; it is not because there is no region that Bill is determinately occupying. The same points mutatis mutandis hold of any other proposition to the effect that the world per se is indeterminate in any respect. In any case, this is what the present author believes. 
But many disagree; and their reasons for doing so seem at first to be good ones. For there certainly seem to be cases of objects with vague boundaries. In fact, all spatiotemporal objects, it would seem, have vague boundaries. Given any person P, there are many particles x such that one cannot non-arbitrarily say that ‹x is a part P's body› is true or that it's not true. This apparent fact is one that has led many a philosopher to hold that there is objective indeterminacy.[192] 
But we'll now see that such philosophers haven’t considered all the possible ways of modeling our intuitions. 
5.1 Non-epistemic indeterminacy 
Smith doesn’t have a full head of hair; but there are a few tufts of hair on his head, in between which there is fuzz of varying degrees of thickness and density. Bearing this in mind, consider the statement: 
(SB) “Smith is bald.” 
is SB true or false? Many philosophers, probably most, would hold that: 
(OV)[193] 
There is no fact of the matter; and that fact has nothing to do with ignorance on our part. Here’s what’s going on. There exists a certain property P that of baldness and a certain person x.(P = the property of baldness; x = Smith.) And x doesn’t exactly instantiate P, but x doesn’t exactly fail to instantiate P. There is no fact as to whether the proposition x has P is true. It isn’t that we don’t know whether it’s true; it’s that there is no fact of the matter. 
Here’s the problem with OV. For argument’s sake, suppose that it is objectively indeterminate whether Smith is bald. Suppose, in other words, that the proposition (not the sentence):[194] 

(SB) Smith is bald, 
is true. And, let us also suppose, the reason SB is vague is that it is objectively indeterminate exactly what conditions a given thing must satisfy to be bald. 
Given these suppositions, it is ipso facto indeterminate what exactly SB entails and what is entailed by it. If it is objectively indeterminate exactly what features a thing must have to be bald, then it is for that very reason indeterminate, for any x, exactly what entails, and also what is entailed by, the proposition (not—nota bene—the sentence): 
(XB) ‹x is bald›, 
for any x. 
Thus, a consequence of the supposition that SB is objectively indeterminate is that it is indeterminate what SB entails and also what is entailed by it. 
But the very idea of such a proposition is not a coherent one. Propositions are individuated by what they entail. Different entailment relations, different propositions. So until the entailment relations of some sentence-like string of verbiage have been fixed, no proposition has been identified to that verbiage; and all we have is, at most, a sentence-schema. 
5.2 An objection to the argument just presented 
I have heard it said that: 
(ER)[195] 
Propositions are not individuated by their entailment relations. The proposition that 1 + 1 = 2 obviously isn’t identical with the proposition that triangles have three sides. But a given proposition entails/is entailed by the one just in case it entails/is entailed by the other.” 
Obviously 1+1 =2 and triangles have three sides are different propositions. But contrary to what ER assumes, they don't coincide in respect of their entailment relations. The way [196] 
in which for some n, n + 2 follows from 1+1 =2 differs—quite dramatically—from the way (or, rather, any one of the infinitely many possible ways) in which for some n, n + 2 follows from triangles have three sides. A corollary is that, until it is settled what the entailment relations are of a given sentence, it ipso facto hasn’t been settled which proposition is meant by that sentence. (This doesn’t mean that one has to know what all of those relations are. No one knows what all of the entailment relations are of “1 + 1 = 2.” But, the semantic rules of the English language being what they are, it is indeed fixed what those entailment relations are.) 
What a sentence says---or, to be precise, what is affirmed by a non-abortive indicative token of that sentence ---is a function of exactly two things: first, what follows from that sentence-token (supposing it is true); second, how those things follow from it (same qualification). Given a sentence-token S, once what it entails and how it entails it is fixed, there is nothing left to be said about what it means. By the same token, if what S entails or how it entails it isn’t fixed, it has yet to be fixed what S means. Thus, a sentence such that there is no fact as to what it entails, or as to how it entails what it entails, is a sentence to which no one proposition has been assigned. 
Bearing these points in mind, suppose the following. P is a true proposition. There are propositions P1….Pn such that, for each i, it is objectively indeterminate whether P entails Pi. Thus, P ipso facto leaves it open whether P is true. But if P leaves it open whether Pi is true, then P 
determinately fails to entail Pi. That doesn’t mean that P entails the negation of Pi. (Snow is white doesn’t entail grass is green or grass is not green.A proposition may be compatible with another proposition and with its 
negation.) 
The believer in indeterminacy has but one way of dealing with this argument. He is forced to say that, although there is no fact as to whether P entails Pi, nonetheless P does not leave it open whether Pi is true. But this 
position is tautologously false. 
5.2.1 An objection to the argument just presented (continued) 
Here is a similar argument. Suppose there to be some propositions P* such that (i), for any given proposition, it is determinate whether P* entails that proposition and therefore that it is determinate, for any i, whether P* entails Pi but such that (ii), with that qualification, P* entails a given proposition iff 
P also entails it. Is P identical with P*? It cannot be. For P* has, whereas P 
lacks, the property of being such that there is a fact as to whether it entails Pi, for some i. Thus, P is distinct from any proposition P% such that P%, supposing it true, settles whether or not Pi is true. So P fails to settle whether 
or not Pi is true and thus fails to entail it or its negation. So the statement “P entails Pi” is determinately false. 
Were there indeterminate statements; i.e., statements such that there was no fact as to whether what they affirmed was true, there would be pairs of statements such that there was no fact as to whether the one entailed the other (or, therefore, whether it entailed its negation). But given any such pair, the one ipso facto leaves it open whether the other is true and thus determinately fails to entail (the negation of the other), an immediate consequence being that there is a fact as to whether the one entails the other. So the concept of a proposition such that there is no fact as to whether it is true is an incoherent one and the same is therefore true of the concept of objective, as opposed to epistemic vagueness. 
6.0 The Sorites paradox 
Consider the following paradox. 
Paradox #1 (P1): A person with only one dollar is poor. If a person with n dollars is poor, then so is a person with n +1 dollars. It follows that a person with a billion dollars is poor. But, obviously, a person with a billion dollars is not poor. 
For reasons that are of no philosophical importance and that, in any case, will soon become clear, P1 is an example of what is known as the “Sorites Paradox” (a.k.a., the “Paradox of the Heap,” “Sorites” being the plural of the Greek word “soros,” which, so I am told, means “heap”). There are three different kinds of Sorites paradoxes, P1 being an example of only one of 
those three kinds. We’ll now outline solutions to all three kinds, beginning with the kind instantiated by P1. 
Here is an outline of the solution to P1: Like most predicates, “poor” is a relational expression. Smith may be poor compared to Jones but wealthy compared to Green, or he may be poor relative to the standard set by some situation and wealthy relative to the standard set by some other situation. If Smith is a millionaire who needs to have a net worth of at least 50 million dollars to become a managing director of company X, he is poor relative to the standard of wealth that, given Smith’s desire to become a managing director of X, is the relevant one. So an utterance of ‘Smith is poor’ is correct if made in a context in which the relevant standard of wealth is set by Smith’s desire to become a managing director of X. For, in such a context, a "poor" person is one whose net worth is less than $50,000,000. For that very reason, it follows that, in such a context, there is a number n--namely, 49,999,999--­such that an utterance of ‹x is poor› is true if x has n dollars and false if x has n + 1 dollars. 
Bearing these points in mind, it’s clear how to solve each member of the infinitely large class of paradoxes to which P1 belongs. Consider the following paradox: 
(P1#) If a person’s top running speed is 1 mph, then that person is slow. For any number, if a person whose top running 
speed is n mph is slow, then a person whose top running speed 
is n + 1 mph is also slow. Therefore, a person whose top 
running speed is 75 mph is slow. 
A story, structurally similar to the one just told, will make it clear how to solve this paradox. At his best, Smith runs a 100 yard dash in 12 seconds. Smith tries to join track team X. In order to qualify for team X, one must run a 100 yard dash in no more than 10 seconds. Obviously Smith doesn’t make the team. Smith then decides to join team Y. In order to qualify for team Y, one must run a 100 yard dash in no more than 100 seconds. Smith obviously qualifies for Y. 
If made in a context in which the relative standard of swiftness is set by Smith’s desire to join X, an utterance of “Smith is fast” is false. But such an utterance is true if made in a context in which the relative standard of swiftness is set by Smith’s desire to join Y. In a context of either kind, there is some number n such that an utterance of ‹x is slow› is true if, at his best, x’s average speed when running the 100 yard dash is n and such that an utterance of “x is fast” is true if x is person whose average running speed when running 100 yards is n + 1. 
In a context of the first kind, n is any number such that if a person whose average speed when running a 100 yard dash is n and who, for that reason, runs the 100 yard dash in over 11 seconds but who, if his speed when running the 100 yard dash were n + 1, would run it in under 11 seconds. The same thing mutatis mutandis holds of contexts of the second kind. 


6.1 These points generalized 
To generalize these points, we must note a fact about language—more specifically, about predicates.[197] 
Some predicates are binary. P is a binary predicate if the property it expresses is one that cannot be had to varying degrees; it is one that a given thing either has or doesn’t have. So “even” (as in “even number”) is a binary predicate. Sorites paradoxes always involve non-binary predicates (i.e., predicates that express properties that can be had to varying degrees), e.g., “fat,” “tall,” “smart.” A corollary is that Sorites paradoxes always involve properties that one thing can have to a greater extent than some other thing. One thing can be smarter than another. 
Bearing these points in mind, consider the following three sentences: 
(i) 
Smith is smart. 

(ii) 
Smith is more smart than Jones. 


(iii) Smith is smarter than Jones. 
(ii) and (iii) are synonyms. In effect, (iii) is just an abbreviation of (ii). Surely, the occurrence of “smart” in (i) has the same meaning (picks out the same property) as the homonymous expression in (ii). This wouldn’t be possible if, in (i), the occurrence of “smart” picked out a binary (non­relational) property. This shows that “smart” is always relational. This, in its turn, shows that tokens of (i) are elliptical for sentence-tokens that express-relational propositions---sentence-tokens having the form: 
(i#) “Smith is smarter than___,” 
or perhaps: 
(i*) “Smith is smart enough for__.” 
So tokens of “Smith is smart” must be elliptical for sentences such as “Smith is smarter than Jones” and “Smith is smart enough to solve the puzzle.” Exactly similar points hold of other non-binary predicates. The meaning of “x is fast” is given by some sentence having the form “x is faster than y” (e.g., “Smith is faster than Jones”) or having the form “x is fast enough to satisfy standard S” (e.g., “that plane is fast enough to make it to 
Pittsburgh by 3:00 P.M.”). 

6.2 A confusion side-stepped 
Here I would like to head off a source of serious confusion. I am not advocating the view that at the level of semantics “Smith is smart,” “Jones is tall” etc. express relational propositions of the just-mentioned kind. It cannot be assumed that the philosophical insights needed to solve puzzles that turn on facts about language are themselves encoded in the semantic rules of English (or of whatever language happens to be the relevant one). So the just-stated analysis is not a semantic analysis; it is not an attempt to identify the semantic rules that assign meaning to sentences of the form “x is P,” where P is an arbitrary non-binary predicate. 
It makes no sense to say that some number is more even than some other number. But this has nothing to do with language; it has to do with the property of being even.
