And if S3 is some t-inclusive time-interval during which the car’s average speed is 60.0001 mph, there is some shorter t-inclusive interval S4 such that the car’s average speed during S4 differs from 60 mph by less than 1/10,000 mph. And so on. 
All statements about what obtains during a given “instant” are elliptical for statements about what obtains during non-null stretches of time. If O’s mass 
is constantly increasing, to say that, at instant t, O’s mass is M is to say that, given any non-null t-inclusive time-interval S1, if O’s mass deviates from M by a given amount, there is a shorter t-inclusive interval S2 such that O’s mass deviates from M by less than that amount. 
Measuring an object’s speed involves seeing how much distance it covers during some interval of time. There is no other way---or, more precisely, no other direct way—of determining a given object’s speed. Given some object O whose speed at time t one wishes to ascertain, one cannot directly ascertain O’s speed at t. (One can indirectly ascertain it, as we’ll see shortly.) What one can directly ascertain is O’s average speed during some t-inclusive interval. The smaller the interval, the better an approximation to O’s speed at 
t. But---and this cannot be stressed enough---it is only by considering O’s speed during (t-inclusive) stretches of time that one can determine O’s speed. 

2.3.2 Why predictability . determinism: Reason #3 (continued) 
That said, there may be reason to believe that O’s average speed during increasingly small t-inclusive intervals approximates without limit to 60 mph. (Put more precisely: there may be reasons to believe that, given any number x, no matter how small, there is some number y such that, if one considers a t-inclusive time-interval of length y, the difference between 60 mph and O’s velocity at t is less than x.) Supposing for argument’s sake that one establishes that the smaller the t-inclusive interval that one considers the closer to zero is the difference between O’s speed during that interval and 60 mph, then one has thereby established that O’s speed at t is 60 mph. Indeed, the italicized claim is the meaning of “O’s speed at t is 60 mph.” (See Section 2.5.1.) It’s not that, because of our scientific limitations, establishing the truth of the italicized claim is the best we can do in the way of establishing that O’s speed at t is 60 mph. It’s that, for reasons inherent in the concept of what an instant is the two claims are identical, the former being but an abbreviation for the latter. 
Since any direct (non-inferential) measurement of an object’s velocity will be of an object’s velocity during some stretch of time, any judgments one makes as to that object’s speed during some instant will involve, as we’ll now see, a heavy element of inference. Suppose that, during non-null, t-inclusive interval INT1. Bearing this supposition in mind, consider the following two 
statements: 
(i) O’s average velocity is 60 mph. 
(ii) if INT1, INT2….are t-inclusive intervals such that, for any n, INTn is bigger than INTn+1, O’s average velocity during INTn+1 is closer to 60 mph than it is during INTn. 
One is justified in accepting (i) if, and only if, one is justified in accepting (ii). 
But how could (ii) possibly be established? Not directly, obviously. Given any time-interval, one can measure O’s average velocity during that interval but once. Speed isn’t like length. One can measure an object’s length over and over again, since length is a property of enduring objects. But one can’t do this with speed, since speed is a property of non-recurring events. So if one judges that O’s speed at instant t is 60 mph, that is based partly on the fact that during the t-inclusive interval during which one measured O’s average speed, that (average) speed was close to 60mph. 
Assuming that judgment to be made on good grounds, there is another, rather troublesome dimension to it. For, in making that judgment, one assumes that: 
(DI)[302] 
had one done the equivalent of performing the doubly impossible task of considering an infinitely long series of t-inclusive intervals, each smaller than its predecessor, one would have found that the limit of the series to be 60 mph. 
Why, incidentally, would the task mentioned in DI be “doubly impossible”? Because: 
(a) since an event only occurs once, one can measure an object’s speed no more than once, 
and: 
(b) for a variety of reasons, it’s impossible to make infinitely many measurements. 

2.3.3 Why predictability . determinism: Reason #3---taking stock before closing the argument 
Before closing the argument, let us take stock. 
(i) 
one can directly ascertain average speeds, but one cannot directly ascertain instantaneous speeds. 

(ii) 
Fact (i) has nothing to do with our limitations as scientists; it has to do with the very meaning of statements of the form ‘such and such was the case at instant t.’ (Why this is so will be clarified and defended in the next section.) 


(iii) For any time t and any object O, one cannot really know what O’s speed at t is; one can, at most, make reasonable but highly theoretical, and therefore inherently tentative, inferences as to what O’s speed at t is. 
(iv) The inferences mentioned in (iii) themselves involve assumptions as to the instantaneous speeds of objects and, unless those assumptions are constituents of a theory for which there is considerable independent evidence, are viciously circular. 

2.3.4 Why predictability . determinism: Reason #3---Closing the argument 
It is inherently impossible to know with what speed an object is traveling at a given instant. (“But doesn’t the speedometer on my car indicate how fast my car is traveling at a given instant?” The speedometer on your car does (consistently, non-accidentally) tell you how fast your car is traveling at arbitrary instant t if various theories turn out to be right; e.g., theories correlating the car’s speed at a given instance with the rate at which the engine turns over. Each of those theories is based on many a belief to the effect that, for some object x, velocity, and instant t, x is moving at v at instant t. Those beliefs don’t register data; they embody judgments that are no less theory-dependent and no more secure than your judgment that O’s velocity at t would coincide with its average velocity during the t-inclusive interval that you considered. 
In conclusion, setting aside anything having to do with interference effects and also with human intellectual and technological fallibility, it is impossible, for reasons inherent in the concept of instantaneousness, to know the state of the universe at any given instant. This means that we cannot have maximally precise knowledge of the present. And, given that we know both the past and the future on the basis of inter alia the present, this in its turn means that we cannot have maximally precise knowledge of the past or the future. 
What we just said about an object’s velocity at a given instant is true of its mass, length, color, and all of its other explanatorily significant properties. We cannot have direct knowledge of an object’s mass at an instant; at most, we can make reasonable inferences as to its mass at a given instance on the basis of our knowledge of its average mass during some interval that includes that instant. To be sure, there is an important difference between speed, on the one hand, and mass and length (etc.), on the other. Speed is a property of non-repeatable events involving objects. Mass and length (etc.) are properties of objects per se. But this makes no difference in the present context. Given some general truths concerning the nature of measurement, which we’re about to state, along with the points already made, it will be clear why this is so. 
3.0 Determinism vs. randomness 
“Random” doesn’t mean the same thing as “undetermined.” A deterministic world isn’t necessarily one in which nothing random happens; and, give or take a few niceties, an indeterministic world isn’t necessarily one in which anything random does happen. A story will make it clear why these points hold. 
Smith arrogantly insulted a high-ranking member of a particularly lethal criminal organization, and that person has thus sworn to kill him. For unrelated reasons, Smith’s wife also wants him dead, and she has just hired a hit man to kill him. She has always wanted him dead; she just married him for his money. Plus, Smith has a serious heart condition, and his doctor is surprised that he didn’t die years ago. You are a friend of Smith’s, and you know all of this. But you don’t know anything else that is relevant to an estimate of how much longer he is likely to live. Given that information, the right estimate is, of course, “not long.” 
But Smith beats the odds. Nobody kills him and nothing goes wrong with his heart. But one day, as he’s making a sales pitch to some prospective clients, a ceiling-lamp comes loose and falls on his head, killing him. 
This was a “random” occurrence. But it wasn’t uncaused. When a ceiling lamp falls, there’s a reason for it (e.g., the bolt wasn’t screwed in tightly enough or the weight of the lamp was too much for the beam it was hanging from). It was “random” because, although caused, it wasn’t the sort of thing that, given the information at your disposal, could reasonably be expected to do him in. Thus, it was “random” not because it was uncaused, but because it was independently caused, meaning that the causal sequence that led to his death was independent of the causal sequences that were under way that were reasonably believed, given the information available to you, to eventuate in his demise. So, in this context, “random” doesn’t mean “uncaused,” it means “uncaused by anything that we had reason to believe would occur.” 
This is what “random” typically means. It may be that microphysicists deal with uncaused events. But the rest of us deal exclusively with things that are quite definitely caused. (As previously stated, the indeterminacies at the micro-level don’t percolate up to the macrolevel, at least not enough to engage the structures that change human lives.) So the “random” things we deal with are things that have unforeseeable causes. 
A consequence is that randomness isn’t a property of events; it’s a relation that an event bears to a body of knowledge. Relative to what you know, it is unforeseeable, and therefore random, that a ceiling lamp will kill Smith. But relative to what Howard the building inspector knows, that same event is not random. (Howard knows that the plank in question will go at any time, and he sees Smith standing underneath it.) 
Thus, randomness isn’t a property of events. It’s a property of statements —or, more accurately, of relations between statements. An event is random, relative to a certain body of information, if its occurrence couldn’t reasonably be predicted on the basis of that information. So randomness is really a relation that holds between the statements describing some body of data and the statement describing some event; that relation holds if the former statements don’t warrant acceptance of the latter. 
It’s obvious that there can be random events in a deterministic world. Smith’s death was an inevitable consequence of pre-existing circumstances. But, relative to the information that you had, it was also quite random. 

3.1 Determinism vs. randomness (continued) 
Supposing that the world is indeterministic, would there for that reason be “random” events in it? The answer is “yes.” But the reasons are not what one would think; and the amount of randomness in such a world is not necessarily as great as one would expect it to be. 
For argument’s sake, suppose we know that, given the current state of the universe, it’s causally completely undetermined whether, in five seconds, object O will move to the right or to the left. Each possible outcome is as likely as the other (they’re “equiprobable”).There’s no way, of course, to predict which way it will go. We could make that prediction only to the extent that we had reason to think one of the outcomes the more likely one— which we obviously don’t. But when, at the moment of truth, it goes to the left, was that “random”? We couldn’t predict it; but it isn’t exactly random. On the contrary, it’s consistent with our expectations of it. 
To see why, let’s modify our earlier story about Smith. This time, he isn’t killed by a ceiling lamp. The vindictive criminal kills him. Before Smith died, you knew that, in all likelihood, he would be killed either by that criminal or by his wife or by his heart-condition—but you didn’t know which, since, given what you knew, they were all equiprobable. When the criminal gets him, that surely isn’t random. Quite the opposite. Even though it could not itself be predicted with certainty to happen, it belonged to a class of events which, given the available evidence, was known to contain all and only the things that would kill him. 
The same is true of O. It is known that, in 5 seconds, O will either to go the left or to the right. So even though its going to the left as opposed to the right could not be predicted, its going to the left wasn't exactly random. So indeterminism doesn’t entail randomness. 
But here we must make a subtle distinction. Relative to the knowledge that it’s undetermined whether O goes to the left as opposed to the right (or vice versa), its going to the left is random. So O’s going to the left is both random (relative to one body of knowledge) and non-random (relative to another). 
4.0 Why determinism, if true, is capable of being verified 
On hearing me say that the world is at least approximately deterministic, students of mine often respond by saying either that determinism is unverifiable or that it’s simply false. Depending how it’s meant, this statement is either false or vacant. With some trivial exceptions, any universal statement (i.e., any statement of the form “all x’s are y’s”; e.g., “all birds have feathers”) is incapable of being definitively verified. (The trivial exceptions concern cases where the generalization concerns only some very circumscribed class of objects; e.g., “all pencils on my desk are yellow,” or where some statement that, in terms of its content, is not a universal generalization but is turned into one through syntax-chopping; e.g., “all objects are such that, if they are identical with George W. Bush, they are mammals.”) Since determinism is given by the statement “all events have complete causes,” it is unverifiable, like “all metal expands when heated.” On this basis, it is concluded that determinism couldn’t possibly be known to be true, and shouldn’t be affirmed, even tentatively. 
But is it so clear that “all metal expands when heated” is unverifiable? So far as that is true, it’s only in the trivial sense in which nothing other than analytic truths can be definitively verified. To be sure, “all metal expands when heated” couldn’t possibly be verified on strictly observation grounds. After all, that statement concerns all metal, not just the metal you see. So no universal generalization, with the irrelevant exceptions noted a moment ago, can be verified on purely observational grounds; some element of inference is involved. Anything that can be observed to occur is, for that very reason, not general. And that is why, despite its syntactic similarity to “all metal expands when heated,” “all pencils on my desk are yellow” is not substantively (as opposed to just syntactically) a universal generalization: one can observe that it is true. You can observe this or that metal bar expanding; but you can’t observe the “general fact,” if there even is such a thing, that heated metal always expands. 
Also, if by “verification” you mean “observation-based verification,” then “all metal expands when heated” and “every event has a cause” are incapable of verification, but only because “verification” has been so defined as to render that statement an empty truism. 
In any case, if one allows at least some inference-rules to be permissible sources of verification, then “all metal expands” is verifiable, depending on what those rules are. And if those rules are anything like those that laypersons and scientists permits themselves, then “all metal expands when heated” is verifiable. So it is only in some trivial sense that “all metal expands when heated” is unverifiable. 

4.1 Why determinism, if true, is capable of being verified (continued) 
Some say that “all metal expands when heated” is unverifiable in the sense that, no matter how many metal objects you’ve seen expand when heated, the next one “could” fail to expand. But what does “could” mean in this context? There is a sense in which I “could” win the lottery, or even sprout wings, even though the latter and probably also the former are prohibited by natural law. (In fact, the former is definitely prohibited by natural law since, given who I am, it isn’t psychologically possible for me to buy lottery tickets. I find the very concept of a lottery appalling.) To say that I “could” sprout wings is not to say that it’s permitted by natural law, let alone that it’s possible in some more robust sense. It is only to say that, given what I know, it isn’t ruled out. But I would contend that I do know that I won’t sprout wings and, therefore, that what I know does rule it out. And you too, outside of a philosophy class, would say that you know that you won’t sprout wings. 
David Hume famously argued that inductive inference isn’t rational. His argument is not easy to refute. (That said, we saw in Chapter 8 how to refute it.) But nobody accepts Hume’s conclusion; and while it’s one thing to say that we don’t know how to justify a belief, it’s quite another to say that it has no justification. Surely my belief that I won’t sprout wings in the next five minutes is not in the same category as a person’s belief that tomorrow it will start raining gumdrops. And it’s a veritable truism that the difference is that the former is justified, whereas the latter is not. 

4.2 An oft-heard argument as to why determinism, even if true, is incapable of being verified 
Here is an argument that several students, independently of one another, have presented to me, and that is also found in the work of C.S. Peirce (1839–1914): 
Let cell X be a “perfect” clone of cell Y, and suppose that X and Y are kept under exactly similar conditions. (So, although they are kept in different Petri dishes, they are subjected to precisely the same forces.) X and Y will behave differently from each other. Therefore, the same initial conditions fail to lead to the same non-initial conditions. According to determinism, this isn’t possible. (If two qualitatively identical circumstances are succeeded by qualitatively different circumstances, then neither circumstance completely determined what it would be succeeded by.) From this it follows that determinism is false. 
Given only that two cells are biologically exactly alike, it doesn’t follow that they’re exactly alike in all other respects. It doesn’t follow, in particular, that they are exactly alike at the atomic and sub-atomic levels. And the chances of their being thus alike are basically zero. There is no real chance that the micro-particles composing one organism will be moving in precisely the same way as the micro-particles composing any other organism. These sub-biological facts can and will have dramatic effects on what happens at the biological level. All this argument establishes, then, is the irrelevant point that different initial conditions may lead to different non-initial conditions. 

4.3 Another oft-heard argument as to why determinism, even if true, is incapable of being verified 
Many students of mine have put forth the following argument: 
Determinism says: “same initial conditions, same non-initial conditions.” But the conditions obtaining at any given time are different in at least some respects from those obtaining at any other time. For, between any two points in time, there has surely been at least one change; some particle has moved or rotated or vibrated.[303] 
So there is no way to verify determinism. 
Causal connections are discovered by seeing how differences in initial conditions correlate with differences in non-initial conditions. You allow initial conditions to change in one respect, but do your best to ensure that they’re unchanged in every other respect. This will guarantee that these other factors will at least tend to remain constant, even though, inevitably, they’ll never be perfectly replicated. If changes in that one factor reliably correlate with changes in the outcome, there’s probably a causal connection; and there’s probably no such connection if there’s no such correlation. 
You may not be able to establish a perfect correlation between your pushing the button and the elevator’s coming. But that doesn’t mean that you can’t have good reasons for positing the existence of a strictly deterministic connection between the first and the second. For there to be such a connection is not for the elevator to come without fail every time the button is pushed. It is for the likelihood that the elevator will come, given that the button was pushed, to approach 100% to the extent that other factors are held constant; that is, it is for there to be no limit to how close to 100% that likelihood can be made to be so by rooting out other factors that aren’t constant. 
Your experience can easily give you good evidence that this condition is satisfied. If you find that it’s always possible to make it more likely than before that the elevator will come, given that the button was pushed—if, in other words, you find that, given enough tinkering about with the relevant circuitry and cables and so on, it’s always possible to tighten this correlation —you ipso facto have evidence that the condition in question is satisfied and, therefore, that a strictly deterministic connection is at work. 
This doesn’t show they can be definitively established. But it does show that, insofar as they’re incapable of being definitively established, it’s only for the reason that nothing known through sense-perception can be definitively established. Your sense-perceptions make it probable that you have a television, but they don’t make it certain. They make it probable that you’re not a disembodied spirit, but they don’t make it certain. They don’t make anything about the external world certain. A fortiori they don’t make the existence of any causal connections certain. But such connections are no less capable of being definitively established than anything else about the external world. Whatever shortcomings induction may have as a form of inference, they’re no more of a problem for attempts to establish causal connections than they are for attempts to establish that you have hands. 
We can’t have perfect evidence of a perfect correlation.[304] 
But that doesn’t mean we can only have evidence for imperfect correlations. It’s possible to have imperfect evidence for perfect correlations. I’ve examined a million mammals, and they all had backbones. Here we have evidence of a perfect correlation. It’s imperfect evidence, but that’s the only kind that’s available. More precisely, it’s imperfect evidence if by “perfect evidence” we mean definitive observational evidence—as opposed to observational evidence plus reasonable inference-rules. But if this is what we mean by “perfect” evidence, then it’s a sterile triviality that we can’t have perfect evidence for the existence of transperceptual correlations. (By “transperceptual,” I mean “happening on the other side of the veil of perception—out there in the world, as opposed to in our minds.”) 
We have similarly “imperfect” evidence for deterministic laws. And such laws are no more incapable of being definitively established, and no less capable of being established with reasonable certainty, than biological concomitances of the kind just described. 
5.0 Some general, but often overlooked, principles concerning determinism 
A deterministic system may consist of parts that behave indeterministically. This is a consequence of a more general principle, to wit: the laws governing the parts don't necessarily govern the whole. (In Chapter 19, we'll see that attempts to reduce psychology to physiology involve a failure to grasp this principle.) 
A story may help make this clear. General Smith is in charge of Battalion 
A. The members of A are extremely disciplined, and none of them would dream of disobeying the command of a superior officer. Smith’s commands determine how A as a whole will behave. But those commands don’t micromanage every detail about every soldier’s behavior. They don’t determine the order in which Private Jones puts on his boots or exactly how the muscles in Private Brown’s mouth move when he’s eating. The forces that determinize (i.e., render deterministic) the behavior of A as a whole don’t determinize the behavior of A’s constituents. 
It may be that other forces determine the behavior of A’s constituents. But, even if this is true, we’re seeing some facts of profound importance. A system cannot just be deterministic; it must be deterministic in this or that respect. It makes no sense to say, without qualification, that a system is just deterministic---unless by that it is meant that it’s deterministic in every respect. 
Also, we’re seeing that the forces in terms of which the behavior of a system is to be understood don’t necessarily coincide with those in terms of which the behavior of its parts are to be understood. So supposing for argument’s sake that our thoughts are brain-states (or changes therein) and, consequently, that they consist of microparticles, it doesn’t follow that psychology is a branch of microphysics; it doesn’t follow, in other words, that the principles in terms of which a person’s thoughts and feelings (and so on) are to be understood coincide with those in terms of which the microparticles composing them are to be understood. 
In objection to this last point, it may well be said that: 
(MP)[305] 
You’re overlooking an important fact. The reason that Battalion A’s behavior is determined by what General Smith says is that each individual soldier in A knows that his career would be over if he were to disobey the command of a superior officer. Were it not for Private Brown’s knowledge that he’d be court-marshaled if he decided to flout a C.O.’s orders, Brown wouldn’t currently be hiking through a mosquito-infested jungle wearing a 70 pound pack. So, at the end of the day, it’s the micro-mechanisms that do all the work. 
True. It is the microstructures that do all the work. It’s always the microstructures that implement the “higher-level” forces. For this reason, people advocate MP; in other words, they conclude that these higher-level forces don’t really exist and also that everything that happens is to be explained and understood in terms of micro-(re)distributions of mass-energy. But they’re wrong. An extension of our story will make this clear 
Battalion A is but one of the many battalions that General Smith commands. Smith also commands Battalion B. A and B have the same structure: for each Captain in A, there is a Captain in B, and vice versa; and given any Captain in A, if that Captain is a fighter-pilot, so is his counterpart in B. A and B are perfect isomorphs of each other. 
But at the sub-structural level, A and B are very different. The members of A tend to be intellectual. Some of them are athletic, but their preferred sport is badminton. The members of B are anti-intellectual brutes; their favorite past-times are getting drunk and throwing sandbags at each other. But because of the way in which the members of each battalion are interrelated, these differences have no effect on how either Battalion acts as a whole. The principles in terms of which those Battalions behave, when taken as wholes, is to be understood in terms of principles that won’t be apparent, at least not for what they are, at the level of this or that particular soldier’s personality or conduct. 
But surely if you knew exactly what each soldier in A was doing, and you knew exactly what his counterpart in B was doing, you could, in theory, deduce how A and B were behaving. And, by obvious extensions of this reasoning, you could easily explain the fact that A and B are, as wholes, qualitatively identical in terms of lower-level forces; i.e., in terms of the forces that govern the parts of A and B (and, ultimately, the parts of the parts [of the parts of the parts…] of the parts of A and B). 
I agree. But these correct points leave out some truths that, given the context, shouldn’t have been left out. Given a knowledge of how (say) A behaves as a whole, one can post hoc see that A’s behavior was strictly determined by the behavior of its parts. (I’m supposing for argument’s sake that acquiring the relevant information about A’s parts won’t be a problem.) That micro-information would have been explanatory of A’s behavior as a whole only to the extent that given similarly structured entities, whose parts may be very unlike A’s parts, it also explains their behavior under circumstances similar to those in which A was operating. 
5.1. An illustration of this principle 
A story may clarify my meaning. There is some time t such that you know exactly what each member of A is thinking and doing at t and such that you know exactly what each member of B is thinking and doing at t. (How you know this isn’t part of the story, since it’s irrelevant to what we’re talking about.) On this basis, you figure out what each of A and B, taken as a whole, is doing. So, at t, A and B are behaving in exactly the same way---despite the fact that, at t, there isn’t a single soldier in either battalion who is acting just like his counterpart in the other battalion. Any battalion whose members are interrelated in the way in which, at t, A’s members were interrelated will, under qualitatively identical circumstances, behave exactly as A behaved (and, therefore, exactly as B did). So supposing that A has organizational properties P1…Pn, anything else that has those properties will react to any 
given situation in exactly the way that A would, even if that other thing’s parts are very different from A’s parts. 
So, when asked “why did A do such and such at t?” the right answer is not: “because Private Green was doing such and such, and Major Max was doing thus and such…” That answer would leave out the information about A’s structure that guaranteed that anything having that structure would have acted in the same way had it been in the same circumstances. That answer would have provided irrelevant information about the specific way in which that structure was implemented on this particular occasion. 
Micro-knowledge is knowledge of how the forces governing macro-structures are implemented. But it isn’t knowledge of those forces themselves. To be sure, everything that happens at the macro-level is fixed by what happens at the micro-level: it is impossible, even in principle, for there to be two worlds that are micro-identical but macro-distinct. But it doesn’t follow that the macro-world is not to be understood on its own terms; it doesn't follow, in other words, that the macro-world obeys laws that, although implemented by events governed by micro-laws, are altogether distinct from those laws. Thus, it doesn't follow that the truths provided by disciplines other than microphysics are merely low-grade microphysical truths. In Chapter 19, we'll find that the general principles about the structure of the world of which such a science apprises us are categorically incapable of being interpreted as (low-resolution) microphysical truths. At the same time, we will find that specific truths belonging to higher-level physical sciences (e.g., botany, astronomy) are capable of being interpreted as low-resolution microphysical truths. But, finally, we'll also find that psychological truths, whether general or specific, are categorically incapable of being interpreted as truths of microphysics or indeed of any science. At the same time, we'll see (in Chapter 22) that psychological truths are almost certainly identical with the (re)distributions of mass-energy that fall within the scope of microphysics. It will be made clear in Chapter 21 how all of these facts can be reconciled with one another. 

5.2 Ramsey's conception of physical law: an illustration of the vicious circularity inherent in hyper-empiricism 
A number of authors (e.g., Wittgenstein, Ayer, Ramsey, Davidson, 
Carnap) have said, in characterizing the world as “deterministic,” one isn’t 
directly saying anything about that world. Rather, what one is saying is along 
the lines of: 
(AR)[306] 
Let T1….Tn 
be a list of truths that jointly describe everything that happens throughout the course of time. Let T be this giant list of truths. There will be ways of organizing T that enable you to compress it. There will be general propositions---propositions having such forms as: 
(*) anything that has phi also has psi, 
and: 
(**) if there’s an occurrence in a given space-region of an event having phi, there will be an occurrence in a neighboring region of an occurrence having psi, 
and the like. 
Your objective, let us suppose, is to compress T as much as possible. In other words, you’re trying identify some truth T* such that: 
(i) 
T* is much shorter than T, the reason being that there many things that T explicitly says that T* does not say explicitly, 

but such that: 

(ii) 
T* contains all the information contained in T, the reason being that, for any truth that T but not T* states explicitly, T* states it implicitly----in other words, that truth can be deduced from the truths in T*. 


Some of the truths on T* will concern specific matters of fact---they will describe how, for at least one time t, mass-energy is distributed at t. (Given the points earlier made about instants, what this really means is that, for at least one time-period t, T will say how mass-energy is (re)distributed during t.) But it will provide as few truths as possible. The remaining members of T* be will general propositions that, given the remaining truths on T*, enable you to deduce all the truths that are not on T* but are on T. 
Let’s suppose that T* is the most compact list of its kind. In other words, it’s the shortest list of truths on the basis of which everything that is on T can be deduced. The general propositions on T* are what we call “the laws of nature.” 
Thus, the laws of nature are just abbreviatory devices. They spare us the trouble of having to know various individual facts; we need only know a few individual facts, along with a few general principles; and we can figure out anything else that we need to know as the occasion arises. 
There may be distinct, equally compact ways of compressing T; and given two such shortenings of T, they may not contain the same general propositions. That doesn’t mean that one of them is wrong. It shows that the laws of nature aren’t “out there,” in the world, and are rather “in here,” in our methods of describing the world.[307] 

Here’s a Mickey Mouse example of the principle at work here. Let L be a list that says of each individual person how many cars he or she has. Now imagine adding another list to L that gives that same information, but does so indirectly: instead of saying “Bob has five cars,” this second list says “Bob has 3 
+ 2” cars. Now imagine a third list that gives that same information but in some third way. This third list says “Bob has the square root of 25 cars.” And let’s suppose that we take 20 more lists such that: 
(a) 
no two of them are identical with each other or with any of the lists just mentioned, 

(b) each says how many cars any given person has, but 

(c) 
each does so by providing an expression that can be proven, on the basis of arithmetic, to refer to the relevant integer. 


Really, L provides no less information than this super-list. If you know that Bob has 2 cars, you don’t need to know that, for some number n, Bob has n cars and n5 = 32. But, given this super-list, in order to see that it gives you the same information as L, you need knowledge of arithmetic. So the laws of arithmetic serve an abbreviatory function. Laws of nature are to be understood in much the same way. They are to be seen as abbreviatory devices, not as forces or structures that regulate the course of events. 
5.2.1. The spuriousness of AR and the uselessness of the Ramsey-sentence 
References to the laws of nature, if only implicit ones, are an ineliminable part of any description of any event. This is because, contrary to what AR assumes, space and time aren’t vessels that happen not to be empty but could be. 
The concept occupancy—as in occupying a certain space---is a causal concept. Smith wants to sit in chair x. By virtue of that Jones is already sitting in x, what must happen in order for Smith to sit in x will be very different from what ceteris paribus would otherwise have to happen. Even if Smith just walks over to x and sits down in it, Jones’ body will serve as a buffer between him and x itself. It makes no sense to say that, while Jones is sitting in x, his presence there has consequences as regards what must ensue if, in the next two seconds, Smith is to be sitting in x. It makes no sense to say that, even though Jones is sitting in x, light is passing through the region he is occupying in exactly the way it would pass through that region were it unoccupied. And so on. 
Spatiotemporal relations are causal relations. (See Chapter 12 for a lengthy discussion of this.) It would make no sense to say that John’s flipping the switch caused the light to turn on, but that the very instance of that light’s turning preceded that very instance of John’s flipping that switch. If the latter caused the former, it ipso facto preceded it. According to Relativity Theory, if a light-beam, sent by event x at the time of its occurrence, reaches y, just as it’s beginning to occur, then relative to any possible frame of reference, x precedes y in time. If a light-beam sent by x doesn’t reach y, and a light-beam sent by y doesn’t reach x, then x and y are simultaneous with each other relative to some frames of references and, relative to others, x precedes y, and relative to others, y precedes x. But, according to Relativity Theory, the causal order doesn’t merely reflect the spatiotemporal order; it is the spatiotemporal order. 
A cause is a law at work. Setting aside exceedingly low-resolution descriptions of events, there is no description of an event that is nomically antiseptic. AR assumes that descriptions of the world can be neatly segregated into two groups, ones consisting of propositions that express laws, the other consisting of propositions none of which makes any assumptions as to what laws obtain, if any. But that’s not true. Once you set the facts, you ipso facto set the laws. The reason lies in the following two facts, taken jointly: 
(1) 
You can’t say whether (relative to a given framework) A preceded, followed, or was simultaneous with B until you establish either that the one event is part of a causal series beginning with the other, in which case the latter was the first to occur, or that there is no such series, in which case they’re simultaneous. 

(2) 
Wherever there’s causation, there’s law. If e1 caused e2, then there is some law L, and some properties phi and psi such that e1 has phi, such that e2 has psi, and such that L is given by a proposition to the effect that anything having phi (occurring 


in a given region) precedes something having psi (occurring in some region related, in some specified way, to the first region). 
To sum up: AR naively assumes that there are anomic facts. (“Nomic” means “having to do with natural law. ““Anomic” means “free from the influence of natural law and therefore capable of being understood independently of anything having to do with natural law.”) In fact, in describing something as “pinewood” or as “copper,” we’re assuming that certain laws hold with respect to it. If it doesn’t conduct electricity, is it copper? If it looks just like solid oak, but you can walk right through it, is it really solid oak? 
The terms that we use to pick out the objects that participate in the events and facts described by T are nomic terms. In describing something as copper, or water, or human, you are, in so doing, ascribing to it certain causal properties.[308] 
(You may not know what those causal properties are. There are certain properties P1…Pn such that, if I say that x is a puddle of mercury, 
the chemist to whom I am speaking will automatically know that, if my 
statement is correct, x has P1…Pn, so that, in effect, I was in some sense ascribing those properties to x. A derivative sense? Yes. An unimportant one? No.) Since AR assumes not just that some events can be understood in thoroughly anomic terms, but that all of them can be so understood, AR isn’t 
even remotely close to the truth. 
6.0 The concept of measurement in relation to the concept of an instant 
Like the expression, “the average person," the word “instant” refers to nothing, its function being to make it possible to abbreviate what would otherwise be long and cumbersome statements. There is no human being x such that the sentence: 
(AP)[309] 
“the average man owns 2.2 cars,” 
which says of x that he owns 2.2 cars. AP is an abbreviation of: 
(AP*) If x is the total number of cars that some person or other owns, and y is the total number of people, then x/y=2.2. 
Neither “the average person” nor any synonym thereof occurs in AP*. Indeed, there is no isolable part of AP* that corresponds to the occurrence in AP of “the average man.” That expression refers to nothing. But “the average man” is nonetheless meaningful. So, given that its meaning isn’t given by saying what it denotes, how is its meaning to be given? 

6.1 The word “instant” to be defined contextually, not denotatively 
Here a brief detour through the philosophy of language is in order. “The average man” is in the same grammatical category as expressions that do refer to specifics; e.g., “the current U.S. President” and “the Earth’s only moon.” For this reason, a sentence of the form “…the average man…” ipso facto appears to concern some individual; it appears, to be more precise, to say of some individual O that….O…(i.e., that O is a thing x such that…x…) Since that is not what is meant by any given sentence E of the form “…the average man…” and since any sentence E that states E*’s meaning in a non-elliptical manner has a grammatical structure that is to no degree comparable to E’s, it follows that E’s grammatical structure is at variance with its meaning. Thus, in virtue of having the form “…the average man…” a sentence’s grammatical form is out of line with its logical form. The meaning of “the average man” is given not by saying what it denotes, but by saying how, when given an arbitrary sentence E of the form “…the average person…” to identify a sentence E* such that: 
(i) E and E* say the same thing, and 
(ii) E*’s grammatical form doesn’t misrepresent its logical form in the way in which E’s grammatical form, by virtue of the fact that it contains an occurrence of “the average man” misrepresents its logical form.[310] 

Everything just said about “the average man” is true of the word “instant.” There are no instants. If E is an arbitrary sentence of the form “…instant…” E is but an abbreviation for some sentence E* that does not contain that word or any isolable part corresponding thereto. The meaning of the word “instant” is not given by a rule of the form: the word “instant” refers to entities having such and such properties. Rather, it is given by a rule to the effect, if E is a sentence of the form “such and such is the case at a given instant t,” E is an abbreviation for some sentence E* of the form[311]: 
(R1) “For any t-inclusive non-null interval S1, if the world’s condition during S1 deviates from such and such by amount M, 
there is some smaller t-inclusive interval S2 such that the world’s condition during S2 deviates from such and such by less than M.” 
“R1 is viciously circular and therefore fails,” it will be said, “as it defines ‘instant’ in terms of itself, given that a ‘t-inclusive’ interval is one that includes instant t.” In Sections 7.5-7.5.3, it will be made clear why R1 is not viciously circular. For now, let us operate on the (soon to be discharged) assumption that R1 is non-circular and otherwise acceptable. 

6.2 The relevance of these semantic points to the concept instantaneity 
One cannot directly determine how quickly the car is moving at instant t. What is it to determine how fast the car is moving during some interval? First of all, measurement is comparison. Given some object O, to measure O’s length is to determine how long it is relative to some object that is taken as a standard. (In a moment we’ll discuss the criteria that an object must satisfy to qualify as such a standard.) It is determined that, for some object O* such that O*’s length is by definition one unit long, and for some number n, O’s length is n multiplied by O*’s length. To determine O’s mass is to determine how O’s mass compares with that of some O* such that O* by definition has a mass of one; it is to determine, for some number n, that O’s mass is n multiplied by O*’s mass. 
All magnitudes are relative; some objects are longer than others; some objects are more massive than others.[312] 
In order for a given object O* to be such that it can appropriately be taken as a standard, it is necessary and sufficient that that there be no object O# such that, if O# is taken as a standard, there are fewer causal anomalies than there are if O* is taken as a standard. 
Let O* be some inflatable raft that we stipulate to be one unit long, no matter what changes it undergoes. A consequence of this stipulation is that inflating O* would have the consequence that, apart from O* itself, every object in the universe shrinks, even though: 
(i) many of those objects are on the receiving end of any causal process initiated by O*’s being inflated, 
and even though: 
(ii) given virtually any object that is on the receiving end of processes initiated by O*’s being inflated, it’s shrinking has nothing to do with that fact about it. 
Object-shrinkages of the first kind would be uncaused and, therefore, anomalous. Although they’d be consequences of O*’s being inflated, they would be logical, not causal, consequences of O*’s being inflated. So they’d be uncaused events. They’d be anomalies. 
Object-shrinkages of the second kind would also be uncaused. It is irrelevant that those objects were on the receiving end of causal processes initiated by O’s being inflated. The laws of physics being what they are, O*’s being inflated couldn’t possibly have caused those objects to shrink. 
Also, O*’s being inflated would have the consequence that distances between objects became smaller. This consequence, it goes without saying, would be quite as inexplicable as the two just mentioned. 
Of course, in order to validate our decision to take O* as having an unchanging length, we might posit physical laws that would explain why O*’s being inflated led to such consequences. But those physical laws would themselves be inconsistent with well-established laws (e.g., that radiation travels at a finite speed), and we couldn’t eliminate those well-established laws from our system of physics without ceasing to understand what we previously understood and without also ceasing to be capable of understanding both what we already understood and what we did not yet understand but were capable of understanding. 
To sum up, a consequence of taking O* as having an unchanging length would be that, to a large extent, the world would cease to be intelligible to us. Given any object that we intuitively regard as being highly alterable in some respect, an analogue of this argument shows, were that object stipulated to be unchanging in that respect, the results would be comparably devastating to our ability to understand the world. 

6.3 The relevance of these semantic points to the concept instantaneity (continued) 
Now suppose that one takes as one’s yard-stick, as it were, some titanium object that is kept in an environment in which, speaking intuitively, it doesn’t undergo any (relevant) changes---that it is kept in a temperature controlled room, that it isn’t subject to forces that would disfigure it, etc. Taking that object as having an unchanging length won’t lead to anomalies of the just-discussed kind and won’t strip the world of whatever causal and explanatory integrity it has. 

6.4 How measurements of speed are, in the relevant respects, comparable to measurements of mass 
Speed, like mass and volume, is to be understood in relative terms. Consider the statement: 
(1) During time-interval T, x’s average speed is such and such. 
The meaning of (1) is to be understood in terms of the concept of a periodic process. A periodic process is a repetitive sequence of events. More precisely, it is a series of events each of which is of the same kind as its neighbor(s) in that sequence (all of those members have two neighbors except for the terminal members). The series of rotations of the Earth around the Sun, during an interval long enough for more than one such rotation to occur, is a periodic process, and so, during such an interval, is the series of rotations of the Earth on its axis. A person’s heartbeat is a periodic process, and so is the series of round-trips made by a beam of light bouncing between two mirrors whose distance from each other remains constant. 
In some cases, direct comparisons of speed are possible. If x and y are engaged in a foot race, then if x makes it to the finishing line before y, x’s average speed during the interval when x was running exceeded y’s average speed during that same interval. (We are assuming that, for the duration of the race, x’s trajectory was the same as y’s and, therefore, that neither covered a significantly greater distance than the other.) 
6.4.1 How measurements of speed are, in the respects that are relevant here, comparable to measurements of mass (continued) 
But direct comparisons of speed are not always possible. Suppose that runners x and y both travel from points A to B, whose distance from each other is held fixed, but that they do so at different times. x’s trajectory, we will assume, is the same as y’s. 
Given those circumstances, how is it to be established who ran faster? One must first identify some periodic process; e.g., a light-beam bouncing between two mirrors held at a fixed distance from each other or ticks on a properly functioning clock. If fewer installments of that process occur during x’s journey from A to B, then x’s average speed during that journey exceeded y’s. 
Bearing this in mind, suppose that the periodic process in question is one that, speaking intuitively, we’d describe as highly variable. Suppose that Smith’s heart rate is this process and that Smith suffers from a heart-problem that involves his suffering from both extreme tachycardia and bradycardia. (Speaking intuitively----in other words, speaking as though it made sense to speak of absolute speeds---“tachycardia” and “bradycardia” may be defined, respectively, as “hyper-accelerated heart rate,” as when one is having a heart attack, and “hyper-decelerated heart-rate,” as when one is in a coma.) In that case, even if x is an Olympic sprinter who is performing at his best during his journey from A to B, and y is an arthritic who couldn’t even make it onto his school track team, Smith’s heart may beat more times during x’s journey than during y’s. 
Let us generalize this point. Suppose that we take Smith’s heart-rate as being unchanging—that, by our stipulation, it doesn’t change and that, serving as it does as a “standard” process, we determine the speeds at which objects are traveling in terms of it. In that case, we’ll end up with counterintuitive results, such as the one just described, and we’ll also end up with rampant anomalies, comparable to those described earlier in connection with mass and volume. Every time that Smith has a heart-attack, everything in the universe will slow down; and every time Smith falls asleep, everything will speed up. For reasons analogous to those described earlier, this will have two consequences: 
(i) There will be otherwise non-existent causal anomalies, 
and: 
(ii) There will be (otherwise non-existent) nomic anomalies (i.e., there will be laws of physics that are inconsistent with other, better corroborated laws of physics). 
To sum up, by stipulating to be non-erratic a periodic process that we intuitively regard as erratic, we strip the universe of much of its causal and explanatory integrity. 

6.4.2 How measurements of speed are, in the relevant respects, comparable to measurements of mass: closing the argument 
But now suppose that, given some period process that we do intuitively regard as non-erratic (e.g. the series of round-trips made by a light-beam between two mirrors whose distance from each other remains fixed), we stipulate that it is indeed non-erratic. This practice will have none of the just-mentioned consequences; it will not have the result that Olympic sprinter x is a slower runner than arthritic, non-sprinter y; it will not have the result that the rate at which a given object O is traveling will change depending on the vicissitudes undergone by some object O* to which O is not (relevantly) causally connected. By the same token, if we stipulate that a process of the just-discussed kind is erratic, the consequences will, by now familiar reasoning, resemble the consequences of stipulatively regarding as non-erratic some process that, intuitively speaking, is erratic. 
Thus, given two periodic processes P and P*, P is less erratic than P* iff ceteris paribus there are fewer causal and nomic anomalies if P is taken as a standard than if P* is taken as a standard. Thus, a given periodic process P is perfectly non-erratic if there is no periodic process P* such that ceteris paribus fewer anomalies would result if P* were taken as a standard than if P were taken as standard. 


6.5 Why RI is not viciously circular 
RI may initially appear circular. But it appears that way only so long as one holds onto the demonstrably false idea that position in time is non-relational. Consider the sentence: 
(S) “Event x occurs at 3:00 P.M. on April 21, 2010.” 
S says that x occurs simultaneously with some event y such that y is an installment in a certain kind of periodic process that is assumed to be unchanging, the reason being that not making this assumption leads to a proliferation of anomalies that would otherwise be easily explained. To say that JMK sneezed at a given time is to say that his sneezing was simultaneous with, let us say, the coincidence of some needle on some clock with some mark on that clock’s face or, more realistically, with the collision of some light-ray with some surface. 
“But,” some will say, “to say that two events are ‘simultaneous’ is to say that they occur at the same instant; so your analysis is still viciously circular.” 
Not true. To say that two events are simultaneous is to say that the laws of physics prohibit either event’s having an effect on, or a hand in, the genesis of the other. (For an explanation of this statement see Chapter 19, Section 8.0.) Thus, the statement “x and y occurred simultaneously”[313] 
means that x cannot have any effect on y or vice versa.[314] 
Given an arbitrary event e, let E be the smallest class containing all and only events e* such that e cannot affect e* or be affected by it. In that case, the statement “x is a member of E” is equivalent with “x occurred at the very same instant as e” or, alternatively, “there is some instant t such that x and e both happened at t.” Thus, an instant is the least inclusive class of events all of whose members are incapable of affecting or being affected by some given event; and an event’s happening at that instant is identical with its being a member of the aforementioned class. Given any class C such that, for some event e, C is the least inclusive class containing e and every event that e can neither affect nor be affected by, let us say that C is an I-class. 
Instants are I-classes. There is no way to pick out an I-class except by picking out one of its members. The reasons for this are of a strictly logical 
nature; they have nothing to do with anyone’s limitations.[315] 

7.5.1 Why RI is not viciously circular (continued): A penultimate preliminary point 
An interval of time is a class C of I-classes such that: 
(i) 
The (distal) cause of any event that is a member of the last member of C is a member of the first member of C. 

(ii) 
if x is any given member of C’s terminal I-class and y is any given one of the members of C’s initial class that is causally responsible for x, then, for each event z such that z was one of the events that was a link in the chain of events whereby y affected x, there is some I-class that belongs to C to which z belongs. 


Given any series of I-classes satisfying these requirements, let us refer to them as S-classes.[316] 


7.5.2 Why RI is not viciously circular (continued): final preliminary point 
There is one last point to make before closing the argument. We assign numbers to instants. The higher the number, the later the instant. So “t” is a variable, the constants corresponding to which are numbers. There must be some one relation R such that if e is a member of some I-class X, that I-class must be assigned a number that bears R to that assigned to any I-class to which one of e’s effects belongs. (We use the relation “lower than,” since it has the right properties and since, unlike some of the other relations that have the right properties, it’s psychologically easy to manage. So if e (somebody’s birth) happens before e* (that person’s beginning to sneeze on his second birthday), then e is assigned a lower number (say, 06:45, June 8,1970) than the one assigned to e* (09:45, June 8,1972). 
Each event is (in principle) assigned a number. But the number it is assigned is not based on the “position” in time that it occupies. There is no such position. It is, since it must be, based on its causal relations to other events.[317] 
e is given a higher number than e# if e is incapable of affecting e#; e is given the same number as e# if neither can affect the other. Given some event e, our conventions assign it a number on the basis of a procedure consistent with the guideline just described; and given one’s knowledge as to the identities of the numbers assigned by the same procedure to other events, one knows (within limits) what is (simultaneous with something that is) the effect of what. 

7.5.3 Why RI is not viciously circular: closing the argument 
Bearing all of this in mind, let’s revisit the question: what does it mean to say that a given time-interval is “t-inclusive”? t is an I-class. t is assigned a number. (Or, what comes to the same thing, each member of t is assigned a number, and that number is then assigned to t itself.) For argument’s sake, let 34 be that number. t is a member of an S-class, which we’ll call “X.” This means only that any given member of t is either the cause (not necessarily the immediate cause) or the effect (same qualification) of at least one member of at least one of X’s terminal I-classes. 
So to say that a given interval is t-inclusive is just a very encrypted way of saying that a certain event (it could be a bolt of lightning, a hiccup, or the ringing of an alarm clock) is a member of a class no two of whose members can affect each other but any given one of whose members is the cause or the effect one of the events marking either that interval’s inception or its cessation. It follows that occurrence of “t-inclusive” in RI is eliminable, being 
but an abbreviated way of making a causal claim of the kind just described. 
Chapter 14 Causality 
1.0 The basics 
Events cause other events to occur. Smith pulls the trigger, causing the gun to fire. Jones throws the vase against the wall, causing the vase to break. There are causes and there are effects. 
Astonishingly, some philosophers have denied the existence of causation. Why? Because many philosophers are empiricists, and given an empiricist outlook, it is hard to accommodate the presumption that events make events happen. According to empiricism, all knowledge is strictly observation based. Thus, if you know it, one of two conditions is met: (a) you observed it (in other words, you saw it, heard it, felt it, etc.); or (b) you inferred it from what you observed, provided that you used no inference rules other than those of whose legitimacy direct observation apprised you. (See Chapter 12.) According to many empiricists, we cannot see or otherwise observe causal ties. We see events, but not forces. We see rocks strike windows, and we see windows shatter upon being thus struck. But we don’t see anything that, given such a collision, compels the window in question to shatter. Since we don’t observe causal connections, we don’t have good reason to believe them to exist. 
But this argument involves a major non-sequitur. We don’t observe electrons or quarks, but we have good reason to believe them to exist. How are causal ties different? Given that it’s methodologically permissible to posit unobservable viruses and particles, why isn’t it equally permissible to posit unobservable causal ties? 
“Because,” we are told, “the concept of a causal tie, unlike that of a proton or a virus, is an incoherent one. For that reason, it wouldn’t do any good to posit causal ties. Causal ties, if they exist, are occupants of space-time, like rocks and vases and chairs; and they are therefore just as incapable as chairs and rocks of being the “glue” that, supposedly, keeps the universe from powdering into so many renegade events.” But notice that the second argument, unlike the first, isn’t an empirical argument at all. It’s a strictly logical one. It is to the effect that forces are in the same category as square circles and therefore couldn’t possibly exist and, therefore, couldn’t possibly be observed. Thus, the first empirical argument against the existence of causal ties is parasitic on a non-empirical, purely a priori argument, and is therefore only as good as the latter. (An a priori argument is one that has its basis, not in observational data, but entirely in considerations of coherence and logic.) 
Moreover, the latter argument isn’t a good one. The concept of persistence is itself a causal notion, and anything that persists is, for that very reason, a causal sequence. Thus, we observe causal sequences whenever we observe anything. And we knowingly observe them. In other words, we don’t merely observe what are in fact causal sequences; we observe such sequences to be causal sequences. This line of thought will be substantiated in Section 5.3. 
Much of this chapter will be spent evaluating the contention that we don’t see or otherwise observe causal ties. Although it has been enormously influential, it’s of doubtful accuracy, as we’ve just seen. And the more it’s scrutinized, the more incoherent it proves to be. For example, the very notion of spatial occupancy is a causal notion, since a given thing’s occupying a given region R ipso facto alters the trajectories and velocities of other would-be and soon-to-be occupants of that region. 
These points generalize. A “steel” object that lacked the requisite degree of malleability or thermal conductivity would ipso facto not be steel. Malleability and conductivity are causal properties. x is more malleable than y if, other things being equal, less force is needed to cause x’s shape to change than is needed to cause y’s shape to change. x has a higher degree of thermal conductivity than y if, other things being equal, less energy is needed to raise x’s temperature by a given amount than is needed to raise y’s temperature by that same amount. Thus, to describe a given object as being of made of steel is to say that, other things being equal, it will react to situations in ways in which it wouldn’t otherwise react. 
In describing something as “self-identical” or as “being such that 1 + 1 = 2,” one is not making a causally loaded claim. But those characterizations say nothing about anything. In being told that x is “self-identical,” one isn’t being told how x is different from, or similar to, water or steel or the planet Neptune or anything else. The same is true of all causally sterile characterizations. For that reason, anything that says anything about anything in the spatiotemporal world has causal content. 
2.0 Causation a relation between events, not objects 
But before we enter these stormy and controversial waters, let us make some non-controversial points about the logic of the concept of causality. 
First of all, it is only events that can be causes. Objects are not causes. The rock is not a cause. The rock didn’t cause the window to break. What did so was some event involving the rock (e.g., the rock’s striking the window at a certain time). 
Sometimes the way we speak suggests that, in our view, objects are causes. For example, people say “Carter was the cause of the recession in the late ‘70s,” “Hitler was the cause of World War II.” But these statements are elliptical for “such and such events involving Carter (Hitler) were responsible for the recession in the late ‘70s (World War II).” 
In connection with this, we must distinguish between something’s being a cause, on the one hand, and its having causal properties, on the other. Non-causes may have causal properties. The rock isn’t a cause, as we discussed, but it has causal properties. The rock’s having a certain mass is among its causal properties, meaning that its having that mass is, or can be, a (partial) cause. (Not every property of the rock is a cause. The rock is such that it either is or is not identical with the number 2. But the rock’s having that property doesn’t cause anything to occur.) 
2.1. Conditions vs. events 
We must also distinguish conditions from events. A condition is a relatively persistent state (e.g., the room’s having a certain temperature). An event is a change in conditions. But conditions themselves seem to be causes. For example, the water’s having a certain temperature is what caused the spaghetti in it to soften. At the same time, conditions appear not to be events. An event is, by definition, a change, whereas a condition is, it would seem, the absence of change. So if conditions are non-events and are also causes, then, contrary to what we earlier said, it isn’t events alone that are causes. 
This argument overlooks the fact that conditions consist of events. The water’s having a given temperature consists in its containing particles that have certain kinetic properties. There is no heat where there are no events. A person’s being healthy (i.e., being in a condition of health) consists in that person’s body doing what it should. There is no life, and therefore no health, where there are no metabolic events. And although events do necessarily constitute changes, those changes may be, and often are, internal to conditions of changelessness. For the water’s temperature to remain at 101° for 5 minutes is for the changes undergone by its constituent molecules to remain within certain limits; it is for their mean kinetic energy to stay within certain bounds. For the water’s temperature to change is for their behavior to exceed those limits. What we call “conditions” are patterns of constant change (i.e., of change that occurs in a uniform manner). 
What we call “events” are changes in the manner of change. When the water’s temperature increases, the way its constituent molecules move about changes. When the water’s temperature stays the same, they still move about —they still undergo change—but the way they do so doesn’t undergo change: those changes fall within certain limits. So conditions can be causes. But since conditions, far from being the absence of events, consist of them, this is in no way inconsistent with our contention that it is events, and events alone, that are causes. 
2.2 All causes ipso facto spatiotemporal 
There are causes only where there are changes, and changes happen in time. So universals, if they exist, are causally impotent. Many have concluded that, for this reason, they cannot be known and, therefore, that there is no legitimate reason to grant their existence. The idea is that there must be some kind of a causal connection between two things if one of them is to know of the other. For me to see the rock, it is necessary that light rays bouncing off of it affect certain sensory surfaces of mine. For me to know of Socrates’ existence, I must be on the receiving end of testimony, the vehicle for which is always some causal process (noises, light rays bouncing off of ink marks), that can be traced back to some state of affairs involving Socrates. One obvious way to generalize this line of reasoning is to say that there is never awareness where there isn’t a causal nexus. 
For reasons given in Chapter 12 of this book (and given in greater detail Chapters 8 and 9 of my (2009) book Analytic Philosophy and in Chapters 6-9 of my (2007) book Conceptual Atomism and the Computational Theory of Mind), this conception of conception is erroneous; under no circumstances does a causal connection between two things by itself mediate the one’s having an awareness of the other. There is always a non-causal component to awareness, even to sense perception, which, of all the many forms of awareness, is the one in which a causal connection between subject and object is most obvious. Further, for reasons given in Chapter 2, we do have good reasons to countenance the existence of universals, and no good reasons not to. 
3.0 Causes as INUS-conditions 
The things we describe as “causes” are really partial causes. Supposing it correct, the sentence “Smith’s drunkenness is what caused the accident” must really be elliptical for “Smith’s drunkenness is a part of what caused the accident.” Had he been driving a car with new tires on an open country road, instead of a car with bald tires on a busy city street, Smith might not have crashed even if he’d been drunker than he actually was. So it wasn’t Smith’s drunkenness or any other one thing that caused the crash, and was instead a confluence of circumstances. In some contexts—for example, those of a legal or ethical or psychological nature—the relevant partial cause might well be Smith’s drunkenness; and that seems to be what we mean when we say that it was the cause.[318] 

The complete cause of anything is very hard to identify. It is a matter of philosophical and scientific debate whether, given an event E happening at t, anything other than the entire state of the universe just prior to t can be the complete cause of E. So for all intents and purposes, the expression “the cause of occurrence E” never refers to a sufficient condition for E. 
“Even though Smith’s being drunk wasn’t sufficient for his crashing the car,” it will be thought, “it was necessary for it. Had he not been drunk, he wouldn’t have crashed.” This is false. Smith’s being drunk wasn’t necessary for his crashing. If he had been sober, but had been driving too fast on an icy road, he might well have crashed. 
J.L. Mackie (1917–1981) made it clear what is meant by “the cause of E,” as this expression is typically used. Smith’s being drunk wasn’t a necessary condition for his crashing.[319] 
He could have crashed if sober. But his being drunk was a necessary condition for his crashing under the circumstances. Given that he wasn’t driving a high-performance car on a country road during a clear day, and given that he was driving a low-performance car on a rainy night on a busy street, Smith’s being drunk was, we may suppose, a necessary condition for his crashing. For it could be that, had he been sober, Smith would have narrowly avoided crashing, despite the rain, darkness, and faulty steering mechanism, and that it was only these things plus Smith’s drunkenness that led to the crash. So, if it is to be correct, the statement “Smith’s drunkenness was the cause of the crash” must be taken to mean that, under the operative circumstances, Smith’s being drunk was necessary for his crashing. 
There are just a few more points to make. First, given that Smith did crash the car, it follows trivially that a sufficient condition for his doing so was fulfilled. Second, whatever that sufficient condition was, it wasn’t necessary. Suppose that what led to the crash was Smith’s driving a low-performance vehicle on a dark, rainy night, while drunk. Even though, by hypothesis, that confluence of circumstance was sufficient for his crashing, it wasn’t necessary. Smith might have crashed even if he’d been driving a high-performance vehicle in broad daylight while stone cold sober. 
Thus, Smith’s being drunk was an insufficient but non-redundant part of an unnecessary but sufficient condition for his crashing. Smith’s being drunk was thus an “INUS-condition” for his crashing. For this reason, Mackie says that if it is to express a true statement “E was the cause of event E*” must be taken to mean that E is an INUS-condition for E*. In a word, “the cause” of an event is an INUS-condition for that event. 
4.0 Aristotle on causality 
Aristotle (384–322 B.C.) distinguished between four different kinds of causality: efficient, final, material, and formal.[320] 

(AC)[321] 
x is the efficient cause of y if x makes y happen. 
x is the final cause of y if y is an action on the part of some creature and x is that creature’s objective in performing y. Final causes are goals or objectives. 
x is the material cause of y if x is the material that y is made of. 
x is the formal cause of y if x is y’s form. (To expedite discussion, we’ll henceforth omit the obvious qualifications relating to the fact that Aristotle didn’t use English words.) Sometimes Aristotle uses the word “form” to refer to shape. But sometimes he uses it to refer to what he elsewhere refers to as “essences.” Those properties that are essential to a given thing jointly constitute its essence; and a property is essential to a given thing if that thing could not lose that property without for that very reason ceasing to exist. The italicized phrase is intended to indicate that the dependence-relation in question is not of a causal nature, and is instead of a logical or constitutive nature. In other words, that relation is comparable to the dependence that triangles have on being three sided, not to the dependence that mammals have on air. 
Setting aside a few trivialities, pretty much nothing Aristotle has to say about causality has any merit. Aristotle incoherently believes that objects simpliciter---as opposed to objects’ having these or those properties---have essences. This belief, as we’ll soon see, is an incoherent one, and along with the more general coherence of which it is but one instance, it vitiates Aristotle’s views on causality. 
It is essential to a thing’s being triangle-shaped that it have three sides. But a given triangle-shaped object’s continued existence needn’t depend on its continuing to have three sides. Things change shape. It is essential to a thing’s being water that it consist of H2O molecules. But a given puddle’s 
continuing to exist needn’t depend on its consisting of such molecules. 
Things undergo chemical changes without ceasing to exist. 
Contrary to what Aristotle thought, dependence-relations don’t hold between objects. They hold between events or between statements, depending on whether they’re of a causal or a logical nature. To say that x’s having three sides is essential to x’s being a triangle is to say that “x is a triangle” entails that “x has three sides.” To say that x’s consisting of H2O molecules is 
essential to its being water is to say that “x consists of water” and “x doesn’t 
consist of H2O molecules” are incompatible statements. To say that treating children with kindness is essential to their becoming sane adults is to say that treating a child unkindly prevents him from becoming a sane adult. 
So-called formal causes don’t hold between events (or states of affairs) or statements; they hold between things. Thus, the concept of a formal cause is an incoherent one. So, for the same reason, is the concept of a material cause. 
The concept of efficient causality clearly is a coherent one. There is such a thing as efficient causality. We’ll see in the next section that it isn’t the only bona fideform of causality. But it’s the most fundamental one. 
What about (so-called) final causes? If, as Aristotle seems to think, final causes are goals per se, he’s wrong to describe them as causes. Goals per se do nothing. Goals are abstract objects and therefore do no causal work. What does do causal work is a given person’s having a given goal. My having the goal that: 
(*) I, JMK, get in shape; 
obviously does causal work; it causes me to jog around the block for hours on end. But (*) per se does nothing. Like all other goals, (*) is a proposition. My having that goal is my intending to make that proposition come true. But my having a goal is a garden-variety efficient cause. In general, goals per se, being propositions, aren’t causes at all. A given person’s (or creature’s) having a given goal is a cause. But it’s a garden-variety efficient cause. So in saying there are such things as “final” causes, Aristotle is either making the trivial point that a person’s having a goal can have effects or he is making the deeply confused point that goals per se can have effects. 
4.1 The importance of the expression “in virtue of” in causal discourse 
The expression “in virtue of” has an important place in philosophical discourse. (I will use “in virtue of” and “by virtue of” interchangeably.) Without this expression, or some equivalent, it would be very hard to say anything meaningful about causal explanation—or about non-causal explanation, for that matter. The meaning of this term is to be understood in terms of two parallel points, namely: 
(i) It is states of affairs (or events), not objects, that have effects; 
and: 
(ii) it is propositions, not objects, that stand in dependence-relations. 
For reasons that will become apparent, (i) and (ii) can be condensed into: 
(iii) dependence-relations hold between propositions, as opposed to objects. 
A story will help us explain what (i)–(iii) mean and why they’re true. Despite being intellectually mediocre, Smith never loses an argument. He wins arguments, not by addressing points with counterpoints, but by bullying his opponent into submission. In this way, Smith recently won an argument with Jones, who is Smith’s superior intellectually. Thus: 
(A) even though Smith won his argument with Jones, he did so not by virtue of making good points, but by virtue of bullying Jones.
