The degree to which a hypothesis is to be preferred to its negation is directly proportional to the degree to which it does a better job than the other of minimizing the net amount of causal anomalousness in the world. 
Probability is not a statistical notion. The word “probability” has a statistical meaning. This is the meaning that it has in the statement: “the chances of a person who’s picked at random having red hair are one in eight.” All this means is that one person in eight has red hair. 
But this isn’t the sort of probability that is relevant to explanations. When you say (“SNS” is short for “Smith no show”): 
(SNS) “Given that Smith hasn’t shown up yet, he’s probably not going to show up at all,” 
you are not making a statistical statement; you are not saying that in more than 50% of situations like the present one Smith doesn’t show up. SNS could be true even if Smith has never failed to show up to anything in his life. And it could be false even if, in the past, he’s failed to show up to 90% of his appointments. 
Statements affirming the probability of hypotheses seldom even appear capable of statistical interpretations. You can know that x is likely to do y in circumstances z without ever having seen x, or anything much like it, do y, or anything much like, in circumstances z, or anything much like them. For example, we have a pretty good idea of what at least some of the consequences of detonating a hydrogen bomb over the South Pole would be, even though nothing much like that has ever occurred. 
“But that’s where you’re wrong,” contemporary Humeans say. “You see, it’s only if it’s interpreted in an absurdly narrow way that that the statistical conception of explanation has any of these problems.” And they defend this position by saying that (“SE” stands for “statistical explanation”): 
(SE) If a hydrogen bomb were detonated over the South Pole, it would by no means be unprecedented. True, we haven’t detonated hydrogen bombs over the South Pole. In fact, we haven’t detonated hydrogen bombs anywhere. But we’ve detonated weapons similar to hydrogen bombs over places similar to the South Pole. Given this information, we have a pretty good idea of what the consequences would be of detonating a hydrogen bomb over the South Pole. 
And while you’re right that SNS may be correct even if Smith has never missed an appointment in his life, you’re wrong to conclude that explanation is not to be understood in statistical terms. If one is to be justified in accepting SNS, one doesn’t need to know that Smith ever failed to show up to anything; and one doesn’t need to know that what the relevant individuals, whoever they might be, failed to do was to show up. One need only know that people similar (in some respect relevant in the present context) to Smith failed to do something similar (same qualification) to showing up. One need only know that people like Smith (e.g., people who have serious drug problems) failed in some way that would be comparable to Smith’s failing to show up (e.g., those people did not keep their promises). 
It’s easy to ridicule the statistical conception of explanation by showing that events exactly like the one being explained haven’t occurred. But the situation being explained needn’t be a perfect replication of any past situation. It need only be like past situations in some very abstract respect. 
The problem with this response is that there is no way to understand the 
concept of “relevant similarity” in statistical terms; and in deciding what is 
relevantly similar to what, the advocate of SE is drawing on hypotheses that 
can’t possibly have received any confirmation of a purely statistical kind. Any two things are similar in some respects and dissimilar in others. Some 
of these similarities are explanatorily significant, and others are not. It often 
happens that, despite our not having first conducted context-specific research, 
we can distinguish the relevant from the irrelevant forms of similarity. For example, it’s obvious that, when trying to figure out what the consequences would be of detonating a given bomb over the South Pole, it doesn’t matter whether that bomb is green as opposed to red, but it does matter whether it’s a nuclear as opposed to a non-nuclear bomb. So it’s obvious that, in the relevant respects, a red hydrogen bomb would be much more similar to a green hydrogen bomb than it would be to a red non-nuclear bomb. 
But this wouldn’t be obvious at all if our evidence for it were strictly statistical. Given that, for any two things, one can contrive some respect in which they are similar, it follows that, with a few trivial qualifications, anything can confirm anything to any degree. 
This is what Nelson Goodman’s argument shows. (See Section 7.3). Find a respect in which green emeralds are similar to blue emeralds, and the fact that, thus far, all emeralds have been green confirms that, after this point, they’ll all be blue. (All green emeralds examined before the present are similar to blue emeralds examined in the future in that they’re all “grue.”) 
Another example: Find a respect in which herbivorous brontosauruses resemble cars that aren’t affected in any adverse way by high-speed collisions, and the fact that all brontosauruses were herbivorous confirms that a speed collision won’t damage your car. (Herbivorous brontosauruses are similar to cases of your crashing your new, as of yet unscathed, car in that they are both “carbivorous.” Something is “carbivorous” if it’s either an herbivorous brontosaurus or a car driven by you after the present time that’s involved in a high-speed collision and isn’t damaged by it.”) 
We know that terms like “grue” and “carbivore” pick out explanatorily hollow properties, and that’s why we don’t base our driving habits on our beliefs about the dietary habits of dinosaurs. We know what to infer and what not to infer only insofar as we know what kinds of similarity count. A precondition for making the right inferences is knowing what the relevant kinds of similarity are. 
Thus, there’s no way that judgments as to what the relevant forms of similarity are could have a strictly statistical basis. (That said, they obviously can and do have a partly statistical basis. But that’s not enough to make a go of the statistical model.) The concept of probability is to be understood in terms of the concept of explanatory integrity, not that of statistical frequency. The concept of explanatory integrity is to be understood in terms of the concept of causal integrity. The concept of causal integrity is to be understood in terms of the concept of continuity of change. One very important kind of change is change of position (motion). But not all change is change of position. Changes in temperature aren’t changes in position. Nor are changes in color, shape, or structure. That said, at least some of these forms of change are to be understood in terms of the concept of change of position. But the same can’t be said of other explanatorily important kinds of change. It can’t be said of higher-order changes (changes in the manner of change), since higher-order changes aren’t spatiotemporal changes at all. (A second-order change is a change in a spatiotemporal change; it is not itself a spatiotemporal change, and the same is obviously true of all other higher-order changes.) Earlier we considered some clearly erroneous hypotheses that seemed at first to do just as good a job of preserving continuities as some clearly worthy hypotheses. Had these initial impressions been correct, our analysis of explanation would have been in trouble. But they weren’t correct. When we took a second look, we found that the clearly wrong hypotheses did a much worse job than their meritorious counterparts of dealing with higher-order continuities. And the continuities in question were ones that we already knew to be explanatorily important; they weren’t contrived ad hoc to buttress our theory. 
6.0 A crucial fact about scientific explanation: Reality-description methodologically subordinate to data-modeling. 
There is more to explaining an event than showing it to be continuous with events in its vicinity. Let M1 and Mn be two mental events. M1, we’ll 
suppose, is Smith’s suddenly realizing that he’s not a good composer and Mn, we will suppose, is Smith’s realizing that his compositional efforts over the last 20 years have been in vain. There are, as we know, good reasons to believe that M1 and Mn are identical with brain events---let B1 and Bn be 
those events. But we’ll see that, in order to explain Mn in terms of M1, it is neither necessary nor sufficient that we show, for each i (1 = i = n), that Bi is continuous with the brain-events in its spatiotemporal vicinity. Scientific 
disciplines (e.g., psychology, physics) are individuated, as we’ll see, not (merely) by what they study, but by the data in terms of which the objects of their study are given to them. Those data are expressed by propositions. 
The same is true of events: they too are known to us through propositions. 
[377] 
Propositions consist of concepts. Disciplines model data. It isn’t the event per se that is explained; it is some proposition describing its occurrence. Any given event---in other words, any (re)distribution of mass­energy---can be correctly described in many ways. There are many true propositions describing it. 
A consequence of these points is that, for any given (re)distribution of mass-energy, there are many possible objects of explanation. Given some event E, let T be some proposition describing E’s occurrence that we wish to explain. Remember that it is T, not E per se, that we are trying to explain. It would be meaningless to say “I’m explaining event E---but there is no truth that I am explaining.” It is (alleged) truths that are explained. Facts and events are explained only in the indirect sense that true propositions about them are explained. 
Moving on: Unless the continuities that we posit in the hopes of explaining T are expressed by propositions consisting of concepts belonging to the same family of concepts to which those constituting T belong we haven’t established continuity within our models of events. And since it is only through these models that we know what the transphenomenal facts are, and thus what the transphenomenal continuities are, we haven’t, under the circumstances described, succeeded in establishing any sort of continuity that is of any use in discovering the facts that lie on the other side of the data. 
So the essence of explanation lies not merely in the discovery of continuities, but in the discovery of propositions that, because of the structures of the concepts out of which they are constructed, establish what we might refer to as “model-internal” (or “data-internal”) continuities. We will clarify, illustrate, and demonstrate the truth of these points in the upcoming chapter. Moreover, we will do this in connection with our discussion of why it is that recent attempts to “scientize” the discipline of psychology are broken and ab initio doomed to failure. 
Chapter 21 Psychological Explanation and Interdisciplinary Reduction 
1.0 Some introductory remarks 
"The brain is an organ just like another." This is a popular saying among contemporary psychologists, especially among those who claim to be doing psychology in a "scientific" manner. So far as this slogan means anything, it means that psychology should be studied physiologically, not psychologically. 
In addition to being tautologically false, this position embodies a failure to grasp certain basic truths about knowledge and scientific methodology. It will be the purpose of this chapter to state those truths and to draw attention to some of their more obvious consequences. One of those consequences is that the mind must be understood on its own terms. So long as psychologists treat psychological truths as low-resolution physiological truths, and so long as they don't treat the class of psychological truths as sui generis, psychology will be a broken and incoherent discipline. 
Before we can substantiate these claims, we must make some general points concerning the nature of scientific inquiry. 
2.0 What it is to be a datum 
In this context, any references to intentions are to intentions that don’t embody any incoherent beliefs. 
Even though, when framing a hypothesis, one’s ultimate objective is to identify the realities with which that hypothesis is concerned, that cannot possibly be one’s immediate objective. For it could be one’s immediate objective to describe those realities only if one knew what they were and therefore didn’t need the help of hypotheses to acquire this knowledge. Thus, one’s immediate objective must be to model the data, not to describe data-transcendent realities. 
A related point is that it is truths that are explained. Not objects. Not events. Rocks aren't explained. Neither are migraines. “But surely explain events," it will be said. "A few years ago, my husband had a seizure. We went to a physician, looking for an explanation, and we got one." If the truth that your husband had a seizure had the same spatiotemporal boundaries as the seizure itself, it would have ceased to exist the moment the seizure ended, and it wouldn't have existed outside the place where the seizure occurred. Thus, the physician you later saw would have been explaining a non-existent truth. In other words, there would have been no truth that he was explaining. But there was such a truth, and there still is. That said, is no place that it is occupying. It isn't propping up a tent or heating up water otherwise behaving like things that occupy places. There isn't some place such that, by virtue of being in it or right next to it, one is better able to see or touch or hear or otherwise be affected by that truth. So it makes no sense to say that it has a location. So that proposition, just like its negation, is a non-spatiotemporal entity. But that event did have a location. So what the physician explained was a truth, not an event, and the same is true of everything that can possibly be explained. We'll see that this seemingly technical point must figure prominently in any decent explanation of explanation. 
2.0.1 What it is to be a datum (continued) 
Data are not raw facts. Data are propositions. Propositions are not raw facts. 
When trying to say what distinguishes a given discipline from every other discipline, the relevant question is not "which things and which events does that discipline study?" but rather "which propositions does that discipline assume to be true and which propositions is it trying to model?" 
Of course, there are some very generic propositions that all disciplines take for granted (e.g., if a thing is, in its entirety, in a given place at a given time, it cannot, in its entirety, simultaneously be in some other place that is a million miles away”). But given any discipline, there will be some class of propositions that it alone assumes to be true; and the subject matter of that discipline is identified when this class's membership is identified. 
There is a plausible objection to this position: 
(PO)[378] 
But astronomy studies stars; geology studies landmasses; zoology studies animals. Surely, contrary to what you say, disciplines are individuated by what they study. Disciplines are therefore not individuated by which propositions they assume to be true. They are individuated, I repeat, by which objects and events they study. 
Much of this is correct. For example, the facts studied by astronomy clearly don't even overlap with the facts studied by zoology. 
But we mustn't let these truths lead us astray. Astronomical facts are microphysical facts. Any movement of a star is nothing but a giant constellation of microphysical facts. Two universes that are indistinguishable at the microphysical level are necessarily indistinguishable at the astronomical level. Two such universes, indeed, are indistinguishable tout court. But astronomy is not a department of microphysics. In fact, those disciplines are disjoint, or nearly so. 
Similarly, even though all zoological facts are microphysical facts, zoology is disjoint from microphysics, or nearly so. Also, all of the facts studied by zoology are microphysical facts, and so are all of the facts studied by astronomy. 
To be sure, there is no specific fact that falls within the scope of both disciplines. But that's irrelevant. At the microphysical level, a dog is not so different from a comet. The general principles instantiated by the one class of microphysical facts overlaps heavily, if it doesn't coincide with, those instantiated by the other class. But that does nothing in the way of causing zoology to merge with astronomy. The fact that the class of things studied by astronomy is disjoint from the class of things studied by zoology is, we must conclude, a consequence of the fact that there are no raw facts described by data belong to both disciplines or by theoretical extensions thereof. 
Thus, disciplines are individuated primarily, and sometimes solely, by the bodies of data that they are trying to model. Disciplines are individuated only secondarily, and sometimes not at all, by the facts that they describe. 
PO embodies a failure to take into account that it is truths, not raw facts, that are explained. The raw facts in virtue of which astronomical facts hold are of the same ilk as those in virtue of which zoology holds. So, were it raw facts (and raw events), that were the foci of scientific explanation, astronomy would be zoology. But astronomy isn’t zoology. 
“But,” it will be said, “when explaining star-constitutive events, one must sometimes apply microphysical principles in ways in which one needn’t apply them when explaining animal-constitutive events.” True, but irrelevant. The way in which one must apply architectural principles to build a 33-story building doesn’t precisely coincide with the way in which one must apply those same principles to build a 29-story building. But it would be absurd to say on that account that, if X designs a 29-strory building, he is not an “architect” in the same sense as someone who builds a 33-story building. 
“But," it will also be said, “the classes of specific raw facts studied by those disciplines are disjoint.” True, but irrelevant. Given two medical researchers X and Y, it’s unlikely that they study precisely the very same tissue samples. But it would be absurd to say on that account that X and Y are practitioners of different disciplines. It could very well be that X and Y are studying the very same problem, in the very same way. 
2.1 What it is to be a datum: conclusion 
Given only that somebody studies what is in fact a plant, it doesn’t follow that he’s a botanist. If his interest in those plants extends only as far as their ability to furnish him with information as to the structure of a certain kind of particle, then they are just heaps of particles to him, and it is as a physicist, not a botanist, that he is interested in them. Similarly, given only that somebody studies heaps of molecules, it doesn't follow that he’s a microphysicist; for if his interest in those heaps extends only as far as their ability to furnish him with distinctly botanical knowledge, he is a botanist, not a microphysicist. 
By parity of reasoning, given only that somebody studies what are in fact neurological events, it doesn't follow that he's a neurologist. And given only that somebody studies what are in fact mental events, it doesn't follow that he's a psychologist. What determines whether somebody is a psychologist as opposed to a neurologist is a function of which truths he's trying to explain, not which raw facts those truths describe. 
3.0 Psychological explanation vs. non-psychological explanation 
We thus have the following facts to work with: 
(i) 
Science tries to eliminate anomalies. (Anomalies are not irregularities. Anomalies are discontinuities. It is in terms of concept of continuity that the concept of an explanatorily significant regularity is to be understood. See Chapter 17.) 

(ii) 
Science doesn’t directly deal with the realities it aspires to describe. (If it did, it wouldn’t have to aspire to describe them.) Science deals directly with data. 


(iii) What distinguishes discipline A from discipline B is that the class of propositions whose truth A assumes doesn’t coincide with the class of propositions whose truth B assumes. 
Bearing these three facts in mind, consider the following situation. Barry is a botanist. Barry leaves plant X in a place where, for hours on end, it is exposed to blistering sunlight. Unbeknownst to Barry, X belongs to a species whose members can live only in cool, shady places. After a few hours, X dies. 
It's clear to Barry's supervisor that the cause of X's death was over­exposure to sunlight. But the supervisor knows Barry to be a brilliant scientist and he is more interested in learning from Barry than in reprimanding him. The supervisor thus asks Barry to produce a maximally thorough botanical explanation of X's death. 
Assume (per impossibile) that Barry has complete knowledge of the microphysical activity constitutive of X’s being placed in the sun, remaining in the sun, and then eventually dying, and also that everything Barry says is correct. 
Barry gives a thorough and precise description of each and every last micro-event involved in the series of particle-flurries mediating between, and including, X's being placed in the sun and X's dying. He uses no botanical or biological terms. The only non-generic terms that he uses belong to microphysics and mathematics. 
Did Barry explain X's death? No. We must remember that it is truths that are explained, not (re)distributions of mass-energy. Things aren't explained. Rocks cannot be explained. Propositions about rocks are explained. Events aren't explained. Truths that hold in virtue of events are explained. 
Barry did an excellent job of describing the (re)distributions of mass-energy mediating between X's being put in the sun and X's dying. True---the first particle-flurry happened to be identical with a certain, still-living plant; and the last particle flurry happened to be identical with a genidentical, recently-deceased plant.[379] 
So Barry successfully explained a microphysical truth that happened to hold in virtue of the same raw fact as the botanical truth that he was asked to explain. But he did not explain that botanical truth itself. So he failed to explain what he was asked to explain. 
3.1 An objection 
Some will feel that, by virtue of giving a maximally precise and thorough account of the microphysical activity involved in X's death, Barry has given a maximally good explanation of X's death. Such thinking is off the mark. 
The botanical changes that mediated between X’s once healthy state and its eventual demise can be realized by infinitely many different microphysical changes. So Barry's excursion into microphysics may have explained why this plant died. But it did nothing in the way of explaining the deaths of plants whose situations were botanically indistinguishable from X’s. Had Barry given a cogent botanical explanation of X's death, he would ipso facto have explained why events botanically similar to X's being moved lead to events botanically similar to X's dying. And by failing to give a cogent botanical explanation of X’s death, Barry failed to say anything about why plants botanically similar to X, when placed in botanically similar situations, end up dying. Therefore, Barry failed to provide a botanical explanation of the death of even this one plant. 
3.2 Why concomitances are not enough for explanation 
If there turned out to be a way to characterize botanical concepts in microphysical terms, then Barry's answer might constitute a bona fidebotanical explanation of X’s death. 
But there is no such way; nor could there be. The relevant distributions of micro-particles couldn’t be described without using botanical terms. A given type of botanical event can be realized by infinitely many different events, no two of which have anything in common at the microphysical level. Let K be the least comprehensive class containing every instance (past, present, future, and possible) of some pine-tree's dying. 
Obviously K's membership is infinitely large. But that isn't important. What is important is that, from a microphysical perspective, K's membership is infinitely diverse. In other words, there is no one microphysical property (or finitely large set of microphysical properties) had by everything in K and by nothing not in K. 
But let's set aside talk of the merely possible; let's focus on the class of all actual pine-tree deaths. Let K* be that class. The likelihood that there is some microphysical property had in common by all and only K*'s members is small (but not zero). Obviously pine trees have similar cellular structures. But cells don't fall within the scope of microphysics. One reason for this is that, although cells are small in absolute terms, they are enormous relative to electrons, quarks, etc. Another far more important reason is that the concept of a cell no more helps the (micro)physicist discover principles relevant to his field than does the concept of a theocratic dictatorship.) But even if this slim possibility materialized, Barry still would have failed to explain X's death. Some science fiction will make it clear why this is so. 
Imagine a world in which round objects were green and square ones were red and in which we knew that colors and shapes were thus coordinated. In such a world, our knowledge of the truth that x is a green wheel could be very useful, as could our knowledge of the truth that y is a red wheel: we’d know that, other things being equal, x would be a much better wheel than y. And, supposing that we lived in a world in which the microphysical truths “tracked” botanical truths in a way similar to the way in which, in the world just described, chromatic truths “tracked” geometrical truths, our knowledge of that fact could potentially be very useful. 
Knowledge of concomitances. But it mustn't be thought that knowledge of concomitances is anything more than a surrogate for genuine understanding. The next section will develop what we've already said in defense of this claim. 
4.0 The concept of psycho-physical reduction 
In this context, when talking about the “physical condition" of some object X, I mean what would be given by a description of the constellation of micro-particles composing X that was put forth by an infallible physicist who was acting in his capacity as a physicist. 
A plant’s botanical condition supervenes on its physical condition. In other words, given two plants that are physically indistinguishable, it is impossible, as a matter of logic, that they should be botanically distinguishable. Since any given plant is composed of nothing but micro-particles, everything that happens to a plant coincides with a change in the inter-relations, if not the individual compositions, of those micro-particles. So where there are no micro-physical changes, there are no botanical changes; and where there are identical micro-physical changes, there are identical botanical changes. 
It has been assumed that, because the botanical supervenes on the microphysical, it must be possible to "reduce" botany to microphysics---that is, to show that what botany has to say about the world could, at least in theory, be said (and said more thoroughly and precisely) by microphysics. 
We're now going to find that: 
(i) Botany couldn't possibly be reduced to microphysics. 
(ii) Psychology couldn't possibly be reduced to microphysics (or any other physical science). 
And 
(iii) The reasons why psychology cannot be reduced to microphysics (or any other physical science) are distinctive. The sense in which psychology cannot be reduced to (micro)physics is more robust than the sense in which botany (or any other physical science) cannot be reduced to microphysics (or any other physical science). 
Let's start by considering the classical answer to the question: "what is it to 
reduce one discipline to another?” or, to put the question more precisely, “what are the conditions the fulfillment of which is both necessary and sufficient for the reduction of one discipline to another”? Here is that answer[380]: 
(CA) Let’s say you’re trying to reduce botany to microphysics. There are many bridges you must cross. Let b be an arbitrary botanical concept. So b, let us suppose, is the concept pine-tree. (A consequence of this supposition, of course, is that x is an instance of b is (to the same effect as) the proposition x is a pine-tree.) You must, at the very least, identify certain microphysical concepts m1….mn such that any 
instance of the concept pine-tree is an instance of m1….mn. In other words, you must, to use Hempel’s (1965) expression, produce an accurate “microphysical characterization” of the concept pine-tree. Needless to say, given any botanical concept, you must do the same thing mutatis mutandis in connection with that concept that we just did (or, rather, described doing) in connection with the concept pine-tree. But that is not all you must do. Let p be any law of botany. (If, for whatever reason, you deny that there are laws of botany, replace the word "law" with the word "principle" in what follows.) p is presumably to the effect that, if a botanical truth of a certain kind is true, then so (probably) is a botanical truth of a certain other kind. To reduce botany to microphysics, you must show that, whatever it is about the universe in virtue of which that general botanical truth holds there is a micro-physical characterization of it. 
Let us clarify this last point. Let B be an arbitrary botanical law. B demands that, if botanical concept b1 is instantiated in space-time region R, then in all likelihood botanical concept b2 be instantiated in space-time region R*. (It is irrelevant in this 
context whether or not R and R* are distinct regions.) Given these assumptions, this is what you must do to reduce botany to microphysics: you must identify two sets of 
microphysical concepts, m1…mk and m*1…m*j, such that (i) b1 is instantiated in R iff m1…mk are instantiated in R and such that (ii) b2 is instantiated in R* iff m*1…m*j are instantiated in R*. 
To sum up: to reduce botany to microphysics you must provide microphysical characterizations of all botanical concepts and all microphysical laws. Doing this involves showing (1) that, for each botanical concept b, there are microphysical concepts m1…mn such that the proposition b is 
instantiated in R is true if and only if the proposition m1…mn are (jointly) instantiated in R is also true; and (2) that for each botanical principle B there is a microphysical law M such that an instance of B occurs in a given region, at a given time, only if an instance of M occurs in that same region, at that same time. 
Of course, given any two disciplines D1 and D2, the points 
just made in connection with the reduction of botany to microphysics are true mutatis mutandis of the reduction of D1 to D2. 
4.1 Concomitances require explanation and don’t provide it (revisited) 
Right now, we’ll evaluate CA. First point: The laws governing an entity are not necessarily identical with those governing its parts. Here are some illustrations of this. A and B are two distinct battalions. General Smith is in charge of both of them. The General’s orders determine how each battalion as a whole behaves. The soldiers composing A are psychologically very different from those constituting B. So, in effect, the soldiers in A are not governed by the same psychological forces (laws) as the soldiers constituting 
B. Nonetheless, the forces that determine the behavior of the battalion as a whole coincide with those determining the other’s behavior as a whole. So the laws, and therefore the principles, in terms of which the behavior of A's (collective) is to be understood coincide with those in terms of which B's behavior is to be understood. 
For the same reason mutatis mutandis, even if the parts composing a thing are governed by the same laws as the parts composing some other thing, it doesn't follow that, taken as wholes, those two things are governed by the same law or, therefore, are to be understood in terms of the same principles. There is considerable evidence that, even though medium-sized objects (e.g., basketballs) are themselves governed by deterministic laws. (More precisely, the sub-atomic parts of the atoms composing them are not governed by deterministic laws.) If this is right (and even if it isn’t, in fact), the laws governing basketballs don’t coincide with those governing their parts. (To clarify the parenthetical qualification: the laws governing basketballs coincide with those governing the behavior of objects having radically different microstructural compositions. As a result, the laws governing the micro-activity constitutive of basketballs don’t coincide with those governing other objects that, as wholes, are governed by the same laws by which basketballs, as wholes, are governed.) 
Thus, two different objects could be governed by precisely the same botanical laws, even though the microactivity constitutive of the one is governed by entirely different laws from the microactivity of the other; and two things could be governed by different botanical laws, even though the microactivity constitutive of the one is governed by the very same laws as the microactivity constitutive of the other. 
4.1.1 Complying with laws vs. being governed by them, being governed by them; being governed by them vs. being explainable in terms of them 
“Your reasoning involves a serious fallacy," it will be said. “The laws of physics govern everything. Therefore, two different things cannot, at least not in the final analysis, be governed by different laws.” 
There are several points to make in response to this. We must start by distinguishing between “constitution” and “identity.”[381] 
Given a statue made of clay that is still soft, one can destroy a statue (by balling up the clay) without destroying the clay. Thus, the statue and clay don’t have the same properties. The one has, whereas the other lacks, the property of being destroyed when balled up. For this reason, we say that the clay constitutes the statue without being identical with it 
For similar reasons, a plant is not identical with the aggregate of particles constituting it. For, by redistributing those particles (without scattering them), one can destroy the plant without destroying the aggregate. And it’s probable, for the same reason mutatis mutandis, that mental states are not identical with the various physiological structures and patterns of physiological activity constituting them. For it’s a theoretical possibility that the part of a given person’s brain responsible for some psychological function is so altered that the brain-part not only continues to exist, but remains alive, even though, because of that alteration, that brain-part no longer performs F. 
The laws of physics clearly govern and explain the behavior of the particle-aggregate constituting the plant. But do they govern the plant itself? No. Before we explain this answer, we must put it in context. Two microphysically identical objects are ipso facto botanically identical. (If neither object is a plant, they’re still botanically identical; for neither has any botanical property not had by the other.) A corollary is that ceteris paribus identical microphysical changes realize identical botanical changes. 
But the laws of physics don’t govern plants; they govern the particle-aggregates on which the behaviors of plants supervene. In order for the laws of physics to govern plants it is necessary, but not sufficient, that they govern plant-constituting particle-aggregates. Thus must govern plants per se. But, as far the laws of physics are concerned, there are particles, particle-swarms, etc.---but not plants. The right position, then, is to say that the laws of physics don’t govern plants, but that the laws of physics govern the entities that constitute plants and that implement all of the changes undergone by them. Plants cannot violate the laws of physics, since a plant’s condition supervenes on that of the physics-governed particle-heap of which it is composed. But those laws don’t govern plants per se. 
Here is another way of thinking about. You could coherently imagine a universe botanically identical with ours----in which plants reacted in the same way to the same stimuli and, at the cellular and super-cellular levels, were structurally just like plants in our world---but in which the laws of physics were different. In such a world, the principles in terms of which plant-behavior was to be understood would coincide with the principles in terms of which plant-behavior is actually to be understood. So the laws of botany in that world, to the extent that there is such a thing as a law of botany, would coincide with the laws of botany our world.[382] 
Given that the laws of physics in that world don’t coincide with the laws of physics in our world, it follows that, in our world, the laws of botany—the laws that govern plants--­aren’t laws of physics. For exactly similar reasons, the laws of psychology in our world are not the laws physics. 
So, although everything that happens to a plant is determined by the laws of physics, it is misleading to say that the plants themselves are governed by such laws. For laws don’t govern entities whose existence they don’t countenance, and the laws of physics don’t countenance the existence of plants. The physicist’s world is plant-free. The laws of physics govern particle-heaps on whose properties those of plants supervene but with which plants are not identical. But only the laws of botany govern such heaps qua plant-constituting entities. Only the laws of botany acknowledge the existence of plants. So only the laws of botany can be said to govern botanical activity. And, for the same reason mutatis mutandis, only the laws of psychology can be said to govern psychological activity: the laws of physics don’t govern it and neither do the laws of physiology. 
4.2 Concomitances require explanation and don’t provide it (revisited) 
The conventional wisdom among philosophers of science is to say that, for the reasons just given, it's an open empirical question whether botany (or any other discipline) can be reduced to microphysics (or any other discipline)[383]: 
(CW) It cannot be known a priori whether or not botany is reducible to microphysics. In other words, given only that the microphysical laws govern the parts composing plants, it doesn’t follow that such laws govern plants themselves. So supposing that all we know about plants is that such and such laws govern the microactivity constitutive of plants, it is an open empirical question---which, in light of future findings, might or might not turn out to be answered affirmatively— whether the laws of botany coincide with, or can be derived from, the laws governing the microphysical activity composing plants. 
CW is false. To say that botany can be reduced to microphysics is to say that microphysics can say whatever botany can say (and, possibly, say it better). We’ve seen that the laws governing the micro-particles composing plants could be different from those governing plants themselves. That means that, even if two objects are botanically indistinguishable, it could be that the one plant’s microstructure has many a property that other’s microstructure lacks. To put it another way: even if, for any botanical property phi, x is phi is true iff y is phi is true, it could be that there exists many a microphysical property psi such that x’s microstructure has psi is true and y’s microstructure has psi is false. This, in its turn, means that, for any two plants x and y, even if it turns out that: 
(a) for any botanical property phi, x is phi is true iff y is phi is true, 
and it also turns out that: 
(b) for any microphysical property psi, x is a psi is true iff y 
is a psi is true, 
microphysical statements about a given plant would still not be analyses, or high-resolution versions, of botanical statements about that plant. 
So even if botanical truths about plants “tracked” microphysical truths about them---even if, for any given plant, a perfect concomitance could be established between its botanical and its microphysical properties---those microphysical truths would have altogether different contents from those botanical truths. Those microphysical truths would not be high-resolutions of those botanical truths; those microphysical truths would not explicate or clarify or precisify the contents of those botanical truths. 
There would thus be no reduction of botany to microphysics. The relationship of the one set of truths to the other would not be a relation of content. We would, under such circumstances, learn no more about botanical truths from microphysical truths than, were we in a world in which all round objects were green and all square ones were red, we would learn about geometrical truths from color-truths. 
4.3 The sterility of brute concomitances in relation to psychophysical reduction 
Bearing this in mind, let MA be a passage that is exactly like CA except that, in each place where CA contains a reference to botanical truths, MA contains a reference to psychology (that is otherwise just like the reference to botany that it supplanted). For reasons exactly analogous to those just stated, even if the conditions described by MA were fulfilled, then psychology would still not be reduced to microphysics. It’s easy to extend this point. Let BA be a passage that is exactly like MA except that, in each place where MA contains a reference to microphysical truths, BA contains a reference to physiology (or neurology or brain-science, or whatnot). It follows for obvious reasons that psychology would not have been reduced to physiology (or whatnot). Thus, even if it turns out that physiological truths “track” psychological truths, the former provide not one shred of insight into the content of the latter. 
Of course, should it turn that there existed some such concomitance between the physiological and the psychological, that fact could be tremendously useful. In fact, it has turned out that (with some qualifications that, although heavy, aren’t relevant here) there is such a concomitance between the neurological and the psychological; and it has turned out that knowledge of this fact has been of tremendous use. (It has made it possible to invent psychoactive medications and, more generally, medical procedures that dramatically improve people’s lives.) But, contrary to what people generally infer from this, this does not entail that truths about the mind are to be sought in facts about the brain. I benefit enormously from the fact that certain things happen to my computer just in case certain buttons on my computer-keyboard are struck. But the truth that such and such keys are struck on the keyboard provides not the slightest wisp of insight into the truth that, thus and such images are showing up on the monitor. 
4.3.1 A variant of the point just made 
Imagine a world W that is just like ours, except that, in it, penguins were the only animals on the South Pole and also, in that world, there were no penguins that were not on the South Pole. In such a world: 
(i) x is an animal on the South Pole, would be true just in case 
(ii) x is a penguin 
was also true. Given that, in W: (HP)[384] 
all and only penguins were animals on the South 
Pole, it follows that, in W, for any given x, (i) and (ii) would be equivalent. But, in W, (i) and (ii) would mean exactly what they mean in the real world and they’d thus have very different meanings. Thus, in W, the meaning of: 
(1) Smith is an animal on the South Pole, would be very different from the meaning of: 
(2) Smith is a penguin. 
Thus, in W, the truth of (2) would not, except perhaps in some very attenuated sense, be explainable in terms of the truth of (1), or vice versa. Suppose that, at time t, Smith is the only person in place p and also that Smith is the only person wearing a black shirt. Under those circumstances, Smith is in p at t and Smith is wearing a black shirt at t are equivalent. But neither proposition to any degree explains the other. 
The relationship between (1) and (2) is, in the relevant respects, identical with the relationship between the just-mentioned propositions about Smith. 
Since, apart from the fact that HP is true in world W but not in our world, W is governed by the same laws as our world. So it is just as possible in W as it is in our world for something to be a penguin that is not on the South Pole. That is why, even in W, (1) doesn’t explain (2), or vice versa; it is why, for any x, (i) doesn’t explain (ii), or vice versa. 
5.0 The sui generis nature of psychophysical explanatory gap 
One of the ways in which psychology cannot be reduced to any one of the physical sciences is comparable to the way in which botany cannot be reduced to physics. But there is a way, we’ll now argue, in which psychology cannot be reduced to any other discipline that is distinctive. The irreducibility of the psychological is distinctive; the sense in which truths of psychology are anomalous with respect to truths of any one of the physical sciences is deeper than the sense in which the truths of botany (or any other physical science) cannot be reduced to those of physics (same qualification). 
5.1 Type-type vs. token-token reduction 
The irreducibility of botany to microphysics lies in the fact that botanical concepts are not co-extensive or a fortiori co-intensive with microphysical concepts. So there is no microphysical concept that is co-extensive with the concept of a pine-tree. Indeed, there is no botanical concept that is co­extensive (or, therefore, co-intensive) with any micro-physical concept, that being why no microphysical principle can replace any botanical principle. 
Nonetheless, given any specific botanical truth B (e.g., plant x died on Tuesday), it is theoretically (though not practically) possible to show B to be a consequence of some microphysical truth. (I am using the term “microphysical truth” to cover truths consisting of enormously long conjunctions of true microphysical propositions.) A metaphor may be of use here. If you know how the various bricks composing some building are interrelated---if you know, for any two such bricks, how they are spatially interrelated---then you can, in principle (if not in practice), figure out the shape of the structure that those bricks jointly constitute. 
For exactly similar reasons, supposing for argument’s sake that you knew, for some time t, exactly how, at t, any two of the micro-particles composing some object O were interrelated, you could on that basis figure out O’s overall structure (at least in principle). [385] 
Given a knowledge of O’s overall structure (at a given time), along with a grasp of the conditions that an object must satisfy to fall under the concept pine-tree or blade of grass or any other botanical concept, you could determine what, if any, botanical properties O had. 
So even though botanical types can’t be identified with microphysical types, botanical tokens (i.e., instances of botanical types) can be identified with microphysical tokens (i.e., instances of microphysical types). Moreover, even though botanical principles are not identical with, and cannot be derived from, microphysical laws, any given non-general botanical truth can (in principle, setting aside interference-effects, though not in practice) be shown to be a consequence of some non-general microphysical truth. And this shows that, even though the principles of botany cannot be derived from those of microphysics and even though, therefore, botanical explanations cannot be replaced by microphysical explanations, it is not anomalous that there should be botanical data in a world all of whose denizens are governed by (micro)physical laws. In other words, it shows that, even though botany cannot, even in principle, be absorbed into microphysics, there is no reason in principle (setting aside interference-effects and other problems relating to the acquisition of knowledge of micro-particles) that, in a world all of whose constituents are composed of objects governed by microphysical laws and must themselves comply with such laws, there should nonetheless be truths that defy microphysical explanation. 
5.2 Type-type vs. token-token reduction (continued) 
But psychology is, in this respect, not to be put in the same category as botany. Not only is it not possible to reduce psychology to microphysics (or any other physical science): given any non-general biological truth, there is no microphysical truth such that---even after every possible allowance is made for interference-effects, human limitations, etc.---knowledge of that microphysical truth could possibly make it at all clear why that psychological truth should hold; there is no microphysical truth such that (even after all the usual allowances are made) makes it at all clear why any given psychological proposition should hold. 
Here’s why. The data modeled by any physical science---by physics, zoology, botany, etc.---is perceptual data. The data modeled by psychology is (for lack of a better word) “introspective” data. What does this mean? First of all, the “raw data” modeled by botany (for example) doesn’t consist of experiences; it consists of things known (or believed to be known) through experiences. That raw data concerns plants, trees, etc. Botanists don’t talk about their experiences; they talk about the things that are the objects of their experiences---the plants, etc. that they see. The same is true of physicists. They don’t talk about their experiences; they talk about the things they see and touch---the needle-displacements, the discolorations on photographic-plates, etc. 
By contrast, experiences themselves constitute the data modeled by psychology. A physicist may refer to an experience that he has (“I suddenly saw a blinding explosion and momentarily couldn’t see”) but only because he is attempting in so doing to describe some phenomenon known through experience (through perception); the experience is of interest only in so far as it gives one information as to some trans-experiential entity---as to something that, although the object of experience, is not itself an experience. 
Psychology is interested in the experience itself, and it’s interested in the object of experience only in so far as knowledge of the latter may help one acquire knowledge of the former. Psychology is interested in what I felt on such and such an occasion; in order to make it clear how I felt, I must inevitably refer to external events (“so and so took my wallet; I punched him; I was arrested; my lawyer was five hours late,” etc.). In fact, descriptions of external events are constitutive of descriptions of the experiential data in which the psychologist is interested. (The contents of one’s experiences are given by “that”-clauses. “I felt that I had been cheated”; “I saw that he was foaming at the mouth.” The exceptions to this prove spurious. “I saw a dog” is really elliptical for “I saw that there was a dog in a certain place.” Grammatically, the object of a verb such as “see,” “feel,” or “know”---the sort of verb that would be integral to any description of one’s experience---­may either be a “that”-clause or an ordinary noun phrase. One can say “I know that snow is white” or “I know Charlie.” But we have seen that, ultimately, what one believes, feels, or otherwise experiences is given by a “that”-clause.) But it is those experiences per se, not their objects, which the psychologist tries to model. 
This is easily shown. Given two people who are atom-for-atom duplicates and whose experiences are qualitatively identical, those people are ipso facto identical as far as a psychologist is concerned, even if one of them is a brain in a vat whose experiences are caused, not by photons bouncing off of the things he thinks he sees, but by stimulations of nerve-endings, whereas the other has veridical experiences. Setting aside the irrelevant, technical issue of how the disembodied brain would make its sentiments known to anyone, the disembodied brain’s experiences are, from a psychoanalytic or psychological perspective, 100% comparable to the other person’s experiences. But to a physicist (or botanist or geologist, etc.), the fact that the one person’s experiences are hallucinatory ipso facto disqualifies them: they are no longer viable sources of information. 
5.3 Weak vs. strong reduction and the reason why mental truths are both weakly and strongly irreducible to physical truths 
Any physical science models things known through perception. Psychology does not model things known through perception. It models our experiences. Of course, our perceptions are among our experiences. But psychology studies the perceptions themselves. Other sciences study the things known through them. Astronomers study stars, not perceptions of stars; psychologists study perceptions of stars, not stars. 
Because experiences are the subject-matter of psychology, two people whose lives are experientially indistinguishable are psychologically indistinguishable, even if one of them, during his waking life, experiences nothing but hallucinations, whereas the other has never had so much as a single hallucination. 
Of course, psychologists are interested in the fact that a given person has had a hallucination—but only in so far as that fact indicates some psychological malfunction on that person’s part. The hallucinations had by the aforementioned brain-in-a-vat are not (necessarily) so indicative, at least not necessarily, and therefore do not (necessarily) interest the psychologist except in so far as, and in the same way as, their veridical counterparts interest him. 
5.3.1 Weak vs. strong reduction and the reason why mental truths are both weakly and strongly irreducible to physical truths (continued) 
Given a building composed entirely out of bricks, if one knew how any two of those bricks were spatiotemporally interrelated, one could in principle figure out the structure of that building. Similarly, by knowing how any two atoms composing a given plant were spatiotemporally interrelated, one could in principle (though not in practice, given how many atoms would be involved) figure out what that plant’s macro-characteristics were---its morphology, its mass, etc. 
Further, supposing that one had such macro-knowledge and that one had a knowledge of the concepts of botany—concepts such as plant, pine-tree, cactus, leaf, etc.---and, therefore, that one knew what morphological, dynamic, etc. properties a thing had to have to qualify as (say) a Venus fly­trap, the aforementioned microphysical propositions would, given the propositions embodying that persons knowledge of the concepts of botany, entail (for example) that such and such was a Venus fly-trap that had thus and such distinctively botanical properties; and the same thing mutatis mutandis would be true of any other given botanical propositions. 
So the truths of microphysics, taken together with truths describing the concepts of botany---truths that, since they merely delineate those concepts and don’t say anything as to whether they’re instantiated or by what, are analytic---entail the truths of botany. In other words, if B1….Bm is the least inclusive list containing every botanical truth, and M1….Mn and Cb1…Cbo are the least inclusive lists containing the truths of microphysics and the truths concerning the structures of botanical concepts (the analytic truths of botany, in other words), then, given M1….Mn and Cb1…Cbo, it is 100% probable that B1….Bm are true. Put yet another way, the way in which the conjunction of M1….Mn and Cb1…Cbo entails B1….Bm is comparable to the way in which x is a triangle entails x has more than two sides. We’re dealing with deductive, not with inductive, inference. So given any one (non-general) botanical truth (e.g., x is a Venus fly-trap), there is some microphysical truth (which, in all likelihood, is a long conjunction of microphysical truths) with respect to which that botanical truth is completely non-anomalous. 
5.3.2 Weak vs. strong reduction and the reason why mental truths are both weakly and strongly irreducible to physical truths (continued) 
So there is a sense, albeit a weak one, in which botany is reducible to microphysics. Botany is reducible to microphysics in the weak sense that, for any given botanical truth, there is some microphysical truth with respect to which the former is non-anomalous. Botany is irreducible to microphysics in the sense that the system of botanical truths that botany puts forth, containing as it does botanical principles alongside the specific botanical truths it contains, cannot be deduced from, or otherwise understood in terms of, the truths of microphysics. In fact, we have seen that, contrary to what Hempel (1965) assumed, even if we happened to live in a world in which botanical-types happened to be co-extensive with microphysical types, botany still couldn’t be reduced, at least not in this robust sense, to microphysics. 
As we’ve seen, a consequence of the irreducibility, in this strong of sense, of botany as a whole to microphysics is that what is said by any given botanical proposition is different from what is said by any given microphysical proposition, even if both truths concern the same displacement of mass-energy. Nonetheless, any given botanical truth is non-anomalous with respect to some microphysical truth. 
5.3.3 Weak vs. strong reduction and the reason why mental truths are both weakly and strongly irreducible to physical truths (continued) 
Bearing this in mind, let’s suppose that Smith has a thorough knowledge of the concepts of psychology (desire, anxiety, intention, etc.). Let’s further suppose that Smith is given a thorough and accurate description of the microphysical events composing Brown’s brain over some period of time. 
By reasoning analogous to that just put forth, Smith could in principle infer everything there is to know about Brown’s brain. But, given only that data, he could infer not one single psychological truth about Brown. Psychological truths (about Brown) are not given by propositions to the effect some external object has some property or has been displaced in a certain way. Whatever information psychological truths do contain, that information is not to the effect that brains or physiological or otherwise sense-knowable entities have (undergone) some sense-knowable property (change). That information is about the experiences through which such changes are known, not the changes themselves. Which, as we’ve said twice before, is why the psychologist qua psychologist regards persons x and y as psychologically indistinguishable if the propositions describing the one person’s mental states coincide with those describing the other person’s, it being irrelevant from his viewpoint whether there is any divergence between those two people in respect of how accurately their experiences depict the world. (“But doesn’t the psychologist care whether somebody is hallucinating or not?” Yes, but only because hallucinations are typically symptoms of psychological disturbances. The envatted brain’s experiences are not thus symptomatic.) 
So if M*1….M*n is the least inclusive list of all of the microphysical truths describing the thing constituting Brown’s brain, and P1….Pm is the least inclusive list of all of the truths concerning the concepts of psychology (i.e., is the least inclusive list of all analytic psychological truths), the conjunction of those two lists of propositions does not, by itself, entail (or, indeed, otherwise confirm) so much as a single psychological truth about Brown. 
5.3.4 Weak vs. strong reduction and the reason why mental truths are both weakly and strongly irreducible to physical truths (closing the argument) 
In order for Smith to make any inferences about what is going on in Brown’s mind, we must add to what Smith already knows. So, granting that Smith knows M*1….M*n and also P1….Pm, Smith would have to know that 
when thus and such microphysical propositions (about the heap of particles constituting Brown’s brain) held, then thus and such psychological truths (about Brown) also held. In other words, in order for Smith---even if given the vast amount of information embodied in M*1….M*n and P1….Pm ---to 
acquire knowledge of so much as a single psychological truth about Brown, he has to know of psycho-physical correlations. 
What this shows is that the best one can do in the way of absorbing psychology into physiology is to establish correlations between them. But this means that what psychology says about the world cannot even in principle be deduced from, or otherwise understood in terms of, what physiology says about the world. Even if psychological types were co­extensive with physiological types, the very fact that psychological types are not necessarily coextensive with physiological types entails what psychological truths say about the world is altogether disjoint from what physiological truths say about the world. 
Even in a world W where all red objects were round, and no non-round objects were red, the information provided by the proposition x is red would be different from that provided by x is round. For it would be true, in W, that, even though the redness and roundness were co-extensive types, they weren’t necessarily so. Even in W, that is to say, the proposition x is red but not round would make sense, as would the proposition x is round but not red, even though they’d be false for all values of x. This shows that, even in a world where two properties P and P* are co-extensive, unless x is P entails x is P*, or vice versa, those propositions, if true, reveal different facts about the world. 
In our world, psychological types are not identical with physiological types. (A given ability on somebody’s part; e.g., that person’s ability to drive or speak English, can migrate. It often happens that, if brain-center A, which thus far has mediated Smith’s ability to drive, is damaged and can no longer do its job, some other brain-center B takes over A’s job---notwithstanding 
that A and B are neurologically very different. There are a lot of different neurological ways to skin a given psychological cat.[386]) 
5.4 A similar line of thought 
The truths that it is the purpose of psychology to model are such that, unless one has had some kind of non-perceptual encounter with those things or with things of the same kind, one couldn't possibly understand them. I obviously can’t have your experiences. But unless I myself had experienced sadness, frustration, etc., I wouldn’t understand what you were saying when you spoke about your own feelings of sadness, etc. (For argument's sake, we'll suppose that, so far as anyone has knowledge of what is going on in any other person's mind, I have knowledge of what is going on in your mind.) So even though I cannot possibly have the direct, intuitive knowledge of your mental states that you can have of them---even though I can do no better than to have "knowledge by description" of them, whereas you can have knowledge "by acquaintance" of them[387]---my knowledge of your mental states isn’t purely formal; it is informed by a knowledge of relevantly similar states in myself, my knowledge of which is completely non-perceptual. 
Moreover, the types of things in which the psychologist is interested are such that their instances are always known in a way that is at least partly non-perceptual. Their instances in the conscious or preconscious parts of one's mind are known in a wholly non-perceptual way.[388] 
Their instances in other people's minds are known in a partly non-perceptual way, as are non­(pre)conscious instances in one's own mind. 
So even though the specific things in which the psychologist is interested are often such that he cannot know them through sense-perception, there are three fundamental differences between the subject matter of astronomy, or any other physical science, and the subject-matter of psychology: 
(i) 
The things in which the psychologist is interested, though known to him in a partly sense-based way (except when he is studying his own mind), are known (to the patient) in a non-sense-based way. 

(ii) 
By virtue of knowing those things in a non-sense-based way, the patient has a more robust knowledge of them than could be had by anyone who knew them in a sense-based way. 


(iii) The types of things studied by the psychologist are such that, unless one has had direct, non-sense-based knowledge of them, one cannot even have descriptive, second-hand knowledge of their occurrence in others. 
Given (i)-(iii), it follows that one’s knowledge of another person’s mental states is partly, though obviously not entirely, based on knowledge of one’s own mental states and, therefore, that knowledge of another person’s mental states is partly, though obviously not entirely, not sense-based. 
5.4.1 Why there is a sense in which psychology is anomalous with respect to the physical that is deeper than the sense in a given physical discipline could possibly be anomalous with respect to another physical discipline 
Botany, astronomy, microphysics, zoology, and geology, though very different from one another, model data to the effect that the structure of the external world is such and such; that things are spatiotemporally interrelated in such and such a way; that the things thus interrelated have such and such properties; and that those properties themselves are such that their instances are inherently constitutive, or at least dispositive, of instances of certain kinds of spatiotemporal interrelations or changes in such relations. Consider the sorts of properties in which a physical scientist is interested: temperature, conductivity, gravitational pull, acidity, malleability, density, migration patterns, physical morphology, way of reproducing, way of obtaining nourishment. It is easily shown that, for any concept C such that C is one of the concepts which is the object of (non-psychological) scientific study, x is an instance of C holds in virtue of the way in which mass-energy is (re)distributed . 
But, for any concept C such that C is one of the concepts which is the object of psychological study, x is an instance of C is not to that effect. The proposition Sam is sad is not to the effect that some (re)distribution of mass-energy holds. It may be---indeed, the present author firmly believes it to be--­that Sam’s sadness is mediated by physiological events and therefore by (re)distributions of mass-energy. But Sam is sad is not to the effect that anything having any motion-constitutive or motion-conducive properties is occupying, or likely to occupy, any position relative to anything else. Sam is sad registers a truth that is known to Sam in a thoroughly non-perceptual way and that cannot be known to anyone other than Sam except on the basis of his own experience of sadness and therefore cannot be known to anyone other than Sam in a way that is in part (though not entirely) non-sense-based. 
5.5 Donald Davidson's failed attempt to demonstrate the anomalousness of the mental with respect to the physical 
Like us, Donald Davidson held that psychological truths are anomalous 
with respect to physical truths. He presents his argument for this in his 
celebrated (1970) paper “Mental Events.”[389] 
Here is that argument: 
(DA)[390] 
Suppose the following. x is some event in Smith’s brain. x also constitutes a desire on Smith’s part to become a lawyer. 
Question: Why does x constitute such a desire? Answer: Because, given the thoughts and deeds on Smith’s part that x follows and given the thoughts and deeds on Smith’s part that x precedes, it makes sense to see x as a desire on Smith’s part to become a lawyer. It is analytic that a desire on somebody’s part to become a lawyer has certain causes and also certain effects. It is analytic that, given certain circumstances, a desire to become a lawyer leads one to study for the LSAT, apply to law school, and so on. And it’s analytic that, given certain circumstances, a desire to become a lawyer be the result from one’s belief that lawyering is the best way to promote the interests of justice (or whatnot). 
Before we take the next step in our argument, we must generalize these points. Let P be an arbitrary physical event and let M be an arbitrary mental category. (An example of a mental category would be belief that snow is white, desire to become a senator, regret at never having learned to play a musical instrument. So for x to fall into the category desire to become a senator is for x to be a desire to become a senator.) If P is to fall into M, it is necessary and sufficient that, given what P’s owner thought and did prior to P’s occurrence, and given also what P’s owner thought and did after its occurrence, it makes sense to suppose that P is an instance of M. In other words, for P to fall into M is for P to be such that it can be reasonably interpreted as falling into M. To be a belief that 1 + 1 = 2 is to be interpretable as being such a belief. 
This must be understood aright. Supposing that P is a belief 
that 1 + 1 = 2, there isn’t anything other than P’s being interpretable as being such a belief that makes it be such a belief. It being thus interpretable isn’t a consequence of its being such a belief: it is its being such a belief. In general, there isn’t anything to anything’s being an instance of mental category M other than its being such that it can reasonably be seen as being such an instance. 
To move forward, let us continue to suppose that P is a belief that 1 + 1 = 2. Let us also suppose that P is a brain-event and, in addition, that P falls into physical category C. 
For P to fall into C isn’t for P to be such that it can reasonably be interpreted as falling into C. It isn’t in virtue of what P’s owner does or thinks before or after P’s occurrence that P falls into this as opposed to that physical category. If P falls into a given physical category, it is in virtue of its chemical structure, or some such, it being irrelevant whether so categorizing P has the consequence that P’s owner is rational or not. 
It follows that, even though mental events are identical with brain-events, the reasons for which a given event is mental are different from those in virtue of which it’s physical. Moreover, the former reasons cannot be understood in terms of the latter. Thus, there is an explanatory gap. 
Although we've seen reason to agree with Davidson that there is an explanatory gap, DA utterly fails to establish this. This is because it depends on two false assumptions. 
The first is the assumption that to be a belief that 1 + 1 = 2 (or a desire to lose weight or an intention to buy a car, etc.) is to be interpretable as being such a belief (or desire or wish, etc.). In addition to being deeply counterintuitive, Davidson’s “interpretivist” view of the mental is demonstrably false. According to Davidson’s interpretivism, for brain-event x, had by person A, to fall into mental category M is for it to be the case that, if x is assumed to fall into M, then A is, to that extent, rational. If this were right, nobody could possibly make any erroneous inferences; nobody could ever think or act irrationally. For, by Davidson’s lights, if x doesn’t have the consequences that a belief that 1 + 1 = 2 should have, it ipso facto isn’t a belief that 1 + 1 = 2. But people make erroneous inferences from their beliefs; people aren’t always rational. (See Chapter 19 for a more thorough refutation of Davidson’s interpretivism.) Therefore, Davidson is wrong. 
Also, Davidson’s argument assumes the truth of a doctrine known as "functionalism,” which, in Chapter 22, Section 7.1, we’ll find to be false. 

6.0 Duly modifying our earlier claim that to explain x is to show x to be continuous with other events in its neighborhood 
Sciences model data. Hopefully these models yield truth. But, since truth is known only through the models we construct, it cannot be a scientist’s immediate intention to describe the truth; his immediate intention must be to construct a model. More specifically, his immediate intention is to construct a model that, although hoped to be truth-conducive, is intended to satisfy some desideratum that can be identified without already knowing the relevant truth: some model, that is to say, that is “good” in a way that can be defined independently of the concept of truth---but that, because it is good in that way, hopefully leads to the truth. 
The body of data at a person’s disposal isn’t homogenous. It automatically differentiates itself into sub-classes of data. These sub-classes comprise propositions that share certain key concepts and that, if accepted, tend to lead one to accept other propositions that share those concepts. If the subject makes a sufficiently intelligent and concerted effort to delineate the consequences of these propositions, they can be organized into an system of propositions whose natural tendency is to become more organized and more comprehensive. 
As we've said many times, a scientist's immediate intention is to model the data, not to identify the truth. Given this fact, along with the fact that to explain is to show the apparently discontinuous to be continuous, it follows that a scientist's immediate intention to establish data-internal continuity, not among in reality per se---not in the data-transcendent reality to which, if all goes well, his models will lead him---but in reality in so far as it can be described using the concepts definitive of his discipline. 
So a botanist wants to avoid botanical discontinuities. In his effort to explain how plant X's not being watered on Monday led to its dying on Tuesday, he'll posit botanical continuities, not microphysical continuities. From his viewpoint, the propositions by which microphysical continuities are described are data-transcendent. Thus, those propositions are meaningless from a botanical perspective, since they are constructed out of concepts that are external to those out of which botanical propositions are constructed. He'll thus posit botanical continuities. True---propositions describing such botanical continuities are exponentially more low-resolution than those describing microphysical continuities. But former propositions, unlike the latter, are data-internal and can describe continuities that help him model the relevant data. 

7.0 The concept of a datum (revisited) 
We began this chapter by outlining an answer to the question: "What is a datum?" We’ll end this chapter by filling in that outline. 
You believe many things. Some of your beliefs are true. Some of your true beliefs are cases of knowledge. Consider the smallest set containing all of those beliefs of yours that are cases of explanatorily robust knowledge. A given piece of knowledge is “explanatorily robust” if the proposition thereby known is explanatorily robust, and a proposition is “explanatory robust” if it leads to explanations that lead to the truth. (So “Smith is a person who just consumed large quantities of cyanide” is explanatorily robust, since it naturally leads to an explanation of the fact that Smith is now dead.[391]) Let S* be the smallest set containing all of the propositions that you accept by virtue of having those pieces of knowledge. 
S* can be divided into sub-classes. Some of those sub-classes are not explanatorily unified. An example of such a class would be the one whose only members are the propositions two is even, Neptune is a planet, and ketchup is not a vegetable. But some of those sub-classes are explanatorily unified. An example of such a class would be the one all and only those propositions concerning numbers that you know to be true. 
Any given class corresponds to a concept.[392] 
The class of all plants corresponds to the concept plant. (This concept may be identified with the property of being a plant, at least for the purposes of this discussion, and the same thing mutatis mutandis is true of every other concept.[393]) The class of all things that are either dogs or numbers corresponds to the concept thing such that x is either a dog or a number. 
7.0.1 The concept of a datum: Concepts that have explanatory value vs. those that don’t 
The concepts in terms of which we instinctively understand the world tend to have considerable explanatory and predictive value. The world is so structured that, given that x is a plant, it follows that it will thrive under certain conditions and die under others; that x cannot talk; that x reproduces in certain ways but not others; that x has certain organelles but not others; and so on. Given this information about x, along with a modicum of knowledge concerning x’s physical surroundings, it can be explained why x died/why, despite previously being on the brink of death x is thriving/whether x will reproduce/and so on. Thus, the concept of a plant picks out an explanatorily unified class of entities. 
Not all concepts are comparable in this respect to the concept plant. Let a dogber be something that is either a dog or a number. Even when taken together with considerable zoological and mathematical knowledge, one’s knowledge that x is a dogber is useless from an explanatory viewpoint. 
Of course, given the knowledge that x is a dogber that isn’t a number, or that it is a dogber that isn’t a dog, one can, given a modicum of knowledge about x’s circumstances, make many a correct statement as to its structure and (supposing that it is a dog and therefore that, unlike numbers, things will happen to it) as to what is likely to kill it, cure it, etc. But this shows that any value had by the concept dogber is stolen, as it were, from some virtue had by the concept number or the concept dog. 
The value of the concept plant is not thus derivative. The fact that x is a plant by itself has many ramifications as to x’s structure, etc. Of course, the fact that x is a rose is, in some contexts (not all), richer in predictive and explanatory information than the fact that x is a plant. But, in and of itself, the fact that x is a dogber is without any insight-or prediction-conducive ramifications. By contrast, the fact that x is a plant is replete with such ramifications. 

7.0.2 Final preliminaries 
Of those beliefs of ours that are cases of knowledge, some have explanatory value, whereas others do not. (Knowledge of a truth of the form x is a plant has explanatory value. Knowledge of a truth of the form x is a dogber does not.) Let Smith be an arbitrary person, let S be the set whose members include all and only those propositions that: 
(i) Smith knows to be true, 
and: 
(ii) have explanatory value. 
S’s members can be divided into different sub-classes. Some of those sub­classes are explanatorily unified; others are not. Given any one of the explanatorily unified sub-classes, there is some set of concepts such that: 
(a) Each of the members of that sub-class contains at least one of those concepts,
