and such that: 
(b) Given any two members of that sub-class, the one bears on the other by virtue of the fact that each contains one or more of those concepts. 
If S# is an arbitrary one of those sub-classes, S# can be divided into two groups of propositions: those of whose truth Smith has direct knowledge and those of whose truth Smith has indirect (inferential) knowledge. 
[394] 



7.1 “Datum” defined 
A proposition P is a datum, relative to S#, if Smith’s knowledge of it is “direct” (in the just-described) sense. 
In general, D is a datum, relative to some class C of propositions known by a given person to be true, if (1) C is explanatorily unified, (2) D is a member of C, and (3) that knowledge of D is direct (in the previously described sense). 

7.2 "Datum" a relative term 
We've just seen that the property of being a datum is inherently relational. In this section, we'll find that this property is relative in more ways than one. 
Patient Z dies. For the attending physician, that’s a datum. (Let’s refer to this datum as “DP.") It isn’t a conjecture. It's known directly, not through inference or a fortiori through theory. 
But for the microphysicist, Z’s being dead isn’t even a fact, let alone a datum. Terms like “dead” and “ill” have no microphysical meaning. So DP is a datum for medicine, but not for microphysics. 
So the concept of a “datum” is a relative notion. Something is a datum relative to one discipline but not relative to some other discipline. In fact, it’s a doubly relative notion, since what is a datum today for a given discipline may come into question tomorrow. 
7.2.1 "Datum" a relative term (continued) 
Also, there are degrees of datumhood. It’s more of a datum that I am having such and such visual and tactile sensations than it is that I am now typing on a keyboard. But it is, surely, a datum that I am typing on a keyboard. Indeed, it is much more of a datum than are the so-called data on which many scientific theories are based. For those data often presuppose the accuracy of instruments that, unless highly elaborate theories are correct, are quite erroneous. 
The right reaction to this last fact isn’t to say that those so-called data aren’t really data. If one used the term "datum" only to refer to things known in a thoroughly theory-innocent manner, that term would refer to nothing. The right reaction is to say what we've been saying---that the concept of a datum is a relative one. 
To sum up: whatever properties a piece of information must have to qualify as a datum, some pieces of information have it to a greater degree than others. At the same time, most, if not all, of those things that we describe as "data" fail to have those properties to such a high degree that there is no context in which that piece of information is a non-datum. The class of things that have those properties to that degree is either empty or highly restrictive. 
[395] 

Part VI Mind, Body, Self 
Chapter 22 Different Views as to the Relation Between Mind and Body 
1.0 Some important terms and concepts 
Beliefs, hopes, tickles, pains, aspirations, dreads, intentions, fantasies, and longings are mental entities. Chairs, explosions, rocks, gusts of air, and quagmires are physical entities. 
How is the mental related to the physical? Here are the different views: 
(1) 
Dualism: mental entities are not physical entities.[396] 


(2) 
Materialism: mental entities are physical entities.[397] 



(3) 
Dual aspect theory: the mental and the physical are different aspects of the same thing.[398] 


(4) 
Mental eliminativism: there is no such thing as the mental. There are brain-states—but no beliefs, tickles, etc.[399] 


(5) 
Idealism: there is no such thing as the physical. There are experiences, hopes, etc.— but no chairs, rocks, etc.[400] 



Right now, let us focus on (1) and (2), since they are, pretty obviously, the only two of these five views that have any real chance of being correct. Later we’ll discuss why, despite their obvious falseness, people have held (3)–(5). 
First of all, (2) is not the view that mental entities don’t exist. (2) must be distinguished at all costs from (4). According to (2), perceptions, beliefs, doubts, and so on, all exist—but they are identical with brain-states. The materialist says that, just as water is H2O, so your belief that 1 + 1 = 2 is 
identical with some pattern of neural stimulation (or some such). Just as the physical chemist isn’t denying the existence of water in identifying it with H2O, so the materialist isn’t denying the existence of the mental in 
identifying it with physical entities. Although there may be some tendency on the part of materialists to be dismissive of certain features of the psychological realm, they don’t have to be thus dismissive: Chomsky is a materialist, as was Freud—and those two were nothing if not great believers in the psyche. 
Advocates of (2) typically (but not universally) hold that mental entities 
are identical with brain-events and brain-structures. For obvious reasons, they don’t usually hold that mental entities are identical with trees or rocks or anything else that is not a part of one’s body (or, more specifically, one’s central nervous system). 
I have published some papers arguing for dualism. I am now a materialist. But I am still fundamentally open on this issue. 
Here are my own views. I believe (as I just said) that materialism is correct. Second, I believe (very strongly) that functionalism (a very popular form of materialism: to be defined later) is wrong. Third, although I believe that materialism is correct, I don’t think (paradoxical though it may sound initially) that it can ever be explained why the mental is identical with (some aspects of) the physical. 
Right now, let us focus on some of the basic arguments for and against (1). (In the process of discussing these arguments, we will find that there are different versions of both materialism and dualism.) Of course, since (1) is the negation of (2), any argument for (1) is an argument against (2), and any argument for (2) is an argument against (1). 
2.0 Two arguments for dualism 
Setting aside arguments that are patently fallacious, there are, ultimately, two arguments for dualism. (The arguments considered in sections 4.0-4.5 are, it is easily seen, variants of these arguments.) 
2.1 The first argument for dualism 
The mental obviously has properties not had by the physical. For example: mental entities are representational; they are purposive; they have “phenomenology” (i.e., there is something it is like to have them). Since physical events obviously don’t have those properties, physical events aren’t mental. (This argument was given by Franz Brentano in Psychology from an Empirical Standpoint.) 
2.1.1 This argument evaluated 
Though it has force, there is a problem with this argument. The materialist can say that physical events do have these properties, but that this simply isn’t obvious to introspection. For example, physical events have lots of properties that aren’t obvious. When you look at a chair or a rock or a pool of water, your perception doesn’t tell you anything about the microstructural properties of what you are seeing—but it would obviously be absurd to conclude that what you were seeing didn’t have invisible (to the naked eye) microstructural properties. Similarly, says the materialist, when you introspect a pain or a tickle or a belief, your introspection doesn’t tell you anything about the neural properties of what you are introspecting—but it would be absurd to conclude, on that basis alone, that what you were introspecting didn’t have neural properties. 
2.1.2 A counterargument 
Some mental entities seem to be appearances. Consider your perception of (e.g.) some nearby table. Your perception is just the event of something’s appearing to you. It doesn’t make sense to say that there is more to an appearance than meets the eye. After all, what doesn’t meet the eye is ipso facto not an appearance. Your perception of the table obviously doesn’t seem to consist of lots of neural events. So, if it did consist of such events, they are beneath the surface—they don’t “meet the eye” of introspection. But given what we said a moment ago, this would mean that such events aren’t part of that perception. 
2.1.3 This counterargument evaluated 
I’m genuinely open as to whether this argument is a good one. I believe (for reasons to be stated) that materialism is correct. But I cannot find any errors in the just-stated counter-response (though others claim to be able to do so). If you can identify some consideration that resolves the matter, or that gives some weight to a certain (attempted) way of resolving the matter, I would be extremely interested in what you have to say. 
2.2 The second argument for dualism: the explanatory gap 
Consider some psychological statement, for example: 
(P) Last year I was very sad, because I completely failed in my efforts to write a best-selling novel. 
(P) is obviously the kind of statement that could be true. But can the truth of (P) be understood in terms of facts about neural-firings? Can we conceive of some statement about a person’s body that made it clear why (P) was true? Of course, we can imagine discovering that people feel sad when, and only when, certain neurons in their brains are firing. But would such a discovery really give us any insight into the nature of the dependence (if any there be) of that psychological fact on the existence of those neural states of affairs? 
Let us generalize this point. There is no denying that we can discover psycho-physical concomitances; that is, that we can discover truths of the form mental phenomenon m occurs when, and only when, physical phenomenon p occurs. But there always seems to be a “gap” between the neural event and the associated psychological event. Permit me to clarify this last point. 
Water is H2O. Of course, when you look at a glass of water, you cannot see that it consists of H2O molecules. But suppose that you could shrink yourself down to the size of such a molecule. In that case, you could literally 
see the molecules with which physical chemists identify water. 
When you look at a brain, you see beige tissue—you don’t see emotions, beliefs, etc. If you were to shrink yourself down the size of a molecule, you still wouldn’t see emotions, beliefs, etc. In other words, you still wouldn’t see the entities that the materialist identifies with brain-states.[401] 
You would see the entities with which the physical chemist identifies with brain-states (atoms, molecules of various kinds) but not, as we just said, those with which the materialist identifies such states. This suggests that psychophysical identifications (e.g., “pain is c-fiber stimulation”) are not comparable to typical scientific identifications (e.g., “water is H2O”); and this makes it 
questionable whether psychophysical identifications are correct. Also, the fact that you could coherently imagine seeing water molecules (even though, for many reasons, our ability to see such things is limited) 
seems to be bound up (in a way that isn’t easy to articulate) with the fact that identifications such as “water is H2O” are explanatory. The identification of 
water with H2O renders explicable otherwise inexplicable facts about water (e.g., that the amount of space occupied by a frozen gram of water is larger than that occupied by a liquid gram of water). But, at an intuitive level at least, it doesn’t seem that a comparable gain of insight into the nature of pain is gained as a result of the identification of pain with c-fiber stimulation. Imagine somebody who, because of some defect, didn’t feel pain. If that person were to learn everything there was to know about the structure of the neural events underlying pain, he would still be ignorant of what pain was. 
[402] 
By the same token, somebody who has no idea what a neuron is can know exactly what pain is. 
This suggests that psychophysical identifications are, in a fundamental way, not comparable to garden-variety scientific identifications. Somebody who knows what water tastes like, looks like, etc., doesn’t necessarily know what water is. But somebody who knows that water consists of H2O 
molecules really does know what water is—it doesn’t really matter what other knowledge he has or lacks. It thus becomes very hard to sustain the idea that (A) “pain is c-fiber stimulation” is in the same category as (B) “water is H2O.” There is a clear sense in which somebody who knows (A) may not 
know what pain is but in which somebody who knows (B) cannot possibly fail to know what water is. In connection with this, there is reason to think that there is an explanatory gap between the mental and the physical—to believe, in other words, that there is no way to understand the mental in terms of the physical. And if this is the case, then it would seem to follow that the mental is not the physical. 
2.2.1 This argument evaluated 
Even if the mental cannot be understood in terms of the physical, it doesn’t follow that the mental isn’t identical with the physical. Even if the fact that Jerry is sad cannot be understood in terms of the fact that Jerry’s brain is in such and such a condition, it doesn’t follow that Jerry’s sadness isn’t identical with his brain’s being in that condition. 
We know that biological phenomena (e.g., digestion, respiration) are identical with interactions of atomic and sub-atomic parts. But there would be no way to translate a biological statement (e.g., “Smith is now breathing”) into a statement about atoms bouncing off of one another. Because statements belonging to biology involve concepts (e.g., respiration) that aren’t found in physics, it is to be expected that the former are not going to be capable of being translated into, or otherwise understood in terms of, the latter. Biology talk isn’t physics talk, even though all biological events are physical events. Similarly, psychology talk isn’t physics talk (or chemistry talk or biology talk) even though psychological events are physical events. Because psychology uses concepts not found in any physical science (e.g., chemistry or physics), it is to be expected that statements belonging to the former are not going to be capable of being translated into, or otherwise understood in terms of, statements belonging to the latter.[403] 

2.2.2. A counter-response 
Although this argument obviously has merit, and is widely accepted, I don't accept it. There seems to me to be a significant difference between the relationship that holds between statements belonging to physics and statements belonging to biology, on the one hand, and the relationship holding between statements belonging to psychology and statements belonging to physics (or chemistry or biology . . .) on the other. This viewpoint is defended in Chapter 21. 
2.2.3 A counter-response to the counter-response 
The mental can be understood in terms of the physical. There is no more of an explanatory gap between the mental and the physical than between the biological and the chemical. In other words, there is no explanatory gap. Right now we’ll discuss why, according to many, there is no such gap. 
2.3 Is there an explanatory gap? 
So far as advocates of the view just described provide clear grounds for it, those grounds lie in two doctrines. Right now, we will discuss just one of them. (In a moment, we’ll discuss the other.) 
Some hold that to explain why one state of affairs accompanies or follows another simply to show that, taken together, those two events instantiate a general regularity.[404] 
To explain why, in this one instance, smoke follows fire is simply to identify some comprehensive regularity of which this particular sequence of events is an instance. If it is shown that fire is always followed by smoke, it has ipso facto been explained why, in this case, fire was followed by smoke. By parity of reasoning, were we to establish perfect concomitances between mental events and physical events, we would ipso facto have explained the mental in terms of the physical. 
2.3.1 A counter-response to the argument given 
Hempel’s conception of explanation is erroneous. The basic problem is that it’s too liberal: if it were right, anything could be said to be the cause of anything. The reasons for this are given in Chapter 17. But here’s the basic idea. 
I grab my phone, so as to pick it up and make a call; just after I do so, it rings. By coincidence, I’m getting a call at that exact moment. Hempel’s theory has the obviously false consequence that my grabbing the phone is what caused it to ring. Let E1 be the event consisting of my grabbing the phone, and let E2 be the event consisting of the phone’s ringing. Obviously E1 will be unique in many respects—no other event will involve exactly the same mass-energy distributions that it does. It follows that E1 uniquely has some property P1. The same thing mutatis mutandis is true of E2; and E2 therefore uniquely has some property P2. Thus, the sequence of events consisting of E1 and E2 is a unique instance of the true universal generalization that any instance of P1 is immediately followed by, and adjacent to, an instance of P2. If Hempel’s analysis were right, then my grabbing the phone would have caused it to ring. Since it didn’t, Hempel’s 
analysis is wrong. 
2.3.2 Another counter-response 
Setting this aside, it isn’t widely held that mind-brain concomitances (other than obviously contrived, explanatorily irrelevant ones similar to the one just described in connection with E1 and E2) are to be found. The reason: 
it is widely believed that the mental is “multiply realizable.” Instances of any kind of mental category can, it is alleged, be constituted by physical events of very different kinds; and for this reason, there are no true statements of the form “events having such and such biochemical properties occur iff events having thus and such psychological properties occur.” 
2.3.3 How the functionalist tries to eliminate the explanatory gap 
But, even though, for the reason just given, the alleged multiple realizability of mental states seems to eliminate one way of closing the explanatory gap between mind and matter, it actually opens what many (myself not included) claim to be a promising way of closing that gap. As previously noted, almost all contemporary materialists hold that mental entities are multiply realizable—that, for example, a belief that snow is white could be composed of any material capable of having the causal liaisons had by a belief that snow is white. For X to be such a belief, it is said, is not for it to be composed of this or that material, but is for it to have certain causes and effects. They hold, in general, that given any mental category M, for a given physical entity P to fall into M simply is for P to have certain causes and certain effects. This doctrine is known as functionalism. 
In Sections 7.1-7.1.2 of the present chapter, it will be argued that functionalism is false, the reason being that it collapses into the obviously false view that there are no mental entities. It goes without saying that, if it’s false, functionalism does nothing to close the explanatory gap. In any case, I’d now like to put forth a positive reason to believe that there is no way to close the explanatory gap. 
3.0 The reason there is an explanatory gap 
For argument’s sake suppose that every mental event is identical with (or realized by) some physical event. In that case, my feeling remorseful that I stole my sister’s cookie is identical with some brain-event of mine. Let M be my feeling of remorse, and let B be the corresponding brain-event. Suppose that I sincerely and accurately express my remorse—taking care to discuss its origins, its exact content, etc. Let SM be this statement. And suppose that I see an accurate image of B on a giant monitor, and I thoroughly and accurately describe what I see. Let SB be this statement. 
SM describes the very same event as SB. But the data of which SM is a synthesis doesn’t even overlap with the data of which SB is a synthesis. Even if mental events are identical with physical events, the data of which mentalistic statements are syntheses doesn’t even overlap with the data of which physicalistic statements are syntheses. This means that, given the data of which any mentalistic statement is a correct synthesis, it is epistemically possible that none of the data of which any given physicalistic statement is a correct synthesis even exists. Mentalistic statements don’t model the same data as physicalistic statements, or vice versa. So even though the facts described by the former probably are identical with (a subset of) the facts described by the latter, any statement belonging to the one category leaves it completely open whether any given statement belonging to the other is correct or not. 
The purpose of Chapter 18 is to show that there is an explanatory gap. In that chapter, we will examine Donald Davidson's attempt to establish that there is an explanatory gap; we will find Davidson's attempt to be a failure. 
4.0 Descartes’ arguments for dualism 
Descartes provided a straightforward and, at an intuitive level, compelling argument for (1). Here it is. I can believe that x is a feeling (or belief or intention) without believing that x is a brain-state. Therefore, x cannot be a brain-state if x is a feeling (or belief or intention). 
4.1 This argument evaluated 
This argument is guilty of the so-called “intensional” fallacy. Remember what we said about intensional contexts: Given only that “Smith thinks that the inventor of bifocals invented bifocals” is true, it doesn’t follow that “Smith thinks that the first postmaster general invented bifocals” is true, even though the first postmaster general is identical with the inventor of bifocals. Similarly, given only that “Smith thinks that x is a belief” is true, it doesn’t follow that “Smith thinks that x is a brain-state” is true, even if beliefs are in fact brain-states. 
4.2 A refinement of Descartes’ arguments for dualism 
Here is an improved version of Descartes’ argument that, so its proponents believe, isn’t vulnerable to the points just made. 
I can coherently think: 
(*) “x is a feeling, but x is not a brain-state.” 
In other words, (*) is not analytically false. 
All necessary truth is analytic truth. In other words, if a statement is necessarily true, that is because it holds entirely in virtue of the concepts composing its meaning (i.e., it is analytic). Therefore, given that (*) is not analytically false, it follows that it isn’t necessarily false and, therefore, that it could be true. So feelings could be distinct from brain-states. 
Next-step: identity holds necessarily if it holds at all. If x and y are identical, then they are necessarily so. Proof[405]: Suppose that x and y are identical, but only contingently so. Obviously x cannot be contingently identical with itself. So if x and y are contingently identical, then y has a property that x lacks: y has the property of being contingently identical with x, whereas x does not have that property. Thus, contrary to our supposition, x is not identical with y, showing that it is incoherent to suppose that there is such a thing as “contingent” identity. 
Thus, given that (*) could be true, and given that identity holds necessarily if it holds at all, it follows that feelings (and, for exactly similar reasons, beliefs and pains) are not brain-states. 
4.3 This argument evaluated 
First of all, it is easy to adapt what we said about (i) and (ii) to this argument. So this refinement of Descartes’ argument is, like the first, guilty of the intensional fallacy. 
But there’s another reason to question that argument. According to many contemporary philosophers, not all necessity is analytic. The sentence “water is identical with H2O,” it is said, expresses a proposition that, although non-analytic, is necessarily true. There is no possible circumstance where water is anything other than H2O. There are circumstances where liquids that, in terms of their macroscopic properties, resemble water but are not H2O. But there are no circumstances where water is not H2O. 
Why is this? The categories in terms of which science explains the world are known as “natural kinds.” Examples of natural kinds are zebra, metal, proton, water, emotion, human being, acid, base, star, and penguin. Natural kinds are generated by properties that are predictively and explanatorily fecund. Properties that don’t have those virtues (e.g., person who drives a green car, edible substance on Larry’s table) don’t generate natural kinds. The property of being H2O generates a natural kind. Two things that are 
explanatorily and predictively very different can be indistinguishable in respect of their macro-characteristics, at least within the narrow horizons within which non-experimentalists typically operate. For this reason, that the property of having such and such macro-characteristics does not determine a natural kind. 
But two things that are indistinguishable in respect of their micro-characteristics (e.g., their chemical compositions) cannot be explanatorily and predictively different. Thus, the property of having such and such micro-characteristics generates a natural kind.[406] 
It can’t be known a priori what chemical composition water has. But, for the reasons just given, its having that composition, whatever it turns out to be, is essential to it. Supposing that x is some body of water, x’s being water is identical with x’s having that composition. Since, therefore, water necessarily has that composition—and, therefore, is necessarily H2O—and since it cannot be known a priori that it has that composition; “water is H2O” expresses a necessary, but non-analytic truth. 
4.4 Evaluating this counter-response 
This is a prima facie very compelling line of thought, and it is almost universally accepted. For reasons that I state in Chapter 9, I do not accept it (even though I accept some parts of it; e.g., the part about how natural kinds are individuated by their microstructures or by whatever it is about them that makes them explanatorily and predictively useful). In any case, these reflections naturally bring us to Kripke’s compelling argument for dualism. 
4.5 Kripke’s argument for dualism 
All identities hold necessarily, and some identities are indeed a posteriori. Nonetheless, dualism can be established by means of an argument not entirely unlike Descartes’. Consider some (alleged) necessary, non-analytic truth; for example: 
(WH) water is H2O. 
First of all, the sentence "water is H2O" must be distinguished from the corresponding proposition. Once we take into account the information on the 
basis of which one determines the identity of the proposition literally meant by that sentence, it becomes de rigueur to se "water is H2O" as encoding either a proposition that is synthetic but non-necessary or necessary but non-
synthetic. I state my reasons for holding this in Chapter 9. I state my reasons for holding this. But, for argument's sake, we'll assume the truth of the orthodox and prima facie plausible position that WH is both synthetic and necessary. 
The reason that WH is non-analytic is that something that appeared, visually and otherwise, to be just like water might not be water, as it might have the wrong micro-structure. In general, whenever a statement of the form x=y is non-analytic, it is because objects that aren’t x can appear just like x. But it makes no sense to say that something that appeared (felt) just like a pain wasn’t actually a pain. Anything that feels just like a pain is a pain. “Pain is identical with brain state X” would be non-analytic, if it were true. Thus, since what makes it possible for it to be non-analytic that water is H2O 
is that appearing like water is different from being water, and the same thing mutatis mutandis being true of all non-analytic necessities, it follows that “pain is identical with brain state X” is not true. 
5.0 The arguments for materialism 
There are several powerful arguments for materialism. But there is one line of thought that lies at the core of these various arguments. 
5.1 The primary argument for materialism 
It is obvious that mental events create, and otherwise affect, physical events; and it is obvious that physical events create, and otherwise affect, mental events. A hot iron is pressed to your skin (physical event); as a result, you feel pain (mental event). You intend to go to the store (mental event); as a result, you end up going to the store (physical event). You feel nervous (mental event); as a result, your heart races (physical event). 
There is extremely strong evidence to the effect that any physical event is the result only of other physical events. To explain why a person’s body moves a certain way, it is necessary only to know what the strictly physical (neural, muscular, etc.) antecedents of that event are, and it is not necessary to know what its psychological antecedents are. The behavior of a person’s body is no more in need of “mentalistic” explanation than is the behavior of a brick. (Of course, a knowledge of a person’s psychological condition is often sufficient, given knowledge of easy-to-ascertain facts about the external world, for a knowledge of what that person is going to do next. But such knowledge is not necessary: such predictions can, in principle, be made without having any knowledge as to the relevant person’s psychology.) 
Given that every fact about a person’s bodily behavior can be explained in strictly physical terms, we can take one of two positions. We can say either: 
(i) The mental does not, contrary to appearances, have any effects on the body, 
or: 
(ii) The mental does have such effects—and the mental is identical with the physical events that we know to have those effects. 
Since it is very hard to believe that the mental is without effect on the physical, (i) is almost certainly false. Hence (ii) is the right view.[407] 

Evaluating this argument: My own personal view is that this argument is pretty solid; that being why I am a materialist. Others have responded (or, given their positions, would respond) differently to this argument. 
For example, according to epiphenomenalism, even though the physical affects the mental, the mental does not affect the physical. 
But epiphenomenalism is clearly wrong. It’s an empirical datum that the mental affects the physical and vice versa. Should it be denied that this is a datum, or even that it’s true, I would respond by showing that epiphenomenalism is at odds with a fundamental fact about the nature of causation. 
Causation is bidirectional. If my hand affects the table (e.g., if my hand pushes the table), then the table affects my hand. So if, as the epiphenomenalist believes, the physical affected the mental, then the mental would affect the physical. But in that case, epiphenomenalism is false. 
The epiphenomenalist might counter-respond by saying that there are exceptions to the principle of bi-directionality that I’ve been advocating: physical situations create, and have effects on, shadows; but shadows don’t have effects on anything. 
But this move is a non-starter. Mental entities, unlike shadows, really do have causal powers. Even the epiphenomenalist doesn’t deny that they affect one another. Given this fact, along with the fact mental events result from physical events, it follows that some of the energy associated with physical states of affairs is transferred to them. So unless energy is implausibly assumed to vanish from the physical world, never to return, we must assume that the mental can, so to speak, spit it back into the physical world and, therefore, that the mental can affect the physical.[408] 
And, as we’ve seen, once it is granted the mental can affect the physical, it must be granted that the mental is physical. 
5.1.1 Another argument for materialism 
As we’ve seen, the mental clearly affects the physical. If mental entities are subject to physical laws, they are ipso facto physical. (After all, what would it be to be physical, if not to obey physical laws?) And if something obeys physical laws, it is ipso facto physical. What would it mean to say “X obeys the laws of physics —but it isn’t physical”? X is physical iff X obeys physical laws. 
Thus, if mental entities are not physical, they are not subject to physical laws. So if mental entities were non-physical, things that didn’t fall within the scope of physical law would constantly have effects on the physical world, resulting in physical events that couldn’t be explained in terms of physical laws—physical events that were, in fact, violations of physical law. But such violations do not occur. In any case, there is no evidence that they occur, and certainly no evidence that they occur with anything even approaching the frequency with which, if dualism were correct, they would occur.[409] 

5.1.2 A counter-response 
Surely we could imagine physical objects breaking physical laws. We can imagine people sprouting wings and flying—even though, given the structures of our bodies, such events would be violations of physical law. 
5.1.3 A counter-counter-response 
Bertrand Russell said that objects are sequences of events that are governed by physical law. I agree with him.[410] 
If Russell is right, it makes no sense to speak of a physical object that is in violation of all physical laws. So when we imagine a person sprouting wings we are imagining something that is subject to physical laws (albeit laws that are different from those that are actually operative). Second, so far as the objects of one’s thoughts aren’t law-governed, those thoughts involve incoherent or otherwise impoverished views as to the nature of physical law. A defense of this controversial point of view lies outside the scope of the present book. 
5.2 The third argument for materialism—Fodor’s argument[411] 

The mental obviously affects the physical. Anything that affects the physical is ipso facto physical itself. What is there to be physical other than being able to displace mass-energy (or whatever it is that events consist of)? 
5.2.1 Evaluating this argument 
I personally find this argument compelling, and have yet to hear a cogent response to it. 
6.0 The Problems with dual aspect theory, idealism, and eliminativism 
Supposing that the mental and the physical are two aspects of the same thing, we must ask: what is that thing?[412] 
It can’t be mental; for surely the mental is not an aspect of the mental. (My belief that snow is white is not an aspect of itself or of any other mental thing.) And it can’t be physical; for surely the physical is not an aspect of the physical. (The chair is not an aspect of itself or of any other physical thing.) So (3) is either incoherent or it presupposes that there is something spatiotemporal that is not either physical or mental. But it is incoherent to suppose that there is anything spatiotemporal that is not either mental or physical. It follows that (3) is simply incoherent. 
It seems to me that so-called “dual aspect” theorists are really just materialists who have misstated their view. So far as that’s correct, we can forget about (3), and focus on (2). And since we’ve already discussed (2), we can move on to (4). 
(4) is obviously a non-starter. But, for what extremely little it’s worth, here’s the argument behind it. Scientific hypotheses are supposed to deal with things that can be publicly verified. Suppose that scientist Smith insisted that he, and he alone, were able to see (or otherwise sense-perceive) the data that confirmed some hypothesis of his. Obviously Smith wouldn’t be taken seriously. My pains, tickles, etc., cannot be witnessed by anyone other than myself. For this reason, some psychologists who were attempting to scientize their discipline said that such things had no place within science and therefore had no place in a scientific world-view. Given this position, it is a short step to saying that pains, tickles, etc., don’t exist at all. In a word, science deals with what is objective; mental states are subjective; therefore, mental states don’t exist. 
There are many fallacies in this argument. One of them is that, in actuality, the existence of pains, tickles, etc., is easily verified. Of course, you cannot have my pains. But you can have your pains, and you can therefore confirm that pains exist. 
Also, as Searle (1992) points out, that argument involves a failure to distinguish two meanings of the term “subjective.”[413] 
Sometimes, when we describe something as "subjective,” we mean that it is influenced by personal biases. (So and so’s reaction to the incident was extremely subjective—it wasn’t impartial and logical.) But when we say that mental entities are “subjective,” we mean—not that they are biased—but that they must be had in order to exist. There can’t be orphan pains and beliefs floating around: a belief must be somebody’s belief. Mental states thus have, as John Searle puts it, a “first-person ontology.” Obviously science mustn’t be “subjective” (i.e., it mustn’t be biased); but it doesn’t follow that it mustn’t deal with the subjective (i.e., with things having a first-person ontology). In any case, it’s a plain fact that mental entities exist, and eliminativism is a hideous monstrosity to which we shall give no further thought. 
(5) 
is not a view that anyone really holds (even though a few—e.g., George Berkeley, William James, Bertrand Russell—have claimed to do so). 

(5) 
is really more of an epistemological view than it is a view about the relation between body and mind: so far as philosophers advocate (5), it is on the grounds that it is the only viable response to skepticism about the external world. (Skepticism is the focus of Chapter 11 and also of Sections 6.0–8.0 of Chapter 12.) 


7.0 The different versions of materialism: behaviorism 
There are different versions of materialism. Let us now consider them, starting with behaviorism. According to the behaviorist, to believe that 1 + 1 = 2 is to only have a disposition to respond with certain overt behaviors to certain physical stimuli. If when asked “what is 1 + 1?” you say “2”—if, in general, you respond to sensory inputs in ways that are characteristic of a belief that 1 + 1 = 2—then in virtue of that very fact, you believe that 1 + 1 = 
2. In other words, according to the behaviorist, behaving in the right way is believing that 1 + 1 = 2. It isn’t a consequence of such knowledge. It is such knowledge.[414] 

The general definition of behaviorism is this. If M is any mental category, P is an instance of M just in case P is a disposition on the part of some individual to respond with certain overt behaviors to certain sensory inputs. 
Behaviorism is false. How a person reacts to a given sensory input is a function, not only of what that input is, but also of what that person’s existing mental states are. If you don’t speak English, an utterance of “what is 1 + 1?” will not cause you to say “2.” It is only in people who have various pieces of background knowledge (e.g., knowledge of linguistic conventions) that such a disposition corresponds to the knowledge that 1 + 1 = 2. What we said about that particular disposition is true (mutatis mutandis) of any other. By itself, no disposition to engage in a certain kind of overt behavior, given certain stimuli, corresponds to any mental state: what does so is such a disposition plus various pre-existing mental states. So, mental states cannot be reduced to behavioral dispositions. At most, they can be reduced to behavioral dispositions plus various mental states. But this means that they can’t be reduced to behavioral dispositions. 
Aware of these problems with behaviorism, but still wanting to holding onto the idea that mental entities could be dispositionalized (identified with tendencies to respond with certain overt behaviors to certain inputs), many philosophers of mind responded to this by adopting functionalism, which we’ve already discussed and will now discuss further. 

7.1 Functionalism 
Consider the kinds of situations that characteristically give rise to a belief that snow is white (e.g., visual perceptions of white snow), and consider all the thoughts and behaviors that characteristically result from such a belief (e.g., one’s forming the belief that snow is not green). According to the functionalist, for a brain-state to be a belief that snow is white just is for it to have the right causes and effects. So if brain-state B has the right causes and effects, B is ipso facto a belief that snow is white (or a desire to become president or a pain or a feeling of euphoria). According to the functionalist, B’s having those causes and effects isn't evidence of B's being such a belief; nor is it a consequence of B's being such a belief. It is B's being such a belief. 
The functionalist says that, for any mental type M, mental entities are among the characteristic causes and effects of instances of that type. So the functionalist—unlike the behaviorist—allows that among the causes of (e.g.) a belief that snow is white are other mental entities (e.g., perceptions of white snow); and that among the effects of such a belief are other mental entities (e.g., a belief that snow is not green). 
Remember that behaviorism falsely supposes that a person who had no linguistic knowledge would react by saying “2” to an utterance of “what is 1 
+ 1?” and, in general, that behaviorism identifies mental states with dispositions that can be understood in strictly behavioral terms. Functionalism doesn’t run into this problem. Unlike behaviorism, functionalism can (supposedly) accommodate the fact that among the causes and effects of a mental entity are other mental entities. (Why “supposedly”? Keep reading.) 
For something is (e.g.) a belief that snow is white wholly in virtue of its causal role. In general, for any mental category M, there is some causal role C such that x falls into M if and only if x has C. (This statement may not be easy to follow, but there is no simpler, but equally accurate way of saying what functionalism is.) 
7.1.1 Problems with functionalism 
For something to be a pain is for it to feel a certain way—its causal role is secondary. It is true, of course, that pains are likely to have certain causes (kicks to the shins) and certain effects (screaming loudly). But for something to be a pain isn’t for it to have a certain causal role; for something to be a pain is for it to feel a certain way. 
Since it says otherwise, functionalism is wrong. 
There is a related point. Supposing that P is some pain, P’s having a given causal role is a consequence of its being a pain; its being a pain is not a consequence of its having that causal role. Supposing that P is some pain of yours, your writhing and screaming is an effect of P’s being a pain and, contrary to what the functionalist alleges, it thus cannot be constitutive of its being a pain. 
Functionalism says that x is a belief that snow is white iff x has the right causal role. That causal role involves other mental entities. Functionalists know that. So it sounds as though functionalism analyzes the mental into causal role plus the mental. It thus seems questionable whether functionalism really is a form of materialism. 
If cogent, this criticism of functionalism is devastating, given that the whole raison d’être for that doctrine is that it supposedly explains the relationship between mind and body. Functionalists respond by saying that, through judicious use of a technical device known as the “Ramsey sentence,” it can be shown that functionalism does reduce the mental to the physical, while at the same time doing justice to the fact that, given any arbitrary mental type M, instances of M may have other mental entities for their causes and effects. Here is their reasoning (this is a paraphrase, not a quotation): 
(RS)[415] 
We must distinguish the concept of all from the concept of any. Among the causes and/or effects of practically every given mental entity are (a) other mental entities and (b) strictly physical inputs (e.g., photons striking one’s retinas) and strictly behavioral outputs (e.g., one’s reaching for the glass). But even though any given mental entity is to be understood in terms of other mental entities, nonetheless the totality of a person’s mental entities can be understood entirely in terms of strictly physical inputs and strictly behavioral outputs. Let MS (short for “mental sentence”) be a single, very large sentence that says, for any given mental kind (e.g., belief that snow is white, dread of visiting one’s mother in law, etc.), what the causes and effects of instances of that kind are. MS is going to contain “constants”: it will contain expressions, such as “dread of going jogging in the morning,” that refer to kinds of mental entities. Given any such expression, replace it with a variable. The result will be an open sentence (an expression that contains a free variable but is otherwise just like a sentence). Bind the occurrences of that variable in that open sentence with an existential quantifier. Do the same thing mutatis mutandis for each occurrence of any expression that refers to a mental kind. But don’t do it for any of the expressions that refer to physical kinds. The result will be a sentence that completely describes the causes and effects of instances of each mental kind, but that does so without using any expressions that refer to anything mental. The mental will thus be completely described in terms of the physical. But that sentence will do justice to the fact that mental events cause other mental events to occur, and it will do justice to the precise way in which they do so. 
By saying that causal role fixes content, RS makes content too brittle: any deviations of any kind between any two mental states ipso facto amount to differences in content. No two mental entities have exactly the same causal roles. (There isn’t anything in your mind that has exactly the same causal role as my belief that 2 is an even prime. There isn’t anything in any person’s mind that has exactly the same causal role as anything in anyone else’s mind.) It follows that, if RS is right, no two people can believe that 1 + 1 = 2 or that Mongolia is in Asia, etc. Since that is obviously false, so is RS. 
A story may clarify this point. Both Smith and Jones believe that snow is white. Smith is a physicist who focuses on the reflective properties of white surfaces. Jones doesn’t know anything about physics. Obviously the functional role of Smith’s belief that snow is white will be very different from that of Jones’ corresponding belief. But if, as functionalism holds, a brain-state’s being a belief that snow is white just is its having a certain functional role, then presumably one person’s belief that snow is white shouldn’t be able to differ, at least not too drastically, from another person’s belief that snow is white. 

7.1.2 The main problem with functionalism 
It is not objects, but states of affairs, that have causal properties. What shatters the window is not the rock—it is rather the rock’s moving with a certain velocity, in a certain direction, etc. Similarly, if B is the brain-state that realizes your belief that (e.g.) water quenches thirst, it isn’t B that causes things to happen—it is B’s having these or those properties. According to functionalism, B’s being identical with a belief that water quenches thirst is identical with B’s having certain causes and effects—it is identical with (e.g.) its causing you to drink water when thirsty. But if B’s being identical with that belief is identical with B’s causing you to drink water (when thirsty), then B’s being such a belief cannot cause such behavior. Cause and effect must be distinct: if x causes y, then x is not identical with y (and neither is a part of the other). So if functionalism is correct, then the fact that you believe that water quenches thirst cannot cause you to do things like drink water when thirsty. Thus, if functionalism is right, then your belief that water quenches thirst does nothing. 
Given any other behavior that we know to be caused by the existence of a certain kind of mental entity, an analogous argument shows that, if functionalism is right, such an entity cannot possibly cause that behavior. Setting aside cases of linguistic incompetence and insincerity, utterances of “snow is white" are caused by, among other things, beliefs to the effect that snow is white. Functionalism says that there is some brain-state B such that that B’s being a belief that snow is white is identical with, among other things, B’s causing that person to utter those words. But if B’s being such a belief is identical with its causing that utterance, then B’s being such a belief cannot cause that utterance to occur. So functionalism strips the mental of any causal powers. Given that the mental does have causal powers, it follows that functionalism is wrong. 
8.0 Conclusion of this Chapter 
The main argument for materialism: Mind and body interact. Such interactions seem not to involve violations of physical law. Given these two facts, it seems likely that materialism is correct. 
The main argument for dualism: Our experiences don't seem to be anything like brain-states or physical entities of any other sort. So, if they are brain-states, it is because we experience them as being very different from how they really are. But it makes no sense to suppose that we experience our experiences; and it therefore makes no sense to suppose that we experience them as being different from how they are. So, given that we experience them as being totally unlike physical entities, they must really be totally unlike physical entities. 
The argument for materialism strikes me as being slight more compelling than the argument for dualism. But second argument is hard to dismiss. It seems to show that there is something distinctive about the relationship between mind and body---that the former is not to the latter what the biological is to the chemical or what the chemical is to the physical. Given these facts, I conclude that materialism is correct, but also that the truths described by psychological statements are, for some reason other, completely and utterly incapable of being understood in terms of the truths described by physicalistic statements. In Chapter 21, I tried to explain exactly why this is so. 
Chapter 23 The Computational Theory of Mind: Progressing Towards a Scientific Psychology or Regressing to Pre-Scientific Animism? 
1.0 Introduction 
These days, a doctrine known as the “Computational Theory of Mind” (CTM) is very popular, both among scholars (especially philosophers and computer scientists) and among the laity. CTM is a form of materialism, for reasons that will become clear. 
Because of its liberal and confident use of words such as “compute” and “algorithm”, CTM has an impressive sheen of rigor, and one would think that this doctrine would be informed by the same intellectual progressiveness that led to the creation and subsequent development of computer science. But we will find that, ironically, CTM involves a regression to archaic, animistic forms of thought and, more specifically, that it represents the recrudescence of the primitive and obviously spurious thinking that the grumbling of thunder represents the wrath of the gods. 
Speaking more philosophically and less psychoanalytically, we’ll find that CTM involves some basic ratiocinative failings. For example, CTM embodies an ignorance of the fact that it is not objects, but events that have effects. These events often involve objects. But objects per se cause nothing. The rock didn't break the window; what did so was the rock’s striking the window. Also, we’ll find that, if CTM were true, we couldn’t know it to be true and couldn’t have any legitimate reason to advocate it. 
1.1 What is CTM? 
According to CTM, to think is to compute. Thoughts are computations. A computation is a formal inference. So CTM is the view that any instance of thought is identical with the making of a formal inference. 
But what is a “formal” inference? To qualify as “formal,” a case of reasoning must be identical with a reaction, on the part of some creature or other, to symbolic-inputs. But not all such reactions qualify as cases of formal reasoning: only those reactions so qualify that aren’t to any degree driven by the knowledge of the meanings of the symbol-tokens in question and are driven entirely by a sensitivity to their forms. So CTM is the contention that thought consists of responses to symbol-tokens that are driven entirely by the formal properties of those tokens and therefore embody no knowledge of what those symbol-tokens mean. In Section 1.2, we’ll give some examples of such responses, thereby eliminating any obscurity from the statement just made. 
Why advocate CTM? Two reasons. First, CTM, if correct, solves the mind-body problem. When you add two numbers, you are ipso facto thinking. Computers presumably add numbers. (Computers presumably compute.) Therefore, computers, when adding numbers, are ipso facto thinking. We know how a computer’s software is related to its hardware. So CTM, if correct, solves the mind-body problem. (In other words, CTM, if correct, makes it clear how brains are responsible for the mental activity that they mediate.) 
Second, CTM, if correct, solves the “tracking problem” (or so CTM-advocates say and so we’ll momentarily assume). Brain-activity, though clearly 100% physics-driven, is also logic-driven (or, in any case, logic-consistent), at least to the extent that it mediates rational thought. So, to the extent that it’s constitutive of rational thought, brain-activity, though governed by descriptive laws, embodies sensitivity to prescriptive laws: where such activity is concerned, the descriptive “tracks” the prescriptive. Nothing that is obeying the laws of physics is, in virtue of that fact, doing anything that can be evaluated---that can be described as “correct” or “valid” or “false.” (In moving hither as opposed to thither, the billiard ball isn’t doing anything right or wrong, valid or invalid.) And, it seems to follow that nothing that can be so described could be constituted by brain-activity. But brain-activity does constitute activity that can be so described. 
CTM (supposedly) solves this problem. It’s possible to create an environment in which there occur symbol-tokens whose logical properties are hewed to their physical properties in such a way that, within that environment, symbol-tokens occur in sequences that are consistent with the requirements of logic. In fact, not only is it possible to create such environments: we routinely do create them—and employ them. We call them “computers.” So it would seem that CTM, if correct, explains how activity that falls within the scope of physics can, at the same time, embody a sensitivity to the demands of logic and, more generally, of normativity. 
1.2 Mentalese: the “language of thought” 
According to CTM-advocates, those symbol-tokens mediating our thoughts are held to belong to a hypothetical language. This hypothetical language is generally referred to as “Mentalese.” 
According to CTM, one doesn’t have to learn Mentalese. Brains are computers. Computers don’t function until they’ve been programmed. Therefore, our brains don’t function until they’ve been programmed. Mentalese is that program. Thus, Mentalese must be programmed into a brain before that brain can mediate cognitive activity, and therefore before that brain’s owner can learn a language or, indeed, do anything that involves having any awareness of anything. Mentalese is to a functioning brain what a computer’s operating system is to that computer. Thus, just as your IBM came “bundled” with DOS, so your brain came “bundled” with Mentalese. 
In light of what we’ve said, it might seem reasonable to say that, according to CTM, one innately knows Mentalese. But if CTM is right, one doesn’t know Mentalese at all, let alone innately. Knowing a language involves being able to correlate linguistic with non-linguistic entities. If I couldn’t correlate snow (the powdery substance) with “snow” (the word), I couldn’t possibly know what “snow” meant. In order to correlate “snow” with snow, I must have some way of being aware of snow that doesn’t involve knowing what “snow” means. Knowing Mentalese would involve being able to correlate the expressions belonging to it with non-linguistic entities. According to CTM, thoughts are identical with Mentalese expression-tokens, and such expressions must therefore be operational if one is to make correlations or, therefore, to know a language. 
So if CTM is right, a precondition for one's being aware of anything is that one's brain be stocked with already operational Mentalese symbol-tokens. So it isn’t by virtue of one’s knowing Mentalese that expression-tokens belonging to it mediate one’s thoughts or otherwise do what CTM-advocates allege them to do. So nobody knows Mentalese and nobody understands the expressions belonging to it. Therefore, it isn’t by being understood that such expression-tokens facilitate thought. 
In this respect, Mentalese is radically different from English and every other non-hypothetical language. Expression-tokens belonging to English, Urdu, etc. do not facilitate thought except by being understood. By contrast, the symbol-tokens of Mentalese, supposing such tokens to exist, need not be understood to facilitate thought. Indeed, it is inherent in what Mentalese expression-tokens are that they be able to discharge all of their duties without being understood to any degree by anyone or anything. 
Because Mentalese, were it to exist, would differ in this respect from English, Spanish, and other bona fidelanguages, it follows (for reasons to be discussed in Section 4.0) that the very concept of a “language of thought” is not a coherent one. Given that CTM assumes there to be a language of thought, and given that (for reasons to be disclosed in Section 4.0) no doctrine that doesn’t assume this bears any resemblance to CTM, it follows that CTM is incoherent. 
1.3 The concept of a formal inference: Some illustrations 
We’ve seen, if correct, CTM explains much. But is it correct? We can’t answer that unless we make it clear what, in this context, the word “compute” means. And we can’t make that clear unless we make it clear what, in this context, it means to say of symbolic activity that it is “form-driven.” 
The following three stories will help answer these questions. 
Story #1 (not an example of computation): Smith, who speaks English, is told: “Jones has two yachts.” On the basis of this information, along with his knowledge of the English language, Smith concludes that the following sentence is correct: “the number n such that Jones has n yachts is such that n has no rational square root.” 
Commentary on Story #1: Smith’s reasoning is cogent. But it is not in any sense “formal.” Smith’s thought process was a driven by an understanding of inter alia the meanings of the words he was hearing. 
Story #2 (an example of a kind of computation): Wooden tokens of the expressions “2,” “+,”“9,” and “=” are fed, in that order, into wood chipper W. Driven solely by the morphological properties of those symbol-tokens, W cranks out a wooden “11.” And given any wooden-token of a sentence-fragment beginning with an operator flanked by two numerals and ending with the sign for equality, W does the same thing mutatis mutandis. 
Commentary: There would seem to be a sense in which W can compute sums. It is typically this sense of the word “compute” that advocates of CTM have in mind when they say that to think is to compute. Why only “typically”? Why not “always”? Because sometimes what they have in mind is the prima facie quite different sense of the word “compute” that is illustrated in the following section. 
Story #3 (an example of a different kind of computation): Smith has no idea what “1,245,” “241,” “1,486,” etc. mean. But Smith has been told by a source whose testimony he rightly trusts that, when given ink-marks having such and such shapes, a correct sentence results when another ink-mark, having thus and such a shape, is placed in a certain position relative to the original ink-marks. In particular, Smith knows that, given their respective shapes, the ink-marks “1,486” and “1,245 + 241 =” form a correct sentence when (some isomorph of) the former is placed to the right of (some isomorph of) the latter. It must be emphasized that Smith has no idea what any of these ink-marks mean. Smith knows nothing of relevance to this situation other than the rules as to how certain shapes ought to be manipulated or complemented. Those rules in fact describe how to do sums involving multi-digit numbers. But Smith doesn't know that. He knows only that, when given ink-marks having such and such a shape, another ink-mark must be placed beneath them if a true statement (as to whose identity he is quite ignorant) is to result. 
Commentary: What Smith is doing seems to be different from what W is doing. Smith’s applying the just-mentioned rule involves his having various sense-perceptions (e.g., he sees various ink-deposits) and various beliefs (e.g., he believes that those ink-marks are symbols of some kind or other, and he believes that a correct statement, albeit one of whose meaning he is ignorant, will result if, underneath them, he produces an ink-mark having a certain shape); and his having such beliefs involves his making quite delicate judgments (e.g., he must judge that the ink-deposits in question were produced by sentient beings with certain intentions---he would not see those ink-deposits as tokening the sentence-fragment “1,245 + 241 =” were he to learn that their existence was the unintended result of some explosion involving an ink-filled urn). 
Nothing comparable holds of W. It isn’t because of any sense-perceptions or beliefs or intentions on its part that, having been fed a wooden token of the sentence-fragment “2 + 9 =” W spits out a wooden “11.” So what Smith is doing in writing a “1,486” seems not to be comparable to what W is doing in spitting out a wooden “11.” 
And, while there is certainly a sense of the word “compute” in which Smith is computing a sum, this cannot possibly be the sense in which, according to CTM, to think is to compute. A precondition for Smith’s performing the just-described computation is his already being able to upload and process information. So CTM would be guilty of vicious circularity were it given by the thesis that, in this sense of the word “compute” to think is to compute. So, supposing CTM coherent, the sense in which to think is to compute is the sense in which W computes, and the sense in which Smith computes is irrelevant. 
We will now see that CTM is indefensible and that no doctrine at all similar to it can possibly be correct. There are five reasons for this. These reasons will given in Sections 2.0-6.0. 
2.0 CTM’s failure to distinguish between shape and syntactic form 
A story will help expose one reason why CTM is false. You shout the following at me: “if your nose starts to bleed in the next ten seconds, I’ll give you a million bucks.” Let T be the sentence-token in question. As a result of T’s being uttered, I do start to bleed out of my noise, and you duly give me $1,000,000. But it wasn’t because of what T meant that I had a nose-bleed; nor was it because of T’s syntax. It was T’s being loud that caused my nose­bleed. 
My reaction here wasn’t symbolic. Even though T is a symbol (or, to be precise, a symbol-token), T’s being a symbol did nothing. For exactly similar reasons, W’s spitting out an “11” isn’t symbolic, even though its doing so was precipitated by events involving symbol-tokens. 
2.1 This line of reasoning generalized 
We’ve just seen that CTM is a non-starter if a symbol-token’s “form” is identified with its shape. But sometimes, when referring to a symbol-token’s “form,” advocates of CTM are (so they say) referring to its syntactic form. Given this use of the word “form,” CTM becomes the contention that thoughts are syntax-driven operations on symbols. 
This contention is easily refuted. Syntax is semantic structure. “Smith loves Mary” and “Sally hates Greg” have the same syntax because the semantics of the one has the same structure as the semantics of the other. 
To be sure, those sentences have very different meanings. But they’re semantically isomorphic. Each constituent of the one sentence corresponds to exactly one constituent of the other (“Smith,” “loves,” and Mary” correspond to “Sally,” “hates,” and “Greg,” respectively); and the relationship borne by the semantics of any given constituent of the one sentence to the semantics of that sentence as a whole coincides with the relationship borne by the semantics of that constituent’s counterpart in the other sentence to the semantics of that sentence as a whole. So the relation borne by the semantics of “Smith” with respect to the proposition that Smith loves Mary coincides with the relation borne by “Sally” to the proposition that Sally hates Greg. 
Given that syntax is semantic structure, syntax-driven operations are ipso facto meaning-driven. Being the contention that “formal” operations are not meaning-driven, CTM is therefore completely incoherent if taken to be the contention that “formal” operations are syntax-driven operations. 
At the same time, CTM is incoherent, as we saw, if “formal” operations are taken to be shape-driven operations. There is no third way to interpret the word “formal.” So CTM is incoherent. 
2.2 Shape vs. syntax (revisited): The equivocation that lies at the heart of CTM 
Here is the thinking embodied in CTM: 
Form-driven responses to symbolic inputs are ipso facto cases of thought. W has form-driven responses to symbolic inputs. Therefore, W is thinking (it is adding numbers). 
But when this argument is stated in a clear and non-elliptical manner, it becomes clear that it involves an equivocation and is invalid for that reason: 
Form-driven responses to symbolic inputs are ipso facto cases of thought. (In other words, syntax-driven responses to symbol-tokens are ipso facto cases of thought.) W has form-driven responses to symbolic inputs. (In other words, W’s responses to its inputs are morphology-driven.) Therefore W is thinking. 
The second argument is clearly spurious. Presumably because they are aware of this, advocates of CTM typically hold that, even though a symbol­token’s shape isn’t identical with its morphology, syntax can be “coded” into morphology---that syntax can be “morphologized” in much the way that geometry can be arithmetized. This is both false and irrelevant. 
It’s false because anything, no matter what its shape, can have any syntactic structure, and anything, no matter what its syntactic structure, can be tokened by anything, no matter what its shape. (In other words, given an arbitrary shape, and given an arbitrary syntactic structure, there is a possible language to which there belong expressions having that syntactic structure that are tokened by objects having that shape.) It’s irrelevant because, even if syntax can be morphologized, it isn’t, as we’ve already seen, in virtue of its having this as opposed to that shape that a symbol-token has this as opposed to that syntax. So in so far as one is responding to an object’s shape, one’s behavior is, to that extent, not the effect of, or otherwise to be understood in terms of, that object’s shape. 
To be sure, one knows what syntax an object has on the basis of its shape. A large part of the reason that I know the syntax of the following sentence­token---“John is tall and grass is green”---is that I know what shape that ink-deposit has. But sentence-tokens with precisely the same syntax can be tokened by hand-movements or by noises; and hand-movements and noises have no strictly morphological resemblance at all to any ink-deposit. (No ink-deposit that tokens “John is tall and grass is green” bears much resemblance to a stream of noises, or a series of hand-movements, that also tokened that same sentence, except relative to rules of projection that were contrived ex post facto to establish such a resemblance.) 
Also, the relationship that holds between (a) my knowledge of that ink­deposit’s shape and (b) my knowledge of its syntax is of a causal, and not of a constitutive, nature. I see that it has that shape. Given that knowledge, along with my background linguistic knowledge, I judge that it has a certain syntax. 
To be sure, from an experiential (phenomenological) perspective, it may seem as though in knowing that it has that shape I ipso facto know that it has that syntax. But that’s not the case. What we have is one bit of knowledge (knowledge of shape) leading, by way of (rapid) judgments, to some other bit of knowledge (knowledge of syntax). 
Echoing what we just said, these two bits of knowledge may seem, at the level of consciousness, to come into existence simultaneously. But that appearance is misleading and, even if not misleading, irrelevant. It’s misleading because any knowledge of an object’s syntax must follow knowledge of its physical properties. To clarify these last two statements: If I judge that you’re angry, it’s on the basis of your facial expression, or some such. My judgment as to your emotional state may immediately follow my awareness of your expression. But given that the former is based on the latter and is also caused by it, the one awareness follows the other, however quickly. Exactly similar points hold of the relationship between my knowledge of a given object’s physical shape and my subsequent knowledge of its syntax: it isn’t possible for me to have the latter knowledge without having the former; it is possible for me to have the former without having the latter; and my knowledge of the former is the sole foundation for, and is also what leads to, my knowledge of the latter. 
Plus, it’s irrelevant that, speaking from a strictly experiential (phenomenological) perspective, the occurrence of the one bit of knowledge seems to coincide with the occurrence of the other. It is the purpose, or at the very least the effect, of consciousness to condense the intricacies of the cognitions underlying it into a single, seemingly homogeneous “experience.” 
If every articulation of pre-conscious cognition were faithfully represented in consciousness, if phenomenology faithfully duplicated every joint in the intricacies of the cognitions of which our conscious judgments are the outcomes, then consciousness would be so overburdened with information that it would cease to be able to perform the executive functions with which it is tasked. When seeing a rabid dog run towards me, my consciousness would present to me a richly articulated mosaic of judgments, whose consequences for my well-being would take much more time to figure out than was available to me. Fortunately, however, my consciousness presents me with a homogenous feeling that causes me to bolt into action. Instead of giving me the psychological equivalent of a two-hundred page state-department report, consciousness gives me the equivalent of an electric cattle-prod in my back. And because the rich cognitive back-story is telescoped into that unpleasant burst of phenomenology, I do the right thing. (I run to the mini-van, lock the doors, roll up the windows, and so on.) And I do it in real time. 
In general, it is precisely because consciousness represents as homogenous “feelings” what are in fact intricate networks of judgments that the contents of consciousness, unlike their cognitive underpinnings, are actionable. It is, I would conjecture, the very purpose, or at least one of the purposes, of consciousness to condense cognitive intricacies into affective simplicities. Therefore, it is inter alia its purpose to condense distinct, albeit adjacent, stages of intricate thought processes into a single, action-causing, survival-ensuring feeling. 
In any case, if this is at all on the mark, then it’s of no relevance that my recognition of the ink-deposit’s shape seems to be temporally coincident with my recognition of its syntax. It is to be pointed out that, if this isn’t on the mark, then much work in psychology crumbles. 
3.0 A related point: CTM incompatible with the fact that distinct thoughts can be part of some one thought-process 
If CTM is right, my thinking 2 is a prime number and 2 is less than three cannot be responsible for my later thinking some prime number is less than three. According to CTM, if B1 is the totality of brain-events constitutive of 
my thinking 2 is a prime number and 2 is less than three, and B2 is the 
totality of brain-events constitutive of my thinking some prime number is less than three, it cannot be B1’s being such a belief that brings about B2. So it cannot be B1’s being such a belief that leads me to believe that some prime number is less than three. 
So, if CTM is right, B1’s being such a belief has nothing to do with B2’s existence or a fortiori with B2’s being constitutive of a thought to the effect that some prime number is less than three. Thus, my believing that two is even and is less than three cannot, if CTM is right, have anything to do with my later believing that some even prime is less than three. So, if CTM is right, T1 has nothing to do with T2, notwithstanding that the brain-events 
constitutive of T1 brought about those constitutive of T2. 
So even though B1 occurs right before B2 and is causally responsible for it, and even though B1 and B2 are constitutive of, respectively, T1 and T2, nonetheless T1 and T2 cannot, if CTM is right, be installments in some one thought-process. 
In general, CTM is incompatible with the fact that distinct thoughts can be part of some one thought-process. CTM is thus incompatible with the fact that thought-processes occur---with the fact that there are sequences of thoughts (setting aside such thought-sequences whose constituents have no thematic coherence, having at best the content-free coherence had by a series of domino-fallings). 
4.0 CTM’s dependence on the false assumption that syntax can mirror logical form 
Context-sensitivity drives a wedge between syntax and logical form. If I say: 
(1) "it is snowing now and it is not snowing now," 
what I'm saying might be true---it might stop snowing before I utter the second conjunct---even though it has the same syntax as: 
(2) 
"n is even and n is not even." Similarly, if I say: 

(3) 
"that guy is identical with that guy," 


what I'm saying might be false, even though it has that same syntax as 
(4) "n is identical with n." 
If our thinking were syntax-driven, we couldn't recognize the differences in respect of logical form between (1) and (2) or between (3) and (4). We can recognize those differences. So our thinking is not syntax-driven. So CTM is wrong. 
Here is a similar line of thought. If, on July 1, 2010, in Richmond, VA, I say: 
(i) "right now, Jim is three thousand miles from here," 
the information encoded in my utterance is very different that encoded in an utterances of: 
(ii) "On July 1, 2010, Jim is 3,000 miles from Richmond VA." 
The information encoded in (i) doesn't follow from the information encoded in (ii), or vice versa. In general, when the context-sensitive expressions in a true statement are replaced with context-insensitive expressions, the result is a statement that, although true, neither entails the first statement nor follows from it. 
For an expression to be context-sensitive is for its referent to vary with the context. What an expression refers to is determined by its semantics, not its syntax. CTM says that thought is to no degree semantics-driven. If that were true, we couldn't grasp perspectival truths, such as that expressed by (i). Since we can grasp such truths, CTM is false. 
5.0 CTM’s reliance on the erroneous assumption that there are minimal units of thought 
First a definition: a “morpheme” is an expression that cannot be decomposed into others. Bearing this in mind, let’s suppose that, just as CTM says, we think in a language. In that case, our concepts are identical with expressions. Linguistic expressions consist of morphemes. (Any given complex expression; e.g., “the cat is on the mat,” decomposes into expressions that cannot, in their turn, be further decomposed; (e.g., “cat,” “mat”). So in contending that our thoughts are identical with (tokens of) Mentalese symbols, CTM is, in effect, assuming that we have simple concepts: concepts that cannot be decomposed in others. So CTM, if correct, entails that any given thought that one has can be decomposed into “simple” concepts. CTM thus has the radically implausible consequence that we have “simple” concepts. In other words, CTM has the consequence that some of our concepts are no more capable of being decomposed into other concepts than a morpheme (e.g., the word “cat”) can be decomposed into other expressions. If this consequence of CTM is correct, it follows, as we’ll now see, that some of our concepts would be such that one could have them without also having other concepts. 
Let T be the token of the Mentalese word for “snow” that went off when, just a moment ago, I thought to myself that snow is white. We may assume that T is a morpheme. (If, for some reason, you reject that assumption, just map what we say about T onto some Mentalese expression-token that, in your judgment, is a morpheme—and you must, if you grant that we think in a language, grant that there is some such token, since morpheme-less language is a surd---and everything that we say about T will hold mutatis mutandis of this other expression-token.) Not being decomposable into other expression-tokens, T presumably exists independently of such tokens. Given any simple expression—given any morpheme—belonging to a language L, you can remove that morpheme without removing other morphemes. Of course, in removing that morpheme, you’ll remove all of the expressions of which it is a constituent. (And, if you choose a non-lexical item; e.g., “and” or “of,” you may thus do a lot of damage to L.) But you won’t, in removing that morpheme, be removing other morphemes. 
Supposing that CTM is right, some of our concepts must be identical with morphemes of Mentalese. Taken together with the points just made, this entails that 
(i) If you strip Mentalese of the word-type of which T is a token, the only other expressions which, in so doing, you’ll be removing from Mentalese will be other morphemes, 
and also that: 
(ii) Some of our concepts are such that one can have them without having others. This means that, if CTM is right, your concept of snow is primitive, the same being true of your concept of Smith, Jones, and Brown (assuming, for argument’s sake, that the Mentalese expressions for these individuals are morphemic). 
5.1 CTM’s reliance on the erroneous assumption that there are minimal units of thought (continued)
