Setting aside people who are simply deluded (e.g., people who believe that joining cult X,a precondition for which is wire-transferring their life-savings to the Master’s Swiss Bank account, is the royal road to self-actualization), when people say that performing self-diminishing acts (e.g., working at a soup-kitchen) has "value," they may be speaking the truth; for what they are saying is that performing such acts, though not intrinsically valuable, is valuable in that it consolidates value-systems that are instrumental in preserving and augmenting agency in general. 
3.0 Minds . Selves 
In this section I will make some points about the difference between minds and selves. What I say in this section will be obscure, and I will provide little or no argumentation for it. The contents of this section will be both clarified and justified in the sections following it. 
All selves are minds, but not all minds are selves. A self is a mind that is an agent. An agent is a mind that acts, and doesn’t just react. In order for a mind to be capable of acting, instead of just reacting, that mind must do more than simply facilitate the gratification of primal urges; it must do more than provide the organism with information concerning the external world that makes it clear how, without being killed or injured, that organism can eat, sleep, etc. A mind whose only objectives are to gratify such urges, and in which the sole purpose of knowledge is to enable such urges to be gratified, merely reacts, in light of the knowledge that it has, to the directives of instinct. Such a mind does not act. It does not itself do anything. It merely reacts to instinctual pressures. 
These reactions are not blind. The exact nature of these reactions is conditioned by the knowledge stored in that mind. But non-blind reactions are not actions; and given an organism of the just-mentioned kind, that organism’s self does nothing. It has no self, as we’ll see; and its instincts, not its non­existent self, are the real agents. The behaviors in which the organism engages are compulsive responses to instinct. They are therefore not acts. Put another way, so far as those behaviors are acts, they are not acts on the organism’s part, but rather on the part of its instincts. 
The organism’s mind doesn’t act. Its only function is to determine, in light of its knowledge of the external world, what exact form the organism’s instinct-directed behaviors must take if those behaviors are not to lead to the organism’s being injured or killed. Such a mind’s function is not to act, but only to ensure that the organism’s reactions to its instincts don’t run afoul of the forces at work in the external world. 
3.1 Minds . Selves (continued) 
A self is a mind that has values; it is a self whose behaviors are driven beliefs as to what is of value. Value-driven acts often involve the gratification of instinctual urges; indeed, if value-driven acts systematically make it impossible for such urges to be gratified, the value-system underlying those acts is not a viable one. Nonetheless, a self is a mind that permits the organism housing it to behave in a given way only if, in its judgment, that behavior is in compliance with some value. Of course, its judgments as to what is of value are, and should be, heavily influenced by its knowledge of what will permit the gratification of primal urges. But what is relevant is that, in an organism that has a self, as opposed to a mere mind, it is judgments as to what is of value that lead to behavior; and it is not, except in the indirect sense just described, urges per se that do so. 
It follows that selves act. Of course, creatures that are selves sometimes merely react. But it isn’t as a self a creature reacts. (I am a tennis player. But it isn’t as a tennis player that I am writing this book.) 
3.2 Minds . Selves (continued) 
A story will help us move forward. Smith is a sapient being. (It doesn’t matter whether Smith is human or not.) Smith can make judgments as to how it must act in order to discharge its instinctual energies. Like all judgments, these judgments involve knowledge of principles. So there must be principles that Smith is aware of and that guide Smith’s thinking. But given an arbitrary one of these principles, Smith doesn’t know that he has knowledge of that principle. 
One day, however, Smith becomes aware of at least some of the principles that guide his thought. (How Smith could come to have this second-order knowledge is discussed in Sections 5.0-6.2 of the present chapter. Let “P” stand for an arbitrary one of the principles that Smith thereby comes to know himself to know. Let us assume that Smith has these realizations at time t. (Though they’re experienced as mere feelings, embodied in these responses are rational judgments as to what to do, given what Smith’s objectives are (instinct-gratification) and given what he knows about the circumstances. We must distinguish the instinctual response per se from the conscious experiences that merely represent it, much as the icons on your desktop must be distinguished from the patterns of electrical activity to which they correspond.) Before he knew that he had knowledge of P, Smith obviously couldn’t make judgments of the form: my judgment that such and such is consistent with my knowledge of P. Prior to time t, Smith’s judgments were indeed guided by a knowledge of P; but he obviously could not, as of yet, make judgments as to whether his thinking was being properly guided by his knowledge of P. (One’s thinking can be misdirected by one’s knowledge of a legitimate principle. This may happen either because one’s auxiliary assumptions are wrong (e.g., knowing that gross disparities in wealth lead to injustice and are themselves unjust, but not knowing that certain ways of eliminating such disparities may lead to even greater injustices, President Jones destroys the economy in his attempt to redistribute wealth) or because one’s ability to deploy one’s knowledge of the principle in question has been blunted by garden-variety performance-inhibiting factors, such as fatigue and lack of memories.) But, as of time t, Smith can form judgments as to whether the manner in which he arrives at judgments is consistent with P. He is thus aware of a norm from which his thinking mustn’t deviate; and, when such deviations occur, he can make judgments as to their nature and extent. He can thus evaluate his own judgments. And his evaluation of them is positive (negative) to the extent that, to his knowledge, they (fail to) comply with P. 
Integral to the argument just put forth is a delicate but important distinction. There is a big difference between being aware of a principle and being aware that one is aware of it. A talented athlete’s behavior embodies awareness of principles that the athlete doesn’t know himself to be aware of. The point being made here is not that his behavior accords with some principle of which, at every cognitive level, he is ignorant. It is that, although a knowledge of a given principle may be what is guiding that behavior, the athlete in question may not be aware of that fact and, indeed, is exceedingly unlikely to be. 
Philosophers and psychologists often regard an act as being entirely “mechanical” if it isn’t guided by knowledge that the agent can articulate. But it is only when one has second-order knowledge----knowledge as to what it is that one knows---that one can articulate what one knows; and philosophers are therefore likely to regard behaviors that fail to embody second-order knowledge as failing to embody any knowledge and, therefore, as being entirely unprincipled. In fact, one needs a certain amount of verbal dexterity in addition to such second-order knowledge if one is to be able to articulate the grounds on which they make practically any one of the decisions that they make. 
Of course, in saying “snow is white," I am not affirming my knowledge that I know that snow is white; I am talking about snow, not about my own mind. But, in producing that utterance, I am expressing the fact that I know that snow is white. And one could very easily know that snow is white without knowing that one knows it. One can know that snow is white without having the concept of knowledge. But one must have that concept to know that one knows that snow is white. So knowledge of P is different from, and needn’t involve, knowledge that one has knowledge of P. Also, by virtue of having a concept of knowledge, one has various concepts---e.g., belief, truth, mental activity---not had by an otherwise comparable creature that doesn’t have the concept of knowledge. 
3.3 Minds . Selves (continued) 
Now endowed with knowledge, not just of P, but of the fact that he has knowledge of P, Smith doesn’t react to situations; he reacts to his reactions to situations. Given a situation, he instinctively makes a judgment. Aware that his judgment must comply with P, he makes a second judgment. This second judgment doesn’t concern the situation in question, at least not directly; it concerns his initial judgment concerning that situation. It concerns the extent to which his initial judgment is consistent with the principles his knowledge of which eventuated in it. 
Assuming there to be any cognitive dimension to it at all, one’s response to any given situation is ipso facto principle-driven. But that, by itself, isn’t enough for that response to be an action, as opposed to a reaction. Actions are behaviors that result from judgments about judgments. Confronted with a situation, one makes an initial judgment. One may then make a judgment as to whether that initial judgment was consistent with the principles guiding it. In other words, having made an initial judgment, one may evaluate that initial judgment. One is acting, as opposed to reacting, if one’s behavior expresses such an evaluation. One is reacting, as opposed to acting, if one’s behavior expresses one’s initial judgment. 
There is no self where there is no ability to act---where there is no agency. There is no agency, where there is no self. There is no self where there is no self-evaluation. 
To put this last point in a way that, in addition to being more precise, doesn’t make it seem viciously circular: there is no self where there are no judgments as to the integrity of other, co-corporeal judgments. 
Where there are such judgments, there are values. To approve of (criticize) a judgment (or anything else) is to judge it to have (lack) some value that it ought to have. 
What directly leads to a bona fideaction is never a desire and is always an attitude of approval towards a desire. Where there are no values, there is no approval or disapproval. So where there are no values, there is no agency. 
4.0 Co-corporeal, informationally integrated mental states enough for a mind, but not for a self 
Anything that has the cognitive wherewithal to have a series of mental states ipso facto has a mind. But there is more to having a self than there is to being capable of having a series of mental states. Consider Smith as he is before time t. Each of his mental states could be understood on its own terms: as a reaction to immediate stimuli. Each of those reactions may have been intelligent. (In other words, each resulted from cogent reasoning as to how to discharge the relevant instincts, given the available information about the environment.) And, supposing that they were intelligent, each was more likely than not to incorporate the information encoded in previously occurring, co-corporeal mental states. So, if we think of Smith’s pre-t mind as a series of links in a chain of events (or conditions), the links in that chain are bound together not merely by virtue of being co-corporeal and not merely, therefore, by virtue of the earlier being partly causally responsible for the existence of the later ones, but by virtue of the fact that (in at least some cases) the former ones bequeathed the information encoded to them to the later ones and, therefore, that it was as mental entities that the earlier ones (in some cases) had a hand in determining the contents of the later ones. 
4.1 Co-corporeal, informationally integrated mental states enough for a mind, but not for a self (continued) 
Still, co-corporeality, even when coupled with content-transmission, isn’t enough for self-hood: supposing that M1…Mn is a series of co-corporeal mental states such that, for each i and j, (1 =i < j = n), for M1…Mn to form a self, as opposed to a mere mind, it is not enough that Mi be corporeal with Mj; nor it is enough that Mi help bring about the occurrence of Mj; nor, most importantly, is it enough that Mi do this in the distinctively psychological manner just described. 
A story will help make this clear. There is a group of around 20,000 people, all of whom live on the same land-mass, which we’ll call “LM.” (LM is big enough that nobody feels crowded but small enough that nobody feels lonely and, more importantly, interactions among its occupants are frequent.) LM-occupants all speak the same language, and they often exchange information with one another. They also often exchange goods with, and provide services for, their fellow LM-occupants. 
Being reasonably intelligent and well-informed people, these people tend to have accurate beliefs; and being reasonably honest people, they tend to provide one another with accurate information. Also, most of the time, they’re reasonably honest not just in their communications with their fellows, but in their transactions with them. They tend not to defraud one another. 
In at least some cases, the ties that LM occupants have to one another are deep ones. (For the moment, we’ll set aside cases where LM-occupants have no significant ties to their brethren.) Those ties are not purely geographical: it isn’t just that the parties involved live in the same place. Nor are those ties purely causal. (It isn’t just that LM-occupants accidentally bump into other LM-occupants, thereby inadvertently changing the latter’s lives.) The ties in question involve: 
(i) 
the fact that one person intentionally transmits information that is arrived in a principled manner to some other person who makes principled inferences from that information, 

(ii) 
the fact that two people may (for prudential, moral, or even libidinal reasons) benefit each other by honoring an agreement to exchange goods or services. 


and: 
One fact about LM’s occupants must be made explicit. There is nothing regulating their exchanges with one another. Should one LM-occupant defraud another, there would be no penalties. Given that there are no laws in LM, the victim would have no legal recourse and he’d have to take it upon himself to see that justice be done. An LM-occupant who’d been misinformed by another would be in the same situation mutatis mutandis. It may be that, because LM’s occupants are so honest with one another, they’re better off for the fact that their lives aren’t weighed down by the presence of the regulatory entities that would be needed for there to be any formal penalties for fraud. 
But what is relevant here is that, precisely because their lives are not thus “weighed down," the occupants of LM do not jointly constitute a nation, at least not in the sense in which France constitutes a nation. There is nothing under whose jurisdiction the occupants of LM fall.[463] 

4.2 Minds that are selves and minds that are not 
Bearing these points in mind, let us turn our attention back to M1…Mn, and let us make some further assumptions about that series. The information encoded in Mi (1 = i = n) is likely to be accurate. That information, if transmitted to Mj, (1 = i < j = n), is likely to be transmitted in an accurate form. Moreover, the synthesizing of that information with other bodies of information (e.g., information currently being uploaded through the senses as to the nature of environment in Smith’s vicinity) is likely to consist of inferences in which correctly understood correct rules of inferences are correctly applied. 
But----and this is the final, and most important, assumption that we’ll make about M1…Mn-----none of the members of that series constitute judgments concerning the merits of either the information-exchanges occurring among other such members or of the manner in which the beliefs encoded therein are generated. Those exchanges and syntheses of information are not policed. It may be that each of the exchanges and inferences in question is done impeccably. But, if so, that isn’t because there is anything overseeing those operations; it is simply because, despite the absence of any supervisory agency, the mental states involved in those operations happen to satisfy the relevant desiderata. By the same token, if the ratiocinative activity that generates M1…Mn is inconsistent, even 
systematically so, with the very principles embodied in that activity, no internal mechanisms exist to ensure that the needed course-corrections occur. The spuriousness of the reasoning involved in M1…Mn may well ensure that 
Smith fails in his attempts to gratify his desires. 
But there isn't any internal agency that prevents Smith from making such mistakes or, therefore, that protects him from the damage to his person that such mistakes are likely to entail. There is, in other words, nothing under whose jurisdiction the various members of M1…Mn fall. Nothing polices 
either the manner in which members of that series exchange or produce information or the manner in which that series generates new members. Thus, M1…Mn, though constitutive of a mind and perhaps of something that has an 
enduring identity in the sense in which a rock does, doesn’t represent anything that has an enduring identity in the distinctive sense in which a human being does. 

5.0 When minds become selves 
Let’s revisit, and duly extend, what we said earlier about Smith/M1…Mn. At time t, it will be recalled, that series generates a mental state that embodies a judgment as to the fitness of (some of) the activities by which that series has thus far arrived at judgments. An internal regulatory agency is thereby born. 
That agency will inhibit the conversion of impulses into actions. This does not mean that it will simply thwart those impulses. It means that if, once that agency scrutinizes a given impulse, that agency judges it to be one worth acting upon, then it will lift the inhibition. But, for the reasons given in Section 3.3., the aforementioned impulse isn’t the proximal cause of the body-movements that result from the lifting of such an inhibition. 
Even before M1…Mn became to any degree self-policing, the activity constituting M1…Mn embodied knowledge, not of some one principle, but of many. So for that activity to become systematically self-policing, it must be guided by a knowledge of many different second-order principles of the sort previously described. But it’s a distinct possibility that not all of those second-order principles will be consistent with one another. As a result, an analogue of the process that led to Smith’s acquiring knowledge of those second-order principles will lead him to acquire knowledge of third order principles, the purpose of which knowledge being to ensure that the totality of second–order principles guiding Smith’s mentation be a coherent one--­that those principles not be such that, when complied with, the result is that it is judged de rigueur to lift the inhibition on some impulse and also de rigueur not to lift that inhibition. Second-order principles that don’t fit in with the rest are weeded out; they are no longer countenanced. For the same reason, second-order principles are countenanced that were not previously so. So far as this enterprise is successful, the result is an integrated body of principles, any two of which are consistent with each other, under whose jurisdiction falls all of the activity constitutive of Smith’s decisions as to how to act. So, given the reasonable presumption that, at this stage, none of Smith’s mental activity is purely theoretical, all of it being oriented towards instinct-gratification, this means that this enterprise, so far as it’s successful, yields a single, cohesive regulatory agency under whose jurisdiction all of Smith’s mental activity falls. 
5.1 Summary 
Just as group of people who live in the same place don’t become a state until their activities come to fall under the jurisdiction of some regulatory agency, so a group of co-corporeal, informationally integrated thoughts don’t necessarily constitute a self until they all fall under the jurisdiction of a regulatory agency. Before that happens, there are no actions, only reactions; after it happens, there are actions. We finally have an agent and, therefore, a self. 
6.0 The concept of intrinsic value in relation to the concept of selfhood 
With the inception of selfhood, values replace desires. Under the growing power of a supervisory structure of the just-discussed kind, the various constituents of that mind become increasingly unified: the structure they form becomes more and more of a self. (Incidentally, a consequence of this last statement, and therefore of our analysis, is that there are degrees of self-hood. This redounds to the credit of our analysis, since selfhood does come in degrees. Though clearly on independent grounds, a justification for it is given later.) Certainly, the initial purpose of this supervisory superstructure was to maximize the amount of instinctual gratification enjoyed by the mind falling within its power. And, surely, that always remains one of its purposes. Indeed, it arguably always remains its primary purpose (though, for reasons I’m about to state, I personally don’t think this). 
But that superstructure has needs of its own; and, as that superstructure develops, it becomes increasingly difficult to find an instinctual basis for those needs and increasingly necessary to understand them on their own terms. 
6.1 Some preliminaries 
Before we can see what exactly this claim amounts to, or, therefore, why it’s true, we must make preliminary points of a general nature as to the nature of the supervisory agency in which we have claimed the essence of selfhood to lie. There are some impulses that, if acted on, would weaken the integrity of this supervisory agency. Tautologously, this agency, so far as it’s in good working order, will inhibit such impulses. But little harm will come to that agency if it’s too good at its job---if it inhibits impulses that it could, without in any way jeopardizing its own authority, allow to be expressed in action. If that agency is too good at its job---that is, if it’s too conservative, if it inhibits impulses that, erring on the side of caution, it needn’t inhibit—the result will be merely a forfeiture of pleasure; it will not, at least not in the short term (or even the medium term), do any damage to itself or to the structures responsible for the mentation falling in its jurisdiction. 
As a result, this supervisory agency comes to be overly restrictive: it disapproves of the disinhibition of impulses that ought to be disinhibited. So far as those inhibited impulses are permitted gratification, it is only on the condition that they assume such forms that, if acted on, consolidate this agency’s power over the course of mental activity falling into its jurisdiction. In some cases, it is possible for those impulses to assume such forms. (This is what Freud referred to as “sublimation.” My aggressive instincts are discharged by my writing treatises that aggressively critique the views of my colleagues.) In other cases, this is not possible. This leads to what Freud calls “neurosis”: an inhibition of impulses that cannot be discharged in ways that are in keeping with one’s values but that, because they are so strong, must come out in some way or other and are forced to be expressed as symptoms. Since symptoms are unintentional, neurosis involves an abridgment of agency. One would have been better off yielding to the impulse and discharging it agentially, instead of forcing to find non-agential ways of discharging itself. (Freud makes this point in his (1926) book Symptoms, Inhibitions, and Anxiety. As he puts it: somebody riding a horse must sometimes let the horse go where it wants to go, lest the horse cease to let the rider have any control over it.) 
6.2 Two Illustrations of Our Thesis that what is Valuable is what consolidates one's Agency 
Illustration #1: We see Bach’s music as being more valuable than Eminem’s. (Eminem is a pop-star.) Why? First of all, the enjoyment of Eminem’s music is easily traced back, by way of multiple pathways, to enjoyment of the sexual act, it being largely for that reason that we enjoy Eminem’s music. By contrast, it is not because of any obvious connection that Bach’s music has to the sexual act that we enjoy it. The pleasure Bach’s music gives us is more akin to the pleasure given us by a philosophical or mathematical insight than it is to the (sub-agential) pleasures given to us by the sexual act. Implicated in the experience of listening to Bach’s music, and largely constitutive of the pleasure it brings us, are ratiocinative abilities that have no obvious connection to sexual gratification, or to any other form of instinctual gratification, and that do have obvious connections to the rational operations on which the supervisory agency in question depends to consolidate and extend the hegemony it has over the course of mental activity. Bach’s music is studied in conservatories; it is performed in places (e.g., concert-halls) where the operative norms of conduct require tremendous self-restraint---where one has to sit still for hours on end, where one must speak to others in a very controlled manner, and where one must display all of the asceticism involved in the transformation of instinct-driven proto­humans into instinct-suppressing actual humans. 
When people say that Eminem’s music is as highly “valued” as Bach’s, so far as what they are saying is true, they are saying in a distorted way that Eminem’s music is liked as much as Bach’s. And there’s no doubt that (at this juncture in history) there are more Eminem fans than there are Bach fans (that said, pop-stars are seldom liked solely for the merits of their music); and it may be that, during its brief recess from oblivion, Eminem’s music is a source of more pleasure (not pleasure per capita, but aggregate pleasure) than Bach’s music. But, in saying that Eminem’s music is more highly valued than Bach’s, one is confusing the concept of pleasure, and the related concept of desire, with the very different concept of value. 
Illustration #2: People enjoy reading (and writing) philosophical treatises. To become capable of this sort of enjoyment, one must alter one’s psychological structure in non-trivial ways. In order to pull off the remodeling of one’s intellect needed to become at all adept at this discipline, or therefore to derive any enjoyment from it, one must suspend gratification of urges that one would otherwise gratify, and one must do so without having any firm assurance that, in due course, one will be able to enjoy gratifications as intense as those that one has foregone. Because it takes a long time to acquire the philosophical acumen needed to make the reading, let alone the writing, of philosophical works more pleasurable than painful, and because during that long period otherwise fecund sources of instinctual gratification are off-limits, one must, if one has chosen to acquire that degree of acumen, develop a certain asceticism. One must come to devalue (some forms of) instinctual gratification and to hyper-value the self-control that comes with becoming capable of suspending instinctual gratification. 
This is not to say that the enjoyment of philosophical discourse has no instinctual foundation. Like Nietzsche, I believe that the enjoyment one derives from the exercise of one’s intellect is a form, or at least a derivative, of the instinctual pleasure one receives from having power over others and acting aggressively towards them. But, supposing this correct, the way in which, by virtue of engaging in philosophical discourse, one discharges these primitive impulses is contingent on one’s exercising faculties that, being purely ratiocinative, are much less directly connected with instinct-gratification than they are with the inhibitions of instinct so essential to the existence, and to the consolidation, of the supervisory agency in which the essence of selfhood lies. 
The same point mutatis mutandis holds of the pleasure one derives from very sophisticated forms of music. Bach’s music is passionate, and the passion embodied in it arguably has a sexual basis. But Bach’s music expresses that passion in an extremely controlled and ratiocination-heavy manner; and the faculty underlying the ratiocinative component of Bach’s music is one and the same with the faculty underlying the instinct-inhibitory ratiocinations constitutive of the regulatory agency that is one’s self. 
6.3 Selfhood a matter of degree 
Some minds are more intact than others. In this respect, minds are like nations. The official government of Pakistan has uncontested control over some areas and only little or no control over others. Thus, the landmass coincident with the nation of Pakistan is less unified than it would be if the loyalties of its occupants weren’t fragmented by the para-governmental agencies that occupy it. By contrast, the landmass coincident with the continental United States can be said to fall under the more or less uncontested jurisdiction of some one government, the same being true of the discontinuous landmass that is formed when Hawaii and Alaska are added. Therefore, the landmass coincident with the U.S. is more of a nation than the landmass coincident with Pakistan. Thus, nationhood comes in degrees. x is more of a nation than y if x’s government does a better job than y’s government ofunifying the occupants of the landmass falling in its jurisdiction. 
It is for similar reasons that one mind can be more of a self than another. If the regulatory agency governing mind x has more scope and power than its counterpart in mind y, then x is more of a self than y. 
That our analysis has the consequences that self-hood isn’t equally distributed among minds is to its credit. People’s selves disintegrate. And there are degrees of integratedness (i.e., of non-disintegratedness), as everyday experience makes obvious and as clinical observation of the mentally ill makes even more obvious. 
Chapter 27 How Is Rationalization Possible? 
1.0 Two kinds of repression 
People routinely deceive themselves. It would be hard to exaggerate how often people deceive themselves or how discrepant with the truth are the lies that self-deceivers tell themselves. But some hold that the concept of self-deception is an incoherent one, and therefore that people never deceive themselves about anything. This viewpoint, in addition to being a case of self-deception itself, is demonstrably false, as we will now see. 
But how exactly is self-deception possible? And what exactly does it involve?[464] 
The concepts of self-deception and repression are easily made to seem incoherent: 
(OR) [465] 
To repress an idea---that is, to drive a conscious idea into the unconscious---you have to know what it is that you’re repressing and you thus have to be conscious of it; but if you know what it is that you’re repressing, you’re conscious of it and it therefore isn’t repressed. Moreover, to keep an idea repressed---that is, to block that idea’s attempts to re-enter consciousness---you have to be conscious of it; for if you are not conscious of it, it will slip back into consciousness unnoticed. But if you are conscious of it, it isn’t repressed. So the concepts of repression, and therefore self-deception, are incoherent ones. 
I will now try to show that there are two kinds of self-deception. For reasons that will become clear, this is a corollary of the fact that there are two kinds of repression.[466] 
In other words, there are two ways in which one can inhibit the entry into consciousness that one has and that, in some way and at some level, one knows that one has. One form of repression involves inaction. That form of repression involves a deliberate, and conscious, intention not to follow up on suggestive leads. One suspects; but doesn't know. And that's how one wants to keep it. So one doesn't exercise due diligence in the way of interpreting existing evidence or generating new evidence. Let’s refer to this kind of repression as “repression1.” 
So repression1 doesn’t involve driving some already formed belief into the unconscious. It involves abstaining from doing the things that, so one strongly suspects, would generate the sort of evidence that make acceptance of that belief de rigueur. 
The other kind of repression, which we’ll refer to as “repression2," does involve already formed beliefs. The essence of repression2 is dissociation. When trying to determine how to act, one tries to give due weight to each of the decision-relevant beliefs. So, in effect, each decision-relevant idea ‘gets a vote.’ To repress2 an idea is to take its vote away; it is to decide to give it no weight. 
Both repression1 and repression2 involve conflict between, on the one hand, forces within oneself of which one is aware and, on the other hand, forces within oneself of which one is unaware. But the natures of the unconscious forces, and also of the conscious forces, involved in the one case of the one sort of repression are different from those involved in cases of the other sort. 
Both forms of repression involve the construction and operationalization of a narrative alternative to the one that, supposing the repressed idea to be correct (which it typically is), describes reality as it really is. In other words, both forms of repression involve rationalization. Without rationalization, it is hard, if not impossible, to repress an idea and also to keep it repressed. (That said, rationalization-construction is more heavily involved in ensuring that already repressed ideas stay repressed than it is in initially repressing them.) 
Right now we’ll talk about “self-deception," since references to “repression” would resonate in a confusion-engendering way with the points just made. In due course, we’ll map what we say about self-deception onto repression1 and repression2. 
2.0 How is repression possible? 
The possibility of self-deception, and therefore of both repression1 and repression2, is a consequence of the following three facts. 
(1) 
The mind is not a perfectly unified entity; it consists of various parts that communicate with each other only very imperfectly. The right hand doesn’t always know what the left is doing. 

(2). There are two very different ways in which one can be aware of a given thing. One can either have “knowledge by acquaintance” of that thing or one can have “knowledge by description” of it. See Chapter 10, Section 9.0, for definitions of these terms and explanations of the corresponding concepts. 

(3) 
There are two very different senses in which a given mental content can be ‘conscious.’ On the one hand, it can be conscious in the sense that it is a constituent of consciousness. (Sense-perceptions are such constituents; so are itches, tickles, and other sensations.) On the other hand, it can be conscious in the sense that it is a mental entity of which one is conscious. Your belief that 1 + 1 = 2 is not a constituent of consciousness. It is "conscious" in the sense that you are, or can readily become, conscious of it. Of course, we are conscious of rocks, trees, and stars, but don’t describe such things as ‘conscious.’ But that, I think, is because they are not mental entities and we thus have no tendency to co-categorize them with constituents of consciousness or with mental entities of any other kind. But since constituents of consciousness are the most obvious examples of mentality, and since we describe them as ‘conscious,’ we have an inclination to describe mental entities that are not themselves constituents of consciousness but that we are (non-inferentially) aware of as ‘conscious.’ We thus, without knowing it, use the word ‘conscious’ equivocally: sometimes it means ‘mental entity that is a constituent of consciousness’ and sometimes it means 


‘mental entity that we are directly conscious of.’ 
2.1 How is repression possible? (continued) 
Given (3), it immediately follows that there is a sense in which all mental entities that aren’t constituents of consciousness are unconscious. Your knowledge that 1 + 1 = 2 is not a constituent of consciousness. So far as it is conscious, it is only in the sense that you can readily become conscious of it. And most of the time you are not conscious of it. But it exists, and is operative, even when you are not conscious of it. If you didn’t know that 1 + 1 = 2, then the way in which you dealt with the world---the way in which you transacted with others, as well as the way you dealt with problems not having an interpersonal dimension----would differ radically from the way in which, even when you’re not consciously thinking that 1 + 1 = 2 or a fortiori thinking about your knowledge that 1 + 1 = 2, you in fact deal with the world. The way in which you reason is not only consistent with, but expressive of, a knowledge that 1 + 1 = 2, the same being true of the way in which you interact with people and also of the way in which you manage matters that don’t involve others. But it is only during, at most, a tiny few of the occasions when one’s thoughts and overt acts are guided by a conscious awareness of the fact that 1 + 1 = 2. It is only rarely that one consciously thinks about the fact that 1 + 1 = 2 or, therefore, that one thinks about one’s belief that 1 + 1 = 2. 
Bearing this in mind, suppose, if only for argument’s sake, that your knowledge that 1 + 1 = 2 is identical with some physiological structure. It follows from what we’ve said that, even when you are not conscious of the fact 1 + 1 = 2, or therefore of your knowledge of that fact, this belief of yours is psychologically operative. Of course, given that it’s a physiological structure, it’s inevitably operative in the same, thought-free way as an involuntary muscle-spasm. But, even when not the object of consciousness, that physiological structure is also psychologically active; it’s active, in other words, as a belief, and not just as a heap of molecules. Your knowledge that 1 + 1 = 2 informs the way in which you deal with the world even when you aren’t consciously thinking that 1 + 1 = 2; and, were this belief of yours inoperative whenever it was blazing a trail across your consciousness, your way of dealing with the world would bear little resemblance to your actual way of dealing with it. 
Given (2), it follows that you may not recognize a given mental content of yours for what it is. You can have thoughts about Charlemagne and you thus have a concept of him. But if you met him, you wouldn't recognize him; and so long as you didn't figure out who he was, you would, without knowing it, have two distinct concepts of him (one based on personal encounters with him, the other based on statements of historians). Given anything that isn't itself a constituent of consciousness, one can fail to recognize it for what it is and, consequently, one can unwittingly have two distinct concepts of that thing. Propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness. So one could, without knowing it, have two distinct concepts of one of one's own propositional attitudes. 
2.2 How is repression possible? (continued) 
A story will clarify these points. You live next to the “Springfield Strangler”: a prolific serial killer who, in the town of Springfield, has killed many children by strangling them. His identity is unknown to everyone (except, of course, the Springfield Strangler himself). You know this person as “Ted Jones.” Since you watch the news, you know of the Springfield Killer. But you don’t know that Ted Jones is the Springfield Strangler. You find Ted’s company agreeable and you play tennis with him. 
In this situation just described, there is some one individual x such that: 
(i) 
you are acquainted with x, 

(ii) 
you have knowledge by description of x, 


and: 
(iii) you know that, in virtue of these facts, you have two distinct conceptions of some one individual. 
But this changes. For, at time t, you find out that Ted Jones is the Springfield Strangler. You see him being arrested. You hear the subsequent news reports. You consider various facts directly known to you about Ted Jones: his sudden nightly disappearances, which typically involved Ted’s dragging large trunks to his pick-up truck; the stench emanating from his house, which he implausibly explained by saying that he had a clogged sink; etc. You thus realize that Ted Jones is indeed the Springfield Killer. 
Just as one can, without knowing it, be acquainted with a given individual while also having descriptive knowledge of it, so one can be acquainted with a given one of one’s own mental contents while also having descriptive knowledge of it. A corollary is that, given some mental entity E that belongs to one, one can discover that one actually has some attitude towards E that one did not previously know oneself to have. You can discover that the gnawing feeling of unpleasantness you experience whenever somebody mentions Smith is your detestation of Smith. Emotions are distinct from their manifestations in consciousness. Your love of your mother (supposing for argument’s sake that she’s alive and that you do love her) is an enduring psychological structure; it is not an ephemeral event. But it gives rise to ephemeral conscious events (to pangs of remorse when you inadvertently hurt her feelings, to surges of joy when, after not hearing from her for three months, she calls you, etc.). But your love for her is not itself a conscious event. It is "conscious" only in the Pickwickian sense that you are conscious of it. Beliefs, like emotions, are enduring structures and are to be distinguished from the constituents of consciousness to which they may give rise. All propositional attitudes are enduring structures and are thus to be distinguished from any constituents of consciousness for whose existence they’re responsible. And a given emotion, e.g., your hatred of Smith, can give rise to conscious events of very different kinds. It can give rise to gnawing feelings of unpleasantness (as when you hear that he’s coming over), to intense feelings of satisfaction (as when you hear that he flunked his economics exam), etc. And given two qualitatively distinct conscious events, both of them expressions in consciousness of some one propositional attitude x and both of them, consequently, ways in which that emotion presents itself to consciousness, there isn’t necessarily any reason why you should recognize x in both of those conscious events. To sum up, given only that x and y are both conscious derivatives of some propositional attitude z, it doesn’t follow that any one part of one’s mind has the information needed to recognize z in both x and y. For this reason, it follows that one can have two divergent attitudes towards z. 
Given (1), therefore, it follows that one can have very different attitudes towards a given one of one’s own propositional attitudes. And it also follows that, without knowing it, one can view a given one of one’s own propositional attitudes as despicable and as laudatory, as deserving to be cultivated and expressed in action and as deserving to be annihilated. 
2.3 Intrapsychic conflict in relation to repression 
But self-deception is not mere ignorance of what one is feeling. In fact, self-deception seems to presuppose that, at some level, one has knowledge of the thing of which one lacks conscious knowledge. So given only that one can fail to recognize some one propositional attitude in two different conscious expressions of it, all that follows is that one is not completely transparent to oneself; it doesn’t follow that one can self-deceive; it doesn’t follow that there can be some sort of internal conflict---between what one knows and what one wants to know, between what is unconscious (because repressed) and what is conscious (because countenanced). A few additions to the three points made thus far will make it clear how self-deception is possible. 
First of all, one must distinguish having a given propositional attitude (or, more generally, mental content) from knowing that one has it. Setting aside anything that has to do with repression, one can feel a certain way towards so and so but not know it. Knowing that one feels that way involves making a judgment about one’s mental state. 
Also, propositional attitudes never make an appearance in consciousness in propria persona---or, rather, they do so, but only in the indirect sense in which rocks and trees do. What is in consciousness; i.e., what is constitutive of consciousness, is at best some representative or derivative of a propositional attitude. On Monday, Smith feels a surge of anger towards his dad. On Tuesday, he feels another surge of anger. These surges of anger, let us suppose, are expressions of hatred. But the hatred per se isn’t what entered his consciousness. What Smith is directly given are various indications that he hates his father. These indications are strong. (In any case, we can imagine developing the story in such a way that, supposing Smith sane, they left no room for reasonable doubt on his part as to whether he hated his father.) But he still has to “synthesize” them; he still has to make a judgment to the effect that they express some enduring attitude. In most cases, this is done so automatically, that he is unaware that any judgment has been made. 
Those judgments are often quite wrong. We like the person towards whom we have constant surges of rage. We dislike the person who repeatedly makes us feel good. (He makes you feel good because he wants to disarm you. And he knows that by “pushing the right buttons”---buying you chocolates, taking you to the zoo, etc.---he’ll generate feelings that, when not the result of this sort of chicanery, tend to express genuine affection. You’ll know in your bones that there is something very wrong about the situation. But you won’t able to say what it is. Assuming that your views about others are mainstream and are thus hewed to the glib, emotionally-driven narratives in terms of which all but the most penetrating thinkers understand others, you won’t have developed the ability to articulate your gut feelings or, therefore, to give them a form in which you or others are likely to give them the credence they deserve. Given that fact, along with the red-herrings that this manipulator is pouring into evidence-repository on the basis of which you make your conscious judgments, your verdict will be that he is a good person. 
In any case, supposing that one has a given propositional attitude, what one is given is not that attitude per se, but various evidences thereof, and those evidences may be dispersed over time and may occur in multifarious contexts. When the propositional attitude is an emotionally sterile one---when it concerns a belief about number-theory or epistemology---we have no trouble making the 
needed judgments.[467] 

2.3.1 Intrapsychic conflict in relation to repression1 
It’s one thing to suspect that something is the case; it’s quite another to know it. The police suspect that Smith is the murderer. The evidence points to him (the bloody footprints leading to his front door step, the hair samples, the smudged fingerprints which are consistent with Smith’s being the killer even though they don’t prove it). But the police don’t yet know that Smith is their man. For there are gaps in the evidence they have on him, as a result of which there are semi-reasonable ways of modeling the scenario that, if correct, would entail that Smith was not the murderer. 
Bearing these facts in mind, suppose the following. Smith is your best friend. You owe him your life many times over. The police strongly suspect that he’s the murderer. You're the detective who is assigned the case. Like your colleagues, you strongly suspect that he's guilty. But you aren't sure. And you don't want to be sure. So you choose not to exercise due diligence. 
What we call “repression” involves failure to exercise due diligence. We suspect, but we don’t know, which is how we want to it to keep it. 
So the customary conception of repression is erroneous. The customary conception is given by assertion that (“CCR” is short for conventional conception of repression”): 
(CCR) the person in question has some propositional attitude P such that (a) he knowingly chooses to cease to be aware of it; i.e., he knowingly drives it into his unconscious; and such that (b) P is constantly struggling to break into consciousness, failing to do so only because the patient keeps it out. 
Part (b) of CCR is indeed paradoxical. For, presumably, to keep P out of his consciousness, the patient must know what P is: otherwise he won’t know what it is he’s trying to keep out. But if he knows what it is he’s trying to keep out, then he’s conscious of it and it is ipso facto unrepressed. 
But CCR doesn’t correctly describe the nature of repression. It’s one thing to know that your best friend is the Springfield Killer. It’s another thing to suspect it but choose not to follow the relevant trail of evidence. Repression---or, rather, repression1 (the subscript has again become relevant)---is a failure to do 
something; it is a failure to perform the operations by which one customarily generates one’s beliefs; it isn’t an operation performed on existing beliefs (or propositional attitudes of any other kind). So repression1 involves choosing not to learn something that, if learned and therefore known, one would wish that one had never learned, but only after it was too late. 
While your parents are on vacation, let us suppose, you look through their bedroom and come across your mother’s private journal. On the basis of its external appearance, along with the information that you’ve gleaned from a cursory glance at its interior, you know enough to know that the journal provides detailed information about your mother’s sexual exploits over the last few years. You thus know that, were you to read on, you’d learn things about your mother that you know you don’t want to know. So you choose not to read on. Your wish not to be traumatized overpowers your curiosity. 
Repression1 is to be understood along these lines. When we speak, 
inaccurately, of “repressed knowledge," we’re referring (in at least some cases, viz., those that aren’t cases of repression2) to suspicions that we have chosen not to verify, since we suspect that, were we to do so, we’d be stuck with 
knowledge that we wish we didn’t have. 
Every case of repression1 does, as CCR says, involve intrapsychic conflict. But, contrary to what CCR says, the conflict is not between unconscious knowledge of some truth T on the one hand, and conscious ignorance of T on the other. The conflict is between a wish to know the truth and a wish to not know the truth. 
2.3.2 One reason why repression1 often fails 
One’s agency only goes so far; there is much within one’s mind that falls outside its scope. Among the various mental entities that lie beyond the reach of what it is for one to choose to occur are the aforementioned judgment-producing processes. So it is not within my power to completely suspend those processes. 
And so far as it is within my power to do so, it is not in the direct, robust sense in which one can choose to move one’s arm, but in the indirect and attenuated sense in which one can choose to become obese. One doesn’t really choose to become obese; one chooses to do things that will redirect automatic processes in such a way that obesity is the inevitable result. Similarly, one can no more choose to stop making judgments than one choose to stop digesting food. One can choose courses of action that will have the effect of redirecting the automatically occurring stream of mental activity that yields judgments (e.g., one can choose activities that will flood that judgment-making faculty with information concerning the judgments that one wants to avoid making); and one can also choose to do things that will deplete that faculty of the energy it needs to function (e.g., one can do intense exercise for hours on end). One can also choose to paralyze or even permanently damage the physiological underpinnings of those judgments (e.g., one can get drunk, thereby paralyzing them, or one can get a lobotomy, thereby destroying them). But, unless one goes so far as to damage one’s brain, that stream of activity will eventually start yielding the very judgments that you don’t want it to. 
2.3.3 The concept of anxiety in relation to repression1 
The anxiety that the subject feels when the forces of repression1 break down isn’t the result of some hitherto unconscious knowledge entering consciousness. It is the result one’s own thought-processes, despite one’s attempt to stymie them, following up on clues that it had good reason to believe would lead to a belief that one doesn’t want to have. 
“But if you already know that you don’t want to have that belief, then you must already know what that belief is and must already have it.” This is false. Suspicion isn’t knowledge; and there’s nothing paradoxical about not wanting to pursue suspicions that one suspects would, if pursued, lead to knowledge one would rather not have. 
Also, one can know what sort of thing something is without knowing which thing it is. If I ask you to find a unique number n such that the square root of n is over 10 and such that two people whose middle names are “Robert” each own n1/3 acres of land, and I prove to you, without identifying the number in question, that there is indeed exactly one such number, you know what sort of thing you’re looking for without as of yet being able to identify any number that fits the description. 
A story will make this clear. You are acquainted with Sally. You know that exactly one person has been stealing money from your wallet---but you don’t know who it is. So, by virtue of knowing the description “person who has been stealing money from my wallet” to be uniquely satisfied, you have descriptive knowledge of Sally. But you don’t know that Sally satisfies that description. 
3.0 Repression2 
Whereas repression1 involves failing to form a belief, repression2 involves blinding oneself to an existing belief that one has already formed. 
How is repression2 possible? How does one repress a belief that has already been formed? And how does one keep such a belief repressed? To clarify the second question, how does one keep a belief that one doesn’t want to enter consciousness from doing so? For one must be conscious of the enemy hammering at the walls of one’s fortress if one is to take measures to keep him out. But, in this context, one cannot be conscious of the enemy, since what one is conscious of ipso facto isn’t repressed. 
3.1 A necessary condition for repression2 
For a propositional attitude to be a candidate for repression2, it must be a 
source of conflict within one’s own psyche. It isn’t enough that it be a source of pain. One often fails to repress2 one’s most painful memories. (Holocaust survivors remember what they’ve been through.) People typically choose to 
suppress painful memories. In other words, they choose not to think about them. But suppression isn’t repression2. 
One represses2 knowledge that one has about one’s husband, because one’s life is so structured that it would be severely disrupted were the truths thereby known to be admitted. One likes many aspects of one’s life; it may well be that, despite the ugly truths in question about one’s husband, one believes (perhaps rightly) that being married to him really is better than not being married to him. But, since one couldn’t stomach marriage to him if one admitted to oneself that he was a child-molesting ghoul, one represses2 that knowledge. 
And one may be right to. Repression2 isn’t always a bad thing. In many contexts, it’s the optimal thing. It may be that Sally's quality of life would plummet if she left her child-molesting husband; it may be that, were she to 
leave him, her children would be in danger. Since she couldn’t be with him if she consciously knew that he was child-molester, she’s well advised to repress2 that knowledge, at least for the time being. 
A person who never repressed2 anything would quickly go mad. Repressions2 are necessary. So how is repression2 bad? First of all, repressions2 outlive their usefulness. The circumstances that prompts one to repress2 a given belief may well be replaced by circumstances in which one’s consciously 
having that belief is vital to one’s wellbeing. (In this context, take “belief” to 
stand for any propositional attitude.) But, repression2 being what it is, one will have no idea what it is that one is supposed to be aware of. In fact, one is unlikely to know that one has represssed2 anything important to one’s welfare. 
Also, repression2 isn’t a one-off affair; it is an on-going process. Whenever one comes across information that confirms the repressed2 belief, one must either repress2 one’s knowledge of that information or one must convince oneself of the cogency of some spurious interpretation of that information. Since 
these cover-ups must themselves be covered up, more knowledge ends up being repressed2 and more spurious rationalizations are accepted. Each instance of 
repression2 creates a hole in one’s body of knowledge that one must explain away. Since these explanations cannot be genuine, and since each one incentivizes the creation of more bogus, anomaly-creating explanations, the need to plug up these holes disposes one to devalue truth and to hyper-value the methods of reasoning whose legitimacy these faux-explanations falsely assume. The result is a loss of both ratiocinative and ethical integrity. 
So, while repressions2 are not necessarily bad things, sometimes being indispensable to one’s well-being, they tend to stick around long after they’ve served any legitimate purpose; and during that time, they tend to spread and, as a result, to eat away at one’s psychological architecture. 
3.2 A repression2-conducive factor 
One can know something without that thing’s being obvious to one. I know that there is a war in Iraq. But it’s not obvious to me the way that it would be if I were there witnessing it. It’s harder to repress2 knowledge of 
the obvious than of the non-obvious. If your knowledge that your husband is a serial killer is based on inferences, even air-tight ones, it will be easier to repress2 it than it would be if it were based on personal observations of him killing people. 
That said, people can repress2 knowledge of truths that are as obvious as truths can be. But one cannot repress2 such knowledge without, in effect, telling oneself that one isn’t capable of knowing the truth. Since the purpose of repression2 is the elimination of conflict within oneself, and since a complete 
loss of faith in one’s ratiocinative ability usually, but not always, creates more such conflict than it eliminates, repression2 tends to target knowledge of what is not totally obvious. In most cases of repression2, there must be what lawyers refer to as “plausible deniability.” 
3.2.1 A related point 
The things that one represses2 tend to be things that, although one knows them to be true, involve one’s making judgment-calls. Until your husband’s psychopathy assumes some particularly brazen form, any knowledge that you have of it involves your putting together various bits of data (e.g., various odd comments he’s made, various murders that you hear about on the news, his unexplained absences during the times that when the murders occurred, his fitting the descriptions given to the police of the murderer). But, having as it does a basis in some many pieces of data, your subsequent knowledge that your husband is the murderer is shaky and is thus vulnerable to repression2, in a way that strictly sense-based knowledge is not. 
“But if one’s ‘knowledge’ of some truth is shaky," it will be said, “then one isn’t convinced of that truth. And if one isn’t convinced of it, one doesn’t have knowledge of it. One only has suspicions.” 
There are different reasons why one may lack confidence in one of one’s beliefs. It may be that one has not, as of yet, encountered adequate evidence for that belief. Or it may be that, even though one has encountered adequate evidence and even though, consequently, that belief would ordinarily be firm, one wants that belief to be false. If a belief concerns something personal, one’s standard of proof tends to be ridiculously high. What it would take to convince you that somebody you’re not married to is cheating on his wife is miniscule to what it would take to convince you that your husband is cheating on you. 
To take a different example: the amount of evidence that favors the theory of evolution is simply enormous. But because that theory says, in effect, that we’re orangutans whose lives have no meaning, we won’t judge it worthy of acceptance until it’s met absurdly high standards of evidence. I have no doubt that people have always known that we evolved from other life forms. Given the anatomical, behavioral, and psychological similarities between us, on the one hand, and members of other mammalian species, on the other, it’s inconceivable that we aren’t related to them. Denying that orangutans are our biological kin is like denying that the one person in the room with grape jelly and crumbs around his mouth is the one who ate your jelly-doughnut. 
Of course, religious people say that God created us. But, if so, why did he choose to make us look so much like apes, and why did he choose to stock our minds with ignominious urges that constantly show us that those external similarities are but representations of internal ones? 
This brings us to another illustration of the principle in question: it’s often said that Freud’s theories aren’t warranted by the empirical data. If you actually read what he says and then, bearing what you read in mind, study a single person’s behavior for a period of around 10 minutes, it becomes clear that Freud’s theories are theoretically extraordinarily conservative; it also becomes clear that he was simply making explicit the principles that we ordinarily use when making intuitive judgments about other people. People don’t want to be told that they lie to themselves. People don’t want to part with rationalizations; they don’t want to face ugly realities. They’d rather be a king in their dreams than a janitor in reality. So it’s not hard to see why it is often dismissed, despite its staggering explanatory power and despite the extraordinarily high degree to which his claims accord with the principles that underlie our judgments. We'll state Freud's principle claims right now. 
3.2.2 Freud's Principle Claims 
Here is a one-paragraph outline of Freud's primary contentions: 
Nobody is perfectly transparent to himself. Nobody is conscious of everything that goes on in his mind. There are different reasons why one may not be conscious of given constituent of one's own mind. In some cases, one can readily become conscious of a constituent of one's mind of which one was previously unconscious. For example, let's suppose that, since the time you woke up this morning, you haven't been conscious of your belief that 2+2=4. You just became conscious of it. Given how effortless this transition was, it didn't involve your resisting any forces within yourself. It was unconscious because, until just a moment ago, you lacked a positive incentive to pay attention to it----not because you had a positive incentive to turn a blind eye to it. 
But in other cases, a given person may be unaware of a given constituent of his mind for the reason that he doesn't want to be aware of it. He finds it so distressing that he chooses to turn a blind eye to it---to repress it, in other words. In repressing that entity, the subject didn't destroy it; he merely blinded himself to it. The subject wouldn't have found that entity important enough to repress if he hadn't known it to have a profound bearing on how he should live and, therefore, on what he should aspire to do. Consequently, the desires to which it gives rise are necessarily especially intense ones, and the subject will experience intolerable frustration until they are discharged. 
Such a desire cannot be discharged unless it employs a subterfuge of some kind, given that it cannot possibly be the subject's conscious intention to gratify it. Such subterfuges are always of one of two types. 
Type #1: The desire in question can disguise itself as a desire that the subject consciously does wish to act on. An example: the subject detests his ailing mother. But he refuses to believe that he has anything but love for her. His detestation for her presents itself to his consciousness as a fanatical devotion to her being safe from both microbial and human predators. So he bathes her in scalding hot water and refuses to let her leave the house. In this way, his repressed hatred of her is discharged in the form of behavior that the subject believes to be motivated entirely by unalloyed concern for her well­being. 
Type #2: It can be expressed as a symptom. An example: Having repressed her complete detestation of her husband, a young woman finds herself gripped by a compulsive desire to do housework whenever her betrothed wishes to engage her in acts of physical intimacy. 
So far as the opposition to these contentions has been given an argumentative foundation, the arguments in question are pitifully weak and involve regressions to extremely crude and, in some cases, demonstrably false positions. “We’re computers” (Fodor). “There is no consciousness” (Dennett). “There are no minds” (Quine). “The mind is completely transparent to itself” (Searle). Nobody believes or doubts or hopes for anything; terms referring to propositional attitudes (e.g. "hope," "believe," "intend") belong to ‘folk-psychology’, which is no more accurate than folk-physics” (Paul and Patricia Churchland). “We’re better off trying to understand Baryshnikov's skill as a dancer in terms of fluid levels in his ears than his ability to upload, process, and distribute information in ways that ensure that his movements are appropriately coordinated.” (Searle). 
These willful denials of the obvious are often embedded in larger philosophical projects that are nothing short of risible, e.g. the Dretske-Fodor view that, details aside, there is no difference between my concept of a given a person and a photograph of a given person. 
And yet all of these flights into inanity are touted as “scientific” and “rigorous.” Why? “Because”, we are told, “in denying the existence of the mental, we’re simply completing the process of ceasing to understand nature in animistic terms and we’re thereby completing the victory of science over non-science.” 
But this argument is no good, and it's clear why. While it's certainly a good idea not to impute minds to stones, it's obviously not such a good idea not to impute them to people. So while it’s a good idea not to understand the world 
projectively, we must remember that the projector itself cannot be a projection. 
3.3 Intrapsychic conflict in relation to repression2: some preliminaries (continued) 
A story, based on the remarks made in Sections 3.0-3.2.1., will help us clarify and develop the points we’ve made about self-deception and repression2. You discover that your husband’s a psychopath. You don’t see him killing anyone. But within the limits set by that fact, you are as sure of it as a rational person could be. Since this knowledge (or near-knowledge) cannot be reconciled with your life, at least not in its current form, and thus creates intolerable conflict within your psyche, you choose to repress it. 
Here is what repressing2 this knowledge involves. First of all, when taken with other propositions whose truth we may reasonably assume you to accept, the proposition: 
(1) My husband is a psychopathic ghoul all of whose protestations of love were fraudulent, as was everything else about him; which, given what it is to be a psychopath along with the well-known (to people interested in the subject) symptoms of psychopathy (glibness, specific lack of insight, etc.) 
entails the much more generic proposition: 
(2) There is some property P such that my husband has P and such that, by virtue of having P, my husband is a worse person than he would otherwise be; and a person’s having P involves his doing the sorts of things that my husband does that trouble me (e.g., it involves his smoothly lying, his vacillating between inexplicable rage and glib charm, the contrast between how he acts and who he claims to be, his inability to authentic his claim that he was an admiral in the Navy). 
By virtue of knowing (1), therefore, you also know (2). So, during the fleeting moment when you consciously know (1), you also know (2). Let’s henceforth refer to that fleeting moment as “FM.” 
(2), unlike (1), is something that you can keep in consciousness without having to overhaul your entire life. For (2), unlike (1), is sufficiently vague that your knowledge of it won’t make you want to retch at the mere sight of your husband. During FM, you realize that you wish you hadn’t discovered (1). But, as you know, if you simply decide not to think about (1)---if you suppress, but do not repress, that knowledge---you won’t be able to live with yourself. You know that you must bury your knowledge of (1). But you also know that you’ll be confronted with the same facts---the strange behaviors, the news reports, etc.­--that led you to know (1) in the first place; and you know that, unless you make some drastic change, those same facts will lead you right back to the same ugly place. 
So you make a decision. You know (2). And you know that you know it. With this knowledge in mind, you resolve that, henceforth, when confronted with the sort of datum that that led you to believe (1), you’ll model it in a way that is consistent with (2) but that doesn’t coincide with (1) or with anything else that would be equally disruptive to your current situation. 
Before we can move forward, we must recall some facts that we’ve already discussed about propositional attitudes, and we must point out a couple of new ones. First of all, propositional attitudes are not, as we’ve made clear, constituents of consciousness. For a propositional attitude to be “conscious” is either for one to be conscious of it or for it to be such that one can readily become conscious of it. Your knowledge that 7 + 3 = 10 is conscious in the sense that you can readily become conscious of it. You weren’t conscious of it a few seconds ago, however. But, even then, it was “conscious” because it was readily made into an object of consciousness. (Freud (1915, 1921) describes such propositional attitudes as “pre-conscious.”) So for your knowledge of (1) to be “conscious” is for it to be a ready object of consciousness. 
3.4 Intrapsychic conflict in relation to repression2: some final preliminaries 
There are some other relevant facts. Beliefs are inert except to the extent that one draws consequences from them and, more generally, that they are allowed to beget or otherwise engage other beliefs. The making of inferences at least sometimes involves a deliberate, conscious effort on one’s part. But some inferences are made involuntarily. Insights often just occur to one; but those insights are based on rational consideration of the relevant evidence. But, even though (so I believe) many an inference is made involuntarily, one has at least some control over what sorts of inferences one’s mind makes. So, given some belief B that one has, one can so structure one’s life that it is very unlikely that one will (consciously) make inferences from B that one would otherwise make. 
[468] 
Thus, one can so structure one’s life that a belief, though still conscious, is (at the level of consciousness[469]) isolated---prevented from engaging the bodies of belief that it would otherwise engage and prevented from begetting the beliefs that it would otherwise beget. Such a belief is conscious in some formal sense; but, at the level of consciousness, it has become inert, like one’s knowledge of some random, uninteresting fact. 
By de-operationalizing one's acceptance of a given fact, one can cease to have anything more than an abstract, formal understanding of what that fact amounts to. I know that there are people who are being tortured. But, because I have not witnessed a torture session, I don’t know what the proposition there are people who are being tortured amounts to as well as I would if ceteris paribus I had witnessed a torture session. So even though I am in some technical sense no less aware of that truth than somebody who has first-hand knowledge of what torture-sessions involve, my awareness of that fact doesn't mean very much to me, whereas his awareness of it means a great deal to him. 
There is one last preliminary fact. Your knowledge of (1) is not derived from some one sense-perception; (1) isn’t the sort of truth that can be known in such a direct way. It embodies a case of inference to the best explanation. (See Chapters 10 and 11 for a definition of this term and an analysis of concept expressed by it.) That doesn’t mean that it isn’t knowledge. (Unless knowledge can be acquired through inferences to the best explanation, then what we actually know is only an infinitesimally small part of what we think we know.) But it does mean that it embodies an attempt on your part (a successful one, in fact) to model various pieces of information. 
There are different ways to model that body of data. (This is not a peculiarity of the data involved in this particular case. Given a body of data, it is more likely than not than there is more than one reasonable, or at least semi-reasonable, way to model it.) [470] 
In this case, so we will suppose, (1) is the best such model. But it isn’t, so we will also suppose, the only one that isn’t totally implausible. The following proposition constitutes an alternative way of modeling that data: 
(3) 
Given that mental activity is governed by brain-activity, it follows that there are (possible, if not actual) physiological conditions whose symptoms include behavior similar to my husbands, accompanied by bouts of forgetfulness. (Not being a physician, I don’t know the specifics.) And his having such a condition would explain how it is that, without being intentionally dishonest, he often says things that are false, and otherwise behaves in substandard ways. 

(3) 
is not a spectacularly good model of the data. But it’s far from being obviously false. And this, for reasons that we’ll now discuss, is enough to repress your knowledge of (1). 


3.5 Intrapsychic conflict in relation to repression2: a conjecture as to what it involves 
In light of these points, I put forth the following conjecture. During FM (the fleeting moment when your knowledge of (1) was conscious), you resolve that, on the occasions that you become conscious (not pre-conscious, but actively conscious; i.e., conscious in the sense in which you are now conscious of reading these very words) of your acceptance of (1), you will take the following steps. First, you’ll isolate that belief. You will, to the best of your ability, refrain from drawing inferences from it (or from conjunctive propositions of which it is one of the conjuncts). You won’t voluntarily make any inferences from it; and if you find yourself having made one involuntarily, you’ll do your best to refrain from pursuing it. You’ll encapsulate this knowledge. 
This will neutralize your belief in (1). First, for reasons given a moment ago, it will blind you to corollaries of (1) of which you'd otherwise be aware, and (1) will start to seem relatively innocuous as a result. A story will help us develop this point. 
You discover that your husband has done X, Y, and Z. (Some jewelry is missing from your drawer. Your husband is wearing new clothes, even though he has no money. And so forth.) Since you’ve decided not to draw inferences from (1), you’ll be more likely than you would otherwise be to take these on a case-by-case basis. Inevitably, you’ll sometimes connect these curious phenomena to your knowledge of (1). But, just as inevitably, bits of knowledge that you have that would otherwise congregate will remain isolated from one another. As a result, your appreciation of just what it is that (1) entails will remain superficial; you’ll be slow to recognize its consequences for your own welfare, and to recognize the extent to which your husband’s condition is impoverishing your life. 
Having decided to isolate (1) you’ll resolve that, whenever you encounter data that clearly confirms (1), you’ll try to look at it from the viewpoint of somebody who believes that (3) is correct. Of course, since you are not such a person, this will, at first, be a kind of intellectual exercise for you: you’ll still know that (1), not (3), is the right way to model the data. But by engaging in this exercise, you are ensuring that energy and thought that would otherwise deepen your understanding of the consequences of (1) don’t have that effect at all: Those energies are now on a fool’s errand. Also, this way of responding to such data will soon become automatic, for reasons similar to those for which, if an actor rehearses his lines often enough, it becomes automatic, even though it wasn’t before, for him to say Y if he just said X. 
This response-mechanism will further isolate your knowledge of (1). That knowledge will, at least at the level of consciousness, become more and more inconsequential. One cannot in any direct way choose what to believe. (One can choose what to believe only in the sense in which one can choose to gain weight. One can choose to do things that one knows will add mass to one’s body; one cannot choose to gain weight in the way in which one can choose to move one’s arm.) But, within limits, one can choose which beliefs to make operational and which ones to make non-operational; one can choose to do things that will make a given belief impotent and irrelevant. I’m an actor; I’m mediocre at it. I know that fact. I cannot directly choose to cease to have that belief. But I can choose to make it irrelevant; for I can choose an occupation in which my lack of acting ability is irrelevant. Similarly, you can, though to a lesser extent, choose to adopt certain practices that make your knowledge of (1) irrelevant or, in any case, make it less relevant than it would otherwise be. 
In this way, your acceptance of (1) becomes, at the conscious level, a mere shadow of what it would otherwise have been and of what it once was. It becomes like an old officer who, having become senile, is no longer allowed to command troops but who, because the higher-ups feel sorry for him, is allowed to keep his title. 
3.6 Why repressions are never complete successes
