Most data-synthesis occurs below the threshold of consciousness. When you walk into a room, you automatically upload a mass of information and you automatically make many inferences from that data. The uploading and synthesizing of information doesn’t need your conscious cooperation. If it did, you’d know very little indeed. (In fact, it doesn’t involve your cooperation at all, since most of it happens sub-personally. As we’ve seen, minds are more basic than selves. Your self is an agency that regulates existing mental activity, most, if not all, of which consists in the uploading and synthesizing of information. So, speaking both logically and chronologically, the sub-personal gathering and processing of information is more fundamental than the personal gathering and uploading and processing of information.) 
It follows, and is clear on independent grounds, that your decisions as to what goes on in your own mind are of limited scope. Those decisions affect how well the conscious (and pre-conscious) strata of the mind communicate with other strata. They don’t affect in any direct way affect what goes on in other, deeper strata. So, even if you've sincerely resolved to make no effort to interpret aberrant behaviors on your husband's part, that resolution fails to shut off a great deal of the ratiocinative activity that such a discovery automatically precipitates. 
Armed with this information, let us return to our story. You have turned your knowledge of (1) into a dead husk, at least as far as its engagements with other denizens of consciousness are concerned. You have deliberately structured your life in a way that drains your knowledge of (1) of much of its importance. So far as it was in your power to do so, you have chosen to refrain from asking questions that you’d otherwise ask and, therefore, from making inferences that you’d otherwise make. You have thus so eviscerated your knowledge of (1), qua denizen of consciousness, that it might as well not even be conscious. You have thus repressed it. 
But we have a problem. As we made clear in the second to last paragraph, you weren’t able to shut off all of the processes that link that knowledge with other beliefs of yours. You could redirect some of those processes and contaminate others; and maybe you could altogether shut off some of them. But you failed to shut off, or even adulterate, much of that activity. And you didn’t really cease to accept (1); rather, you ceased to treat that belief’s manifestations in consciousness in the way in which you treat those of other beliefs. But, just as you cannot typically uninstall a computer program by dragging the desktop icon for it into the desktop garbage can, you cannot “uninstall” a belief by tinkering with its representations in consciousness. Beliefs are enduring structures. Your belief that 1 + 1 = 2 has been around a long time; it does a lot of work for you even when you’re not consciously deploying it. If you really stopped knowing that 1 + 1 = 2, your way of dealing with the world would suddenly change in a radical way; and the changes would pervade practically every field of endeavor, not just those in which you are required to consciously think that 1 + 1 = 2. That belief isn’t like a mood or any of the other will-o-the-wisps that populate consciousness. And, like any other enduring structure that is constitutive of one’s metabolism, one has, at most, partial control over its fortunes; and, so far as one does have such control, it tends to be of the indirect kind previously discussed. Given any other propositional attitude, the same thing mutatis mutandis is true of it. 
Thus, the conscious representative of your belief in (1) is an innocuous shell. It has been repressed. But it still lives on, and it “presses for discharge” to use Freud’s term. Since, however, you no longer acknowledge its existence, it cannot be discharged through intentional behavior on your part; it must, without your knowing it, insinuate itself into your intentions (e.g., you displace your repressed rage at your father by being mean to your students) or it must be expressed as a symptom (e.g., when you come into contact with situations that remind of your rage towards him, you become crippled by anxiety). 
Whatever it is that you’ve repressed, in order to keep it repressed, you must be able to identify it. But if you can identify it, then you’re conscious of it, and it’s not repressed. So how can it be repressed? We’ll now answer that question. 
3.7 Intrapsychic conflict in relation to repression2: conclusion 
I submit that, if completed in the following way, our story describes one way in which repression2 can occur. 
During FM, you learned that (2) is the case, and you consciously choose to retain that knowledge. This enables you to have your cake and eat it too. (1) and 
(2) hold in virtue of the same, ugly fact. But (1) is much more specific than (2), and an acceptance of (1) is commensurately less likely than an acceptance of (2) to upset an existing psychological integration. At the same time, by virtue of knowing (2), you enable yourself to continue to be aware of an ugly an undeniable fact, and you've thus spared yourself a constant, difficult struggle to not see the obvious. (2) is enough like (1) that, by consciously accepting (2), one's conscious disposition isn't completely antagonistic to the still rational side of you that urges you to accept (1). So, by accepting (2), you're not locked into a draining struggle with the forces of rationality and truthfulness within oneself. At the same time, by accepting (2), you are neutralizing the message of which those forces are trying to apprise you, and you are thus spared some painful realizations as well as the labor-intensive changes to oneself that they demand. 
3.8 Summing up 
We can't choose to destroy the beliefs we don't want to have. But we can partly de-operationalize them. We can choose not to make any conscious effort to delineate their consequences. We can choose to immerse ourselves in activities or lifestyle that don't permit us to pay attention to them. And, though belief is no more voluntary than disbelief, we can also choose to look for reasons to have beliefs that are opposed to those that we wish we didn't have. We can look for such reasons without having much faith that we'll ever find them, just as a lawyer can build a case for a client he knows to be guilty. And the mere fact that we're looking for them means that the belief we wish to destroy no longer fits smoothly into our psychological architecture, since it no longer has the support of the psychological structures implicated in the search. So even though we can't directly choose our beliefs, we can choose to do things that make it harder to pay attention to a given belief than to withdraw our attention from it. The result may be that it becomes so hard to attend to that belief that it becomes one of which we becomes altogether unconscious. 
3.9 Rationalizing rationalization 
People sometimes repress their knowledge of ugly truths about themselves, and they must rationalize in order to prevent the knowledge they've repressed from re-entering consciousness. Unfortunately, the science of psychology has itself become little more than a means by which people rationalize ludicrous attempts to repress their knowledge of these obvious facts. 
Many claim to believe that there is no unconscious mental activity and a fortiori that self-deception, repression, etc. are all artifacts of dated psychoanalytic theories; many claim that the concepts of repression, etc. are internal to a discipline (psychoanalysis) that have been superseded by ‘rigorous’ studies of the physiological underpinnings of thought. The thoroughly hypocritical and self-deceptive character of such pronouncements is evident when one looks at the judgments and conduct of these naysayers. Not a single one of those judgments concern the physiological underpinnings of a person’s psychology; they concern that person’s psychology. And, though this could technically be explained in terms of the fact that people can’t routinely subject others to PET-scans, those PET-scans would be of no psychological interest---to anyone---unless it were shown that the findings of those PET-scans correlated with independently known facts about psychology. The giant discoloration on Smith’s PET-scan would be of no interest to psychology were it not known independently of the results of that PET-scan that Smith’s mentation was aberrant---that Smith thought that he was E.T., or some such, and was therefore mentally ill. Were it discovered that mental activity were mediated by the gall­bladder, the results of PET-scans would immediately cease to be of any psychological interest; for they would no longer be correlated with independently known, and independently explained, psychological data. Which shows that brain-science, to the extent that it’s of any relevance to psychology, is parasitic on psychological knowledge. 
Most of those guilty of this hypocrisy provide no arguments for their view, other than empty, boiler-plate repetitions of the slogan that “science” studies brains and molecules, not intangibles such as emotions and thoughts. 
As for the idea that emotions, thoughts, etc. are too intangible to be worthy of scientific study---that position is decidedly implausible. Whatever we know about the external world—and, therefore, about brains, etc.---we know it through perceptions and thoughts and thus through such alleged intangibles. So while brains and neurons may be ontologically more basic than thoughts, thoughts and perceptions are epistemologically more basic than neurons and brains. Indeed, the term “brain” is, believe it or not, a theoretical term; in characterizing something as a “brain," you are ascribing to it various functions that, without engaging in a great deal of theory-soaked extrapolating, you cannot know it to discharge. “Brain” is a theoretical term that is deeply entrenched in a well-confirmed body of theory. (Hence the illusion that it is a non-theoretical term.) So, speaking epistemologically, these psychological “intangibles” are much more tangible, and their existence infinitely less dubitable, than “tangible” things such as brains. 
But even though many rail against the inevitable encroachment on their lives of psychodynamic truths that they’d very much like to stave off—even though contemporary professional psychologists, having invested their lives in the bankrupt and tautologously false idea that psychology ought to be studied non-psychologically, are especially shrill in their antipathy towards any attitude towards the psychodynamic approach that isn’t one of unalloyed, unquestioning antipathy---very few people have tried to produce bona fidereasons to reject the tenets of such an approach. 
I’ve heard more than one professor of psychology explicitly state that the study of emotions must be replaced by the study of neurons. Why? “Because,” they say, “the study of emotions is itself an emotional enterprise.” This is like saying that thoughts about plants are themselves plants. That anyone of even minimal intelligence should commit such a crass and grievous ratiocinative gaffe is incomprehensible. But it becomes comprehensible if we adopt the hypothesis that, within the mind of a person who advocates this view, there is something with which such discussions resonate uncomfortably and to which that person wants to continue to remain blind. Thus, the denial of emotions is itself a thoroughly emotional position, and the denial of repression is itself an instance of repression. 
Those who deny the existence of emotions and repression say that, in so doing, they’re being “scientific.” But it’s hard to see how such dishonesty and obtuseness could deserve to be so characterized. People don’t see themselves for what they are. Is it scientific to deny this? In some cases, lack of self-knowledge has the same causes as other forms of ignorance: lack of ratiocinative ability, lack of effort, lack of raw data. But given the empirical fact that hyper-intelligent people are quite as prone to not seeing themselves for who they are as their less gifted brethren, it is de rigueur, from the viewpoint of scientific methodology, to suppose another factor to be operative. And it’s pretty clear what this other fact is: People don’t want to see themselves for who they are; so they don’t. Given the obvious and, outside of the discipline of psychology, universally acknowledged fact that people deceive themselves, there’s no coherent way to deny that repression is not only possible, but actual, and not only actual, but integral to the human condition. 
3.4.4 Sartre on repression and the unconscious 
Jean-Paul Sartre held there is no such thing as unconscious mental activity and a fortiori no such thing as repression. His position was that the mind is completely and utterly transparent to itself, it being in the nature of mentationthat a given mind should have immediate and complete access to all of its own contents. But unlike the previously mentioned authors, Sartre argued for his position. And his argument is initially persuasive: 
(SA)[471] 
One must know, said Sartre, what it is that one is trying to keep out of consciousness if one is to succeed in doing so. But so far as one has that knowledge, he continued, one is conscious of the very thing that one is trying to keep out of consciousness; and so far as one is conscious of thing, it isn’t repressed. 
Given this argument, there are two positions one might take: 
(1) Sartre is right and his reasoning is cogent. 
(2) Sartre is wrong. So his argument must be fallacious and we must pinpoint the fallacy in it. 
In my book Conceptual Atomism and the Computational Theory of Mind,I try to identify an error in Sartre’s reasoning. In this chapter, I have developed what I said in that book. But I must make it clear that, although I have no doubt that people do deceive themselves, repress conflicting engendering beliefs and sentiments, etc., I am not convinced that: 
(i) My attempts to show the concepts of self-deception (etc.) to be coherent were entirely successful. 
And supposing for argument’s sake that I have shown those concepts to be coherent, I am not convinced that: 
(ii) The specific forms I have shown them to be capable of 
taking are the forms that they in fact take. 
I’ve identified one possible model (or, rather, two such models: one for repressions1 and one for repression2). But I don't know that I’ve identified models that correctly identify the forms that those phenomena do take. Still, I am convinced that there are elements of truth in those models. And I think it is a philosophical task of the utmost urgency to make it crystal clear what is wrong with Sartre’s powerful argument and also to make it crystal clear what exactly self-deception and repression involve. Unfortunately, philosophers have neglected to do this; which, so far as it’s had any effect on psychology, has encouraged it to go down the blind allies of scientism, methodological incoherence, and (cf. the view now widely endorsed by theoretical psychologists) the obviously false views that constitute contemporary theoretical psychology. 
Chapter 27 Psychopathy, Sociopathy, and Non-Psychopathic, Non-Sociopathic Criminality 
1.0 some preliminary points concerning the concept of mind 
A mind is a collection of structures such that 
(i) those structures create and direct mental activity; 
and such that 
(ii) if X1 and Xn are any two of those structures, one of two conditions is satisfied: (i) at least one of them can directly 
transmit the information stored in it to the other faculty; (ii) there is a set of faculties X1, X2…Xn such that, for each i (1= i = n), Xi, can directly transmit the information it bears to Xi+1. 
(i) is self-explanatory; but (ii) requires clarification. In order for you to acquire information as to what I believe (or hope or fear, etc.), one of three conditions must be met: 
(a) 
I must engage in overt bodily behaviors (e.g., laughing, throwing furniture around) that you can interpret as indicative of my having a certain belief (or whatnot). 

(b) 
I must engage in behaviors that that result in ink-deposits, bursts of noise, or otherwise publicly knowable entities, that you can interpret as being thus indicative. 

(c) 
I must engage behaviors of the sort described in (a) and (b) that, although you do not personally witness them, initiate a testimonial-sequence of which you are on the receiving end. 


Thus, the exchange of information between minds involves non-mental intermediaries and, for that reason, is in some important sense “indirect.” 
But information-transmissions that occur within a mind is either direct or, if it isn’t direct, consists solely of direct information-transmissions (i.e. that consist of sequences of information-transmissions, each one of which is direct, even though, obviously, those direct transmissions jointly constitute an indirect transmission). I know that Jerry is a vicious and prolific murderer. All of a sudden, I see Jerry’s grinning face pressed against my window. The result: I’m afraid. (I wouldn’t have reacted with fear if my pre-existing belief had been to the effect that Jerry was a harmless prankster who, in his attempts to be funny, pressed his grinning face against people’s windows.) Clearly, the information encoded in my knowledge about Jerry is “pooled” with the contents of my sense-perception, that being why I am struck by fear. That pooling occurs without anyone’s engaging in any overt behaviors and, therefore, without anyone’s employing any symbolic intermediaries. The one mental entity’s contents directly merge (if that’s the right word) with the others. 
The fact that these two bodies of information can merge thus directly is not a consequence of their both belonging to the same mind: it is constitutive of their belonging to the same mind. Two mental entities whose contents are thus related ipso facto both “belong” to some one mind. 
Of course, there are distinct mental entities that belong to some one mind that are not as directly related to each other as are the two just-mentioned mental entities. For example, none of the mental entities constitutive of my mind in 1987 is related in that way to any given one of my current mental contents. And there are mental entities in my mind right at this very moment that are not thus interrelated. But, given one of those 1987-mental entities, how are its contents pooled with those of a given one of my 2010 mental contents? Through overt behaviors on my (or somebody else’s) part? No. Through symbolic intermediaries? No. The pooling is accomplished via a series of mental states S1…Sn such that S1’s contents directly merge with those of the aforementioned 1987 mental entity, such that Sn’s contents directly merge with those of the aforementioned 2010 mental entity, and such that, for each i, the contents of Si directly merge with those of Si+1. The same thing mutatis mutandis is true of any two mental entities that simultaneously inhabit a given mind but that, perhaps because the one’s position in that mind is remote from the other’s, cannot pool their contents with the directness with which my knowledge of Jerry and my sense-perception of Jerry’s pale, grinning face can pool their contents. 
Of course, a given mental entity may fail to leave a trace of itself and may thus fail to transmit its contents to other mental entities belonging to the same mind, and the contents of two mental entities that simultaneously belong to a given mind may fail to be pooled together. But were such a pooling of contents to occur, it would be through a series of mental states of the just-described kind; it would not be through non-symbolic intermediaries (e.g., overt behaviors). 
It incoherent to hold that, underlying the various wasps that compose a swarm of wasps, there is some entity, this entity being the swarm per se, to which those various wasps belong but of which they are not constitutive. It is similarly incoherent to suppose that, underlying the contents of a given mind, there is some “self” that has those contents but is distinct from them. Were such a thing to exist, its presence wouldn't enable wrongly interrelated mental entities to belong to the same mind, and its absence wouldn't prevent appropriately interrelated ones from belonging to the same mind. Such a thing would do nothing and would therefore be nothing. 
2.0 Desires vs. values 
Bearing in mind the points just made, let M be some mind (notice that I did not use the word “self”), and let S1…Sn be the series of aggregates of mental entities constituting M.[472] 
In every respect but one, M is just like a human mind. Being housed in a suitably equipped body, M can see things, touch them, etc., and it can thus acquire information concerning the external world. Being rational, M has the ability to draw inferences from that information that enable it to gratify its desires. And, because the body housing it is in good working order, it can act on the intentions to which those inferences lead. But M values nothing. This is the one respect in which it differs from (most) human minds. M wants things, one of those things being to survive. 
But M, we will suppose, values nothing. M sometimes seems to value things; for there are things that it wants that don’t have any obvious survival-value and that don’t relate in any obvious way to the gratification of its urges. But, in such cases, M believes the thing in question to conduce to the gratification of its desires; and so far as M appears to value it for its own sake, it is only because M isn’t disclosing why it believes that thing to be thus conducive. 
There is a sense in which M has a concept of self-improvement. If it knows that acquiring the ability to sing well will, for some reason or other, enable it to gratify some desire that it cannot otherwise gratify, M can resolve to learn to sing well. In general, if M knows that, in order to gratify some urge that it has, it has to change itself in such and such a way, M is able to resolve to make that change. But, beyond that, M cannot possibly have any concept of self-improvement. To improve oneself is to change oneself in such a way that one comes closer to satisfying some standard that one has that, for that reason, one judges to endow one with more value than one had previously. Given that, by hypothesis, M values nothing, it thus has no conception of self-improvement apart from the strictly prudential one just described. 
It follows that all of M’s actions are really reactions. It has desires—it wants to eat, sleep, and so on. Changes in circumstances sometimes bring about changes in what M has to do to gratify these desires; and M is reasonably adept at making the needed changes. But, given that M values nothing, M cannot possibly aspire to make any changes to itself that aren’t intended to gratify some base urge. So any given action on M’s part that isn’t a direct attempt to gratify a base urge is an indirect attempt to so. Each of M’s actions falls into one of two categories: either it’s an attempt (possibly a successful one) to eat or sleep (or some such) or it’s an attempt to do something that, in its judgment, it must to do in order to eat or sleep (or some such). M’s conduct is always reactive. 
So far as M has a self, it does nothing other than mediate between, on the one hand, M’s urges and, on the other hand, M’s beliefs as to what, given the circumstances, must be done if those urges are to be gratified. 
By virtue of having no values, M is necessarily incapable of understanding much that creatures with values, but that are otherwise comparable to M, are capable of understanding. M won’t really have the concept of friendship. (M will have a concept of a strategic alliance, but not of friendship.) M won’t understand why Smith chose a non-lucrative and difficult career path over a lucrative and easy one. M cannot possibly have any concept of intrinsic, as opposed to purely instrumental, value. 
The essence of the human condition will elude M. He feels nothing that involves an ability to value something for its own sake. He can feel frustration (because his efforts to find food are unsuccessful); he can feel rage (towards those who stand between him and the successful execution of his machinations). But he doesn’t love anybody; he doesn’t even like anybody. And there is nothing towards which he aspires. 
M has no concept of legitimacy. There are desirable outcomes and there are undesirable outcomes. But nothing is any more right than anything else. 
2..1 Desires vs. values (continued) 
Some other facts about M deserve mention. M values nothing and therefore doesn’t value the truth, at least not for its own sake. He values the truth only to the extent that, in his judgment, knowledge of it will help him gratify his desires. 
For purely strategic reasons, M may learn to ‘hit the right notes’---to say the right things. In fact, since there isn’t anything that he wants to do or, therefore, to say that he doesn’t believe to be to his strategic advantage, he’ll do his best to do and say the ‘right’ things; unlike actual people, whose deeds and utterances ‘come from the heart’ and, therefore, are often not strategic, M, though in actuality completely heartless, will strike many as having an exceptionally pure heart. M always says the correct thing, as opposed to the human thing. He says what he believes it to be to his practical advantage to say, given what he has learned about human nature from his examination of it. 
It is from an outsider's perspective that M examines people. It is thus to be expected that M's analysis of human nature will be hollow and off-the-mark. At the same time, M's analysis will strike less acute observers as unusually cogent. And, ironically, this is precisely because M is so blind to how people really are. Being incapable of saying anything substantive about the human mind, M will be forced to produce an analysis that is formally good, a corollary being that his analysis will be free of the ragged edges and inconsistencies that vitiate analyses put forth by people who, unlike M, have access to far more psychological data than can possibly be embodied in a few well-manicured truisms. 
Also, in attempting to describe the human mind, M will be his forced by his lack of psychological insight to give undue weight to what people say about themselves. What a person says about himself doesn't reflect who he is so much as it reflect who wants to be and who, depending how convinced he is by his own rationalizations, believes himself to be. Thus, M's descriptions of people will be consonant with their self-serving rationalizations and congenial to their fragile emotional integrations. As a result, they will strike people as accurate and heartening. By contrast, somebody who is psychologically insightful will see people for who they are; and, depending on how much stock people put in their own narratives, his psychological analyses strike people as false or threatening and will be rejected either way. 
2.2 Desires vs. values (continued) 
A corollary of the fact that M doesn’t value truth for its own sake is that he doesn’t negatively value falsehood for its own sake. He has no inhibitions, other than purely prudential ones, to accepting anything, so long as he thinks that, by doing so, he stands to come out ahead. 
Granting that most people are dishonest to some degree---a very high degree, in most cases---they value truth for its own sake. This doesn’t necessarily mean that they’ll tell the truth or that they’ll (consciously) accept it when they see it. But it means that a high, non-prudential regard for truth is operative within them and, in some way or other, will affect what they say, do, and feel. If they lie, they’ll feel guilty; and what they refuse to accept but believe deep down often comes out in their actions. (They refuse to believe that Smith is an evil man and have but kind words to say about him. But they just can’t find it in themselves to go visit him in the hospital when he’s sick, they forget to pick him up at the airport, etc.) 
But it goes without saying that much of the time a person’s high regard for truth is expressed in his telling the truth. I’ve heard many a police officer say that criminals want to tell you the truth. Freud said that what a person doesn’t explicitly say ‘oozes’ (Freud’s own term) out of him; he fidgets; he unwittingly spins what he believes to be purely fictitious yarns that, when the names are changed, are precisely what the individual in question is trying to keep a lid on. (I don’t know whether Freud or the aforementioned police officers had psychopaths in mind when they made these statements. I suspect that they were thinking of non-psychopaths who were dissembling.) 
The reason that truth-serum (sodium pentothal) works so well is that it lowers the inhibitions that one has to erect, and expend considerable energy maintaining, in order to prevent the truth from pouring out of one’s mouth. People are fundamentally truthful---even those that lie 99% of the time. I personally believe that very little of what people say is completely sincere and that the pervasiveness of mendacity cannot be overstated. But that isn’t because people don’t value the truth for its own sake. It’s because, in addition to valuing the truth, they value their own welfare; and their concern for their own welfare overpowers their wish to tell the truth. But, echoing what we just said, this doesn’t mean that a non-psychopathic liar has successfully decommissioned his regard for the truth. His high valuation of it comes out in rearguard ways: he feels guilty; he volunteers at an orphanage (to alleviate his feelings of guilt); he is an unremittingly faithful husband; and, most importantly, the (non­psychopathic) liar will, at least at some level, keep a mental record of the truth, this being, at least in this context, the most important difference between non-psychopaths, be they liars are or truth-tellers, and psychopaths. 
3.0 These points in relation to psychopathy 
M is what is known as a “psychopath.” This is because, for M, what is true has no more (non-instrumental) value than what is untrue, and the essence of psychopathy lies is a complete failure to regard the truth as having any non-instrumental value. Whereas the non-psychopath keeps a mental log of the truth and, since he genuinely values the truth for its own sake, does so even when he doesn’t judge there to be any practical reason to know the truth, M keeps a log of the truth only to the extent that, in his judgment, doing so is a practical necessity. 
This fact about M leads to no end of trouble for him. It’s very hard to know which truths will be of use and which one’s won’t. (In fact, given points made in the previous chapter concerning the limits to which, even in a deterministic universe, the future can be predicted, it is, technically speaking, impossible to be unerring in one’s judgments as to which truths will have which consequences and, therefore, as to which truths are worth knowing and which ones are not.) So it’s extremely easy to make false judgments as to which truths are, and which ones are not, worth logging. 
By the same reasoning mutatis mutandis, it’s hard (or, strictly speaking, impossible) to know exactly which falsehoods are worth regarding as truths--­or, in any case, as operational truths---and which ones are not. Since M’s commitment to keeping the facts straight extends no further than his conviction that it’s in his interest to keep the facts straight, and since it’s hard, if not impossible, to know which facts are the ones that are relevant to one’s designs or a fortiori exactly how they are thus relevant, M often has no mental record, or only a very distorted one, of the facts. These gaps themselves change what it is to M’s practical advantage to believe. 
Since, by obvious extensions of the points just made, these gaps in M’s knowledge tend to spread, M is forced to have an extremely flexible relationship to the truth; M’s failure to see the truth as having any intrinsic (non-strategic) value has the consequence that the purely instrumental value that the truth has for M tends to shrink with the passage of time. 











3.1 These points in relation to psychopathy (continued) 
For these reasons, M’s “narrative”---what he tells both himself and others--­isn’t consistent. In fact, M’s narrative is as mercurial as the weather. M has no stable self-concept. M values nothing. Apart from his having certain base desires, there is nothing fixed about M’s personality. Consequently, M’s personality changes every time he judges there to be a reason to change the manner in which he attempts to gratify those desires. His personality thus changes every time he judges there to be a change in his circumstances that is relevant to the methods he must employ to gratify his desires. 
This means that M’s personality is as fleeting as a summer breeze. And this, in its turn, means that M doesn’t really have a personality. He doesn’t really have a self. He has base desires; he has (mis)information as to how to gratify those desires; and he has intentions corresponding to that (mis)information. But that’s all he has. He is whatever circumstances require him to be. So he is a Potemkin village---an empty suit, a mask covering, not a face, but a void. M is a mind, clearly, but M is not a self; for it no more makes sense to speak of a self that changes with every decision-relevant change in circumstances than it does to speak of a square circle. A self is, by definition, what remains, or tends to remain, constant throughout the changes in the circumstances in which one is operating. 
In the last section of this book, I discuss some famous psychopaths. 

3.2 Who does the psychopath fool? 
Even though everyone lies, the non-psychopath tends to speak from the heart and thus to say what he believes, as opposed to what others want to hear. The psychopath has no tendency at all to say what he believes. For he has no heart and, therefore, no heart to speak from. Since, therefore, his only reasons for speaking are strategic, he says what people want to hear. Thus, even though he doesn't have a heart, the psychopath is more likely than others to strike people as having an exceptionally pure one . 
But the psychopath doesn’t fool everybody. He only fools only those who fall into one of two categories: 
(i) Those who simply lack the acumen to see through his chicanery 
and 
(ii) Those who, because of special circumstances, have an emotional incentive not to see through it. 
Among those falling into the second category are 
(a) Those who are themselves children or parents of psychopaths 
and 
(b) Those who, having been brutalized in some way or other, possibly by some other psychopath, find much needed solace in his trite blandishments and thus have an emotional need to believe in the authenticity of their source. 
Those not thus blinded will see hollow performances in the psychopath’s noble deeds and empty clichés in his insights. In due course, those who see through the psychopath are likely to see that there isn’t a person behind the mask, only a proto-person who believes in nothing, values nothing, and is nothing, and who, so far as he isn’t trying to convince himself and others otherwise, aspires only to gratify base animalistic urges and quasi-human derivatives thereof, such as a need (not a desire—a need) for adulation or wealth. 
4.0 Sociopathy vs. psychopathy vs. non-sociopathic, non-psychopathic criminality 
The terms “sociopath” and “psychopath” are frequently used. Unfortunately, most people, without knowing that they are doing so, tend to use each of those terms to refer to three very different classes of people: 
(1) Those who don’t have consciences at all; 
(2) Those who have consciences but whose consciences have been corrupted by rationalization; 
and: 
(3) Those who have consciences, and whose consciences have not been corrupted by rationalization (or, necessarily, by anything else) but who are evil. 
The result is that these three conditions, each of which is both psychologically and ethically very different from each of the others, are lumped together. 
People in Category 1 are psychopaths. Before we talk about what psychopathy is, we must talk about what it isn’t. Psychopathy must be distinguished from psychosis. Psychosis is the psychological disorganization that results when there is a lowering of the inhibitions that ordinarily limit the freedom with which different parts of the psyche exchange information. A possible consequence of psychosis, but not an inevitable one, is a ‘break from reality’: the psychotic ceases to be able to distinguish between reality and fantasy. But, it must be stressed, such breaks from reality (which may, or may not, include hallucinations), are a by-product of psychosis, not the essence of it. (Incidentally, the hallucinations in question are usually auditory, not visual.) Psychotics are as likely as non-psychotics to have consciences. So psychosis is not psychopathy. Having cleared this up, we will now clear up some widespread misconceptions about psychopathy. 
When people of my nationality and approximate age hear the term “psychopath," they tend to think of Dr. Hannibal Lecter---the evil super-genius in the move Silence of the Lambs. The character of Hannibal Lecter is fictional in every possible sense. There is no real person on whose character his is modeled; and, human psychology being what it is, there couldn’t possibly be such a person. He is about as unrealistic a character as one could imagine. He bears no resemblance to psychopaths---or, really, to anyone else. There is nothing to be learned from the character of Hannibal Lecter about psychopathy, psychopathology, or (setting aside the fact he has certain extremely generic traits in common with actual human beings; e.g., he doesn’t like being in a cage) human psychology generally. 
A related point is that history’s great evil-doers are seldom, if ever, psychopaths. Stalin, for example, was not a psychopath.[473] 
For reasons that we’ll now discuss, psychopaths don’t have the attention-span to do what Stalin did and they cannot experience hatred, or any other emotion, with the depth with which Stalin did. 
One’s conscience has many functions. In certain cases, under certain circumstances, one such function is to prevent one from acting in anti-social ways. But that isn’t the only function of conscience or even the primary one. Non-psychopathic individuals hold themselves to standards. One’s conscience is the part of one’s mind that stores one’s standards and that punishes one if one falls short of them. The standards in question may not be morally good ones. To make the same point, but in a way that doesn’t prejudge any moral questions: those standards may be ones that, if complied with, hurt others more than they help them and (what is a related, but not a coincident, fact) tend to undermine the social institutions on which people’s welfare depends. 
But speaking from a psychological, as opposed to an ethical, viewpoint, there is all the difference in the world between, on the one hand, holding oneself to “bad” standards, whatever that means, and, on the other hand, holding oneself to no standards. Were it not for the standards to which we hold ourselves, we wouldn’t have selves to begin with. Creatures that don’t hold themselves to standards may have minds---but they don’t selves. 
To understand how selves can be different from minds, we must first state some basic truths relating to what minds are. The points about to be made (in Section 4.1) may initially seem purely digressive and irrelevant. But their relevance will soon become clear. 

4.1 Why psychopaths are dysfunctional 
M is a very pure example of psychopathy. Actual psychopaths tend to have some values. They like to tinker with cars, to build model airplanes, or whatnot. But the minds of actual psychopaths differ surprisingly little from M. 
There is one respect in which actual psychopaths resemble M that deserves special mention: like M, they have an extremely flexible relationship to the truth. (Psychopaths are unusually likely to be able to pass lie-detector tests. This isn’t because they are good liars. It’s because----setting aside the rationalization-proof deliverances of their current, as opposed to their remembered, sense­perceptions---a psychopath’s relationship to the truth is so elastic that there isn’t anything that he believes. So the psychopath doesn't have to lie. For the psychopath, some beliefs are more useful than others; so, for him, there is operational truth and falsehood. But there is no such thing as truth and falsehood simpliciter. Thus, psychopaths don’t have to lie. They can pass lie detectors because, to them, the distinctions between truth and falsehood, and therefore between honesty and fraud, are purely technical ones. 
Since, consequently, a psychopath’s grasp on the truth is so tenuous, he is very unlikely to succeed in life.[474] 
His fakery, braggadocio, and showmanship often make him appear in his youth and early adulthood to be success-bound; and sometimes he achieves success, at least in a narrow professional sense. But their careers tend to fall apart. The highly conditional nature of their commitment to the truth forces them to make decisions on the basis of an unduly constricted body of knowledge, the results being that they are likely to commit horrible gaffes that alienate them from institutions within which one has to operate to succeed. 
Also, because their grasp of the truth is so feeble, they are prone to act impulsively and therefore to commit acts that, to any non-psychopath, would obviously have consequences for them of the most adverse kind. According to Hervey Cleckley, whose book The Mask of Sanity is undoubtedly the best one on the subject of psychopathy, they do not do this because of an unconscious sense of guilt. There is, Cleckley says, no independent evidence that any such force is operative in these people. My own experience strongly supports Cleckley’s contention. 
4.1.1 Why psychopaths are dysfunctional (continued) 
A related point is that psychopaths are extraordinarily bad at learning from their mistakes. [475] 
They make the same mistakes over and over again. They always have a story. And those stories often seem cogent when taken in isolation from one another and when considered in abstraction of the psychopath’s back story. But their stories---which, in my experience, they describe using words such as “cogent," “rigorous," and “scientific”---turn out to be models of flimsy reasoning from half-true premises; and they have nothing more than a veneer of cogency, which, on the rare occasions when you can pin them down, are easily penetrated. 
Psychopaths thus bear no resemblance to Hannibal Lecter and other Hollywood villains who are often (mis)characterized as “psychopaths”; and they bear no resemblance to similarly mischaracterized, real life villains, such as Stalin and Mao. 
Psychopaths are dysfunctional. They can pull off cons. But that is pretty much all they can do. They can put on a good show for a while. They are charming, at least at first; they are, or seem to be, witty; and they often strike one as exceedingly intelligent and learned. 
But psychopaths are like a house of cards.[476] 
To borrow a simile used by Mary Aston in her novel The Incredible Charlie Carewe[477], which depicts a psychopath, psychopaths are to people what snake-skins are to snakes. For one thing, the proverbial charm of the psychopath’s is doubly fraudulent. First of all, it hides their absolute indifference to others. Second, at the end of the day, they aren’t charming. Or, rather, they aren’t charming: it is the people from whom they plagiarize that are charming. More often than not, a psychopath’s genuinely witty comments turn out to have been lifted. And, when a psychopath’s attempts at charm don’t involve plagiarism, it isn’t witty at all, consisting as it does of stale clichés and curiously two-dimensional pseudo­apercus. 


4.2 The psychopath's veneer of intelligence 
These points mutatis mutandis hold of the psychopath's proverbial intelligence. Psychopaths are more likely than non-psychopaths to show-case what they know, and they're more likely than non-psychopaths to choose endeavors that will lead to results they can show-case. Given a particular field, the psychopath will learn just enough to convince non-experts that he's an expert in it. If he knows that a given person is an expert in a certain field, he'll avoid that topic when talking with him or he'll avoid that person altogether. What the psychopath lacks in actual insight, he makes up for in plagiarized insights. What he lacks in both actual and plagiarized insights, he makes up for in his delivery. Psychopaths are long on delivery and short on content. A lecture given by a psychopath is likely to strike those who attend it as profound and to strike those who read transcripts of it as curiously hollow. 
I would like to quote from Robert Lindner’s (1944) classic Rebel Without a Cause (no relation to the movie of the same name, which it predates): 
In the literature on [psychopathy] frequent mention is made of the “high” intelligence of psychopaths…However derived, these notions are misleading or at least insufficient to serve either as diagnostic aids or explanatory propositions….So far as intelligence per se is concerned…what is outstanding about psychopathy is not its arithmetic proportions but is its peculiar variety and design…The intelligence of the psychopath can be described only adjectivally and in terms of the [psychopath’s] whole personality. Perfectly adapted to his needs in the same way as protective coloring is suited to the preservation of the life of an animal, all those psychological functions (thinking, understanding, imagining, remembering, etc.) which are held to be components of “intelligence” have in the psychopath superimposed on them an aura of shrewdness and secretive cunning, of calculating canniness. These elements not only serve psychopathic ends but effectively distort and divert all known measuring instruments, the rigid designs of which prevent their divinatory use with such individuals…A further striking feature of the intelligence of the psychopath, and one which appears only after long time acquaintance with such individuals, is concerned with the amazing excess-cargo of uncoordinated and useless information they possess. Frequently one is misled by their typically encyclopaedic range into considering them persons of high intellect, even of culture. Penetration with time, however, discloses that, like the veneer of mahogany applied to inferior wood, this mass of “knowledge” is superficial and undigested; that it is free-floating, lacking the requisite elements of cohesiveness and relativity.[478] 


4.3 The reverence that people have for psychopaths 
The reverence that people have for these empty vessels has nothing to do with the all but non-existent content of what they’re saying; it has instead to do with their charisma and braggadocio. They exude an unabashed self-confidence and authoritativeness. When discussing U.S. history, a non-psychopathic expert on U.S. history is likely to appear self-confident, because he really is self-confident. And when he’s talking about non-standard analysis (supposing that he isn’t also a mathematician), he’s likely to lack self-confidence and, therefore, to appear to lack it. 
A psychopath, on the other hand, always exudes self-confidence. He may be an expert on what he’s talking about, or may know nothing about it at all. In each case, he will exude the same level of confidence. There will be no changes in mannerisms, no vocal modulations, no trace of anxiety that would indicate self-doubt or compensatory hubris. Regardless how confident he ought to be, he will appear utterly self-assured. He is likely to use histrionics to draw attention away from what he’s actually saying. In general, psychopaths are confidence-men (con-men). They con by exuding confidence. 
There are two doctrines to which all but one or two of the many psychopathic professors I’ve known were drawn: Marxism and Cultural Relativism. What these doctrines have in common is that they deny there is such a thing as truth. Marxism: “The truth is a lie told by the ruling class; so there is no truth.” Cultural Relativism: “Truth is whatever a given culture believes it to be; so there is no truth.” 
Setting aside the fact that any doctrine to the effect that there is no truth is self-defeating, any such doctrine is maximally easy to absorb, since, if that doctrine is right, there is ipso facto nothing to absorb. And to the extent that a given discipline accepts such a doctrine, its methods are ipso facto purely exhortatory; for, if there is no truth, then the traditional way of finding the truth­--namely, objectively considering the relevant evidence and making inferences from that evidence that are licensed by rules of inference whose truth-conduciveness has been established---belongs in the ash-can. 

4.3 The Psychopath’s psychological architecture fundamentally different from that of the non-psychopath 
In any case, psychopaths are not at all like Hannibal Lecter. Psychopaths are frauds. They can’t accomplish anything without cheating. Hannibal Lecter is evil. But he isn’t a fraud; he isn’t a cheat; his intellectual accomplishments are legitimate. 
Also, Hannibal Lecter was a person, in Frankfurt’s sense of the word. That by itself means that he’s not a psychopath. Psychopaths are pseudo-people. Psychopaths have minds, but they don’t have selves. They have narratives that replace the selves they lack. This is why (intellectually minded) psychopaths are drawn towards nihilism (nothing means anything) and relativism (there’s no right or wrong; no person’s viewpoint is any more accurate than anyone else’s; no culture’s values are any more reasonable than any other culture’s). As far as a psychopath can tell, there is no difference between truth and propaganda. So, after a fashion, he really does believe that all opinions are equally correct. An opinion is a view as to what the truth is. So, by virtue of having an opinion, one is assuming that there is such a thing as truth. That assumption is false, according to the psychopath: all opinions 100% wrong, he believes, and are therefore equally wrong. 
The word “value” means nothing to the psychopath. He can acquire a rudimentary understanding of how to use value-related words. He can figure out that theft is “bad” and that saving a drowning child is “good.” But he doesn’t know what these terms mean. (Wittgenstein urged acceptance of the thesis that there is nothing to a word’s meaning that isn’t known by knowing how that word is used. (See Chapter 1 for an examination of this thesis.) In Section 6.4, it will become clear why this is relevant.) So he really does believe that all value-systems are equal: they are all, he believes, 100% wrong and they are therefore equally wrong. 

4.4 Psychopaths are legion 
Psychologists say that psychopaths make up around 3% of the population. There are two reasons why I put little stock in that statistic. First, it’s unclear what it means. Any degradation of psychological architecture due to a loss of truthfulness with oneself is ipso facto psychopathy. One’s psychological integrity can be intact in some respects but not in others. Also, psychological integrity comes in degrees. So, unless we’re told in what respect a person’s psychological integrity must be damaged, and to what degree, we’re not being told anything in being told psychopaths make up 3% of the population. 
Second, the diagnostic techniques employed by psychology presuppose that there are very rigid and simple connections between a person’s psychological condition and his outward behavior. This, I suspect, is a by-product of psychology’s attempt over the last 50 years to scientize itself. That attempt is driven by a combination of anti-mentalism and strict empiricism. These doctrines jointly constitute a framework that recognizes no diagnostic methods that don’t link psychological conditions with forms of behavior so narrowly defined that instances of them are as unmistakable as the color of litmus-strip. 
It follows that such tests are of limited probative value, given that different conditions can assume the same outward form and that a given condition can assume different outward forms. Also, such tests being what they are, it is easy for someone to figure out how must act, when being administered such a test, if the resulting diagnosis is to be exactly what he wants it to be. Being the con-artists that they are, psychopaths are inevitably quick to acquire precisely this knowledge. 
In any case, unlike the psychologists who came up with the previously-mentioned statistic, Cleckley succeeds in giving us some understanding of the extent to which psychopathy is a part of mankind’s lot: 
It becomes difficult to imagine how much of the sham and hollowness which cynical commentators have immemorially pointed out in life may come from contact in serious issues with persons affected in some degree by the disorder [namely psychopathy] we are trying to describe. The fake poet who really feels little; the painter who, despite his loftiness, had his eye chiefly on the lucrative fad of his day; the fashionable clergyman who, despite his burning eloquence or his lively castigation of the devil, is primarily concerned with his advancement; the flirt who can readily awaken love but cannot feel love or recognize its absence; parents who, despite smooth convictions that they have only the child’s welfare at heart, actually reject him except as it suits their own petty or selfish aims: all these types, so familiar in literature and in anybody’s experience, may be as they are because of a slight affliction with the personality disorder now under discussion. I believe probable that many persons outwardly imposing yet actually of insignificant import really are so affected.[479] 

5.0 Sociopathy vs. Psychopathy 
A psychopath: somebody with no conscience. 
A sociopath: somebody who has a very corrupt conscience or no conscience but who, during his formative years, did have a non-corrupt conscience and whose psychological architecture, developing as it did during those years, is that of a non-psychopathic person. 
The mechanisms of self-censure and self-correction that distinguish the non-psychopath from the psychopath are present in the sociopath. And, in most cases of sociopathy, those mechanisms are laid down and developed before sociopathization occurs; so they’re fairly hardy. Thus, at least in its structural respects, the sociopath’s psychological integration is, at least during the early phases of sociopathy, more similar to the non-psychopath’s than to the psychopath’s. 
To be sure, the sociopath’s mind lacks the values that give integrity to a non­psychopath’s mind. (I’m referring to psychological, not moral, integrity.) But since those values were once present in the sociopath, and since his psychological architecture was formed when he still had values and wasn’t yet a sociopath, that architecture is basically that of a non-psychopath. 
That said, it is entirely by virtue of the force of inertia that the sociopath’s psychological architecture doesn’t collapse. The sociopath’s psychological integrity, which is what distinguishes him from the psychopath, is, at this point, purely vestigial. Consequently, there is little keeping the sociopath from becoming a psychopath. 
A psychopath is a pseudo-person. He constructs a narrative that acts as a surrogate for the life-history that, had he actually had a self, he would have had. To be sure, the psychopath has experiences, just like everyone else, and he remembers them as well the next person. But he doesn’t have a life’s story. Much of what a normal person refers to as his “life-experience” or his “story” consists, not of his experiences, but of his reactions to his experiences: the distress they caused him; the self-criticism they prompted him; the subsequent changing of his values and his objectives; the elation he felt at having triumphed over the deficiencies in himself that led to his previous failures. These meta-experiences that unify a person’s various first-order experiences into a cohesive structure. That structure is his “life’s story.” The psychopath experiences doesn’t have such meta-experiences. His life is a mere sequence of experience. The psychopath values nothing. Therefore, he doesn’t analyze his experiences, unless there is some immediate practical reason to do so. He doesn’t experience the internal struggles make us who we are (“who am I?,” “ what do I really want?,” “am I going to law school because I really want to be a lawyer, or because that’s the ‘right’ thing to do?”, etc.). The psychopath is never conflicted (except in some pragmatic sense---he may not know whether or not he has to take a right turn if he’s to make it to work on time). He never wonders whether he’s being true to himself. For a person who values nothing, and therefore doesn’t value truth, doesn’t care whether he’s being true himself; he doesn’t even know what it is to be true to oneself. Nor does the psychopath come into conflict with other people. Of course, other people inevitably stand in his way. But the psychopath merely sees people as threats or nuisances; he is no more in conflict with them than you are in conflict with a bobcat that you’re defending yourself against. The bobcat is a threat to your survival. But it isn’t by representing an indictment of your psychological integration, or the values constitutive thereof, that it’s a threat to you. So your altercation with the bobcat, though a serious and potentially life-altering or life-terminating matter, isn’t a drama. There’s nothing distinctively human about it. There’s drama only where there is a clash of values, and there’s a life story only where there’s drama---­only, that is to say, where one has value-driven experiences in response to one’s experiences and where, consequently, one’s current experiences, thoughts, and decisions are informed, not merely by what has happened to one, but the value-driven changes that one made to oneself in response to those experiences. Since the psychopath has no values, his current experiences, etc. are not thus informed; he lives in the moment, in a pseudo-Zen manner. He has no life’s story. There is no “him”, really. There is a mind; but the meta-mental superstructure that is a person’s self is quite absent. 
The psychopath has to seem like an actual person. Otherwise, he’ll be seen for the freak that he is and won’t be able to gain people’s trust or therefore to predate upon them. So, because he has to fit in and therefore seem human, he has to create a life’s story; he has to manufacture a narrative. He is likely to have different narratives, since a narrative that works with one person may not work with another. Those narratives are not based on a first-hand understanding of what personhood really is. They are based on what, in the psychopath’s judgment, is most likely to work. What sort of narrative he concocts depends on who he’s dealing with and what he wants. Inevitably, his narratives are not completely false; in fact, they may be largely accurate. But that isn’t because he values the truth; it’s because a pure lie is much less effective than one that has a component of truth; and it’s also because, if his narratives were pure lies, he would have a hard time keeping them straight and would seen be seen for what he is. 
The psychopath’s self is just a script, albeit one that, like many scripts, isn’t pure fiction. The psychopath isn’t speaking from the heart; he’s reading from a teleprompter. Since he doesn’t exist, except in the same sense as Elmer Fudd, there is nothing in himself to which he wishes to be true and thus no off-message point that he wants to make. So the psychopath is unusually likely to say just what will make the boss promote him, just what will make Sally fall in love with him, just what will make Bill hand over his life’s savings to him. He’s unusually likely to be seen as “a great guy.” 
One corollary of the fact that the psychopath has no self deserves special mention. When you refer to a non-psychopath by his name---when you refer to him as "Smith", or whatnot----the way in which you are using that expression is different from the way in which you are using that expression when referring to a pet parakeet of the same name. The parakeet is an organism that has a mind but not a self. Since personal names (e.g. "Smith"), as opposed to impersonal names (e.g. "Paris"), are, by virtue of their semantics, to be given only to beings that have selves, parakeets cannot have personal names, and attempts to give them such names, when not ironic, embody some seriously misguided views about parakeet-psychology (or about semantics). When we refer to a psychopath by his legal name, we are using that expression in the same, improper way in which we would use it to refer to a parakeet. 
5.0.1 Cleckley on the nature of psychopathy 
Two quotations from Cleckley will reinforce and clarify what we’ve been saying: 
The [psychopath’s] out functional aspect masks or disguises something quite different within, concealing behind a perfect mimicry of normal emotional, fine intelligence, and social responsibility a grossly disabled and irresponsible personality. 
Cleckley (1964), p. 420. 
Attempts to interpret the [psychopath’s] disorder do not, of course, furnish evidence that he has a disorder or that it is serious. For reliable evidence of this we must examine his behavior. Only here, not in psychopathologic formulations, can we apply our judgment to what is objective and demonstrable. Functionally and structurally all is intact on the outside. Good function (healthy reactivity) will be demonstrated in all theoretical truths. Judgment as well as sound reasoning will appear at verbal levels. Ethical as well as practical considerations will be recognized in the abstract. A brilliant mimicry or sound, social reactions will occur in every test except the test of life itself. In the psychopath, we confront a personality neither broken nor outwardly distorted but of a substance that lacks ingredients without which normal function in major life issues is impossible. Cleckley (1964), p. 422. 


5.1 Rationalization: The gateway to sociopathy 
Smith is a talented novelist, and he considers novel writing to be an extremely valuable activity and he also rightly considers it to be the most valuable activity of which he personally is capable. For a while, Smith tries to write novels and to indulge his craving for pot and junk food. But he soon finds that his pot-induced lethargy put him in an either/or situation. Either smoke pot or write novels. But don’t do both. It isn’t possible. 
Being lazy and self-indulgent, Smith chooses to smoke pot and eat junk foot. At first, he feels terrible guilt as a result. But his guilt, though intense, isn’t intense enough to overpower the forces, or lack thereof, within him that are responsible for his ditching his career as a novelist in favor of a non-career as a binge-eating junky. Still, the ever present, gnawing feeling of guilt is souring his otherwise unalloyedly blissful existence. 
He thus has a choice. Either: 
(1) Start writing novels and stop smoking pot/eating junk food; 
or: 
(2) Eliminate the part of conscience that makes him feel guilty for taking the easy path (smoking pot, etc.), as opposed to the difficult, but right, path (writing novels). 
Taking path (2) involves Smith’s telling himself that, in fact, he’s doing the right thing, as opposed to the easy thing. It involves Smith’s reconstituting his values so as to validate the weakness-driven choice that he has made. Taking path (2) involves Smith’s rationalizing. It involves his constructing a spurious narrative relative to which the wrong choice is the right one. Such a narrative might be along the following lines[480]: 
(SR) I like writing novels, and I’m good at it. But it's morally wrong to write novels, since people's use novels to escape from ugly truths instead of dealing with them. The apparent counterexamples to this are actually the best illustrations of it. X, let us suppose, is a latter day Steinbeck. He writes about the insidious machinations of the wealthy and their devastating effects on the poor. His novels are masterpieces. But they do anything in the way of helping bring about the needed social changes? No. They do the opposite, in fact. X’s novels turn the sufferings of society’s victims into a source of amusement. Token concern for their plight becomes all the rage; it becomes chic to wear T-shirts emblazoned with anti-establishment slogans. The corporation that manufactures those T-shirts uses over-seas sweatshop-labor. It dumps toxic waste into reservoirs. Its board members vivisect poor people for fund. So it is itself a pillar of the iniquitous social order that it was X’s novels describe. 
So, even though X’s heart was in the right place, he his hands are covered in blood. But his hands would be clean if he'd smoked pot, instead of writing his novels. Thus, it is my ethical duty not to write novels and to smoke pot all the time. 
Even if SR is correct, Smith is still living a lie and, as a result, he is, or will in due course become, a hollow shell. For, even if SR is correct, it isn’t Smith’s acceptance of SR that leads him to take Path (2): it is his laziness that does so. In deferring to his laziness, Smith is alienating himself from his core values. And, in doing this, Smith is alienating himself from himself and from the sources of energy on which, when attempting to perform any sort of action, he must draw. For, as we’ve established, the self is a set of values---or, more precisely, an agency that oversees and manages an otherwise desultory stream of mental activity, giving it cohesiveness and thereby endowing that mind-constituting, but self-less stream with an enduring identity; and, as we’ve also established, it is through its imposition of values on this empty, identity-less stream of mentation that this supervisory agency accomplishes these feats. So, in so far as his conduct is rationalization-driven, it isn’t self-driven, a consequence being that, so far as Smith’s rationalizations play an increasing role in Smith’s life-path, Smith is regressing into a condition of not having a self---of being an empty shell, who, lacking in any real identity, has to fall back on the pseudo-identities of which his rationalizations and false narratives avail him. 
5.1.1 Rationalization: The gateway to sociopathy (continued) 
Rationalizations tend to involve putting sincerely held beliefs to insincere use. Individual facts are not denied; but they are taken out of context, and the patterns they form are conveniently overlooked. Part of what makes it relatively easy to overlook such patterns is that, whereas one literally sees (or otherwise sense-perceives) raw data, patterns aren’t in any literally sense seen. To "see" a pattern is to become aware of a commonality holding among many different events, between any two of which there is a gap in time and which, taken collectively, may occupy a long period of time. Thus, seeing a pattern involves making correct judgments on the basis of information stored in memories. 
It follows that patterns are easily overlooked. Memories are easily corrupted, especially when they relate to emotionally touchy subject-matter. Also, the making of any judgment of any sophistication involves acceptance of an intricate network of inference rules and general principles. Given a person who is incapable of rigorous thought and is just slightly biased, or who is capable of rigorous thought but is deeply biased, it doesn’t take much to make that person doubt the accuracy of the aforementioned constellation of beliefs. A rigorous thinker is ipso facto likely to have the wherewithal to produce arguments that, although hollow and sophistical, initially appear to meet his own high standards of proof and that consequently suffice to give him reason to doubt the accuracy of a once cherished belief. An unrigorous thinker ipso facto needs little argumentative inducement to part with a once cherished belief and therefore probably does have the modicum of argumentative sophistication needed to give himself that inducement. 
Actually, I doubt that any real acumen is needed to rationalize; and I suspect that, although intelligent people are probably better rationalizers ceteris paribus than unintelligent people, the degree to which the former surpass the latter as rationalizers isn’t even close to being commensurate to the degree to which the former surpass the latter as thinkers. These points are discussed and defended in the next section; so I’ll hold off on them for now. 
The rationalizer does not do what he thinks is right. Moreover, it’s not through simple ignorance that he does the wrong thing. He’s not in the same category as somebody who mistakenly thinks that smoking is healthy and therefore smokes. He’s in the same category as a smoker who knows that smoking is unhealthy and tries to stave off the subsequent wrath of his conscience by concocting some narrative relative to which his hands are clean (e.g., “It’s not as though I’m an axe-murderer---in the big scheme of things, smoking is a harmless vice,” “we all die anyway---why not do what I enjoy while I’m still alive?,” etc.). 

5.1.2 Why do people rationalize?[481] 

Rationalizers see the world as they want it to be, not as it is. Thinkers see the world as it is not as they want to be. So people have an incentive both to rationalize and to not think. 
Also, rationalizing is the path of least resistance. Working for what you want is hard; pretending that you have it is easy. This obviously gives people another incentive both to rationalize and to not think. 
Also, thinking does, whereas rationalization does not, involve recognizing that one is fallible and, therefore, that the world was not designed to validate one's opinions. Thinking involves subordinating one's mental activities to objective norms. This involves evaluating one's own thoughts and, oftentimes, admitting that they're wrong. Rationalization involves not subordinating one's thoughts to objective norms and not admitting that one is wrong. So the rationalizer's ego is spared the hard knocks that the thinker's ego has to endure. 
Rationalization is a manifestation of our instinct to flee from danger. Through physical flight, we flee from an external threat; through 
rationalization, we flee from an internal threat.[482] 
Thus, a person's tendency to rationalize has deep instinctual roots. For this reason, rationalizing doesn't involve exercising one's agency. In fact, it involves letting sub-agential, instinctual forces triumph over one's agency. So far as one's agency is involved in the construction of a rationalization, it is nothing more than the puppet of sub-agential instincts, its sole function being to make instinct-driven, lapses in self-discipline and rationality appear to oneself to be expressions of rationality and self-control. Of course, everyone rationalizes, even the greatest of thinkers. But to the extent that one’s mental activity mediates rationalization, that activity is sub-agential; and to the extent that one’s mental activity mediates genuine thought, it is agential. These points are conjectural, it must be emphasized. Nonetheless, I wish to end this section with a point that is even more conjectural than those just made. We all know people who are extraordinarily “street smart”, even though their discursive abilities are those of somebody whose level of intelligence is extremely low. Speaking personally, I used to believe that a street smart person was an intelligentwho didn't have the good fortune to receive a decent education; I used to believe that, if a given street smart person had been properly educated, he would be as discursively intelligent as, in actuality, he was street smart. 
Having had a number of illuminating exchanges with a talented student of mine, Jared Murphy, I no longer hold this view. Mr. Murphy isn't a criminal in any sense of the word. But he grew up on the streets. Most of his childhood friends became career gang-members. Many of them are either dead or in jail and those who aren’t soon will be. I apprised Mr. Murphy of my view that street intelligence was merely a different manifestation of the cognitive faculties that, in an educated person, are manifested as discursive intelligence. Mr. Murphy disagreed. Here is what he said verbatim: 
First of all, most criminals are extraordinarily “street smart”, and very few non-criminals are particularly street smart. I have had many friends who chose a life of crime and who, quite early in life, become phenomenally street smart. Most of those people were not only not intellectually gifted, but were of below average intelligence. 
My experiences have made it clear to me that so-called street smart people aren’t smart at all. They are not natively intelligent people who weren’t educated; and had they been educated, they would have been intellectually mediocre, at best. 
Of course, some criminals are smart; the ones at the top of the heap---the Pablo Escobars, the Al Capones---are obviously highly intelligent. (I’ve dealt only with lower-echelon criminals; I’ve never met a crime-lord. But given what such people accomplish, one doesn’t have to met them to know that they’re smart.) 
But, apart from a few kingpins, criminals are, pretty much invariably, not intelligent. In fact, a prerequisite for street smarts is an absence of intelligence. The intelligent person’s cognitive search space is too large. When he has to make a speedy decision, he has to rummage through so many possible scenarios, that, before he’s made up his mind, he’s dead. 
Surviving on the streets isn’t about being smart; it’s about 
having very highly developed instincts. The only way to 
have such highly developed instincts is to be an instinct-
driven person. And the only way to be an instinct-driven 
person is to lack intelligence. 
There are a couple of reasons for this. First, intelligent 
people reflect on their decisions and therefore tend to 
devalue their instincts. Second, for the intelligent person, 
thought becomes an end unto itself and the structures that 
mediate thought end up crowding out those that mediate 
instinctive responses.Thus, the instincts of a thinker cannot 
possibly be as finely honed as those of a non-thinker. 
To be sure, I’ve known people who are reasonably smart 
and have reasonably good instincts. But, on the streets, 
“reasonably good” isn’t good enough. The margins are too 
thin. Things happen to quickly. And the things that happen 
are irreversible. On the streets, you aren’t given two weeks' 
notice; you’re given two in the back of the head. No matter 
how little formal education a person has had, that person is a 
dead mean on the streets if his natural bent to is to be a 
thinker. That person will start to question his lifestyle. As a 
result, he'll be less "in the zone" than his unintelligent 
counterpart and therefore less attentive to the nuances to 
which, as a criminal, he must be attentive and less quick on 
the draw in situations where the first person to pull the 
trigger is the one who lives. So, long story short, street smart 
people aren’t smart. They can't be. They have to be people 
whose only option is to hone their animal instincts. If they 
have any intelligence, that won't be their only option. 
Since, unlike Mr. Murphy, I didn't grow up on the streets, I don't whether 
he's right or wrong. But my suspicion is that, while there is almost certainly 
an element of hyperbole in his words, there is more truth than falsehood in 
them. 
5.2. Why rationalization is inevitable and often healthy 
Everybody rationalizes. Setting aside people who are exceedingly damaged (e.g., people who have sustained serious brain-damage) it is psychologically impossible for a person not to rationalize. 
Moreover, it isn’t always bad to rationalize. In fact, it would be bad to never rationalize. There would be decision-paralysis if the brain-centers tasked with making decisions were flooded with too much truth. Also, one’s conscious mind can only withstand a modicum of truth, lest one’s self-concept sustain irreparable damage. Speaking from an evolutionary-biological perspective, knowledge is a means to an end, the end being health. A complete absence of conscious knowledge isn’t health-conducive, but neither is an excess of such knowledge. One has to make decisions in real-time. One’s “search-space” can’t be too large. Moreover, so many truths of which one is aware, at some level or other, are so ugly that one cannot confront them all at once and must do so in a piecemeal fashion. 
People can’t deal with everything at once. So they compartmentalize. Sometimes bodies of information that are conscious (i.e., are readily accessible to consciousness, not being held down by the forces of repression) are compartmentalized. But this form of compartmentalization is unstable. Two pieces of information both of which one is consciously aware, tend to coalesce. There’s only so long one can consciously know both (a) that one’s good buddy Smith is the only person who could have put arsenic in one’s tea and (b) that one has been hospitalized repeatedly for arsenic poisoning without also knowing (c) that Smith isn’t really one’s good buddy. 
Also, there isn’t a sharp line between rationalization, on the one hand, and the legitimate employment of rationality on the other. There are three reasons for this: 
(1) 
The construction of rationalizations tends to involve the legitimate employment of rationality. 

(2) 
As previously stated, some rationalizations are true. And, in at least some cases, the difference between a belief that results from rationalization-based belief and a ‘legitimate’ belief isn’t that the former is, whereas the latter is not, true; nor, necessarily, is it even that the former is, whereas the latter is not, arrived at in 

a spurious manner. In at least some cases, the difference lies in the use to which the belief---which may be true and legitimately arrived at—is put. And a given (legitimate and legitimately arrived at) belief can be put to different uses. It can be used to figure out how to help struggling nations become more prosperous and it can also be used to figure out how to impoverish those same nations. 

(3) 
A given belief can be a rationalization in one respect and a non-rationalization in others. One may have different reasons for arriving at a given belief, some of them embodying wishful thinking and others embodying sober consideration of the facts; and one may use a given belief as the basis for a rationalization and for a legitimate pursuit of the truth.
