You believe that you mom is a good person partly because you want to believe that and partly because it’s true to a large extent, though not as large an extent as you’d like to think, and the evidence supports it, though not as much you’d like. And you can put your belief that your mother is a good person to different uses: you can use it as an excuse to look the other way when she does something that a good person would not do (rationalization) or you can use it to subject a claim made about her to sober examination (non­rationalization); e.g. on the basis of your belief that your mother is a good person, you may accept the rationalization that her not allowing you to do athletics wasn’t intended to emasculate you or to vent her rage at your father (who was a professional athlete and incessantly carried on with other women before dumping your mother); and on the basis of that same belief, you can determine that so and so is demented or deliberately untruthful, since he routinely makes claims about your mother (e.g. “she eats little children”) that plainly aren’t true. 




5.3 When rationalization is not healthy 
Given that everybody is, to some degree or other, a rationalizer, what is the difference between those rationalizers who sociopathize and those who don't? There are two differences: 
(1) 
For non-sociopaths, rationalizations are misfortunes, not deeds. For sociopaths, they're deeds, not misfortunes. Non-sociopaths don't seek out rationalizations; rationalizations are sought out in them but not by them. In the non-sociopath, rationalization happens sub-agentially. In the sociopath, rationalizations are deeds; he seeks them out, perfects them, and accepts them. In the sociopath, rationalizations also occur sub­agentially. So the difference between the sociopath and the non-sociopath isn't that the faculties responsible for the construction of rationalizations have been transferred; it's that, without losing any of their original (sub-agential) jurisdiction, they spread: they appropriate the subject's agency, leading in some cases to a complete reconstitution of the self.[483] 


(2) 
Non-sociopaths care about the truth. Sociopaths do not. The non-sociopath's concern for the truth keeps his personality intact; it insulates it from his rationalizations. The sociopath's self has no such insulation. As a result, it is eventually taken over by its own rationalizations. 


The sociopath, unlike the psychopath, was once a person. The sociopath's personality-architecture, at least during the initial stages of sociopathization, is far more like that of non­sociopathic non-psychopathic than is the personality architecture, what rudiments of it there happen to be, of the psychopath. When the soon-to-be sociopath stops caring about the truth, the rationalizations that swoop in occupy the same positions in that personality as the beliefs and values that they displaced. Thus, for a while at least, a sociopath's rationalizations operate within the same sort of structure as a non-sociopath's genuinely held beliefs. But that structure embodies values that the person in question no longer has, and it eventually collapses. 
(2) is a corollary of (1). If a given person has no concern for the truth, there is nothing preventing him from actively seeking out rationalizations. 

5.3 Sociopaths incessantly moralize 
Sociopaths are very moralizing. When speaking with them, one cannot be oneself; one must behave in a hyper-correct fashion, lest one incur their virulently ill-willed, pseudo-moral vituperations Being with a sociopath is like being in Oceania, the hyper-totalitarian society described in Orwell’s novel 1984. Just as, in Oceania, one is vaporized if one has any resistance to accepting the government’s lies, so, when speaking with a sociopath, one is censured, and thus vaporized, as it were, if one doesn’t operate within the sociopath’s candy-coated, morality-drenched narrative. 
But the morality is fake; it has nothing to do with the sociopath’s beliefs as to how the world ought to be. This fake morality has four sources. 
First, sociopaths don’t want people to see them for the vampires that they are. They want people to think that they’re good. It isn't only for strategic reasons that they want this. The sociopath has nothing but his image. Whatever substance he one once had has been drained away and replaced with a narrative. He's reading from a teleprompter, not speaking from the heart. There is no heart left. There is no self, in other words. So sociopaths need the approval of others to feel that they have selves. And that's why they insist on saying "correct" things, instead of human things. It's also why they're drawn to "glamour." Show business is replete with sociopaths. Second, because sociopaths are so alienated from what is (or, when it existed, was) human in themselves, they are forced to “phone it in”: they have to read scripts; there is no longer a person, a self, within them for whom they can speak; if their statements expressed their true inner lives, it would consist of nothing but the tirades of an infant who hasn’t yet acquired a self and whose emotional life is driven by infantile narcissism and, for that reason, sheer detestation of those who interfere with their infantile aspirations. 
Third, sociopaths resent their condition; they resent selling their souls; they resent being made to give up their selves; and, for that reason, they’re envious of those who have hung on to their selves. So they lash out at those people--­but, not wanting to be seen for the empty, tyrannical frauds that they are, they do so under the banner of morality. Which, if the recipient of their morality-coated rage is naïve, will hurt him and which, at the same time, will help nobody, since its only real effect is to send the message that it’s better to be a non-entity who wears a diamond-studded mask (underneath which there is no self, only a disorganized mixture of self-hatred, compensatory rage, and infantile (and also shame-driven) feelings of entitlement) than it is to be the real person who is who he is. 
Fourth, for the sociopath, morality is a weapon. By being moralizing, sociopaths have what they’ve always wanted but never had: power. Powerlessness makes one sociopathize; and once one has sociopathized, and has thus overthrown one’s conscience, one has no compunctions about using morality to belittle others. 
Earlier we mentioned Orwell’s book 1984. Speaking from a psychodynamic viewpoint, 1984 is not fiction. It is an accurate description of mass sociopathization. If the forces at work within the real world were embodied in our political institutions, the result would be the world that Orwell describes. 1984 is not primarily about politics; it’s about people being driven by fear into believing what they know to be lies and, as a result, ceasing to be human. Fortunately, a system of government in which there are checks and balances is capable of inhibiting, and sometimes altogether preventing, the sociopathization of the political institutions on which people depend for their welfare. 

5.4 Vampirism a metaphor for sociopathy 
Many movies and books are about vampires. Vampires are typically represented as having certain properties. 
(i) Vampires don’t appear in reflective surfaces, such as mirrors. 
(ii) Vampires are creatures of darkness. Sunlight kills them. 
(iii) A vampire cannot see his own face. (This follows from (i).) 
(iv) 
Only others can see a vampire’s face (This follows from (iii).) 

(v) 
Vampires live in opulence; they are fabulously wealthy. Their spacious domiciles are richly appointed. They have all the material trappings of success. They are elegant and well-cultured. They dress like royalty. 


(vi) Vampires can turn into bats. 
(vii) One becomes a vampire by selling one’s soul. 
(viii) A vampire must drink the blood of the living; otherwise he dies. 
(ix) Vampires are parasites and thus have only a borrowed, 
second-class existence. (This follows from (viii).) . 
Taken jointly, (i)-(ix) suggest that vampires represents sociopaths. 
Interpretation of (i) and (ii): Vampires have no substance. That’s why they cease to exist in the light of day, and it’s why they don’t appear in mirrors. Like vampires, sociopaths have no substance. That’s why, when scrutinized---when looked at in the light of day, as it were, and not allowed to take refuge in darkness---the sociopath’s personality vanishes, his morality and indeed his entire personality proving to be nothing more than fictions. 
Interpretation of (iii): The vampire’s face represents the sociopath’s self-concept, and the vampire’s inability to see his own face represents the fact that the sociopath has no endogenous self-concept. Lacking in any real self-concept, sociopaths are empty; there is no life in them. 
Interpretation of (iv): The fact that only others can see the vampire’s face corresponds to the fact that the sociopath’s self-concept is dependent on the acknowledgement of others. (Sociopaths tend to spent a lot of time in front looking at themselves in the mirror.) 
Interpretation of (v): The sociopath is empty; he tries to fill the void with external tokens of the success. Also, since can’t distinguish the image from the reality, and wealth creates the image of success, the sociopath equates wealth with success. 
Interpretation of (vi): Bats are blind. So are sociopaths. Sociopaths believe what they want to believe, not what is real; they are blind to the truth. 
Interpretation of (vii): One becomes a sociopath by selling out. 
Interpretation of (viii) and (ix): The sociopath’s existence is a waking death, from which he has no respite except when he’s drinking up the adulation of others, a corollary being that, without the adulation, the sociopath suffers the same fate as the blood-deprived vampire. 

5.5 The professor as sociopath 
I will try to answer this question by answering a more specific one, namely: what kind of a person is a sociopathic professor likely to be. Why take this approach? First, since I work on a daily basis with many sociopathic professors, and since, being a professor myself, I am inevitably made privy to their machinations, I am able to speak authoritatively about them. Second, because my sociopathic colleagues are strikingly similar to the many sociopathic non-professors with whom I acquainted, even though the latter come from all walks of life and are engaged all manner of professions, I have reason to suspect that those character-traits are inherent in sociopathy itself and, therefore, that points similar to those that I will now proceed to make about professors hold, in some form or other, with respect to sociopaths in general. 
Sociopaths are weaklings who can’t hack it and then lie, first to others and then to themselves, in order to cover up their deficits. They are people who aren't great but are so afflicted by infantile narcissism that they cannot tolerate not being great. People of integrity who’d like to be an Einstein or a Beethoven but find out that they’re not in that league don’t become sociopaths; they become people who do what they can do and they take pains to do it properly. The non-sociopath who wishes he were Einstein, but knows that he isn’t, becomes a capable and hard-working civil engineer. The non-sociopath who wishes he were Beethoven, but knows that he isn’t, becomes a capable and hard-working film-composer or music-teacher. The sociopath chooses to be a fake Beethoven rather than a real sub-Beethoven. He chooses to be John Cage, whose work is bogus but chic, rather than Paul Simon, whose work, though sub-Beethovenian, is superb. 
Sociopaths claim to be rebels who “think outside the box.” But they’re not rebels; in fact, they’re arch-conformists. And they don’t think outside the box; in fact, they don’t think at all. They embrace positions (e.g. Marxism, Cultural Relativism, Post-Modernism) that, in some cases, were once rebellious but, at least in the contexts in which the sociopath advocates them, are not only not rebellious but shield their advocates from the scrutiny and criticism to which their opponents are exposed. 
If a professor takes the post-modernist view that truth is culturally relative, he’ll be applauded; if he takes the view that truth is not culturally relative and that, in some cases, entire cultures have the wrong view, he’ll be derided by his students and censured by his superiors. If a professor takes the radically implausible post-modernist view that the psychological differences between men and women have no biological basis, he’ll be praised for his open-mindedness; if he takes the opposite view, he’ll be branded a moron and chauvinist pig. If a professor takes the Marxist view that so-called moral verities are but artifices by which the haves manipulate the have-nots, he’ll be seen as a cutting edge thinker who is willing to question “dominant paradigm.” If a professor takes the non-Marxist view that moral truths are not mere chicanery and that they reflect opinion-independent facts about what conduces to the health of individuals and groups thereof, he’ll be seen as a pointy-headed, retrograde square. Also, if one takes the post-modernist view that there is no truth and, more generally, that none of the benchmarks in terms of which human beings evaluate themselves have any legitimacy, one thereby insulates oneself from criticism; for any criticism of his views presupposes that there is truth and is therefore spurious. 
The chic Marxist law professor who, in the U.S. in the year 2010, advocates the downfall of the U.S. government isn’t a rebel at all. He knows that his words will have no effect at all, except to misinform his students and stock the empty heads of faux-intellectuals with ready-made slogans that they can use at cocktail parties, and he knows that the very government whose downfall he advocates will ensure that not one hair on his head will be harmed. Also, unless he’s so totally sociopathized that he himself is completely convinced by his own mythology, he knows that his proposals, if by some miracle put into action, would obliterate the social structures on which life as we know it depends. So he's a fool if he believes what he's saying and a fraud if he doesn't. Finally, given the almost certainly correct supposition that he knows, at least some degree, that what he's saying isn't true, he knows that he’s misinforming his students, weakening their minds, and undermining their autonomy. 
Similar points hold with respect to the hip media studies professor who says that only suckers read books by dead, white males and that, were it not for the machinations of advertising executives, we’d realize that listening to hip-hop was better for our intellects than reading John Stuart Mill. This enlightened hipster is saying that logic and hard-work mean nothing. This message may sound liberating. It is not. It’s a way of telling people to cripple themselves. (“Deprogram yourself. Whatever part of you is responsible for what you naively thought of as thinking—rip it out!”) Thus, it’s a way of telling them to cease to exist. For nothing remains of a person once he ceases to be able to think for himself. 
Like the Marxist law professor, the media studies professor hobbles his students under the banner of emancipating them. The same is true of the women’s studies professor who contends that the psychological differences between men and women are entirely the result of social conditioning. This contention entails that, because women have been brainwashed, they can’t think for themselves and, therefore, that anything they have to say is to be disregarded. It also entails that, since the dawn of civilization, men have succeeded in duping, not just a few women, but all of them, with a tiny number of exceptions. This in its turn entails that women are, by nature, weak and suggestible. It also entails that men seriously outclass women intellectually. And this, in its turn, undermines the contention that, were it not for the lies told by men, women would be just like men. For, were this thesis true, it wouldn’t have been so easy for men to manipulate women. 
In fact, that hypothesis, when considered in isolation of the contexts in which it is advocated, has decidedly retrograde and anti-feminist undercurrents. Men are brutes, who through charm and cunning, manipulate women into being their willing servants. This sounds like the central conceit of a Harlequin romance, and it hardly seems a viable basis of a political movement whose objective is to emancipate women from the shackles of archaic, misogynist attitudes and the social structures that perpetuate them. 
So one in saying that, were it not for misogynist propaganda, women would be psychologically just like men, one is saying, if only by implication, that 
(i) men are naturally more cunning and treacherous and women and, consequently, that men and women are psychologically different; 
and also that 
(ii) women by nature easily taken advantage of. 
“But you’re reasoning is quite off the mark,” it will be said. “First of all, supposing that, indeed, men have been dominating women through the ages, they may well have been doing so through sheer physical force. Second, it could just be a historical accident that men happened to be the first gender to use propaganda as a way of controlling the opposite gender; so the fact that, thanks to their chicanery, men are “on top,” as it were, may reflect nothing more than happenstance.” 
First of all, the contention being discussed is that it was not through force, but through propaganda, and therefore through trickery, that men came to dominate women. Second, given that men are the, for lack of a better word, dominant gender in every society, many of which were isolated from the others, shows that, if indeed it was through chicanery that men came to dominate women, it wasn’t the product of historical happenstance and was instead the result of some constitutional difference between men and women. 
Let us move one. Women have nothing to gain, and much to lose, by accepting the contention that, but for male propaganda, women are psychologically just like men. For a woman who accepts that view ipso facto believes that she has been brainwashed and, therefore, that she can’t think for herself, and she ipso facto thinks the same of other females. (“But women who realize that they’ve been brainwashed,” I’ve heard it said, “are ipso facto free of the effects the brainwashing to which they’ve been suggested.” This is deeply implausible. So far as it’s even possible to completely undo the effects of a lifetime of brainwashing, it can’t be done overnight: realizing that one has been brainwashed is only the first step in a very long journey whose final destination is, at best, only a partial restoration of one’s faculties.) Thus, a women who accepts this supposedly progressive thesis necessarily believes that men are the only people who have not been brainwashed and therefore that, whatever moral deficiencies men might have, they are the only people who are even capable of seeing things as they are or, therefore, of providing sound guidance. So such a woman undervalues herself, along with her fellow females, and she over-values men. This double irony has a grim, as well as ironic, consequence, namely, that a woman of the kind just described is an unusually easy mark for male predators. 
It’s obvious that “so and so has been brainwashed” entails “so and so’s judgment has been impaired.” In fact, the second statement is a tautologous consequence of the first, given that it makes no sense to say that somebody has been has been brainwashed but that his powers of judgment haven’t been negatively affected. So the professors who say that, for the last several thousand years, women en masse have been brainwashed must surely know that, in saying this, they’re saying that women are intellectually stunted. Thus, such professors cannot possibly be motivated by a wish to help the plight of women and can only be motivated by hatred of them or a by characteristically sociopathic willingness to base one’s career on a lie. 
Each of the three pseudo-iconoclasts just described is driven by shame: shame at not being able to produce a legitimate line of goods; shame at being sterile and impotent. Having failed relative to the yardsticks by which it was their original intention to succeed, they embrace an ideology that invalidates those yardsticks. (Post-modernism: the standards in terms of which we evaluate what we say and do have only as much validity as we want them to have. Relative to one standard, modern medicine is superior to Neanderthal medicine; relative to a different, but equally valid standard, it’s the other way around. Marxism: the truth is a fairy tale told by the haves to manipulate the have nots. You didn’t really fail that test----that’s just what The Man wants you to believe.) Given how brazenly false such ideologies are, their advocates cannot accept them without ceasing to value truth and thus, given how much of a psychologically healthy person’s identity depends for its existence on that person’s valuing the truth, without eviscerating themselves. 
These fraudsters thus have multiple incentives to convince others of the truth of the falsehood to which they’ve sacrificed their identities. 
First, misery loves company: they want others to make the same sacrifices they’ve made so that others will suffer with them. 
Second, they desperately need others to tell them they’re not frauds. This is because the doctrines they espouse are so at variance with such obvious facts that, deep down, they don’t really accept those doctrines, notwithstanding the psychosurgery they’ve performed on themselves. 
Third, they need others to adulate them. The reason for this is different from the reason for which they need others to tell them that they’re not frauds. People who value the truth can validate themselves. An author who values the truth can take pride in a book he's written that nobody ever reads but that he knows to be good. As somebody who values truth, he knows that any praise that he were to receive for his book would have no more value (except, of course, of a purely instrumental kind) than the book itself. So, since he already knows his book to have value, any praise that he might receive for it would (except from a practical point of view) be redundant. 
But, to somebody who doesn’t value the truth, true statements are no more valuable than false one. A corollary is that, as far as such a person is concerned, it’s irrelevant whether the praise they receive is well founded. Well-founded praise is truthful praise. Since sociopaths have to believe their own spurious narratives, they identify the appearance of truth with truth itself. A writer whose works aren't read appears to be a failure. So, from the sociopath's viewpoint, he is a failure. A writer whose works are best-sellers appears to be a success. So, from the sociopath's viewpoint, he is a success. Since the image is the reality, a book is only as good as it is praised, and a person is as good as he is adored. 
Though he doesn’t want be adulated, the non-sociopathic literary genius wants to be recognized. Adulation is different from recognition. Recognition=being praise because of what one has done. Adulation=being praised, not because of what one has done, but because of who one is. For Smith to be adulated is for Smith to be praised for being Smith. For Smith to be recognized is for Smith to be praised for composing a great symphony. 
People of conscience want see justice done, and they thus want credit to be given where credit is due. To be sure, there is an element of sheer egoism in a writer’s desire for recognition. In fact, his egoism is almost certainly likely to be much more of a fact than his sense of justice. But the way in which egoism is expressed in a person of conscience is very different from the way it is a expressed in a sociopath. The writer’s egoism is expressed in his wanting to be praised and in his not caring very much whether other, equally deserving writers are praised; his sense of justice is expressed in his wanting to be praised because he deserves it. Many writers, thinkers, and artists of genius are praised for works of theirs that they rightly regard as among their worst. For example, Rachmaninov, who was a musical genius of staggering proportions, was best known for his prelude in C# minor, which, as he knew, was one of his worst works. For financial reasons, he had to perform it. But, whenever he did so, he went into a depression. Although I have read extremely little good literature and have no eye for graphic art, I am quite certain that Rachmaninov’s situation is by no means unusual. The reason that Rachmaninov found it so dispiriting that he was praised for this work of his is that he wanted to be praised for the right reasons: he wanted the commendations that he received to be ones that he earned; if only within the confines of his attitude towards people’s feelings towards his work, he wanted justice. 
Rachmaninov’s attitude towards the misguided adulation that he was received was quintessentially non-sociopathic. The sociopathic wants praise for its own sake. He doesn’t care whether he’s earned it or not. In fact, he doesn’t really have a concept of earning anything. For if one distinguishes between those who have things because they earn them, and those who just have them, one must distinguish between image and reality; and the essence of sociopathy is a refusal, driven by a need to believe one’s own lies, to make the latter distinction 
“According to you,”, it is likely to be said, “authors who know that they’re work is good don’t want praise. But that isn’t true. And surely that discredits much, if not all, of what you’ve just said.” 
The first part of this point is quite right: many an author who values the truth wants adulation despite knowing that what he’s written is good. But this doesn’t undermine anything of I’ve said. This is because, when such an author wants praise, it is for one of three reasons: 
(i) 
Although he knows at some level that what he’s written is good, some part of him skeptical; and, in being praised, his insecurities are finally being put to rest. 

(ii) 
in being praised, this previously unnoticed literary giant is finally being given evidence that there is at least some justice in the world; 


or 
(iii) such praise brings with it all manner of monetary and practical benefits thanks to which one doesn’t have to waste time groveling before slimy editors and working at a menial job and thanks to which one finally has access to some of the finer things in life. 
But this only confirms our point that, if a person genuinely is convinced that what he’s written is good, he doesn’t want adulation per se: what he wants are the benefits that adulation brings with it. 
Some are likely to reject (i). “If an author knows that what he’s written is good,” it will be said, “he ipso facto cannot possibly be at all insecure about its merits.” This criticism falsely assumes that people cannot have mutually opposed beliefs. The statement “Smith believes that 1+1=2 and Smith does not believe that 1+1=2” is incoherent. But the statement “Smith believes that 1+1=2 and Smith believes that 1+1.2” is perfectly coherent. In fact, the history of ideas is replete with cases of people having incompatible beliefs. In particular, many a great artist (e.g. Brahms) was rightly convinced, in a genuine and non-defense way, of the excellence of his work while being tormented by terrible insecurities about it. People are not cognitively unified. And an author who knows that his work is great can, at some level, believe that his work is bad and, therefore, will find praise for his to work to be a source of comfort. 

5.6 Fame as sociopathogen 
Fame is a great sociopathizer. People who, within narrow limits, had merit are, for some random reason, propelled to the heights of stardom, at which point they are grossly overvalued by the public and start to feel like frauds. They then have a choice: 
(i) They can believe the lie that everyone is telling them (you're great, you're a real thinker, not just some comedian whose sense of humor was so anodyne that some board of directors knew it risked nothing by making you a talk-show host); 
or: 
(ii) They can admit that they're not great and then either renounce the benefits of fame or consciously live a lie. 
One can understand why, confronted with this choice, many people go with (i). 
6.0 The non-sociopathic/non-psychopathic predator 
A person who doesn’t rationalize---who doesn’t replace his true self with a fake narrative---is not a sociopath. Non-sociopaths are sometimes evil. Some of them, in fact, are supremely evil. In fact, if a list were made of the 10,000 most evil people of all time, not a single sociopath would appear on it. (Nor, for very different reasons, would a single psychopath be on that list.) This is because sociopaths want to believe that they’re not as empty as they really are. And, despite their willingness to prefer fiction over truth, they’d make it very hard for themselves to believe that they had merit if they acted as treacherously as a Stalin or a Mao. 
“Sociopath” doesn’t mean “evil person.” “Sociopath” means “fake person with a corrupt conscience.” (“Psychopath” means “non-person who never had a conscience and who, for that reason never had a self, has always lived through narratives fabricated ad hoc.”) Sociopaths are always evil. But evil people are not always sociopaths. And evil non-sociopaths are more evil than sociopaths, since, unlike sociopaths, the former aren't struggling to convince themselves that they're good and thus have no compunctions about going all out, as it were, when it comes to evil-doing. 
Sociopaths aren't human. They've stopped being human. Evil non-psychopathic, non-sociopaths are thoroughly human. But, whereas my objective is to write treatises and yours, let us suppose, is to become a pediatrician, their objectives are to do harm. 

6.1 The non-sociopathic/non-psychopathic predator (continued) 
“How is it possible," it will be asked, "for that to be the objective of somebody who isn’t deranged in some way?” 
The right question is: “How is it not possible?” [484] 

We’re the victors of a long, brutal evolutionary struggle. We chose to fight it out. We didn’t opt out, like clams, by becoming so lame and harmless that we weren’t worth destroying; nor did we become peaceful herbivores whose entire lives are but preludes to being slaughtered and eaten. So it’s no surprise that there are at least a few predators among our ranks. 
Would a tiger be better off if it renounced violence? No! Tigers must be tigers; if they try to be sheep, they’ll die on the inside. Would a born predator be better off if he were a Buddhist monk? No! Like the tiger, he’d die on the inside; and, in all likelihood, his need to predate would come out in circuitous ways (e.g., pettiness towards underlings, thwarting those whose aspirations are legitimate and whose work-product is authentic). By trying to be peaceniks, these born war-mongers either injure themselves or, by turning structures on which the public depends for its welfare into outlets for their undischarged aggression, do harm on a far greater scale than they would have had they discharged their aggressions more directly. 

6.2 Criminalization as a way of avoiding sociopathization 
Some people who become professional criminals (e.g., members of organized crime) do so to avoid sociopathizing. In their view, working for “the man” involves throwing oneself into a sausage-grinder: one must tow the company line and, to use a phrase from Orwell’s Keep the Aspidistra Flying, “lick the blacking off the boss’s boots.” It involves becoming an empty suit: a hollowed out shell who believes nothing except what higher ranking suits want him to believe. 
Winston Smith, the main character in 1984, says how he hates “goodness” and “purity.” What he means is that he hates the fake goodness and the fake purity with which, as a citizen of Oceania, he is inundated. What he means, in other words, is that he wants to be human, not “pure” or “good”, which words, as they are used in his society and as they are used by the sociopath, don’t refer to purity or goodness, but to their plastic, sociopathized analogues. 
Winston was a good and honest person in a world of criminals. So why did he say that he hated purity and goodness? Ms. Marks’ insight can help us answer this question and, in so doing, can help us understand the mentality of non-sociopaths who operate outside “the system.” 
Former Mafiosos who joined the Witness Protection Program don’t rationalize. Sammy “the Bull” Gravano said that he was never, at any point, to any degree, a “Robin Hood” whose intentions were to do good; he was, he said, somebody who wasn’t educated but who wanted power and was willing to “scratch and kick and do whatever it [took]” to acquire it. Other former Mafiosos, without few exceptions, say the same thing. Jimmy “the Weasel” Frattiano said that he was a less than stellar human being who chose a life of crime not because he had no other options, but because he liked having power more than he liked being moral and, he implied, he would have been a powerless nobody had he “gone legit.” 
People who admit to themselves that they’re evil are to that extent non-sociopaths. The essence of sociopathy is a shame-driven rationalization of one’s inability to live up to one’s own values. So far as one genuinely “owns” one’s actions, which oftentimes involves admitting that one is a bad human being, one is not a sociopath. 
In this context, it must be stressed, we are discussing people who criminalize in order to stave off sociopathization; we are not discussing sociopaths who criminalize in order to hide their condition from themselves. Many people become predators as a result of sociopathizing; and they falsely tell themselves that, in going this route, they were simply doing what the laws of the jungle required them to do. (“It’s a rough world. Nobody does you any favors. Do whatever it takes. Just don’t get caught.”) Such people are lying by pretending to be brutally honest: their pseudo-honest admissions to themselves and others that they are predators are just ways of cloaking their weakness-driven descent into sociopathy. 
But in some cases, as we’ve said, one criminalizes in order to hold onto one’s identity, and therefore in order to avoid sociopathizing. Since sociopaths aren’t who they are---since they half-believe their own propaganda and thus half-believe they are good---there tend to be limits to how evil they can be. But there are no limits to how evil a non-psychopathic, non-sociopath can be. For example, Joseph Stalin---who, by any measure, was one of the most wicked human beings ever---was not a sociopath. He was a serial killer who, having managed to acquire an enormous amount of power, was able, unlike other predators, to predate on a large scale and without fear of legal reprisal. He knew he was evil; and he rejoiced in it. He didn’t deceive himself; he didn’t say that “it was for their own good” that he displaced entire populations and condemned millions to starvation. He did it because he wanted to do harm.[485] 
To accomplish this, he obviously had to lie to others. But he saw himself for what he was: a mass-murderer who also happened to be a head of state. So he wasn’t a sociopath. 
Although Stalin was a national leader, he saw himself for what he was: a butcher, who, through chicanery and deceit, obtained for himself a position from which he could, with impunity, be the serial killer the he was. So Stalin was not a sociopath; for, although he lied to others (on an unprecedented scale, in fact), he didn’t lie to himself (except in so far as everyone does). 
Nor was Stalin a psychopath. A psychopath couldn’t have done what Stalin did. Stalin’s ascent to power involved his being able to evaluate himself with respect to yard-sticks that weren’t concocted ex post facto to rationalize his errors. He wouldn’t have learned from the past if, when evaluating his mistakes in terms of yardsticks that were independent of his desires, he weren’t able to see the folly of his ways. 
Also, psychopaths are extremely impulsive. They can contain this side of themselves for a while; but sooner or later it comes out. And when it does, their careers are over. Their impulsiveness is a consequence of their having only a limited and contextual grasp of the truth. Since, as previously stated, they don’t value truth for its own sake, they value it only when they know that it will serve them well. And since, as we observed, it’s impossible to prejudge when some now useless truth will become useful, the result is that the psychopath has an excessively limited body of truths from which to draw when making decisions. Because he is thus blinkered, his impulses aren’t countered by a firm grasp of their consequences. Hence his impulsiveness. Stalin was not impulsive. He was calm and rational; his decisions, though maximally evil, were judicious and calculated. 
Etymologically, the morpheme “path” (as in “sociopath” and “psychopath”) means “disease.” Sociopathy and psychopathy are both form of pathology. That said, psychopathy is a much more acute form of pathology than sociopathy. The sociopath's psychological architecture is in the process of imploding; he's the psychological equivalent of somebody whose disease-ridden internal organs are only semi-operational but have retained their basic shapes. By contrast, the psychopath is like somebody who never developed those organs or who did develop only for them to be liquefied by a case of Ebola. 
Stalin didn’t fall into either of these categories. He knew what he was; he knew what he wanted. What he was: a predator; a person of some intelligence, but not as much intelligence as others; a person who, if he was to predate without being predated upon, had to engage in all manner of chicanery. Since he had a self, he wasn’t a psychopath; and since he didn’t tell himself that he was something that he was not, he was not a sociopath. He was just evil. [486] 


6.2 Donald Davison’s analysis of what intentions are 
According to Donald Davidson (1963), an intention is simply one’s strongest desire. More precisely, it is one’s strongest contextually relevant desire. So, if I am in an ice-cream store and, for some reason, it’s incumbent on me to eat ice-cream, my subsequent intention to eat chocolate ice-cream is the strongest intention that I have that is an intention to eat ice-cream at that time, in that place; it is stronger than my desire to eat any of the other kinds of ice-cream that are available. At the same time, of course, my desire to eat chocolate ice-cream is not my strongest desire tout court. (In what follows, any references to one’s “strongest” desire are always abbreviated references to one’s strongest contextually relevant desire.) So, according to Davidson, an intention is the desire that, because of its strength, beats out the other desires with which it is in competition and thus, unlike them, expresses itself in action.[487] 

This reasonable-seeming analysis embodies several confusions. (I should point out that, in his excellent book The Faces of Intention, Michael Bratman makes points similar to, but not coincident with, those that I am about to make.[488]) A desire that is directly converted into overt behavior is a reaction, not an action proper. For a desire to lead to action, it must be inhibited and scrutinized, so as to ensure that it embodies the right values. By virtue of surviving such scrutiny, a desire becomes an intention and, to the extent that circumstances allow, automatically discharges itself in action. 
Even those desires that are expressed in action despite not surviving such scrutiny are not cases of desires being directly converted into action. They are cases of desires being scrutinized, then found to fall short, but being allowed to discharge themselves anyway. The reason the tobacco-addict feels ashamed is that, despite what his conscience tells him as he’s considering his wish to smoke, he nonetheless lifts the initial inhibition that he has on smoking. And even though, in respect of his overt behavior, he may pounce on the cigarette the way a tiger pounces on red meat, the addict’s behavior is that of somebody in whom the impulse to smoke is the result of a decision: his impulse is initially quarantined, then scrutinized, and only then, despite its falling short of the relevant valuative benchmarks, allowed to be discharged in action. The tiger’s desire, on the other hand, is directly translated into action. Where selves are concerned, few so-called impulsive behaviors, if any, involve a desire’s being directly translated into action; they typically involve cases where there is an initial inhibition which, despite his better judgment, the person in question chooses to lift. 
That said, the decision to lift the inhibition sometimes is a wise one. The person in question wishes to appear like a violent, unpredictable animal, since he knows that, given the circumstances, this is to his strategic advantage; and he knows that, if he punches the person who just insulted him, that is precisely how he will appear. Many apparently impetuous actions are carefully considered. We must remember that “carefully considered” . “slowly considered.” A carefully considered decision can be made virtually instantaneously. This is partly because we think fast. But it’s primarily because, given previous decisions that we spent a great deal of time making and that we’ve decided to comply with, it’s immediately obvious how to behave, when contingencies arise, in a manner that is consistent with those decisions. 
Our desires are fleeting. They constantly change. If Davidson were right, we’d be buoyed hither and thither by our desires. Every time a sufficiently strong desire came along, we’d “act out.” But, in so doing, we wouldn’t really be acting at all. For our overt behavior wouldn’t be the outcome of a decision. 
In fact, if Davidson’s theory were correct, we wouldn’t be involved at all. Our impulses would use us to express themselves.[489] 
The overt behavior in which that desire was issued wouldn’t be an action at all, at least not in the relevant sense. (It would be an action only in the sense in which a tiger’s instinctual reactions are actions; it wouldn’t be an action in the sense in which your rational and carefully considered decision to become a physician is an action.) 
To be sure, if a desire is overwhelmingly strong, we will tend to act on it. But, setting aside bona fidepsychopaths, what tends going in such cases isn’t that the desire directly results in action, and is instead that the screening process leading to the lifting of the relevant inhibition is fast-tracked and, possibly (but not necessarily[490]), done shoddily. 
Contrary to what Davison holds, an action isn’t the direct expression of any desire, be it one’s strongest desire or one’s weakest. An action is the direct expression of a value-driven decision to lift an inhibition on a desire. When deciding whether to lift that inhibition, one considers how doing so would affect one’s self-concept and one’s overall life-course. 
Thus, an intention, contrary to what Davidson holds, isn’t a desire at all. It is a judgment. That judgment is intended to gratify some desire; but the desire is not the intention. To sum up: if Davidson were right, we’d never act; we’d only react. We’d be like pinballs, bouncing from bumper to bumper, each bumper being our strongest desire at the time. 
But that isn’t how we are. As Bratman says, we make plans. Once we make these plans, we tend to stick with them. Desires come along that, if acted upon, would thwart those desires. We tend to inhibit those desires. Sometimes the desire in question is too strong; so we gratify it and thus either suspend or altogether junk the plan. But such a situation, though all too common, represents a breakdown in the structure that mediates between desires, on the one hand, and bona fideactions, on the other. 
Also, although these plans are to a large extent intended to gratify desires, and although that is what to a large extent they should be intended to do, the desires in which they have roots are not typically raw, instinctual ones. They are desires that incorporate one’s values and also typically reflect previous decisions that one has made. I don’t much want to read so and so’s latest book on semantics. But my intention to become a semanticist requires that I do so. In reading so and so’s book, I am acting on a desire that I have. But that desire is a consequence of a previous intention that I formed, and that previous intention reflects my values and my self-concept. Those values, in their turn, reflect---though they are not mere puppets of---raw instinctual desires.[491] 
But those values are not desires. Those values are judgments as to how to extend the hegemony of the agency within myself that polices sub­agential mental activity on my part. (Why “sub-agential” mental activity? Because that regulatory agency is my self. Of course, after my self comes into existence, that regulatory agency polices its own activities and thus polices agential activity.) 

6.2 Donald Davison’s analysis of what intentions are (continued) 
Davidson identifies one’s intentions with one’s “strongest” desires. But the term “one’s strongest desires” is ambiguous. There are two kinds of strength that a desire can have, which I’ll refer to as “intrinsic strength” and “organization-dependent strength.” An analogy will help us move forward. 
Smith is, without any doubt, the best hand-to-hand fighter in the world. He is the best boxer, the best wrestler, and so on. So there is obviously some sense in which he is an extremely powerful human being. But none of the organizations that officially manage these sports will let him join them. So he wins no official competitions; he is given no awards; he has no titles. He has fought with the best and won without so much as breaking a sweat. And this fact is well known. But he’s still not part of “the club,” so to speak. So as much of a threat as he might be on the street, his fighting-prowess doesn’t mean anything: it doesn’t translate into money or acclaim or influence. 
Jones is a reasonably good professional pugilist. He isn’t remotely in the same league as Smith. (The two have fought. Jones didn’t even land a punch.) But he is part of the club. So he does win awards for his fighting-talents, relatively modest though they are; he does make money; he does receive acclaim. 
Even though Smith is a much better boxer and all around pugilist than Jones, Jones is a more powerful figure within the boxing world than Smith. In fact, Smith is powerless within that world, even though he is the best boxer alive. 
The mind is much like the sort of organization of which Jones is a member. It’s a club; and if a desire isn’t a member of it, it doesn’t lead to action. (It may become a member and then lead to action. And, as a non­member, it can have effects. But those effects will be symptoms, not actions, since the desire, not being a member of the club, cannot avail itself of the reigns of agency.) A desire can be extremely strong; but if it isn’t part of the club, its likelihood of being converted into action is small. (I say “small," as opposed to “zero," because, if a desire is a strong enough, it is likely to become a part of one’s psychological integration and, on that basis, to be converted into action---just as, given his level of talent, Smith would be likely, other things being equal, to be given a break and given membership in the boxing-federation.) And if a desire is weak, but it’s deeply embedded in “the club," it’s likely to be converted into action. 
So in saying that an intention is one’s strongest desire, Davidson hasn’t said anything. If he’s saying that it is the strongest desire that is in one’s mind, regardless of whether it is part of one’s psychological organization, then Davidson is wrong; for such organization-external desires don’t have access to the “reigns of agency” and are less likely than organization-internal ones, even quite weak ones, to be expressed as actions. If Davidson is talking about organization-internal desires, he runs into the same problem. For, given two desires, the stronger one may be more out of line with the plans, self-concept, and general psychological organization, and may therefore be less likely than its weaker counterpart to lead to action. If by one’s “strongest desire," Davidson is referring to that desire of one’s that, given its position in one’s personality-architecture, is most likely to lead to action, no matter how intrinsically weak it is, then his position is false or empty. For Davidson is then saying either: 
(a) That an intention is that desire that, despite very possibly having less strength than other desires, is so positioned that it will beat out those other desires; 
or: 
(b) The true measure of a desire’s strength is its likelihood of being expressed in action. 
If (a) is the right interpretation, Davidson is simply wrong to say that one’s intention is one’s strongest desire. If (b) is the right interpretation, Davidson is stating the empty truism that the desire that is most likely to lead to action is the one that is most likely to lead to action. 
The most fundamental problem with Davidson’s analysis, however, is the one that, following Bratman[492], we identified earlier. Behaviors that directly result from desires are reactions, not actions. The immediate cause of any bona fideaction is, not that desire itself, but the judgment-driven lifting of an inhibition on a desire. 

6.3 Nietzsche’s ethical egoism: An exhortation to avoid sociopathy[493] 

Nietzsche infamously argued for a doctrine known as ethical egoism (EE). According to this doctrine, it is one’s sole ethical obligation to promote one’s own welfare. 
One important desideratum that an ethical theory must satisfy is to say how people should treat others. Obviously EE fails to satisfy this desideratum. Since no viable ethical theory can fail to satisfy this desideratum, EE fails as an ethical theory. 
But there are desiderata that an ethical theory ought to satisfy and that, unlike every other ethical theory, EE does satisfy. First of all, an ethical theory shouldn’t require people to diminish themselves. The most pure way of being evil towards someone is to diminish them. An ethical theory that diminishes those who follow it is therefore evil. And an ethical theory that is itself evil is ipso facto not a coherent one. Aside from EE, all ethical theories do require people to diminish themselves: they require people to do what others want and need them to do, not what they want and need to do. EE doesn’t require people to diminish themselves. For EE’s sole injunction is: Don’t diminish yourself! EE isn’t evil towards those who follow it. Thus, there is a respect in which EE is coherent and in which all other ethical theories are incoherent. (That said, there are respects in which EE is incoherent and in which most, if not all, other ethical theories are coherent.) 
There is another important desideratum that EE satisfies and that all other ethical theories fail to satisfy. People are self-centered. People who don’t allow themselves to do what they want to do are frustrated, unhealthy people. (When I talk about “what people want to do," I mean what people want to do in so far as what they want to do isn’t the result of cowardice or complacency or otherwise self-diminishing factors. In other words, I am talking about the wishes that people’s selves have, and I am therefore not talking about the craven impulses that, although in people, are not of them---i.e., that, although in people’s minds, are not constitutive of their selves.) One can obey EE faultlessly without jeopardizing one’s psychological health. The same cannot be said of any other ethical theory. All other ethical theories require one to put other people’s interests ahead of one’s own. And, setting aside people who are already severely damaged, nobody can do this unremittingly. A system of morality with which it is not psychologically possible to be unremittingly compliant is ipso facto incoherent; for one has no obligation to do what one cannot do (“ought implies can”). 
“But some people may genuinely want to be kind to others,” it will be said. “EE forces people to be evil and thus to go against their own natures. So, contrary to what you say, EE is evil towards its own followers.” Not true. EE says: “Do what you want to do, so long as what you want to do is authentic and doesn’t involve a diminution of who you are.” Not everybody always wants to be a predator. In fact, few people are completely predatory, and many people are nurturers by nature. Kindness and altruism, though often given exogenous reinforcement, usually have endogenous roots. So EE does not demand that one hurt people whom one doesn’t want to hurt. 
Bearing all of this in mind, let AET be an arbitrary ethical theory other than ethical egoism, and let Smith be an arbitrary person who advocates AET. Given what we’ve said, Smith is damaged if he follows AET to the letter; and supposing that Smith isn’t damaged, he’s a hypocrite, since he tells people to follow AET, even though he himself does not do so. It’s psychologically impossible for anyone who, like Smith, is not damaged, to be unremitting in his adherence to any ethical doctrine other than EE. Smith is therefore a hypocrite. Given that he’s a hypocrite, he has a choice: 
(i) he can admit to himself that he’s a hypocrite, 
or: 
(ii) he can deny that he’s a hypocrite. 
No one wants to believe that he’s a fraud. So Smith will probably choose (ii). (Speaking empirically, Smith may choose (i)—but it’s unlikely.[494]) 
So, given the reasonable supposition that Smith doesn’t see himself as a fraud, he’ll take path (ii). This means that he’ll rationalize and that, to that extent at least, he’ll ipso facto sociopathize. I suspect that, in advocating EE, Nietzsche was trying steer people away from the path of sociopathy­conducive rationalizations. Nietzsche was obviously smart enough to know that EE is not viable as a theory as to how people should treat one another. But he also said explicitly that ethical theories other than EE either damage their adherents or turn them into frauds or both. 
Nietzsche said many things that, when taken out of context, suggest that he wanted people to be evil towards others. Presumably, we should take authors at their word. But supposing, if only for argument’s sake, that Nietzsche did want people to be evil towards one another, his wanting that was subordinate to his wanting people to be authentic. 
“Supposing that you’re right,” I have been asked, “why didn’t Nietzsche say what you just said? Why did he not duly disclaim his exhortations that people look out for themselves? Why did not he say ‘I don’t really want you to be evil towards others; what I really want is for you not to be hypocrites.’?” 
Nietzsche’s basic message was: “people are weak and cowardly, but they tell themselves that their weakness and cowardice are virtues; and as long as they keep believing this, they cannot live authentically.” Obviously one of Nietzsche’s objectives in making this point was to point out an interesting fact about the human condition. But that wasn’t his only or, indeed, his primary objective. His primary objective was to cut through the rationalizations by which people convinced themselves that their cowardice and weakness were virtues and by which, consequently, they kept themselves in a diminished state. Nietzsche was trying to crack the whip. Had he duly disclaimed his words, he would have failed to do that; his points would have registered with people as purely theoretical ones. Moreover, his equivocations and qualifications would have undermined his own message. For they would (rightly) have been seen as embodying the slimy evasiveness of the scholar who, not wanting to be pinned down, rationalizes his pedantry as “rigor”; and he would thus have been seen as exemplifying the very cowardice and hypocrisy that it was his intention to extirpate. 
In this connection it is to be noted that Nietzsche invented the concept of “intellectualization.” To intellectualize is to make a painful truth seem innocuous by treating it as being purely theoretical. Intellectualization is a form of repression. But, in intellectualizing, what one represses (or keeps repressed) is not one’s knowledge of the painful truth per se and instead one’s knowledge of how that truth bears on one’s life-situation. 
By keeping one’s knowledge of that truth per se unrepressed, one is at liberty to use it in discursive contexts, and one is also spared having to rationalize away any evidence for it that one encounters. Intellectualization is thus a “thinking man’s” form of repression. Like everyone else, intellectuals engage in repression. Sometimes, what they wish to repress is knowledge of a truth that, so long as they consciously know it, enhances their intellectual powers. Not wanting to forfeit the intellectual benefits of having that knowledge, they compromise: they don’t repress that knowledge per se but they do repress their knowledge of its bearing on their lives. So, qua piece of theoretical weaponry, that knowledge remains conscious. But, qua knowledge that warrants their changing themselves in fundamental ways, it is repressed. 
Let us end this section by dealing with a problem that came up earlier but that we did not then have the chance to address. We saw some reason to believe that ethical theories are categorically incoherent. Supposing this to be correct, if only for argument’s sake, a question arises: If we find an ethical theory to be incoherent, should we cease to endorse it? No. Any viable ethical theory is necessarily incoherent. We have a word for that incoherence: injustice. 
Unless restrained, people will destroy the institutions that give our lives much of their meaning and value. Thus, any viable ethical theory restrains people. At the same time, any instance case of restraining someone is ipso facto unjust, since injustice is the thwarting of aspirations, even though such an injustice may be necessary to off-set some far greater injustice. 
When choosing between ethical theories, we are choosing between bad and worse, not between good and better. An extensive defense of this contention is given in my (2010) book Morality, Politics, and Law. So I will say no more about it here. 

6.4 Some famous psychopaths 
I would like to end by revisiting the topic of psychopathy. 
Psychopaths are always charlatans. For this reason, among others, they tend to be cult leaders. Many an “enlightened” sage is a psychopath. If someone is described as having a “spacious consciousness”, odds are: he’s a psychopath. 
Ira Einhorn, an icon of the 1960’s, was a very pure example of a psychopath. After being put on trial for murdering his girlfriend, Einhorn fled, was convicted, and sentenced to death in absentia. During that time, he lived in France. (At the time, France’s policy was not to extradite fugitives who faced the death penalty. Hence Ira’s decision to reside there.) Despite being well known in France as somebody who had been convicted of murdering his girlfriend, he was extraordinarily successful at attracting women. He managed to convince them, as he did many males, that he was the victim of a government conspiracy----notwithstanding that, by his own admission, the mummified corpse of his girlfriend had been in a trunk in his closet for two years. 
Einhorn’s murder of his girlfriend was a mere by-product of his psychopathy. Most psychopaths are not murderers. The essence of psychopathy isn’t murderousness; it’s emptiness. What made Einhorn a psychopath was the fact that he was an empty shell who hid his emptiness with a veneer of learnedness and of compassion for others. Because Einhorn was so empty, nothing meant anything to him. Therefore, killing his girlfriend meant nothing to him. In a non-psychopath, a desire to kill a loved one have to power through heavy-duty bulwarks erected by one’s conscience. So there would have to be intense rage. In a non-psychopath, there is no conscience; so an act that, if committed by a non-psychopath, would indicate white-hot passion might, if committed by a psychopath, indicate nothing more than a passing whim. 
While a student at the University of Pennsylvania, Einhorn’s mentor was a distinguished historian by the name of Morse Peckham. Peckham was very much not a psychopath. Peckham was initially deeply impressed by Einhorn; he thought he had had found a protégé in Einhorn. After a couple of years, Peckham realized that Einhorn’s theatrical way of speaking had blinded him to the fact that Einhorn never said anything that wasn’t simply a repetition of a point that he (Peckham) had made to him. 
Famous for his speeches on behalf of both environmentalism and pacifism, his advocacy of each doctrine was insincere. He used environmentalism not to enhance people, but to diminish them. In telling people that virtually everything they did was bad for the environment, he was, in effect, telling them that they were bad for the environment and therefore they did not deserve to exist. His environmentalism was quite as pure an expression of homicidal rage as his murder of his girlfriend. 
His advocacy of pacifism was similarly underhanded. Like many psychopaths, he advocated moral relativism (“there is no right or wrong”) as well as alethic[495] 
relativism (“there is no truth; it’s all subjective”). His advocacy of world-peace was based, not on the principle that certain things are objectively wrong, but on the principle that, since nothing is objectively right or wrong, no culture has the right to act aggressively towards another. What Einhorn didn’t say is that if nothing is right or wrong there’s no moral reason not to hurt others. (According to Marxism, the concept of right and wrong are bourgeois hogwash. This made it possible for Stalin, Mao, and Pol Pot to kill on an unprecedented scale.) Also, by advocating alethic relativism, Einhorn was wiping away thousands of years’worth of hard work, since the message he was sending was that the accomplishments of thinkers over the ages were worth nothing. This message obviously appeals to people who want to be great thinkers but either lack the requisite talent or aren’t willing to do the requisite work. 
The themes underlying his speeches, and often explicitly affirmed in them, were: 
(i) One’s emotions are as good a guide to truth as a scientist’s experiments. 
(ii) Astrology is no less worthy of study than physics. 
(iii) Commerce is inherently evil. 
(iv) Institutionalized authority is inherently evil. 
These views seem liberal and progressive. They are not. For they are misleading ways of saying that 
(a) 
Hard work, personal integrity, and genuine ability mean nothing. 

(b) 
One’s emotions, and thus one’s prejudices, are the royal road to truth (that being why astrology, which one can practice without having ever so much as cracked a book, is no less worthy 

a discipline than physics, which requires years of patient study). 

(c) 
The appropriate attitude for a human being is the unbridled narcissism of an infant, an expression of which is a virulent hatred of anyone who frustrates his desires. 

(d) 
There is nothing of value in the institutions that prevent us from killing one another and that require us to rise above the narcissistic pettiness to which, in the absence of external inducements, we default. 


In urging acceptance of (i)-(iv), Einhorn was really urging acceptance of (a)­(d), and he was thus imploring people to understand the world in the same emotion-driven, projective manner as our cave-dwelling ancestors. Thus, Einhorn’s supposed progressiveness was the purest form of regressivism. Because Einhorn was representative in this respect of an entire generation of so-called liberals, people who don’t want to return to a tribal mode of existence are given an incentive to not be liberal, even if they haven’t a conservative bone in their body. 
I feel that a few remarks about my personal experiences may not be out of order, so long as it’s kept in mind that those remarks may well be nothing more than prejudice-driven interpretations of facts about my life that, even if interpreted dispassionately, would reveal little about the world. I personally have known many leading members of the 1960’s counterculture; a very close relative of mine is one of the two or three best known astrologers in the nation. These particular individuals are among the most ill-willed and intellectually rigid people that I know. And, having attended many functions over which they presided, I have found the same to be true of their followers. For this reason, I suspect that acceptance of 1960’s-style liberalism often has roots in one, or both, of the following factors: 
(1) A wish to disguise, both from oneself and from others, a virulent, all-consuming ill-will, 
and: 
(2) A combination of a rabid desire for power, coupled with a narcissistic unwillingness to put in the work required to achieve success within institutions where they don’t make the rules and where they’ll be subjected to meaningful scrutiny. 
6.4.1 Wittgenstein 
Einhorn was a big Wittgenstein fan. This was no accident. Wittgenstein was a psychopath. A below average student in both high-school and college, he received a PhD from Cambridge without taking any of the standard entrance-exams, without taking a single class, and without writing so much as a single paper, apart from the TLP. He submitted the TLP as his dissertation and, on that basis, was “awarded” a doctorate in Philosophy. 
Wittgenstein supposedly labored over the TLP. If this is true, his efforts were to no avail. The end result was an absolute failure. It’s maximally obscure, except when what it is saying isn’t trivial or obviously false. No effort is made to clarify the obscure statements or to substantiate them. Each sentence is labored and artificial and fails to flow into the next one. 
Also, Wittgenstein doesn’t say how one sentence, or one section, relates to the next. Instead, he uses an elaborate numbering system that is meant to identify the logical interrelations holding among the various statements composing the TLP. But the numbering system, though giving the TLP a much needed appearance of rigor and coherence, only adds to the obscurity. To this day, scholars have failed to produce a single interpretation of Wittgenstein’s numbering system that doesn’t add more incoherencies to the TLP than are already known to be there. 
In Chapter 1, we consider the TLP’s main contentions and saw how wrong and shallow they were. But Bertrand Russell, the world’s most distinguished philosopher at the time, and still considered by many (including the present author) to be the greatest philosopher of the last 150 years or so, gave the TLP his seal of approval. (He later deeply regretted doing so.) And voila! Wittgenstein had a PhD in philosophy, despite Wittgenstein’s previously mentioned lack of credentials and the despite the TLP’s lack of merit. The TLP is discussed at length and in depth, in Chapter 1. In any case, here are a few of the many problems with the TLP that we discussed. 
The Tractatus contains no argumentation. It consists of assertions that, on the rare occasions when they’re intelligible, are very obviously false. Consider his thesis that all meaningful statements are verifiable. No sooner did philosophers read that sentence than they saw it to be subject to obvious counter-examples 
(e.g. “all copper conducts electricity”). To take another example: Consider this thesis that all complex statements (statements consisting of other statements) are truth-functions of the component statements.[496] 
In other words, given a 
complex sentence, e.g. “Smith is tall and Jones is short”, whether that sentence is true is determined by whether its components (“Smith is tall” and “Jones is tall”) are true.) Again, no sooner does one read this sentence than one sees it to be subject to obvious counterexamples. (Consider the sentence: “Jones got fired because he has poor people skills.” Given only that each of “Jones got fired” and “he has poor people-skills” is true, it’s an open question whether Jones’ getting fired had anything to do with his having poor people-skills.) Given the profound differences between iconic and non-iconic forms of representation (which are discussed in Chapter 5), Wittgenstein’s “picture-theory of meaning” can only be seen as making the empty point that sentences are picture-like in that, like pictures, they are (sometimes) representational. With a few trivial exceptions, none of the other intelligible sentences in the Tractatus fares any better. 
The Tractatus is a tiny work. If printed in the same font as the sentence you are reading, and on pages the size of the one before you, it would be around 10 pages long. But it appears much longer than it is. The reason for this is that it isn’t written in paragraphs, like other books. It consists of numbered remarks, each of which is separated from its neighbors by large spaces, as if to emphasize its importance. 
The remarks are numbered by decimals, not whole numbers. The decimals are supposed to indicate relations of subordination. (So, remark #5.211 is subordinate to remark #5.21, as is remark # 5.212. I use a similar system in this book.) Thus, the numbers are supposed to indicate the logical relations holding among the corresponding statements. 
But in the Tractatus, there is no discernible relationship between a given statement’s number and its relation to the statement, or statements, to which it is supposedly subordinate. A philosopher named Kevin Gibson wrote a paper with the title “Is the numbering system in the Tractatus a joke?”[497] 
Presumably the author thought so. I agree with him.) The numbers give the Tractatus an appearance of hard-hitting rigor that a reading of it fails to bear out. 
At the time, Russell was the most influential and respected figure in the philosophical world. Having convinced Russell of his philosophical greatness, Wittgenstein enlisted Russell’s help in finding a publisher for the Tractatus. Russell was obviously as capable as anyone in the philosophical community of convincing publishers to accept a work they would otherwise reject. Evidently, the publishers judged that they had more to lose in the way of would-be publishers. (And that determination would have been correct had they been operating in any context where book sales are driven by market-forces, as opposed to hegemony-internal politics.) Nonetheless, the first 20 publishers whom Russell urged to publish Wittgenstein’s credibility by publishing Wittgenstein’s work than by being black-listed by Russell. In any case, the 21st publishing house agreed to publish it, but only on the condition that Russell write a substantial preface to it, so that the book would basically be a paper by Russell, which would inevitably be good, followed by Wittgenstein’s curious little effort, which, it was presumably hoped, it would overshadow. 
Russell’s preface is both illuminating and enjoyable to read. Wittgenstein rewarded Russell for his efforts by saying that his preface thoroughly misrepresented the Tractatus, but without saying how it did so and without entertaining the possibility that it might be his fault that nobody, including Russell, could understand what he was saying. (Russell did in fact misrepresent some of Wittgenstein’s claims. But, in so doing, he attributed views to Wittgenstein that were more cogent than those advocated by Wittgenstein himself.) Wittgenstein fumed for the entirety of his career about how nobody understood what he wrote. He never blamed himself for this. It was always the reader’s fault. Soon after the Tractatus was published, every clear statement in it, with a few unimportant exceptions, was shown to be false, thoroughly confused and, unlike other false, confused statements, not even obliquely suggestive of anything that was true or fruitful. (See Chapter 1.) Since it was written by Wittgenstein, who everybody knew to have been given Russell’s seal of approval, the Tractatus was treated with reverence (and still is). But not a single philosopher could find anything in the Tractatus that, no matter how liberally interpreted, was even remotely close to the truth or that provided clear evidence that its author had any philosophical ability. 
In the immediate aftermath of its publication, when the grievous problems with the Tractatus became public knowledge, Wittgenstein vanished for ten years, resigning his professorship and severing all contact with anyone in the philosophical community. During that time, he had no jobs of substance. He was a middle school teacher for a while, but was fired for physically abusing his students. 
When he returned to Cambridge, he argued that there is no truth (or, what is the same, that truth is culture-dependent, being nothing more than a myth we create to validate our linguistic practices); that, so far as they don’t consist of sensations, minds are identical with overt bodily movements; that all philosophical puzzles are immediately solved by looking at how words are ordinarily used; and that mathematical statements never represented discoveries and were in all cases conventions or stipulations. 
After returning to philosophy, Wittgenstein published nothing. He disseminated his thought through lectures. He did not permit people to attend his lectures unless he had a personal relationship with them. Distinguished philosophers from other universities were not allowed to attend his lectures. He thus ensured that the Tractatus would be the last work of his that, during his lifetime, was made available to anyone over whom he didn’t have personal power. 
Most of his lectures were transcribed. The ones that his followers judged to be the more presentable ones have been published. Once somebody who desperately wanted to see merit in Wittgenstein’s work, I have read them carefully. They consist of scattered remarks. The remarks are in most cases devoid of any discernible meaning. They are seldom clarified or substantiated. 
That said, certain themes clearly run through them. There is no truth; what scientists refer to as “discoveries” are just changes in the conventions governing certain terms; if one knows how a word is used, one knows everything there is no know about its meaning. Psychopaths don’t really understand terms like “right” and “wrong,” “good” and “bad.” But they know how to use such terms. In saying that, once one knows how a word is used, one ipso facto knows everything there is to know about its meaning, Wittgenstein was, I suspect, trying to convince himself that, falsely, that he did grasp the meanings of moral terms, given that he knew how they were used (at least relative to a conception of word-usage, such as the one that Wittgenstein advocated, that takes into account public behaviors, but not their psychological underpinnings). 
What all of these themes have in common is that, if they’re right, everybody who has ever sought truth was on a fool’s errand. The nihilistic currents that run through the various remarks composing his lectures give them a superficial unity. But ultimately those lectures are heaps of disjoint comments, which, unlike the two-liners produced by other thinkers, are uninformative and painful to read. 
But those who listened to those very lectures were mesmerized by Wittgenstein’s charisma. (Among those was Norman Malcolm, who, following Wittgenstein, claimed that people don’t actually have dreams, our misguided belief to the contrary being a product of our mistakenly thinking that the words that people utter when discussing their (non-existent) dreams are anything more than empty noises.) It is suggestive that, setting aside self-described Wittgensteinians, those who read his lectures have a negative reaction to them, if they have any reaction at all, whereas those who saw him talk reacted very favorably. It’s also suggestive how carefully Wittgenstein vetted those who wished to attend his talks. 
One point that Wittgenstein did make clearly is that there is no psychological component to linguistic behavior. He said that thought “consists in manipulations of symbols.” He also said that linguistic symbols are inherently public. In his view, it isn’t by virtue of any mental state of yours that when you say “snow is white," you mean what you are saying, whereas, when a parrot says it, it doesn’t mean anything. Although he wrote in a sufficiently loose and obscure manner that always allowed him the option to back away from what he seemed to have said, he made remarks that either mean nothing or mean that beliefs, values, and other enduring psychological structures, are identical with the overt behaviors of which, so it is generally presumed, they are but the effects; and he made remarks that strongly suggest that he didn’t believe there to be such a thing as consciousness. His ridiculous view that thought is an inherently social, as opposed to individual, phenomenon is an artifact of these clearly erroneous assumptions. 
Wittgenstein’s false identification of the mind with bodily behavior (plus consciousness) makes it pointless to examine oneself. It is thus an attractive view for somebody who doesn’t want to examine himself. Wittgenstein said that “there are no mysteries.” It was unclear whether he was referring to the mind or to philosophy. He seems to have been referring to both. If he were right about this, then one would have carte blanche to believe one’s own rationalizations. 
When he first met him, Russell described Wittgenstein as “the purest example of genius that I know.” In so describing Wittgenstein, Russell was describing the latter’s mannerisms, not his thought. When substantiating this characterization of Wittgenstein, he cites the fact that Wittgenstein would alternate between long silences, during which he appeared engrossed in thought, and sudden bursts of speech, which, though obscure, were accompanied by energetic, almost aggressive, gestures that made it clear that, think what one may of them, those outbursts contained true insights. Russell mentions only one comment that Wittgenstein made during his conversations with him. Russell had put forth an argument, in which it was assumed for argument’s sake there wasn’t a rhinoceros in the room they were in. Wittgenstein’s only response to this argument: “how do you know that there isn’t a rhinoceros in the room?” As any philosophy professor knows, this is a perfect instance of the knee-jerk skepticism on which people with no talent for this discipline fall back when they don’t know how else to engage what they’re being told. [498] 
After knowing Wittgenstein for a month or so, Russell wrote that Wittgenstein had nothing of substance to say and that conversations with him were a "waste of time."
